--- Document Chunk 192 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 193 ---
1.3 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 194 ---
1.3.1.1 Train control is an important part of any railway operations management system. In the 

--- Document Chunk 195 ---
past a number of different Automatic Train Control (ATC) systems have evolved in 

--- Document Chunk 196 ---
different countries at different times. These systems are incompatible and not 

--- Document Chunk 197 ---
interoperable with each other. Only a few of these systems are u sed in more than one 

--- Document Chunk 198 ---
country, and even in those cases there have been differences in detailed development 

--- Document Chunk 199 ---
which have resulted in incompatible and not interoperable versions. 

--- Document Chunk 200 ---
1.3.1.2 Many railways anticipate a significant increase in density of train traffic and ar e 

--- Document Chunk 201 ---
rethinking their i nfrastructure strategy, to accommodate high levels of traffic, in which 

--- Document Chunk 202 ---
ATC systems play an important part. Also many railways would like to introduce 

--- Document Chunk 203 ---
standardised systems to reduce system costs. In order to establish international 

--- Document Chunk 204 ---
standardisation of ATC systems, the following document specifies the European Rail 

--- Document Chunk 205 ---
Traffic Management System/European Train Control System (ERTMS/ETCS). 

--- Document Chunk 206 ---
1.4 Advantages of an International Interoperable System 

--- Document Chunk 207 ---
1.4.1.1 The advantages expected by the railways can be summarised as: 

--- Document Chunk 208 ---
 Cross border interoperability. 

--- Document Chunk 209 ---
 Improvement of the safety of national and international train traffic. 

--- Document Chunk 210 ---
 Improvement of international passengers and freight train traffic management.  

--- Document Chunk 211 ---
 Shorter headway on heavily trafficked lines, by driving on moving bl ock, enabling 

--- Document Chunk 212 ---
exploitation of maximum track capacity. 

--- Document Chunk 213 ---
 The possibility of step-by-step introduction of the new technology. 

--- Document Chunk 214 ---
 Enabling Pan -European competition between the manufacturers of ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 215 ---
components. Strengthe ning the position of the European railw ay industry on the 

--- Document Chunk 216 ---
world market. 

--- Document Chunk 217 ---
 Enabling preconditions for future harmonisation in other areas of rail traffic 

--- Document Chunk 218 ---
management. 

--- Document Chunk 219 ---
1.5 About this Document 

--- Document Chunk 220 ---
1.5.1.1 The purpose of this document is to specify the unified European Train Control System 

--- Document Chunk 221 ---
(ETCS) from a technical point of view. 

--- Document Chunk 222 ---
1.5.1.2 Some parts of the system are only specified to allow a migration from existing train 

--- Document Chunk 223 ---
control systems to ETCS (e.g. STM’s) over a transition period. They might be removed 

--- Document Chunk 224 ---
in a future edition of the standard. 

--- Document Chunk 225 ---
1.5.1.3 To reach technical interoperability it is necessary not only that telegrams are generated 

--- Document Chunk 226 ---
and understood according to well specified rules but also that a train respectively 

--- Document Chunk 227 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 228 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 229 ---
SUBSET-026-1 

--- Document Chunk 230 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 231 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 232 ---
System Requirements Specification  

--- Document Chunk 233 ---
Chapter 1  

--- Document Chunk 234 ---
Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 235 ---
Page 6/8 

--- Document Chunk 236 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 237 ---
trackside equipment reacts in a uniform way to information received. Technical 

--- Document Chunk 238 ---
interoperability requires specifications of a detailed level. 

--- Document Chunk 239 ---
1.5.1.4 For operational interoperability it is necessary to add operating rules, engineering 

--- Document Chunk 240 ---
standards etc. to the system design. Reaching operational interoperability i s outside 

--- Document Chunk 241 ---
the scope of the SRS. 

--- Document Chunk 242 ---
1.6 How to Read and Use the SRS 

--- Document Chunk 243 ---
1.6.1.1 The SRS cover s 9 chapters, which are briefly described in the section following this 

--- Document Chunk 244 ---
introduction. 

--- Document Chunk 245 ---
1.6.1.2 All readers may need to refer to the Glossary  of terms and abbreviations (SUBSET -

--- Document Chunk 246 ---
023). 

--- Document Chunk 247 ---
1.7 Requirements 

--- Document Chunk 248 ---
1.7.1.1 This specification defines the functions that allow reaching the techn ical 

--- Document Chunk 249 ---
interoperability. This is materialised through numbered clauses which are formally 

--- Document Chunk 250 ---
identified as containing ERTMS/ETCS on -board and/or ERTMS/ETCS trackside 

--- Document Chunk 251 ---
requirements (see details in chapter 9). 

--- Document Chunk 252 ---
1.7.1.2 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall implement all its allocated requirements, 

--- Document Chunk 253 ---
with the only exceptions and conditions explicitly stated in the Control -Command and 

--- Document Chunk 254 ---
Signalling TSI and in this SRS. 

--- Document Chunk 255 ---
1.7.1.3 For ERTMS/ETCS trackside the implementation of functions has to be defined 

--- Document Chunk 256 ---
according to the characteristics of the specific lines and the related operational needs. 

--- Document Chunk 257 ---
In any case, the requirements of this SRS , which are allocated to the trackside and  

--- Document Chunk 258 ---
related to the implemented functions, shall be respected. 

--- Document Chunk 259 ---
1.7.1.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 260 ---
1.7.1.5 Not specified requirements and solutions shall only be permitted as long as they do not 

--- Document Chunk 261 ---
generate any interoperability problems. 

--- Document Chunk 262 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 263 ---
1.8 Contents of the SRS 

--- Document Chunk 264 ---
1.8.1.1 The SRS defines the system requirements for the European Train Control System 

--- Document Chunk 265 ---
(ETCS) of ERTMS. 

--- Document Chunk 266 ---
1.8.1.2 This sub-section is intended to give a rough over view of the contents of each chapter 

--- Document Chunk 267 ---
within the SRS so that readers interested only in specialised subjects can easily find 

--- Document Chunk 268 ---
the relevant chapters. 

--- Document Chunk 269 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 270 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 271 ---
SUBSET-026-1 

--- Document Chunk 272 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 273 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 274 ---
System Requirements Specification  

--- Document Chunk 275 ---
Chapter 1  

--- Document Chunk 276 ---
Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 277 ---
Page 7/8 

--- Document Chunk 278 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 279 ---
1.8.2 Chapter 1: Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 280 ---
1.8.2.1 Chapter 1 (this chapter) gives a general introduction to the intention and structure of 

--- Document Chunk 281 ---
the SRS, including a brief overview of the contents of each chapter. 

--- Document Chunk 282 ---
1.8.3 Chapter 2: Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 283 ---
1.8.3.1 Chapter 2 gives an overview of the ERTMS/ETCS system structure. 

--- Document Chunk 284 ---
1.8.3.2 Chapter 2 also contains a description of the basic application levels. 

--- Document Chunk 285 ---
1.8.3.3 Chapter 2 does not contain technical requirements. 

--- Document Chunk 286 ---
1.8.4 Chapter 3: Principles 

--- Document Chunk 287 ---
1.8.4.1 Chapter 3 specifies the system principles of ETCS/ERTMS. These principles apply to 

--- Document Chunk 288 ---
onboard and trackside subsystems. 

--- Document Chunk 289 ---
1.8.4.2 The principles define the behaviour of the system in general and functional terms. 

--- Document Chunk 290 ---
1.8.5 Chapter 4: Modes and Transitions 

--- Document Chunk 291 ---
1.8.5.1.1 Chapter 4 defines the modes of the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment and all 

--- Document Chunk 292 ---
transitions between modes. 

--- Document Chunk 293 ---
1.8.6 Chapter 5: Procedures 

--- Document Chunk 294 ---
1.8.6.1 Chapter 5 defines the dynamic behaviour of procedures that are necessary for 

--- Document Chunk 295 ---
interoperability. Pro cedures are presented by a state transition chart and a 

--- Document Chunk 296 ---
corresponding table, where all elements (States, events, transitions) of the chart are 

--- Document Chunk 297 ---
defined. The description of the procedures shows all states of the ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 298 ---
onboard unit and the conditions tha t must be fulfilled to switch from one state to 

--- Document Chunk 299 ---
another. 

--- Document Chunk 300 ---
1.8.7 Chapter 6: Management of older System Versions 

--- Document Chunk 301 ---
1.8.7.1.1 Chapter 6 defines the envelope of legally operated system versions and list s the 

--- Document Chunk 302 ---
exceptions that shall apply by derogation to the requirements listed in  the other 

--- Document Chunk 303 ---
chapters of the SRS, when an older ERTMS/ETCS system version is used  by the 

--- Document Chunk 304 ---
trackside subsystem. 

--- Document Chunk 305 ---
1.8.8 Chapter 7: ERTMS/ETCS Language 

--- Document Chunk 306 ---
1.8.8.1 Chapter 7 defines and describes the necessary variables to be used for the data flow 

--- Document Chunk 307 ---
over the air gap between track a nd train. The grouping of these into packets is 

--- Document Chunk 308 ---
described. The format of messages is given in Chapter 8. 

--- Document Chunk 309 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 310 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 311 ---
SUBSET-026-1 

--- Document Chunk 312 ---
3.6.0

--- Document Chunk 315 ---

--- Document Chunk 316 ---
Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 317 ---
Page 8/8 

--- Document Chunk 318 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 319 ---
1.8.9 Chapter 8: Messages 

--- Document Chunk 320 ---
1.8.9.1 Chapter 8 defines the application protocol (format and content of messages, logical 

--- Document Chunk 321 ---
sequence for radio) necessary to achieve technical interoperability. 

--- Document Chunk 322 ---
1.8.9.2 The scope of this chapter is limited to the application protoc ol and the content of 

--- Document Chunk 323 ---
messages. 

--- Document Chunk 324 ---
1.8.10 Chapter 9: Classification of the SRS clauses 

--- Document Chunk 325 ---
1.8.10.1 Chapter 9 encloses a classification into categories of all the clauses in the chapters 1 

--- Document Chunk 326 ---
to 8 of the SRS. 

--- Document Chunk 327 ---
1.8.10.2 In particular to assess properly the compliance of an ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 328 ---
equipment with the SRS, it identifies which clauses contain requirements allocated to 

--- Document Chunk 329 ---
the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment and conversely which ones do not, either 

--- Document Chunk 330 ---
because th ey contain requirements allocated to the ERTMS/ETCS trackside only or 

--- Document Chunk 331 ---
because they are of another type. 

--- Document Chunk 332 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 333 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 563 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 564 ---
2.3 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 565 ---
2.3.1 Scope and purpose 

--- Document Chunk 566 ---
2.3.1.1 The present chapter gives the basic description of the ERTMS/ETCS system 

--- Document Chunk 567 ---
proposed to achieve technical interoperability. 

--- Document Chunk 568 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 569 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 570 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 571 ---
SUBSET-026-2 

--- Document Chunk 572 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 573 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 574 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 575 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 576 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 577 ---
Page 7/25 

--- Document Chunk 578 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 579 ---
2.4 System structure 

--- Document Chunk 580 ---
2.4.1.1 Due to the nature of the required functions, the ERTMS/ETCS system will have to be 

--- Document Chunk 581 ---
partly on the trackside and partly on board the trains.  

--- Document Chunk 582 ---
2.4.1.2 This defines two subsystems, the on-board subsystem and the trackside subsystem. 

--- Document Chunk 583 ---
2.4.1.3 The environment of ERTMS/ETCS system is composed of: 

--- Document Chunk 584 ---
a) the train, which will then be considered in the train interface specification; 

--- Document Chunk 585 ---
b) the driver, which will then be considered via the driver interface specification; 

--- Document Chunk 586 ---
c) other onboard interfaces (see architecture drawing in 2.5.3), 

--- Document Chunk 587 ---
d) external trackside systems (interlockings, control centres, etc.), for which no 

--- Document Chunk 588 ---
interoperability requirement will be established. 

--- Document Chunk 589 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 590 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 591 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 592 ---
SUBSET-026-2 

--- Document Chunk 593 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 594 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 595 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 596 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 597 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 598 ---
Page 8/25 

--- Document Chunk 599 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 600 ---
2.5 Subsystems 

--- Document Chunk 601 ---
2.5.1 Trackside subsystem 

--- Document Chunk 602 ---
2.5.1.1 Depending of the application level (see further sections), the trackside subsystem can 

--- Document Chunk 603 ---
be composed of: 

--- Document Chunk 604 ---
a) balise 

--- Document Chunk 605 ---
b) lineside electronic unit 

--- Document Chunk 606 ---
c) the radio communication network (GSM-R) 

--- Document Chunk 607 ---
d) the Radio Block Centre (RBC) 

--- Document Chunk 608 ---
e) Euroloop 

--- Document Chunk 609 ---
f) Radio infill unit 

--- Document Chunk 610 ---
g) Key Management Centre (KMC) 

--- Document Chunk 611 ---
h) Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) 

--- Document Chunk 612 ---
2.5.1.2 Balise 

--- Document Chunk 613 ---
2.5.1.2.1 The balise is a transmission device that can send telegrams to the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 614 ---
subsystem. 

--- Document Chunk 615 ---
2.5.1.2.2 The balise is based on the existing Euroba lise specifications. These documents are 

--- Document Chunk 616 ---
included in the frame of the ERTMS/ETCS specifications. 

--- Document Chunk 617 ---
2.5.1.2.3 The balises provides the up -link, i. e. the possibility to send messages from trackside 

--- Document Chunk 618 ---
to the on-board subsystem. 

--- Document Chunk 619 ---
2.5.1.2.4 The balises can provide fixed messages or, w hen connected to a lineside electronic 

--- Document Chunk 620 ---
unit, messages that can be changed.  

--- Document Chunk 621 ---
2.5.1.2.5 The balises will be organised in groups, each balise transmitting a telegram and the 

--- Document Chunk 622 ---
combination of all telegrams defining the message sent by the balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 623 ---
2.5.1.3 Lineside electronic unit 

--- Document Chunk 624 ---
2.5.1.3.1 The lineside electronic units are electronic devices, that generate telegrams to be sent 

--- Document Chunk 625 ---
by balises, on basis of information received from external trackside systems. 

--- Document Chunk 626 ---
2.5.1.4 Trackside radio communication network (GSM-R) 

--- Document Chunk 627 ---
2.5.1.4.1 The GSM -R radio communication network  is used for the bi -directional exchange of 

--- Document Chunk 628 ---
messages between on-board subsystems and RBC or radio infill units.  

--- Document Chunk 629 ---
2.5.1.4.2 Intentionally deleted 

--- Document Chunk 630 ---
2.5.1.5 RBC 

--- Document Chunk 631 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 632 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 633 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 634 ---
SUBSET-026-2 

--- Document Chunk 635 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 636 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 637 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 638 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 639 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 640 ---
Page 9/25 

--- Document Chunk 641 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 642 ---
2.5.1.5.1 The RBC is a computer-based system that elaborates messages to be sent to the train 

--- Document Chunk 643 ---
on basis of information received from external trackside systems and on basis of 

--- Document Chunk 644 ---
information exchanged with the on-board subsystems. 

--- Document Chunk 645 ---
2.5.1.5.2 The main objective of these messages is to provide movement authorities to allow the 

--- Document Chunk 646 ---
safe movement of trains on the Railway infrastructure area under the re sponsibility of 

--- Document Chunk 647 ---
the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 648 ---
2.5.1.5.3 The interoperability requirements for the RBC are mainly related to the data exchange 

--- Document Chunk 649 ---
between the RBC and the on-board subsystem. 

--- Document Chunk 650 ---
2.5.1.6 Euroloop 

--- Document Chunk 651 ---
2.5.1.6.1 The Euroloop subsystem operates on Level 1 lines, providing signalling information in 

--- Document Chunk 652 ---
advance as regard to the next main signal in the train running direction. 

--- Document Chunk 653 ---
2.5.1.6.2 The Euroloop subsystem is composed of an on -board functionality and by one or more 

--- Document Chunk 654 ---
trackside parts.  

--- Document Chunk 655 ---
2.5.1.7 Radio infill Unit 

--- Document Chunk 656 ---
2.5.1.7.1 The RADIO INFILL subsystem operates on Level 1 lines, providing signa lling 

--- Document Chunk 657 ---
information in advance as regard to the next main signal in the train running direction. 

--- Document Chunk 658 ---
2.5.1.7.2 The RADIO INFILL subsystem is composed of an on -board functionality and by one or 

--- Document Chunk 659 ---
more trackside parts (named RADIO INFILL Unit).  

--- Document Chunk 660 ---
2.5.1.8 KMC 

--- Document Chunk 661 ---
2.5.1.8.1 The role of the KMC is to manage the cryptographic keys, which are used to secure 

--- Document Chunk 662 ---
the EURORADIO communications between the ERTMS/ETCS entities (ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 663 ---
on-board equipments, RBCs and RIUs). 

--- Document Chunk 664 ---
2.5.1.9 PKI 

--- Document Chunk 665 ---
2.5.1.9.1 The role of the PKI is to manage and distribute digital certificates, so as to allow a  

--- Document Chunk 666 ---
secure on-line distribution of cryptographic keys between KMCs and from a KMC to the 

--- Document Chunk 667 ---
ERTMS/ETCS entities (ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipments, RBCs and RIUs). 

--- Document Chunk 668 ---
2.5.2 On-board subsystem 

--- Document Chunk 669 ---
2.5.2.1 Depending of the application level (see further sections), the on -board subsystem can 

--- Document Chunk 670 ---
be composed of: 

--- Document Chunk 671 ---
a) the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment; 

--- Document Chunk 672 ---
b) the on-board part of the GSM-R radio system; 

--- Document Chunk 673 ---
2.5.2.2 ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 674 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 675 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 676 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 677 ---
SUBSET-026-2 

--- Document Chunk 678 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 679 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 680 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 681 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 682 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 683 ---
Page 10/25 

--- Document Chunk 684 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 685 ---
2.5.2.2.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment is a computer -based system that supervises 

--- Document Chunk 686 ---
the movement of the train to which it belongs, on  basis of information exchanged with 

--- Document Chunk 687 ---
the trackside subsystem. 

--- Document Chunk 688 ---
2.5.2.2.2 The interoperability requirements for the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment are 

--- Document Chunk 689 ---
related to the functionality and the data exchange between the trackside subsystems 

--- Document Chunk 690 ---
and the on -board subsystem and to the functional data exchange between the on -

--- Document Chunk 691 ---
board subsystem and: 

--- Document Chunk 692 ---
a) the driver; 

--- Document Chunk 693 ---
b) the train; 

--- Document Chunk 694 ---
c) the onboard part of the existing national train control system(s). 

--- Document Chunk 695 ---
2.5.2.3 Onboard radio communication system (GSM-R) 

--- Document Chunk 696 ---
2.5.2.3.1 The GSM -R on -board radio system is used for the bi -directional exchange of 

--- Document Chunk 697 ---
messages between on-board subsystem and RBC or radio infill unit. 

--- Document Chunk 698 ---
2.5.2.3.2 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 699 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 795 ---
2.6 Levels and transitions 

--- Document Chunk 796 ---
2.6.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 797 ---
2.6.1.1 The different ERTMS/ETCS application levels (short: levels) are a way  to express the 

--- Document Chunk 798 ---
possible operating relationships between track and train. Level definitions are related 

--- Document Chunk 799 ---
to the trackside equipment used, to the way trackside information reaches the on -

--- Document Chunk 800 ---
board units and to which functions are processed in the trackside and i n the on-board 

--- Document Chunk 801 ---
equipment respectively.  

--- Document Chunk 802 ---
2.6.1.2 Different levels have been defined to allow each individual railway administration to 

--- Document Chunk 803 ---
select the appropriate ERTMS/ETCS application trackside, according to their 

--- Document Chunk 804 ---
strategies, to their trackside infrastructure and to t he required performance. 

--- Document Chunk 805 ---
Furthermore, the different application levels permit the interfacing of individual 

--- Document Chunk 806 ---
signalling systems and train control systems to ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 807 ---
2.6.1.3 For the purpose of a consistent specification a level 0 has been defined. This level is 

--- Document Chunk 808 ---
used for operation on non -equipped (unfitted) lines or on lines  equipped with train 

--- Document Chunk 809 ---
control system(s) but operation under their supervision is currently not possible.  

--- Document Chunk 810 ---
2.6.2 Definitions 

--- Document Chunk 811 ---
2.6.2.1 A train equipped with ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment always co -operates with the 

--- Document Chunk 812 ---
ERTMS/ETCS trackside equipment in a defined ERTMS/ETCS level.  

--- Document Chunk 813 ---
2.6.2.2 All transitions between levels are performed according to well-specified rules.  

--- Document Chunk 814 ---
2.6.2.3 ERTMS/ETCS can be configured to operate in one of the following application levels:  

--- Document Chunk 815 ---
 ERTMS/ETCS Level 0 (tra in equipped with ERTMS/ETCS operating on a line not 

--- Document Chunk 816 ---
equipped with any train control system  (ERTMS/ETCS or national system ) or on a 

--- Document Chunk 817 ---
line equipped with ERTMS/ETCS and/or national system(s) but operation under 

--- Document Chunk 818 ---
their supervision is currently not possible) 

--- Document Chunk 819 ---
 ERTMS/ETCS Level NTC (train equipped with ERTMS/ETCS operating on a line 

--- Document Chunk 820 ---
equipped with a national system) 

--- Document Chunk 821 ---
 ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 1 with or without infill transmission (train equipped 

--- Document Chunk 822 ---
with ERTMS/ETCS operating on a line equipped with Eurobalises and optio nally 

--- Document Chunk 823 ---
Euroloop or Radio infill) 

--- Document Chunk 824 ---
 ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 2 (train equipped with ERTMS/ETCS operating on 

--- Document Chunk 825 ---
a line controlled by a Radio Block Centre and equipped with Eurobalises and 

--- Document Chunk 826 ---
Euroradio) with train position and train integrity proving performed by the trackside 

--- Document Chunk 827 ---
 ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 3 (similar to level 2 but with train position and train 

--- Document Chunk 828 ---
integrity supervision based on information received from the train)  

--- Document Chunk 829 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 830 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 831 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 832 ---
SUBSET-026-2 

--- Document Chunk 833 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 834 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 835 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 836 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 837 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 838 ---
Page 13/25 

--- Document Chunk 839 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 840 ---
2.6.2.4 It is possible to superimpose several application levels in parallel on the same track, for 

--- Document Chunk 841 ---
example to run trains without train integrity device in level 2 and in parallel trains 

--- Document Chunk 842 ---
equipped with train integrity device in level 3. Other examples might be a station which 

--- Document Chunk 843 ---
is shared by trains arriving over level 1 and level 2 lines (junctions) or parallel operation 

--- Document Chunk 844 ---
of a national system with ERTMS/ETCS. Mixed levels are supported. 

--- Document Chunk 845 ---
2.6.2.5 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 846 ---
2.6.2.6 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 847 ---
2.6.2.7 It is possible to transmit information not intended for ERTMS/ETCS but for other 

--- Document Chunk 848 ---
systems over the ERTMS/ETCS transmission chan nels. This information is not used 

--- Document Chunk 849 ---
by ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 850 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 851 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 852 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 853 ---
SUBSET-026-2 

--- Document Chunk 854 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 855 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 856 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 857 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 858 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 859 ---
Page 14/25 

--- Document Chunk 860 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 861 ---
2.6.3 ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 0 

--- Document Chunk 862 ---
2.6.3.1 General description 

--- Document Chunk 863 ---
2.6.3.1.1 Level 0 covers operation of ETCS equipped trains on lines not equipped with ETCS or 

--- Document Chunk 864 ---
national systems or on lines where trackside ERTMS/ETCS infrastructure  and/or 

--- Document Chunk 865 ---
national systems may exist but operation under their supervision is currently not 

--- Document Chunk 866 ---
possible (e.g. commissioning or on-board/trackside failed components).  

--- Document Chunk 867 ---
2.6.3.1.2 In Level 0 it is authorized to operate trains without any train control system and 

--- Document Chunk 868 ---
therefore line side optical signals or other means of signalling are used to give 

--- Document Chunk 869 ---
movement authorities to the driver.  

--- Document Chunk 870 ---
2.6.3.1.3 ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment provides no supervision except of the maximum 

--- Document Chunk 871 ---
design speed of a train and maximum speed permitted in unfitted areas.  

--- Document Chunk 872 ---
2.6.3.1.4 Train detection and train integrity supervision are performed by the trackside 

--- Document Chunk 873 ---
equipment of the underlying signalling system (interlocking, track circuits etc.) and are 

--- Document Chunk 874 ---
outside the scope of ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 875 ---
2.6.3.1.5 Level 0 uses no track -train transmission except Euroba lises to announce/command 

--- Document Chunk 876 ---
level transitions. Eurobalises therefore still have to be read. No balise data except 

--- Document Chunk 877 ---
certain special commands are interpreted. 

--- Document Chunk 878 ---
2.6.3.1.6 No supervisory information is indicated on the DMI except the train speed. Train data 

--- Document Chunk 879 ---
has to be entere d in order not to have to stop a train at a level transition to 

--- Document Chunk 880 ---
ERTMS/ETCS equipped area and to supervise maximum train speed. 

--- Document Chunk 881 ---
ETCS

--- Document Chunk 882 ---
end of  track segm ent

--- Document Chunk 883 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 884 ---
Figure 2: ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 0

--- Document Chunk 887 ---

--- Document Chunk 898 ---
 No ERTMS/ETCS trackside equipment is used except for Eurobalises to announce 

--- Document Chunk 899 ---
level transitions and other specific commands. 

--- Document Chunk 900 ---
2.6.3.2.2 Main ERTMS/ETCS trackside functions: 

--- Document Chunk 901 ---

--- Document Chunk 903 ---

--- Document Chunk 905 ---

--- Document Chunk 908 ---

--- Document Chunk 921 ---
2.6.4 ERTMS/ETCS Application Level NTC 

--- Document Chunk 922 ---
2.6.4.1 General description 

--- Document Chunk 923 ---
2.6.4.1.1 Level NTC is used to run ERTMS/ETCS equipped trains on lines equipped with 

--- Document Chunk 924 ---
national train control and speed supervision systems.  

--- Document Chunk 925 ---
2.6.4.1.2 Train control information generated trackside by the national train contr ol system is 

--- Document Chunk 926 ---
transmitted to the train via the communication channels of the underlying national 

--- Document Chunk 927 ---
system.  

--- Document Chunk 928 ---
2.6.4.1.3 Note: Lineside optical signals might be necessary or not, depending on the 

--- Document Chunk 929 ---
performance and functionality of the underlying systems.  

--- Document Chunk 930 ---
2.6.4.1.4 Intentionally deleted.  

--- Document Chunk 931 ---
2.6.4.1.5 The achievable level of supervision is similar to the one provided by the underlying 

--- Document Chunk 932 ---
national systems.  

--- Document Chunk 933 ---
2.6.4.1.6 Train detection and train integrity supervision are performed by equipment external to 

--- Document Chunk 934 ---
ERTMS/ETCS.  

--- Document Chunk 935 ---
2.6.4.1.7 Level NTC uses no ERTMS/ETCS track -train information except to 

--- Document Chunk 936 ---
announce/command level transitions and specific commands related to balise 

--- Document Chunk 937 ---
transmission. Eurobalises therefore still have to be read. 

--- Document Chunk 938 ---
2.6.4.1.8 The information displayed to the driver depends on the functionality of the underlying 

--- Document Chunk 939 ---
national system. T he active national system is indicated to the driver as part of that 

--- Document Chunk 940 ---
information. Full train data has to be entered in order not to have to stop a train at a 

--- Document Chunk 941 ---
level transition position and to supervise maximum train speed. 

--- Document Chunk 942 ---
2.6.4.1.9 A combination of national systems can be regarded as one NTC level. 

--- Document Chunk 943 ---
2.6.4.1.10 Depending on the functionality and the configuration of the specific national system 

--- Document Chunk 944 ---
installed onboard, the ERTMS/ETCS Onboard system may need to be interfaced to it, 

--- Document Chunk 945 ---
in order to perform the transitions from/to the nationa l system and/or in order to give 

--- Document Chunk 946 ---
access to ERTMS/ETCS Onboard resources (e.g. DMI). This can be achieved through 

--- Document Chunk 947 ---
a device called an STM (Specific Transmission Module) using a standardised interface. 

--- Document Chunk 948 ---
2.6.4.1.11 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 949 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 950 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 951 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 952 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 953 ---

System

Optional, 

--- Document Chunk 966 ---
depending on

national

system

2.6.4.2 Summary of characteristics of Application Level NTC 

--- Document Chunk 973 ---
2.6.4.2.1 Trackside equipment:  

--- Document Chunk 974 ---
 Level NTC uses the track -train transmission system from an underlying national 

--- Document Chunk 975 ---
system, which is not part of ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 976 ---
 For level transition purposes Eurobalises are used. 

--- Document Chunk 977 ---
2.6.4.2.2 Main ERTMS/ETCS trackside functions: 

--- Document Chunk 978 ---
 None. 

--- Document Chunk 979 ---
2.6.4.2.3 On-board equipment:  

--- Document Chunk 980 ---
 Onboard equipment with Eurobalise transmission. 

--- Document Chunk 981 ---
 Onboard part of the national system. 

--- Document Chunk 982 ---
2.6.4.2.4 Main ERTMS/ETCS on-board function: 

--- Document Chunk 983 ---
 No train supervision, it is fully handed over to the national system.  

--- Document Chunk 984 ---
 Reading of Eurobalises to detect level transitions and certain special commands. 

--- Document Chunk 985 ---
All other messages are rejected. 

--- Document Chunk 986 ---
 Management of the national system through  STM, in case the ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 987 ---
board equipment is interfaced to the national system through an STM. 

--- Document Chunk 988 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

 No cab signalling. 

--- Document Chunk 1000 ---
2.6.5 ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 1 

--- Document Chunk 1001 ---
2.6.5.1 General description 

--- Document Chunk 1002 ---
2.6.5.1.1 ERTMS/ETCS Level 1 is a spot transmission based train control system to be used as 

--- Document Chunk 1003 ---
an overlay on an underlying signalling system. 

--- Document Chunk 1004 ---
2.6.5.1.2 Movement auth orities are generated trackside and are transmitted to the train via  

--- Document Chunk 1005 ---
Eurobalises.  

--- Document Chunk 1006 ---
2.6.5.1.3 ERTMS/ETCS Level 1 provides a continuous speed supervision system, which also 

--- Document Chunk 1007 ---
protects against overrun of the authority.  

--- Document Chunk 1008 ---
2.6.5.1.4 Train detection and train integrity supervision ar e performed by the trackside 

--- Document Chunk 1009 ---
equipment of the underlying signalling system (interlocking, track circuits etc.) and are 

--- Document Chunk 1010 ---
outside the scope of ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 1011 ---
2.6.5.1.5 Level 1 is based on Eurobalises as spot transmission devices.   

--- Document Chunk 1012 ---
2.6.5.1.6 The trackside equipment does not know the train to which it sends information. 

--- Document Chunk 1013 ---
2.6.5.1.7 If in level 1 a lineside signal clears, an approaching train can not receive this 

--- Document Chunk 1014 ---
information until it passes the Eurobalise group at that signal. The driver therefore has 

--- Document Chunk 1015 ---
to observe the lineside signal to know when t o proceed. The train has then to be 

--- Document Chunk 1016 ---
permitted to approach the stopping location below a maximum permitted release 

--- Document Chunk 1017 ---
speed.  

--- Document Chunk 1018 ---
2.6.5.1.8 Additional Eurobalises can be placed between distant and main signals to transmit infill 

--- Document Chunk 1019 ---
information, the train will receive new information before reaching the signal.  

--- Document Chunk 1020 ---
2.6.5.1.9 Note: Lineside signals are required in level 1 applications, except if semi -continuous 

--- Document Chunk 1021 ---
infill is provided. 

--- Document Chunk 1022 ---
2.6.5.1.10 Semi-continuous infill can be provided using Euroloop or radio infill. In this case, the 

--- Document Chunk 1023 ---
on-board system will be able to show new information to the driver as soon as it is 

--- Document Chunk 1024 ---
available and even at standstill.  

--- Document Chunk 1025 ---
2.6.5.1.11 Euroloop or radio infill can improve the safety of a level 1 system as they allow the 

--- Document Chunk 1026 ---
operation without release speed. 

--- Document Chunk 1027 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1028 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1029 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1030 ---
SUBSET-026-2

--- Document Chunk 1066 ---
2.6.5.2 Summary of characteristics of Application Level 1 

--- Document Chunk 1067 ---
2.6.5.2.1 Trackside equipment:  

--- Document Chunk 1068 ---
 Eurobalises for spot transmission from track to train.  

--- Document Chunk 1069 ---
 Eurobalises must be able to transmit variable information. 

--- Document Chunk 1070 ---
 Semi continuous infill transmission by using Euroloop or radio infill is optional. 

--- Document Chunk 1071 ---
2.6.5.2.2 Main ERTMS/ETCS trackside function: 

--- Document Chunk 1072 ---
 Determine movement authorities according to the underlying signalling system. 

--- Document Chunk 1073 ---
 Transmit movement authorities and track description data to the train.   

--- Document Chunk 1074 ---
2.6.5.2.3 On-board equipment: 

--- Document Chunk 1075 ---
 Onboard equipment with Eurobalise transmission. 

--- Document Chunk 1076 ---
 Euroloop transmission if infill by Euroloop is required. 

--- Document Chunk 1077 ---
 Radio infill transmission if infill by radio is required. 

--- Document Chunk 1078 ---
2.6.5.2.4 Main ERTMS/ETCS on-board function: 

--- Document Chunk 1079 ---
 Reception of movement authority and track description related to the transmitting 

--- Document Chunk 1080 ---
balise. 

--- Document Chunk 1081 ---
 Selection of the most restrictive value of the di fferent speeds permitted at each 

--- Document Chunk 1082 ---
location ahead. 

--- Document Chunk 1083 ---
 Calculation of a dynamic speed profile taking into account the train running/braking 

--- Document Chunk 1084 ---
characteristics which are known on-board and the track description data. 

--- Document Chunk 1085 ---
 Comparison of the train speed with the permitted speed and commanding of the 

--- Document Chunk 1086 ---
brake application if necessary.  

--- Document Chunk 1087 ---
 Cab signalling to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 1088 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1089 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1090 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1091 ---

2.6.6 ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 2 

--- Document Chunk 1100 ---
2.6.6.1 General description 

--- Document Chunk 1101 ---
2.6.6.1.1 ERTMS/ETCS Level 2 is a radio based train control system which is used as an 

--- Document Chunk 1102 ---
overlay on an underlying signalling system.  

--- Document Chunk 1103 ---
2.6.6.1.2 Movement authorities are generated trackside and are transmitted to the train via 

--- Document Chunk 1104 ---
Euroradio.  

--- Document Chunk 1105 ---
2.6.6.1.3 ERTMS/ETCS Level 2 provides a continuous speed supervision system, which also 

--- Document Chunk 1106 ---
protects against overrun of the authority.  

--- Document Chunk 1107 ---
2.6.6.1.4 Train detection and train integ rity supervision are performed by the trackside 

--- Document Chunk 1108 ---
equipment of the underlying signalling system (interlocking, track circuits etc.) and are 

--- Document Chunk 1109 ---
outside the scope of ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 1110 ---
2.6.6.1.5 Level 2 is based on Euroradio for track to train communication and on Eurobalises as 

--- Document Chunk 1111 ---
spot transmission devices mainly for location referencing.   

--- Document Chunk 1112 ---
2.6.6.1.6 The trackside radio block centre which provides the information to the trains knows 

--- Document Chunk 1113 ---
each ERTMS/ETCS controlled train individually by the ERTMS/ETCS identity of its 

--- Document Chunk 1114 ---
leading ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment.  

--- Document Chunk 1115 ---
2.6.6.1.7 Note: Lineside signals can be suppressed in Level 2. 

--- Document Chunk 1116 ---
ETCS

--- Document Chunk 1117 ---
Eurobalise

--- Document Chunk 1118 ---
Radio Block Centre

--- Document Chunk 1119 ---
Interlocking

--- Document Chunk 1120 ---
end of track segment

--- Document Chunk 1121 ---
Optional

--- Document Chunk 1122 ---

2.6.6.2 Summary of characteristics of Application Level 2 

--- Document Chunk 1137 ---
2.6.6.2.1 Trackside equipment:  

--- Document Chunk 1138 ---
 Radio block centre. 

--- Document Chunk 1139 ---
 Euroradio for bi-directional track-train communication. 

--- Document Chunk 1140 ---
 Eurobalises mainly for location referencing.  

--- Document Chunk 1141 ---
2.6.6.2.2 Main ERTMS/ETCS trackside function: 

--- Document Chunk 1142 ---
 Knowing each train equipped with and running under ERTMS/ETCS within an RBC 

--- Document Chunk 1143 ---
area by its ERTMS/ETCS identity.  

--- Document Chunk 1144 ---
 Following each ERTMS/ETCS controlled train’s location within an RBC area.  

--- Document Chunk 1145 ---
 Determine movement authorities according to the underlying signalling system for 

--- Document Chunk 1146 ---
each train individually. 

--- Document Chunk 1147 ---
 Transmit movement authorities and track description  to each train individually.  

--- Document Chunk 1148 ---
 Handing over of train control between different RBC’s at the RBC-RBC borders. 

--- Document Chunk 1149 ---
2.6.6.2.3 On-board equipment:  

--- Document Chunk 1150 ---
 Onboard equipment with Eurobalise and Euroradio transmissions. 

--- Document Chunk 1151 ---
2.6.6.2.4 Main ERTMS/ETCS on-board function: 

--- Document Chunk 1152 ---
 The train reads Eurobalises and sends its position relative to the detected b alises to 

--- Document Chunk 1153 ---
the radio block centre. 

--- Document Chunk 1154 ---
 The train receives a movement authority and the track description  via Euroradio 

--- Document Chunk 1155 ---
relating to a balise.  

--- Document Chunk 1156 ---
 Selection of the most restrictive value of the different speeds permitted at each 

--- Document Chunk 1157 ---
location ahead. 

--- Document Chunk 1158 ---
 Calculation of a dyn amic speed profile taking into account the train running/braking 

--- Document Chunk 1159 ---
characteristics which are known on-board and the track description data. 

--- Document Chunk 1160 ---
 Comparison of the train speed with the permitted speed and commanding of the 

--- Document Chunk 1161 ---
brake application if necessary.  

--- Document Chunk 1162 ---
 Cab signalling to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 1163 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

2.6.7 ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 3 

--- Document Chunk 1175 ---
2.6.7.1 General description 

--- Document Chunk 1176 ---
2.6.7.1.1 ERTMS/ETCS Level 3 is a radio based train control system. 

--- Document Chunk 1177 ---
2.6.7.1.2 Movement authorities are generated trackside and are transmitted to the train via 

--- Document Chunk 1178 ---
Euroradio.  

--- Document Chunk 1179 ---
2.6.7.1.3 ERTMS/ETCS Level 3 provides a continuous speed supervision system, which also 

--- Document Chunk 1180 ---
protects against overrun of the authority.  

--- Document Chunk 1181 ---
2.6.7.1.4 Train position and train integrity supervision are performed by the trackside radio block 

--- Document Chunk 1182 ---
centre in co -operation with the train (which sends position reports and tr ain integrity 

--- Document Chunk 1183 ---
information).  

--- Document Chunk 1184 ---
2.6.7.1.5 Level 3 is based on Euroradio for track to train communication and on Eurobalises as 

--- Document Chunk 1185 ---
spot transmission devices mainly for location referencing.   

--- Document Chunk 1186 ---
2.6.7.1.6 The trackside radio block centre which provides the information to the trains kno ws 

--- Document Chunk 1187 ---
each train individually by the ERTMS/ETCS identity of its leading ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 1188 ---
board equipment.  

--- Document Chunk 1189 ---
2.6.7.1.7 Note: Lineside signals are not foreseen to be used when operating in Level 3. 

--- Document Chunk 1190 ---
ETCS

--- Document Chunk 1191 ---
Eurobalise

--- Document Chunk 1192 ---

--- Document Chunk 1193 ---
train

--- Document Chunk 1194 ---
integrity

--- Document Chunk 1195 ---
Interlocking

--- Document Chunk 1209 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1210 ---
2.6.7.2.1 Trackside equipment:  

--- Document Chunk 1211 ---
 Radio block centre. 

--- Document Chunk 1212 ---
 Euroradio for bi-directional track-train communication. 

--- Document Chunk 1213 ---
 Eurobalises for mainly location referencing.  

--- Document Chunk 1214 ---
2.6.7.2.2 Main ERTMS/ETCS trackside function: 

--- Document Chunk 1215 ---
 Knowing each train within an RBC area by its ERTMS/ETCS identity.  

--- Document Chunk 1216 ---
 Following each trains location within an RBC area.  

--- Document Chunk 1217 ---
 Route locking and route releasing based on information received from the trains. 

--- Document Chunk 1218 ---
 Determine movement authorities for each train individually.  

--- Document Chunk 1219 ---
 Transmit movement authorities and track description  to each train individually.  

--- Document Chunk 1220 ---
 Handing over of train control between different RBC’s at the RBC-RBC borders. 

--- Document Chunk 1221 ---
2.6.7.2.3 On-board equipment:  

--- Document Chunk 1222 ---
 Onboard equipment with Eurobalise and Euroradio transmissions. 

--- Document Chunk 1223 ---
 Train integrity proving system. 

--- Document Chunk 1224 ---
2.6.7.2.4 Main ERTMS/ETCS on-board functions: 

--- Document Chunk 1225 ---
 The train reads Eurobalises and sends its position relative to the detected balises to 

--- Document Chunk 1226 ---
the radio block centre. 

--- Document Chunk 1227 ---
 The train monitors train integrity (external function, not part of ERTMS/ETCS) and 

--- Document Chunk 1228 ---
sends this information to the radio block centre. 

--- Document Chunk 1229 ---
 The train receives a movement authority and the track description  via Euroradio 

--- Document Chunk 1230 ---
relating to a balise.  

--- Document Chunk 1231 ---
 Selection of the most restrictive value of the different speeds permitted at each 

--- Document Chunk 1232 ---
location ahead. 

--- Document Chunk 1233 ---
 Calculation of a dynamic speed profile, taking into account the train running/braking 

--- Document Chunk 1234 ---
characteristics which are known on-board and the track description data. 

--- Document Chunk 1235 ---
 Comparison of the train speed with the permitted speed and commanding of the 

--- Document Chunk 1236 ---
brake application if necessary.  

--- Document Chunk 1237 ---
 Cab signalling to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 1238 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 1249 ---
2.6.8 Level transitions 

--- Document Chunk 1250 ---
2.6.8.1 An ERTMS/ETCS equipment which is not isolated always operates in one of the above 

--- Document Chunk 1251 ---
described levels. All transitions between these levels are performed according to 

--- Document Chunk 1252 ---
defined functions and procedures.  

--- Document Chunk 1253 ---
2.6.8.2 Additional national functions and rules which might be used by an individual railway to 

--- Document Chunk 1254 ---
for example prevent not equipped trains from entering a level 2/3 area are not 

--- Document Chunk 1255 ---
specified here and have to be implemented outside ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 1256 ---
2.6.8.3 The following table shows all possible transitions (marked with Grey): 

--- Document Chunk 1257 ---
to 

--- Document Chunk 1258 ---
from                  

--- Document Chunk 1259 ---
0 NTC 1 2 3 

--- Document Chunk 1260 ---
0      

--- Document Chunk 1261 ---
NTC  a)    

--- Document Chunk 1262 ---

--- Document Chunk 1266 ---
a) Transitions between level NTC and level NTC describe the switching from one 

--- Document Chunk 1267 ---
national system to another national system.  

--- Document Chunk 1268 ---

--- Document Chunk 1269 ---
describe the handover between RBC’s.

--- Document Chunk 1715 ---
3.3 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 1716 ---
3.3.1 Scope and purpose 

--- Document Chunk 1717 ---
3.3.1.1 The chapter 3, Principles, specifies the system principles of ETCS/ERTMS. These 

--- Document Chunk 1718 ---
principles apply to on-board and trackside subsystems. 

--- Document Chunk 1719 ---
3.3.1.2 The principles define the operational and technical behaviour of the system in general 

--- Document Chunk 1720 ---
and functional terms. 

--- Document Chunk 1721 ---
3.3.1.3 The chapter is divided into subchapters. In each subchapter normally several 

--- Document Chunk 1722 ---
requirements are defined. Each requirement is identified with a unique identification 

--- Document Chunk 1723 ---
number. 

--- Document Chunk 1724 ---
3.3.1.4 Notes, Justifications and Examples are only informative and shall not be regarded as 

--- Document Chunk 1725 ---
requirements. 

--- Document Chunk 1726 ---
3.4 Balise configuration and linking 

--- Document Chunk 1727 ---
3.4.1 Balise Configurations – Balise Group Definition 

--- Document Chunk 1728 ---
3.4.1.1 A balise group shall consist of between one and eight balises. 

--- Document Chunk 1729 ---
3.4.1.2 In every balise shall at least be stored: 

--- Document Chunk 1730 ---
a) The internal number (from 1 to 8) of the balise 

--- Document Chunk 1731 ---
b) The number of balises inside the group 

--- Document Chunk 1732 ---
c) The balise group identity. 

--- Document Chunk 1733 ---
3.4.1.3 The internal number of the balise describes the relative position of the balise in the 

--- Document Chunk 1734 ---
group. 

--- Document Chunk 1735 ---
3.4.2 Balise Co-ordinate System 

--- Document Chunk 1736 ---
3.4.2.1.1 Every balise group has its own co-ordinate system. 

--- Document Chunk 1737 ---
3.4.2.1.2 The orientation of the co -ordinate system of a balise group (i.e., nominal or reverse 

--- Document Chunk 1738 ---
direction) is identified as balise group orientation. 

--- Document Chunk 1739 ---
3.4.2.2 Balise groups composed of two or more balises 

--- Document Chunk 1740 ---
3.4.2.2.1 The origin  of the co -ordinate system for each balise group is given by the balise 

--- Document Chunk 1741 ---
number 1 (called location reference) in the balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 1742 ---
3.4.2.2.2 The nominal direction of each balise group is defined by increasing internal balise 

--- Document Chunk 1743 ---
numbers. 

--- Document Chunk 1744 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1745 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1746 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1747 ---

--- Document Chunk 1767 ---
3.4.2.3 Balise groups composed of a single balise 

--- Document Chunk 1768 ---
3.4.2.3.1 Balise groups consisting of only one single balise are referred to as "single balise 

--- Document Chunk 1769 ---
groups" in the following. 

--- Document Chunk 1770 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1771 ---
No inherent coordinate system 

--- Document Chunk 1772 ---
Location Reference 

--- Document Chunk 1773 ---
Single Balise Group 

--- Document Chunk 1774 ---
schematic representation 

--- Document Chunk 1775 ---
1st 

--- Document Chunk 1776 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1777 ---
Figure 1a: Single balise group 

--- Document Chunk 1778 ---
3.4.2.3.2 Level 1: 

--- Document Chunk 1779 ---
3.4.2.3.2.1 The assignment of the co-ordinate system shall be by means of linking data. 

--- Document Chunk 1780 ---
3.4.2.3.2.2 For balise groups consisting of a single balise, the information "direction with which 

--- Document Chunk 1781 ---
the linked balise group will be passed over" received from a previous balise group shall 

--- Document Chunk 1782 ---
assign a co-ordinate system to the balise.  

--- Document Chunk 1783 ---

--- Document Chunk 1802 ---

information 

--- Document Chunk 1808 ---

--- Document Chunk 1810 ---
3.4.2.3.2.3 The reference for the linking data shall be either a single b alise group if a co -

--- Document Chunk 1811 ---
ordinate system has been assigned to it before, or a balise group consisting of two or 

--- Document Chunk 1812 ---
more balises (with "inherent" co-ordinate system) 

--- Document Chunk 1813 ---
3.4.2.3.3 Level 2/3: 

--- Document Chunk 1814 ---
3.4.2.3.3.1 If the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment cannot evaluate the orientation of the last 

--- Document Chunk 1815 ---
balise group detected, being a single balise group, i.e. no linking information is 

--- Document Chunk 1816 ---
available to identify the orientation of the co-ordinate system of this single balise group, 

--- Document Chunk 1817 ---
the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall report its position by means of a position 

--- Document Chunk 1818 ---
report based on two balise groups reporting the train position in reference to the LRBG 

--- Document Chunk 1819 ---
and the “previous LRBG”, if any. 

--- Document Chunk 1820 ---
3.4.2.3.3.1.1 Note: Receiving this type of position report advises the RBC of the need to assign a 

--- Document Chunk 1821 ---
co-ordinate system to this single balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 1822 ---
3.4.2.3.3.2 When a  single balise group is detected and the previous LRBG is known, the 

--- Document Chunk 1823 ---
position report based on two balise groups shall use as direction reference a move 

--- Document Chunk 1824 ---
from the  “previous LRBG”  towards this single balise group (being the new LRBG): 

--- Document Chunk 1825 ---
directional information in the position report pointing in the same direction as the 

--- Document Chunk 1826 ---
direction reference shall be reported as “nominal”, otherwise as “reverse”. 

--- Document Chunk 1827 ---
3.4.2.3.3.3 If the “previous LRBG “ is not known, the “previous LRBG” and all directional 

--- Document Chunk 1828 ---
information of the position report based on two balise groups shall be reported as 

--- Document Chunk 1829 ---
“unknown”. 

--- Document Chunk 1830 ---
3.4.2.3.3.4 If a new single balise group (BG2), different from the current LRBG (BG1), 

--- Document Chunk 1831 ---
becomes LRBG while the running direction of the train is opposite to the running 

--- Document Chunk 1832 ---
direction when this current LRBG (BG1) was last  passed, the “previous LRBG” and all 

--- Document Chunk 1833 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

directional information of the position report based on two balise groups shall be 

--- Document Chunk 1845 ---
reported as “unknown” (see Figure 2a). 

--- Document Chunk 1846 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1847 ---
Figure 2a: Position report based on two balise groups versus train running direction 

--- Document Chunk 1848 ---
3.4.2.3.3.5 If a single balise group, being the LRBG,  is detected again, the LRBG and the 

--- Document Chunk 1849 ---
“previous LRBG” of the position report based on two balise groups shall remain 

--- Document Chunk 1850 ---
unchanged. 

--- Document Chunk 1851 ---
3.4.2.3.3.6 The assignment of a co -ordinate system received from the RBC shall iden tify the 

--- Document Chunk 1852 ---
balise group for which the assignment is given, and shall assign a balise group 

--- Document Chunk 1853 ---
orientation “nominal” or “reverse” to this balise group  relative to the on-board direction 

--- Document Chunk 1854 ---
reference reported in the position report based on two balise groups (see 3.4.2.3.3.2). 

--- Document Chunk 1855 ---
3.4.2.3.3.6.1 Note: From the sequence of reported balise groups,  the RBC can derive the balise 

--- Document Chunk 1856 ---
group orientation with which the balise group was passed. 

--- Document Chunk 1857 ---

--- Document Chunk 1880 ---
3.4.2.3.3.7 For single balise gr oups reported as LRBG and stored according to 3.6.2.2.2c, 

--- Document Chunk 1881 ---
awaiting an assignment of a co -ordinate system, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 1882 ---
equipment shall be able to discriminate if a single balise has been reported more than 

--- Document Chunk 1883 ---
once and with different “previous LRBGs” to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 1884 ---
3.4.2.3.3.7.1 Note: For a single balise group reported as LRBG awaiting the assignment of a co -

--- Document Chunk 1885 ---
ordinate system also the rules for LRBGs reported to the RBC (see 3.6.2.2.2) apply. 

--- Document Chunk 1886 ---
3.4.2.3.3.8 A co-ordinate system assignment received from trackside shall be rejected by the 

--- Document Chunk 1887 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment if the referred LRBG is memorised (see 3.6.2.2.2c) 

--- Document Chunk 1888 ---
to have been reported more than once and with different “previous LRBGs”. 

--- Document Chunk 1889 ---
3.4.2.3.3.8.1 Note: If a single balise group is memorised, according to 3.6.2.2.2c, more than 

--- Document Chunk 1890 ---
once, and with different “previous LRBGs”, the assignment of the co-ordinate system is 

--- Document Chunk 1891 ---
ambiguous. 

--- Document Chunk 1892 ---

--- Document Chunk 1894 ---
in case where only one balise is correctly read.

--- Document Chunk 1942 ---
3.4.3 Balise Information Types and Usage 

--- Document Chunk 1943 ---
3.4.3.1 In level 1, a ll information to the on -board system is given from balise groups or 

--- Document Chunk 1944 ---
additionally from EUROLOOPS or Radio Infill Units  (see section 3.9). In level 2/3, 

--- Document Chunk 1945 ---
balise groups are mostly used for location information. 

--- Document Chunk 1946 ---
3.4.3.2 A balise may contain directional information, i.e. valid either  for nominal or for reverse 

--- Document Chunk 1947 ---
direction, or may contain information valid for both directions . In level 1, t his 

--- Document Chunk 1948 ---
information can be of the following type (please refer to section 3.8.5): 

--- Document Chunk 1949 ---
a) Non-infill 

--- Document Chunk 1950 ---
b) Intentionally deleted 

--- Document Chunk 1951 ---
c) Infill. 

--- Document Chunk 1952 ---
3.4.3.2.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 1953 ---
3.4.3.2.2 Note: Infill information is referring to the location reference of an announced balise 

--- Document Chunk 1954 ---
group. 

--- Document Chunk 1955 ---
3.4.3.3 Some information shall be read  also in sleeping mode and when no linking information 

--- Document Chunk 1956 ---
is available (see Chapter 4 Use of received information). If such information is 

--- Document Chunk 1957 ---
transmitted by balises, and if the information is directional, balise groups consisting of 

--- Document Chunk 1958 ---
at least two balises shall be used. 

--- Document Chunk 1959 ---
3.4.4 Linking 

--- Document Chunk 1960 ---
3.4.4.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 1961 ---
3.4.4.1.1 Aim of linking:  

--- Document Chunk 1962 ---
 To determine whether a balise group has been missed or not found within the 

--- Document Chunk 1963 ---
expectation window (see section 3.4.4.4) and take the appropriate action.  

--- Document Chunk 1964 ---
 To assign a co-ordinate system to balise groups consisting of a single balise. 

--- Document Chunk 1965 ---
 To correct the confidence interval due to odometer inaccuracy (see section 3.6.4). 

--- Document Chunk 1966 ---
3.4.4.1.2 A balise group is linked when its linking information (see section 3.4.4.2) is known in 

--- Document Chunk 1967 ---
advance. 

--- Document Chunk 1968 ---
3.4.4.1.2.1 Note: In cases where a balise group contains repositioning information, the term 

--- Document Chunk 1969 ---
linked also applies since the balise group is announced, marked as linked and contains 

--- Document Chunk 1970 ---
repositioning information marked accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 1971 ---
3.4.4.2 Content of linking information 

--- Document Chunk 1972 ---
3.4.4.2.1 Linking information shall be composed of: 

--- Document Chunk 1973 ---
a) The identity of the linked balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 1974 ---
b) Where the location reference of the group has to be found. 

--- Document Chunk 1975 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1976 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1977 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1978 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 1979 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 1980 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 1981 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 1982 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 1983 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 1984 ---
Page 15/204 

--- Document Chunk 1985 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1986 ---
c) The accuracy of this location. 

--- Document Chunk 1987 ---
Note: If the reference balise is duplicated, it is the trackside responsibility to define 

--- Document Chunk 1988 ---
the location accuracy to cover at least the location of the two duplicated balises. 

--- Document Chunk 1989 ---
d) The direction with which the linked balise group will be passed over (nominal or 

--- Document Chunk 1990 ---
reverse). 

--- Document Chunk 1991 ---
e) The reaction required if a data consistency problem occ urs with the expected balise 

--- Document Chunk 1992 ---
group. 

--- Document Chunk 1993 ---
3.4.4.2.1.1 "Linking information is used" shall be interpreted as when balise group(s) are 

--- Document Chunk 1994 ---
announced and the minimum safe antenna position has not yet passed the expectation 

--- Document Chunk 1995 ---
window of the furthest announced balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 1996 ---
3.4.4.2.2 Instead of the identity of a linked balise group it shall be possible to identify a following 

--- Document Chunk 1997 ---
linked balise group as unknown but containing repositioning information 

--- Document Chunk 1998 ---
3.4.4.2.2.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 1999 ---
3.4.4.2.2.2 Note 1: Regarding the repositioning information, see chapter 3.8.5.3.5 and 3.8.5.2. 

--- Document Chunk 2000 ---
3.4.4.2.2.3 Note 2: In case the identity of the next balise group is not unambiguously known 

--- Document Chunk 2001 ---
because the route is not known by the trackside, this feature allows to link this balise 

--- Document Chunk 2002 ---
group. 

--- Document Chunk 2003 ---
3.4.4.2.3 For each linked balise group, the trackside shall select one of the following reactions to 

--- Document Chunk 2004 ---
be used in case of data inconsistencies: 

--- Document Chunk 2005 ---
a) Train trip  (Trip mode, see Chapter 4) 

--- Document Chunk 2006 ---
b) Command service brake  

--- Document Chunk 2007 ---
c) No reaction 

--- Document Chunk 2008 ---
For further details see section 3.16.2. 

--- Document Chunk 2009 ---
3.4.4.3 Unlinked Balise Groups 

--- Document Chunk 2010 ---
3.4.4.3.1 A balise group, which contains information that must be considered even when the 

--- Document Chunk 2011 ---
balise group is not announced by linking, is called an unlinked balise group.  

--- Document Chunk 2012 ---
3.4.4.3.2 Unlinked balise groups shall consist at minimum of two balises.   

--- Document Chunk 2013 ---
3.4.4.3.3 Unlinked balise groups shall always contain the unlinked balise group qualifier. 

--- Document Chunk 2014 ---
3.4.4.4 Rules related to linking 

--- Document Chunk 2015 ---
3.4.4.4.1 When no linking information is used on -board, all balise groups shall be taken into 

--- Document Chunk 2016 ---
account. 

--- Document Chunk 2017 ---
3.4.4.4.2 When linking information is used on -board, only balise groups marked as linked and 

--- Document Chunk 2018 ---
included in the linking information and balise groups marked as unlinked shall be taken 

--- Document Chunk 2019 ---
into account. 

--- Document Chunk 2020 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2021 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2022 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2023 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 2024 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 2025 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 2026 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 2027 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2028 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 2029 ---
Page 16/204 

--- Document Chunk 2030 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2031 ---
3.4.4.4.2.1 When linking information is used on-board and the expected balise group is referred 

--- Document Chunk 2032 ---
in the linking information with a balise group with ID “unknown”, a balise g roup marked 

--- Document Chunk 2033 ---
as linked shall only be taken into account if: 

--- Document Chunk 2034 ---
a) the on-board equipment can determine the orientation of the linked balise group by 

--- Document Chunk 2035 ---
information from the balise group itself (therefore excluding for example single 

--- Document Chunk 2036 ---
balise groups), AND 

--- Document Chunk 2037 ---
b) the balise gr oup contains repositioning information valid for the train orientation, 

--- Document Chunk 2038 ---
AND 

--- Document Chunk 2039 ---
c) the balise group is crossed with the direction announced in the linking information. 

--- Document Chunk 2040 ---
3.4.4.4.3 The on-board equipment shall accept a balise group marked as linked and included in 

--- Document Chunk 2041 ---
the linking information (i.e. the balise giving the location reference) from  

--- Document Chunk 2042 ---
 when the max safe front end of the train has passed the first possible location of 

--- Document Chunk 2043 ---
the balise group  

--- Document Chunk 2044 ---
until  

--- Document Chunk 2045 ---
 the min safe front end of the train has passed the last possible location of the 

--- Document Chunk 2046 ---
balise group 

--- Document Chunk 2047 ---
taking the offset between the front of the train and the balise antenna into account. 

--- Document Chunk 2048 ---
3.4.4.4.3.1 Note: The first possible location and the last possible location of the balise group 

--- Document Chunk 2049 ---
are defined by the linking distance and the location accuracy. 

--- Document Chunk 2050 ---
3.4.4.4.3.2 Note: The  interval between the outer limits to accept the balise group defines the 

--- Document Chunk 2051 ---
expectation window. 

--- Document Chunk 2052 ---
3.4.4.4.4 In case of a balise group containing repositioning information, the first possible location 

--- Document Chunk 2053 ---
shall start from the previously linked balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 2054 ---
3.4.4.4.5 The on-board equipment shall expect balise groups one by one (i.e., it shall supervise 

--- Document Chunk 2055 ---
only one expectation window at a time) according to the order given by linking 

--- Document Chunk 2056 ---
information. 

--- Document Chunk 2057 ---
3.4.4.4.6 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall stop expecting a balise group and shall 

--- Document Chunk 2058 ---
expect the next one announced in the linking information (if any) when: 

--- Document Chunk 2059 ---
a) the balise group is found inside its expectation window 

--- Document Chunk 2060 ---
b) a linking consistency error is found, see 3.16.2.3.1 

--- Document Chunk 2061 ---
3.4.4.4.6.1 Linking consistency error due to early reception of balise group expected later (see 

--- Document Chunk 2062 ---
3.16.2.3.1 c)): if the balise group found is the next one announced in the linking 

--- Document Chunk 2063 ---
information, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall check its linking consistency 

--- Document Chunk 2064 ---
and apply again clause 3.4.4.4.6, i.e. it will immediately expect the further next balise 

--- Document Chunk 2065 ---
group announced in the linking information. 

--- Document Chunk 2066 ---

--- Document Chunk 2077 ---
3.5 Management of Radio Communication 

--- Document Chunk 2078 ---
3.5.1.1 Note: the following section refers to the behaviour of the user application interacting 

--- Document Chunk 2079 ---
with Euroradio protocols. How the messages are actually transported from the sender 

--- Document Chunk 2080 ---
to the receiver user application is not relevant for this description. 

--- Document Chunk 2081 ---
3.5.2 General 

--- Document Chunk 2082 ---
3.5.2.1 Each communication session managed by an entity allow s the exchange of data with 

--- Document Chunk 2083 ---
only one other entity. 

--- Document Chunk 2084 ---
3.5.2.2 Note: in the following sections reference is made to safe radio connections, whose 

--- Document Chunk 2085 ---
definition and management is contained in Euroradio specification. 

--- Document Chunk 2086 ---
3.5.2.3 Note: The information Initiation of a Communication Session and Version not 

--- Document Chunk 2087 ---
Compatible (see sections 3.5.2.4 and 3.17) are the same in every system version. 

--- Document Chunk 2088 ---
3.5.2.4 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall be able to manage simultaneous 

--- Document Chunk 2089 ---
communication sessions with at least two different entities. 

--- Document Chunk 2090 ---
3.5.3 Establishing a communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2091 ---
3.5.3.1 Only the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment can initiate a communication session. 

--- Document Chunk 2092 ---
3.5.3.2 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2093 ---
3.5.3.3 Note: Only communication sessions between an ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 2094 ---
and a trackside equipment (RBC or Radio Infill Unit) are considered here. 

--- Document Chunk 2095 ---
3.5.3.4 The on-board shall establish a communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2096 ---
a) At Start of Mission (only if level 2 or 3). 

--- Document Chunk 2097 ---
b) If ordered from trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 2098 ---
c) If a mode change, neither considered as an End of Mission  nor triggered from 

--- Document Chunk 2099 ---
condition g) below, has to be reported to the RBC (only if level 2 or 3) 

--- Document Chunk 2100 ---
d) If the driver has manually changed the level to 2 or 3 

--- Document Chunk 2101 ---
e) When the train front reaches the end of an announced radio hole 

--- Document Chunk 2102 ---
f) When the previous communication session is considered as terminated due to loss 

--- Document Chunk 2103 ---
of safe radio connection (refer to 3.5.4.2.1) 

--- Document Chunk 2104 ---
g) When a Start of Mission procedure, during which no communicat ion session could 

--- Document Chunk 2105 ---
be established, is completed in level 2 or 3 

--- Document Chunk 2106 ---
h) When outside the Start of Mission procedure, the driver has manually selected the 

--- Document Chunk 2107 ---
RBC contact information (only if level 2 or 3) 

--- Document Chunk 2108 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2109 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2110 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2111 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 2112 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 2113 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 2114 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 2115 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2116 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 2117 ---
Page 18/204 

--- Document Chunk 2118 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2119 ---
3.5.3.4.1 In respect of a), b), c) , d), e) and h) of 3.5.3.4, the on -board shall not establish a new 

--- Document Chunk 2120 ---
communication session with an RBC/RIU in case a communication session is currently 

--- Document Chunk 2121 ---
being established or is already established with this RBC/RIU. 

--- Document Chunk 2122 ---
3.5.3.5 The order to contact an RBC shall include 

--- Document Chunk 2123 ---
a) The identity of the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 2124 ---
b) The telephone number of the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 2125 ---
c) The action to be performed (establish/terminate the session). 

--- Document Chunk 2126 ---
d) Whether this applies also to Sleeping units. 

--- Document Chunk 2127 ---
3.5.3.5.1 See table at the end of section 3.5.3.  

--- Document Chunk 2128 ---
3.5.3.5.2 If the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment has  to establish a communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2129 ---
with an RBC whilst in session with another RBC, the existing communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2130 ---
shall be terminated (see 3.5.5.2 for details) and the new one shall be established. 

--- Document Chunk 2131 ---
Exception: the order to contact an Accepting RBC shall not terminate the 

--- Document Chunk 2132 ---
communication session with the Handing Over RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 2133 ---
3.5.3.5.3 The order to contact an Accepting RBC shall be part of the RBC transition order and 

--- Document Chunk 2134 ---
shall include: 

--- Document Chunk 2135 ---
a) The identity of the Accepting RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 2136 ---
b) The telephone number of the Accepting RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 2137 ---
c) Whether this applies also to Sleeping unit. 

--- Document Chunk 2138 ---
3.5.3.6 The order to contact a Radio Infill Unit shall include 

--- Document Chunk 2139 ---
a) The identity of the Radio Infill Unit 

--- Document Chunk 2140 ---
b) The telephone number of the Radio Infill Unit 

--- Document Chunk 2141 ---
c) The action to be performed (establish/terminate the session). 

--- Document Chunk 2142 ---
3.5.3.7 The establishment of a communication session shall be performed ac cording to the 

--- Document Chunk 2143 ---
following steps: 

--- Document Chunk 2144 ---
a) The on-board shall request the set-up of a safe radio connection with the trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 2145 ---
If this request is part of an ongoing Start of Mission procedure  or is related to the 

--- Document Chunk 2146 ---
establishment of a communication session due to condition 3.5.3.4 c ), it shall be 

--- Document Chunk 2147 ---
repeated until successful or a defined number of times (see Appendix A.3.1). 

--- Document Chunk 2148 ---
If this request is not part of an ongoing Start of Mission procedure  and is not related 

--- Document Chunk 2149 ---
to the establishment of a communication session due to condition 3. 5.3.4 c), it shall 

--- Document Chunk 2150 ---
be repeated until successful. 

--- Document Chunk 2151 ---
A request shall be repeated immediately after EURORADIO has indicated that 

--- Document Chunk 2152 ---
setting up the safe radio connection has failed. 

--- Document Chunk 2153 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2154 ---

--- Document Chunk 2163 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2164 ---
b) As soon as the safe radio connection is set -up, the on -board shall send the 

--- Document Chunk 2165 ---
message Initiation of communication session to the trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 2166 ---
c) As soon as the trackside receives the information, it shall send the system version. 

--- Document Chunk 2167 ---
d) When the on -board receives the system version it shall consider the 

--- Document Chunk 2168 ---
communication session established and: 

--- Document Chunk 2169 ---
 If one of  its supported system versions is compatible with the one sent by 

--- Document Chunk 2170 ---
trackside, it shall send a session established report, including its  supported 

--- Document Chunk 2171 ---
system versions, to the trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 2172 ---
 If none of its supported system versions is compatible with the one sent by 

--- Document Chunk 2173 ---
trackside, it shall send a version independent message indicating “No 

--- Document Chunk 2174 ---
compatible version supported”. It shall inform the driver and shall terminate the 

--- Document Chunk 2175 ---
communication session. 

--- Document Chunk 2176 ---
e) When the trackside receives the session established report or the information tha t 

--- Document Chunk 2177 ---
no compatible system version is supported by the on -board, it shall consider the 

--- Document Chunk 2178 ---
communication session established.

--- Document Chunk 2289 ---
3.5.4 Maintaining a communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2290 ---
3.5.4.1 When a communication session is established , in case of a loss of the safe radio 

--- Document Chunk 2291 ---
connection, i.e., if the  disconnection has not been ordered (see 3.5.5.1), the involved 

--- Document Chunk 2292 ---
entities shall consider the communication session still established for a defined time. 

--- Document Chunk 2293 ---
The defined time shall start as soon as EURORADIO has indicated the loss of the safe 

--- Document Chunk 2294 ---
radio connection. 

--- Document Chunk 2295 ---
3.5.4.2 When EURORADIO indicates the loss of the safe radio connection, the ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 2296 ---
on-board equipment shall immediately try to set-up a new safe radio connection. 

--- Document Chunk 2297 ---
3.5.4.2.1 If the safe radio connection is not re -established after the defined time (as defined in 

--- Document Chunk 2298 ---
A.3.1), b oth, on -board equipment and trackside, shall consider the session as 

--- Document Chunk 2299 ---
terminated. 

--- Document Chunk 2300 ---
3.5.4.3 The attempts shall be repeated, until at least one of the following conditions is met: 

--- Document Chunk 2301 ---
 The safe radio connection is set-up. 

--- Document Chunk 2302 ---
 The session is considered as terminated. 

--- Document Chunk 2303 ---
 The train passes the location indicated in the RIU order “Terminate the 

--- Document Chunk 2304 ---
communication session” 

--- Document Chunk 2305 ---
3.5.4.3.1 Note: if the session is considered as terminated due to 3.5.4.2.1, the attempts will be 

--- Document Chunk 2306 ---
resumed immediately according to 3.5.3.4 f). 

--- Document Chunk 2307 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2308 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2309 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2310 ---

--- Document Chunk 2317 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2318 ---
3.5.4.4 Exception to 3.5.4.2 and 3.5.4.3:  the on-board equipment shall not try to set up a new 

--- Document Chunk 2319 ---
safe radio connection and shall stop any ongoing attempts  if the train front is inside an 

--- Document Chunk 2320 ---
announced radio hole (see 3.12.1.3). The on -board equipment shall try to set it up 

--- Document Chunk 2321 ---
again when the train front reaches the end of the radio hole. 

--- Document Chunk 2322 ---
3.5.4.5 In case a message has to be sent during the loss of the safe radio connection, this 

--- Document Chunk 2323 ---
message shall be considered as sent. 

--- Document Chunk 2324 ---
3.5.5 Terminating a communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2325 ---
3.5.5.1 The termination of a communication session shall be initiated only by t he on-board and 

--- Document Chunk 2326 ---
in the following cases: 

--- Document Chunk 2327 ---
a) If an order is received from trackside (RBC , RIU  or balise groups) (see section s 

--- Document Chunk 2328 ---
3.5.3.5 and 3.5.3.6 concerning the content of the order). 

--- Document Chunk 2329 ---
b) If a condition requiring the termination of the communication session is fulfilled 

--- Document Chunk 2330 ---
without any explicit trackside order . The situations in which such  condition is met 

--- Document Chunk 2331 ---
are detailed in other sections of this specification. 

--- Document Chunk 2332 ---
c) Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2333 ---
d) Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2334 ---
e) Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2335 ---
f) Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2336 ---
3.5.5.2 In case a session is  established, t he on -board equipment shall terminate the 

--- Document Chunk 2337 ---
communication session according to the following steps: 

--- Document Chunk 2338 ---
a) The on -board equipment shall send a Termination of communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2339 ---
message.  

--- Document Chunk 2340 ---
b) As soon as this information is received, the trackside shall  consider the 

--- Document Chunk 2341 ---
communication session terminated and send an acknowledgement to the on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 2342 ---
c) When the acknowledgement is received the on -board shall consider the 

--- Document Chunk 2343 ---
communication session terminated and request the release of the safe radio 

--- Document Chunk 2344 ---
connection with trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 2345 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2346 ---

--- Document Chunk 2378 ---

--- Document Chunk 2380 ---
