--- Document Chunk 2381 ---
“Termination of communication session” message, the message shall be repeated with 

--- Document Chunk 2382 ---
the fixed waiting time after each repetition. 

--- Document Chunk 2383 ---
3.5.5.3.2 After a defined nu mber of repetitions ( see Appendix A.3.1), and if no acknowledgment 

--- Document Chunk 2384 ---

--- Document Chunk 2385 ---
“Termination of communication session”, the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 2386 ---

--- Document Chunk 2387 ---

--- Document Chunk 2388 ---
Acknowledgement of the termination of communication session.

--- Document Chunk 2390 ---
Acknowledgement are the same in every system version. 

--- Document Chunk 2391 ---

--- Document Chunk 2392 ---
communication session” has been sent shall be ignored with the exception of the 

--- Document Chunk 2393 ---
Acknowledgement of the termination of communication session.

--- Document Chunk 2395 ---
3.5.6 Registering to the Radio Network 

--- Document Chunk 2396 ---
3.5.6.1 ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall order the registration of its connected Mobile 

--- Document Chunk 2397 ---
Terminal(s) to a Radio Network: 

--- Document Chunk 2398 ---
a) At power-up 

--- Document Chunk 2399 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2400 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2401 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2402 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 2403 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 2404 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 2405 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 2406 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2407 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 2408 ---
Page 24/204 

--- Document Chunk 2409 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2410 ---
b) Following driver entry of a new Radio Network identity 

--- Document Chunk 2411 ---
c) If ordered from the trackside 

--- Document Chunk 2412 ---
3.5.6.2 When power ed-off, ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall memorize the last 

--- Document Chunk 2413 ---
received Radio Network identity (from trackside or from driver) and shall use it when 

--- Document Chunk 2414 ---
powered-up again. 

--- Document Chunk 2415 ---
3.5.6.3 If no Radio Network identity received from trackside or from driver could have been 

--- Document Chunk 2416 ---
memorized by ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment (e.g. after a System Failure or at 

--- Document Chunk 2417 ---
very first power -up), this latter shall nevertheless order the registration of its Mobile 

--- Document Chunk 2418 ---
Terminal(s) to a default Radio Network. 

--- Document Chunk 2419 ---
3.5.6.3.1 Note 1: the source used to retrieve the default Radio Network identity (on -board 

--- Document Chunk 2420 ---
equipment permanent storage, Mobile Terminal itself, or other external source) is 

--- Document Chunk 2421 ---
implementation dependent.  

--- Document Chunk 2422 ---
3.5.6.3.2 Note 2: if ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment is powered-up in an area not covered by 

--- Document Chunk 2423 ---
the memorized or default Radio Network, attempts to register to this Radio Network will 

--- Document Chunk 2424 ---
be repeated unconditionally by the Mobile Terminal(s) until either an attempt is 

--- Document Chunk 2425 ---
successful or a new Radio Network identity is received from trackside or from driver, 

--- Document Chunk 2426 ---
preventing Mobile Terminal(s) from registering to any unwanted Radio Network. 

--- Document Chunk 2427 ---
3.5.6.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2428 ---
3.5.6.5 On reception of the trackside order, ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 2429 ---
immediately order the Radio Network registration of each Mobile Terminal that fulfils 

--- Document Chunk 2430 ---
the following conditions: 

--- Document Chunk 2431 ---
a) it is not yet registered to the ordered Radio Network, AND 

--- Document Chunk 2432 ---
b) it is not used for an established communication session, AND 

--- Document Chunk 2433 ---
c) no safe radio connection is being set-up 

--- Document Chunk 2434 ---
3.5.6.6 If a Mobile Terminal is not currently registered to the Radio Network ordered by 

--- Document Chunk 2435 ---
trackside and if one of the conditions b) or c) is not fulfilled, ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 2436 ---
equipment shall initiate the Radio Network registration once communication session is 

--- Document Chunk 2437 ---
terminated and safe radio connection is released. 

--- Document Chunk 2438 ---
3.5.6.7 If no Mobile Terminal is duly registered to a Radio Networ k, any order to contact an 

--- Document Chunk 2439 ---
RBC or an RIU received from trackside shall be rejected by ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 2440 ---
equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 2441 ---
3.5.7 Safe Radio Connection Indication 

--- Document Chunk 2442 ---
3.5.7.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall inform the driver about the status of the 

--- Document Chunk 2443 ---
safe radio connection. T o that purpose, the following indication statuses of the safe 

--- Document Chunk 2444 ---
radio connection are defined: “No Connection”, “Connection Lost/Set -Up failed”, 

--- Document Chunk 2445 ---
“Connection Up”. 

--- Document Chunk 2446 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.5.7.2 In addition, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall use a “connection status” 

--- Document Chunk 2458 ---
timer (see Appendix A.3.1), in order to manage properly the transitions to the indication 

--- Document Chunk 2459 ---
status “Connection Lost/Set-Up failed”. 

--- Document Chunk 2460 ---
3.5.7.2.1 Note: The purpose of the “connection status” timer is to avoid distracting the driver for 

--- Document Chunk 2461 ---
any short disturbance of the safe radio connection. 

--- Document Chunk 2462 ---
3.5.7.3 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall start the “connection status” timer as 

--- Document Chunk 2463 ---
soon as the first request to set-up a safe radio connection with the relevant RBC/RIU is 

--- Document Chunk 2464 ---
sent: 

--- Document Chunk 2465 ---
a) for what regards the session establishment, see items b), c), d), e) in 3.5.3.4. 

--- Document Chunk 2466 ---
b) for what regards maintaining a communication session, see 3.5.4.2 and 3.5.4.4 

--- Document Chunk 2467 ---
3.5.7.4 If the “connection status” timer is ongoing, it shall be stopped if the requests to set -up 

--- Document Chunk 2468 ---
a safe radio connection are stopped with the relevant RBC/RIU. 

--- Document Chunk 2469 ---
3.5.7.5 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equ ipment shall execute the transitions between the 

--- Document Chunk 2470 ---
different indication statuses of the safe radio connection with the relevant RBC/RIU as 

--- Document Chunk 2471 ---
described in Table 1 according to the conditions in Table 2 (see se ction 4.6.1 for 

--- Document Chunk 2472 ---
details about the symbols).

--- Document Chunk 2522 ---
3.5.7.6 For the case of an RBC/RBC transition, the safe radio connection indicated to the 

--- Document Chunk 2523 ---
driver shall switch from the indication status of the safe radio co nnection with the 

--- Document Chunk 2524 ---
Handing over RBC to the one with the Accepting RBC as soon as one of the following 

--- Document Chunk 2525 ---
conditions is met: 

--- Document Chunk 2526 ---
a) the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment sends a position report directly to the 

--- Document Chunk 2527 ---
Accepting RBC with its maximum safe front end having passed th e border, see 

--- Document Chunk 2528 ---
3.15.1.3.5 (i.e. the Accepting RBC becomes the supervising RBC), 

--- Document Chunk 2529 ---
b) the safe radio connection is released with the Handing over RBC and the minimum 

--- Document Chunk 2530 ---
safe rear end of the train has crossed the border, see 3.15.1.2.7 and 3.15.1.3.9. 

--- Document Chunk 2531 ---
3.5.7.6.1 Note: During an  RBC/RBC handover procedure, an indication status transition table 

--- Document Chunk 2532 ---
and a connection status timer might have to be managed at the same time, for each 

--- Document Chunk 2533 ---
RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 2534 ---
3.5.7.7 For the case of safe radio connection with RIU’s, the safe radio connection indicated to 

--- Document Chunk 2535 ---
the driver shall be the one related to the current infill area. 

--- Document Chunk 2536 ---
3.6 Location Principles, Train Position and Train Orientation 

--- Document Chunk 2537 ---
3.6.1 General 

--- Document Chunk 2538 ---
3.6.1.1 Two types of location based data are defined: 

--- Document Chunk 2539 ---
a) Data that refers only to a given location, referred to as Location data (e.g. level 

--- Document Chunk 2540 ---
transition orders, linking) 

--- Document Chunk 2541 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2542 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2543 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2544 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 2545 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 2546 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 2547 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 2548 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2549 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 2550 ---
Page 27/204 

--- Document Chunk 2551 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2552 ---
b) Data that remains valid for a certain distance, referred to as Profile data (e.g. SSP, 

--- Document Chunk 2553 ---
gradient).  

--- Document Chunk 2554 ---
3.6.1.2 Note: Determination of the Train Position  is always longitudinal along the route, even 

--- Document Chunk 2555 ---
though the route might be set through a complex track layout. 

--- Document Chunk 2556 ---
1       2     3

--- Document Chunk 2557 ---
4         5      6

--- Document Chunk 2558 ---
7

--- Document Chunk 2559 ---
Figure 6: Actual route of the train 

--- Document Chunk 2560 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2561 ---
1 5 7

--- Document Chunk 2562 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2563 ---
Figure 7: Route known by the train 

--- Document Chunk 2564 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2565 ---
3.6.1.3 The Train Position information defines the position of the train front in relation to a 

--- Document Chunk 2566 ---
balise group, which is called LRBG (the Last Relevant Balise Group). It includes: 

--- Document Chunk 2567 ---
 The estimated train front end position, defined by the estimated distance between 

--- Document Chunk 2568 ---
the LRBG and the front end of the train 

--- Document Chunk 2569 ---
 The train position confidence interval (see 3.6.4) 

--- Document Chunk 2570 ---
 Directional train position information in reference to the balise group orientation 

--- Document Chunk 2571 ---
(see 3.4.2, also Figure 14) of the LRBG, regarding: 

--- Document Chunk 2572 ---
 the position of the train front end (nominal or reverse side of the LRBG) 

--- Document Chunk 2573 ---
 the train orientation  

--- Document Chunk 2574 ---
 the train running direction 

--- Document Chunk 2575 ---
In case of an LRBG being a single balise group with no co -ordinate system 

--- Document Chunk 2576 ---
assigned, directional information is defined in reference to the pair of LRBG and 

--- Document Chunk 2577 ---
“previous LRBG”, see 3.4.2.3.3 

--- Document Chunk 2578 ---
 A list of LRBGs, which may alternatively be used b y trackside for referencing 

--- Document Chunk 2579 ---
location dependent information (see 3.6.2.2.2 c)). 

--- Document Chunk 2580 ---
3.6.1.4 Balise groups, which are marked as unlinked, shall never be used as LRBG. 

--- Document Chunk 2581 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2582 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2583 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2584 ---
SUBSET-026-3

Chapter 3

--- Document Chunk 2591 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2592 ---
3.6.1.4.1 Justification: The location of an unlinked balise group, or the balise group itself, may 

--- Document Chunk 2593 ---
not be known to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 2594 ---
3.6.1.5 If there is an active cab, this one defines the orientation of the train, i.e . the side of the 

--- Document Chunk 2595 ---
active cab shall be considered as the front of the train. If no cab is active, the train 

--- Document Chunk 2596 ---
orientation shall be as when a cab was last active. 

--- Document Chunk 2597 ---
3.6.1.6 The “train orientation relative to LRBG” is defined as the train orientation related to the 

--- Document Chunk 2598 ---
orientation of the LRBG, see Figure 14. It can be either “nominal” or “reverse”. 

--- Document Chunk 2599 ---
3.6.1.6.1 Note: The train orientation cannot be affected by the direction controller position. 

--- Document Chunk 2600 ---
3.6.2 Location of Data Transmitted to the On-Board Equipment 

--- Document Chunk 2601 ---
3.6.2.1 Data Transmitted by Balises 

--- Document Chunk 2602 ---
3.6.2.1.1 All location and profile data transmitted by a balise shall refer to the location reference 

--- Document Chunk 2603 ---
and orientation of the balise group to which the balise belongs. 

--- Document Chunk 2604 ---
3.6.2.1.2 Exception: Regarding infill information the section 3.6.2.3.1 shall apply. 

--- Document Chunk 2605 ---
3.6.2.2 Data Transmitted by Radio from RBC 

--- Document Chunk 2606 ---
3.6.2.2.1 All location and profile data transmitted from the RBC shall refer to the location 

--- Document Chunk 2607 ---
reference and orientation of the LRBG given in the same message. 

--- Document Chunk 2608 ---
3.6.2.2.2 For the LRBG the following requirements have to be met: 

--- Document Chunk 2609 ---
a) The on -board equipment shall use the last balise group passed as a reference 

--- Document Chunk 2610 ---
when reporting its position to the RBC (in the following termed as LRBGONB). Only  

--- Document Chunk 2611 ---
 balise groups marked as linked and contained in the previously received linking 

--- Document Chunk 2612 ---
information, if linking information is used on-board 

--- Document Chunk 2613 ---
 or  

--- Document Chunk 2614 ---
 the last balise group not marked as unlinked, if no linking was used when this 

--- Document Chunk 2615 ---
balise group was passed 

--- Document Chunk 2616 ---
shall be regarded. 

--- Document Chunk 2617 ---
b) The RBC shall use a balise group which was reported by the on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 2618 ---
as a reference (in the following termed as LRBG RBC). At a certain moment LRBG RBC 

--- Document Chunk 2619 ---
and LRBGONB can be different. 

--- Document Chunk 2620 ---
c) The on-board equipment shall be able to accept information referring to one of at 

--- Document Chunk 2621 ---
least eight LRBGONB last reported to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 2622 ---
3.6.2.2.2.1 Exception to a) : When on -board position is unknown or when position data has 

--- Document Chunk 2623 ---
been deleted during SoM procedure , the on -board equipment shall use an LRBG 

--- Document Chunk 2624 ---
identifier set to "unknown" until the onboard has  validated its position again by passing 

--- Document Chunk 2625 ---
a balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 2626 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.6.2.2.2.2 Exception to b): When the RBC has received from the onboard an unknown position 

--- Document Chunk 2638 ---
(as per 3.6.2.2.2.1)  or during SoM procedure an invalid position which it is not able to 

--- Document Chunk 2639 ---
confirm, the RBC shall use an LRBG identifier set to "unknown" until it receives a 

--- Document Chunk 2640 ---
position report from the onboard having validated its position by passing a balise 

--- Document Chunk 2641 ---
group. 

--- Document Chunk 2642 ---
3.6.2.2.2.3 Regarding c):  From the time it has reported an unknown position, or an  invalid 

--- Document Chunk 2643 ---
position during SoM procedure, to the time it has received from the RBC a message 

--- Document Chunk 2644 ---
with an LRBG not set to “unknown”, the on -board equipment shall also be able to 

--- Document Chunk 2645 ---
accept messages from the RBC containing LRBG “unknown”. 

--- Document Chunk 2646 ---

3.6.3 Validity direction of transmitted Information 

--- Document Chunk 2751 ---
3.6.3.1 General 

--- Document Chunk 2752 ---
3.6.3.1.1 The direction for which transmitted information is valid shall refer to: 

--- Document Chunk 2753 ---
a) the direction of the LRBG for information sent by radio 

--- Document Chunk 2754 ---
b) the direction of the balise group sending the information. 

--- Document Chunk 2755 ---
3.6.3.1.2 Data transmitted to the on -board equipment (by balise or radi o) shall be identified as 

--- Document Chunk 2756 ---
being valid for 

--- Document Chunk 2757 ---
a) both directions 

--- Document Chunk 2758 ---
b) the nominal direction 

--- Document Chunk 2759 ---
c) the reverse direction 

--- Document Chunk 2760 ---
of the referenced balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 2761 ---
3.6.3.1.2.1 Deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2762 ---
3.6.3.1.3 When receiving information from any transmission medium, the ERTMS/ETCS on-

--- Document Chunk 2763 ---
board equipment shall only take into a ccount information valid for its orientation. Other 

--- Document Chunk 2764 ---
information shall be ignored. Exception: for SL , PS  and SH engines, balise group 

--- Document Chunk 2765 ---
crossing direction shall be considered. 

--- Document Chunk 2766 ---
3.6.3.1.3.1 If the train position is unknown, data received from any transmission medium valid 

--- Document Chunk 2767 ---
for one direction only (nominal or reverse) shall be rejected by the onboard equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 2768 ---
Data valid for both directions shall be evaluated (see section 4.8). 

--- Document Chunk 2769 ---
3.6.3.1.4 If no co -ordinate system has been assigned to a single balise group, data transmitted 

--- Document Chunk 2770 ---
by trackside, which refers to that balise group requiring the co -ordinate system to be 

--- Document Chunk 2771 ---
known (i.e. all data which are only valid for one direction (nominal or reverse) ) shall be 

--- Document Chunk 2772 ---
rejected by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment. Data valid for both directions shall 

--- Document Chunk 2773 ---
be evaluated (see section 4.8). 

--- Document Chunk 2774 ---
3.6.3.1.4.1 Exception: if not rejected due to balise group message consistency check (see 

--- Document Chunk 2775 ---
3.16.2.4.4.1 and 3.16.2.5.1.1), data to be forwarded to a National System (see section 

--- Document Chunk 2776 ---
3.15.6) shall be accepted. Justification: the co -ordinate system o f the balise group 

--- Document Chunk 2777 ---
might be known to the National System by other means inherent to the National 

--- Document Chunk 2778 ---
System itself. 

--- Document Chunk 2779 ---

--- Document Chunk 2814 ---
3.6.3.2.2 With regard to Figure 12 the following applies to continuous profile data: 

--- Document Chunk 2815 ---
a) Value (n) shall be valid for distance (n+1)  

--- Document Chunk 2816 ---
b) For distance (1) the previously received data shall be used (in case of an SSP this 

--- Document Chunk 2817 ---
includes train length delay, refer to 3.11.3.1.3). 

--- Document Chunk 2818 ---
c) Distances shall be given as unsigned incremental values representing the distance 

--- Document Chunk 2819 ---
between value(n) and value(n-1). 

--- Document Chunk 2820 ---
d) The last value (n) transmitted shall be valid for an unlimited distance unless value(n) 

--- Document Chunk 2821 ---
represents a special "end of profile" value. 

--- Document Chunk 2822 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2823 ---

--- Document Chunk 2829 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2830 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 2831 ---
Page 33/204 

--- Document Chunk 2832 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2833 ---
e) If distance (n+1) = 0 then the corresponding profile value n shall still be taken into 

--- Document Chunk 2834 ---
account. 

--- Document Chunk 2835 ---
3.6.3.2.3 With regard to Figure 12 the following shall apply to location data: 

--- Document Chunk 2836 ---
a) Distances shall be given as unsigned incremental values repr esenting the distance 

--- Document Chunk 2837 ---
between value(n) and value(n-1). 

--- Document Chunk 2838 ---
b) For distance (1) the previously received data shall be used. 

--- Document Chunk 2839 ---
c) Each value (n) may represent a single value or a set of data. 

--- Document Chunk 2840 ---
3.6.3.2.4 According to Figure 12 the structure  for non -continuous profile data shall allow to 

--- Document Chunk 2841 ---
contain multiple elements (value(n) for length(n)) inside the profile.  

--- Document Chunk 2842 ---
a) Distance to the start of each element (value(n) for length(n)) shall be given as 

--- Document Chunk 2843 ---
unsigned incremental values , each increment representin g the distance between  

--- Document Chunk 2844 ---
starts of element (n) and element (n-1). 

--- Document Chunk 2845 ---
b) For distance (1) the previously received data (or initial data/default values, see 

--- Document Chunk 2846 ---
section 3.7) shall be used. 

--- Document Chunk 2847 ---
c) Each value (n) may represent a single value or a set of data.  

--- Document Chunk 2848 ---
d) Note: There is no relationship between length of element (n-1) and distance (n), i.e., 

--- Document Chunk 2849 ---
elements may overlap. 

--- Document Chunk 2850 ---
3.6.3.2.5 It shall be possible for the RBC to shift the location reference, e.g., after a change of 

--- Document Chunk 2851 ---
train orientation or running direction. 

--- Document Chunk 2852 ---
3.6.3.2.5.1 Justification: Refer to Figure 13. To make it possible to shift the location reference if 

--- Document Chunk 2853 ---
– due to the location of the LRBG and the start location – distance (1) would become a 

--- Document Chunk 2854 ---
negative value. 

--- Document Chunk 2855 ---

3.6.3.2.6 With regards to Figure 12 the following applies to linking information  

--- Document Chunk 2880 ---
a) The distance (1) shall be given to the first balise group included in the linking 

--- Document Chunk 2881 ---
information 

--- Document Chunk 2882 ---
b) The distance (n) shall be given as the distance between two consecutive balise 

--- Document Chunk 2883 ---
groups  

--- Document Chunk 2884 ---
c) Each value (n) shall represent the linking information related to that balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 2885 ---
3.6.4 Train Position Confidence Interval and Relocation 

--- Document Chunk 2886 ---
3.6.4.1 All location related information transmitted from trackside equipment shall be used by 

--- Document Chunk 2887 ---
the on -board equipment taking into account the confidence interval to the train 

--- Document Chunk 2888 ---
position, if required for safe operation. 

--- Document Chunk 2889 ---
3.6.4.2 The confidence interval to the train position shall refer to the distance to the LRBG and 

--- Document Chunk 2890 ---
shall take into account 

--- Document Chunk 2891 ---
a) On-board over-reading amount and under-reading amount (odometer accuracy plus 

--- Document Chunk 2892 ---
the error in detection of the balise group location reference) 

--- Document Chunk 2893 ---
b) The location accuracy of the LRBG. 

--- Document Chunk 2894 ---
3.6.4.2.1 Distance information received from trackside shall be evaluated on -board as nominal 

--- Document Chunk 2895 ---
information (without taking into account any tolerances). 

--- Document Chunk 2896 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2897 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2898 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2899 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 2900 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 2901 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 2902 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 2903 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2904 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 2905 ---
Page 35/204 

--- Document Chunk 2906 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2907 ---
3.6.4.2.2 Note: The confidence interval increases in relation to the distan ce travelled from the 

--- Document Chunk 2908 ---
LRBG depending on the accuracy of odometer equipment until it is reset when another 

--- Document Chunk 2909 ---
balise group becomes the LRBG. 

--- Document Chunk 2910 ---
3.6.4.2.3 The value of the Location Accuracy shall be determined by Linking information if 

--- Document Chunk 2911 ---
available, if not, by the correspondin g National Value, or the corresponding Default 

--- Document Chunk 2912 ---
Value if the National Value is not applicable. 

--- Document Chunk 2913 ---
3.6.4.3 When another balise group becomes the LRBG or when evaluating (see section 4.8) 

--- Document Chunk 2914 ---
location related trackside information, which is referred to a previously received  balise 

--- Document Chunk 2915 ---
group different from the LRBG, all the location related information shall be relocated by 

--- Document Chunk 2916 ---
subtracting from the distances that are counted from the reference balise group of the 

--- Document Chunk 2917 ---
location related information: 

--- Document Chunk 2918 ---
a) the distance between the reference balise  group of the location related information 

--- Document Chunk 2919 ---
and the LRBG, retrieved from linking information if it is available and it includes both 

--- Document Chunk 2920 ---
the reference balise group and the LRBG, OR 

--- Document Chunk 2921 ---
b) in all other cases, the estimated travelled distance between the reference balis e 

--- Document Chunk 2922 ---
group of the location related information and the LRBG. 

--- Document Chunk 2923 ---
3.6.4.3.1 Justification: it is always the trackside responsibility to provide linking in due course, 

--- Document Chunk 2924 ---
knowing this rule; if the location related information is to be used in situations where 

--- Document Chunk 2925 ---
linking is not pro vided (e.g. TSR transmitted by balise group marked as unlinked), the 

--- Document Chunk 2926 ---
trackside can include provisions, if deemed necessary, when engineering the distance 

--- Document Chunk 2927 ---
information. 

--- Document Chunk 2928 ---

--- Document Chunk 3003 ---
3.6.4.4 The train front end position shall be identified in the following way 

--- Document Chunk 3004 ---
a) The estimated front end position. 

--- Document Chunk 3005 ---
b) The max(imum) safe front end position, differing from the estimated position by the 

--- Document Chunk 3006 ---
under-reading amount in the distance measured from the LRBG plus the location 

--- Document Chunk 3007 ---
accuracy of the LRBG. 

--- Document Chunk 3008 ---
 I.e. in relation to the orientation of the train this position is in advance of the 

--- Document Chunk 3009 ---
estimated position.  

--- Document Chunk 3010 ---
c) The min(imum) safe front end position, differing from the estimated position by the 

--- Document Chunk 3011 ---
over-reading amount in the distance measured from the LRBG plus the location 

--- Document Chunk 3012 ---
accuracy of the LRBG. 

--- Document Chunk 3013 ---
I.e. in relation to the orientation of the train this position is in rear of the estimated 

--- Document Chunk 3014 ---
position.  

--- Document Chunk 3015 ---
3.6.4.4.1 Note: The rear end position is referenced in the same way. However min safe rear end 

--- Document Chunk 3016 ---
is only safe if sent together with train integrity information. 

--- Document Chunk 3017 ---

--- Document Chunk 3080 ---

--- Document Chunk 3081 ---

--- Document Chunk 3082 ---

--- Document Chunk 3083 ---

--- Document Chunk 3086 ---

--- Document Chunk 3141 ---

--- Document Chunk 3142 ---

--- Document Chunk 3143 ---

--- Document Chunk 3144 ---
b) The mode changes. 

--- Document Chunk 3145 ---
c) The driver confirms train integrity. 

--- Document Chunk 3146 ---
d) A loss of train integrity is detected. 

--- Document Chunk 3147 ---
e) The train passes a RBC/RBC border with its min safe rear end. 

--- Document Chunk 3148 ---
f) The train passe s with its min safe r ear end a level transition border which led to a 

--- Document Chunk 3149 ---
transition from level 2/3 to level 0, NTC or 1. 

--- Document Chunk 3150 ---
g) The level changes.

--- Document Chunk 3170 ---
3.6.5.1.5 For the position report parameters requested by the RBC the following possibilities 

--- Document Chunk 3171 ---
shall be available, individually or in combination 

--- Document Chunk 3172 ---
a) Periodically in time. 

--- Document Chunk 3173 ---
b) Periodically in space. 

--- Document Chunk 3174 ---
c) When the max safe front end or min sa fe rear end of the train has passed a 

--- Document Chunk 3175 ---
specified location. 

--- Document Chunk 3176 ---
d) At every passage of an LRBG compliant balise group (see 3.6.2.2.2). 

--- Document Chunk 3177 ---
e) Immediately. 

--- Document Chunk 3178 ---

--- Document Chunk 3179 ---

--- Document Chunk 3181 ---
from the RBC.

--- Document Chunk 3183 ---

3.6.5.2 Report of Train Rear End Position for Level 3 

--- Document Chunk 3185 ---
3.6.5.2.1 Train integrity information shall be given by external device or by driver. 

--- Document Chunk 3186 ---
3.6.5.2.2 Driver input of train integrity shall only be permitted at standstill. 

--- Document Chunk 3187 ---
3.6.5.2.3 The train integrity information shall consist of 

--- Document Chunk 3188 ---
a) Train integrity status information 

--- Document Chunk 3189 ---
 No train integrity information 

--- Document Chunk 3190 ---
 Train integrity information confirmed by integrity monitoring device  

--- Document Chunk 3191 ---
 Train integrity information confirmed (entered) by driver 

--- Document Chunk 3192 ---
 Train integrity lost 

--- Document Chunk 3193 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 3200 ---

--- Document Chunk 3201 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 3202 ---
Page 42/204 

--- Document Chunk 3203 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3204 ---
b) Safe train length information (only valid if train integrity is confirmed at the same 

--- Document Chunk 3205 ---
time). 

--- Document Chunk 3206 ---
3.6.5.2.4 The safe train length information shall represent the distance between the min safe 

--- Document Chunk 3207 ---
rear end (by subtracting the train length from the min. safe front end position at the 

--- Document Chunk 3208 ---
time when integrity was established last time) and the estimated position of the train 

--- Document Chunk 3209 ---
front. 

--- Document Chunk 3210 ---
3.6.5.2.5 The safe train length information shall be re -calculated for e very position report using 

--- Document Chunk 3211 ---
the same last value of min safe rear end position until a new min safe rear end position 

--- Document Chunk 3212 ---
is established on-board taking into account the time to detect train integrity.

3.6.6 Geographical position reporting 

--- Document Chunk 3234 ---
3.6.6.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall  display, only on driver request, the 

--- Document Chunk 3235 ---
geographical position of the estimated front end of the train in relation  to the track 

--- Document Chunk 3236 ---
kilometre. The display of the geographical position shall also be stopped on driver 

--- Document Chunk 3237 ---
request. 

--- Document Chunk 3238 ---
3.6.6.2 The resolution of the position indication shall be 1 metre (sufficient to allow the driver 

--- Document Chunk 3239 ---
to report the train position when communicating with the signalman).   

--- Document Chunk 3240 ---
3.6.6.3 When receiving new geographical position information (from radio or from balise 

--- Document Chunk 3241 ---
group), the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall replace the currently stored 

--- Document Chunk 3242 ---

--- Document Chunk 3253 ---
geographical position information (if any) by this new received one, continuing the 

--- Document Chunk 3254 ---
ongoing geographical position calculation until at least one of the condition of 3.6.6.9 

--- Document Chunk 3255 ---
applies. 

--- Document Chunk 3256 ---
3.6.6.4 Geographical position information shall always use a balise group as geographical 

--- Document Chunk 3257 ---
position reference balise group and if needed an offset from that balise group . A 

--- Document Chunk 3258 ---
geographical position reference balise group shall be either: 

--- Document Chunk 3259 ---
a) part of the last reported balise groups memorised on -board, in case the information 

--- Document Chunk 3260 ---
is transmitted by radio, OR 

--- Document Chunk 3261 ---
b) the balise group transmitting the information, in case the information is transmitted 

--- Document Chunk 3262 ---
by balise group, OR 

--- Document Chunk 3263 ---
c) any balise group not yet passed at the time of reception of the information. 

--- Document Chunk 3264 ---
3.6.6.4.1 In case the information is received by radio and at least one of the announced 

--- Document Chunk 3265 ---
geographical position reference balise group(s) is part of the last repo rted balise 

--- Document Chunk 3266 ---
groups memorised on-board, the on-board equipment shall use the data related to the 

--- Document Chunk 3267 ---
most recently reported balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 3268 ---
3.6.6.4.2 From the currently stored geographical position information, t he track kilometre 

--- Document Chunk 3269 ---
reference given for a geographical referen ce location shall be come applicable if the 

--- Document Chunk 3270 ---
train has detected the related geographical reference balise group and has  travelled 

--- Document Chunk 3271 ---
the offset distance from this reference balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 3272 ---
3.6.6.4.3 The announced and not applicable geographical references shall be deleted on-board 

--- Document Chunk 3273 ---
if the train changes orientation. 

--- Document Chunk 3274 ---
3.6.6.5 The distance travelled from the geographical reference location shall be taken into 

--- Document Chunk 3275 ---
account when calculating the geographical position.  

--- Document Chunk 3276 ---
3.6.6.6 In cases where the track kilometre is not incremental (jumps, changes in cou nting 

--- Document Chunk 3277 ---
direction, scaling error) the reported position might be wrong between the point of 

--- Document Chunk 3278 ---
irregularity and the next new reference.   

--- Document Chunk 3279 ---
3.6.6.7 In cases where single balise groups are used as a reference for geographical position 

--- Document Chunk 3280 ---
information and where no linking info rmation is available (and therefore no orientation 

--- Document Chunk 3281 ---
can be assigned to the balise  group), the on -board equipment shall ignore the 

--- Document Chunk 3282 ---
geographical position information related to these single balise groups. 

--- Document Chunk 3283 ---
3.6.6.8 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 3284 ---
3.6.6.9 The on-board equipment shall co ntinue calculating the position from a track kilometre 

--- Document Chunk 3285 ---
reference (i.e. this track kilometre reference shall remain applicable) until: 

--- Document Chunk 3286 ---
a) a new track kilometre reference becomes applicable, OR 

--- Document Chunk 3287 ---
b) it is told not to do so, OR 

--- Document Chunk 3288 ---
c) the calculated geographical position becomes negative, OR 

--- Document Chunk 3289 ---

3.7 Completeness of data for safe train movement 

--- Document Chunk 3333 ---
3.7.1 Completeness of data  

--- Document Chunk 3334 ---
3.7.1.1 To control the train movement in an ERTMS/ETCS based system the ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 3335 ---
on-board equipment shall be given information from the trackside system both 

--- Document Chunk 3336 ---
concerning the route set for the train and the track description f or that route. The 

--- Document Chunk 3337 ---
following information shall be given from the trackside 

--- Document Chunk 3338 ---
a) Permission and distance to run, the Movement Authority (MA) (see section 3.8) 

--- Document Chunk 3339 ---
b) When needed, limitations related to the movement authority, i.e. Mode profile for On 

--- Document Chunk 3340 ---
Sight, Limited Supervision or Shunting and signalling related speed restriction (see 

--- Document Chunk 3341 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 3342 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3343 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3344 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 3345 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 3346 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 3347 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 3348 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 3349 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 3350 ---
Page 45/204 

--- Document Chunk 3351 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3352 ---
sections 3.12.4 and 3.11.6). Mode profile and Signalling related Speed restriction 

--- Document Chunk 3353 ---
shall always be sent together with the MA to which the information belongs 

--- Document Chunk 3354 ---
c) Track description covering as a minimum the whole distance defined by the MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3355 ---
Track description includes the following information 

--- Document Chunk 3356 ---
 The Static Speed Profile (SSP) (see section 3.11.3). 

--- Document Chunk 3357 ---
 The gradient profile (see section 3.11.12). 

--- Document Chunk 3358 ---
 Optionally Axle load Speed Profile (ASP) (see section 3.11.4) 

--- Document Chunk 3359 ---
 Optionally Speed restriction to ensure a given permitted braking distance (see 

--- Document Chunk 3360 ---
section 3.11.11) 

--- Document Chunk 3361 ---
 Optionally track conditions (see section 3.12.1). 

--- Document Chunk 3362 ---
 Optionally route suitability data (see section 3.12.2). 

--- Document Chunk 3363 ---
 Optionally areas where reversing is permitted (see section 3.15.4). 

--- Document Chunk 3364 ---
 Optionally changed adhesion factor (see section 3.18.4.5.5). 

--- Document Chunk 3365 ---
d) Linking information when available. 

--- Document Chunk 3366 ---
3.7.2 Responsibility for completeness of information 

--- Document Chunk 3367 ---
3.7.2.1 The Movement Authority (MA) shall be given to the on-board equipment  

--- Document Chunk 3368 ---
 Together with the other information ( as listed in section 3.7.1.1 c) and d)) 

--- Document Chunk 3369 ---
or 

--- Document Chunk 3370 ---
 Separately, if the other information has already been correctly received by the on-

--- Document Chunk 3371 ---
board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 3372 ---
3.7.2.2 The trackside shall be responsible fo r that the on -board equipment has received the 

--- Document Chunk 3373 ---
information valid for the distance covered by the Movement Authority. 

--- Document Chunk 3374 ---
3.7.2.2.1 In case of LOA, trackside shall be responsible for including any track description 

--- Document Chunk 3375 ---
beyond the LOA relevant for calculating safe supervision limits. 

--- Document Chunk 3376 ---
3.7.2.3 The MA and the related mode profile, if any, shall not be accepted by the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 3377 ---
equipment if the SSP and gradient already available on -board or given together with 

--- Document Chunk 3378 ---
the MA do not cover the full length of the MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3379 ---
3.7.2.3.1 Full length means at least from t he estimated front end of the train to the supervised 

--- Document Chunk 3380 ---
location. 

--- Document Chunk 3381 ---
3.7.2.4 It shall be possible for the trackside to send additional information when needed. The 

--- Document Chunk 3382 ---
information referred to is 

--- Document Chunk 3383 ---
 Emergency messages (from RBC only) 

--- Document Chunk 3384 ---
 Request to stop earlier (from RBC only) 

--- Document Chunk 3385 ---
 Temporary speed restrictions 

--- Document Chunk 3386 ---
 National values 

--- Document Chunk 3387 ---

3.7.3 Extension, replacement of track description and linking information 

--- Document Chunk 3403 ---
3.7.3.1 New track description and linking information shall replace (in the ERTMS/ETCS on-

--- Document Chunk 3404 ---
board equipment) stored information as detailed below: 

--- Document Chunk 3405 ---
a) New Static Speed Profile information shall replace all stored Static Speed Profile 

--- Document Chunk 3406 ---
information from the start location of the new information. 

--- Document Chunk 3407 ---
b) New Gradient Profile information shall replace all stored Gradient Profile information 

--- Document Chunk 3408 ---
from the start location of the new information. 

--- Document Chunk 3409 ---
c) New Axle Load Speed Profile information shall replace all stored Axle Load Speed 

--- Document Chunk 3410 ---
Profile information from the start location of the first element of the new information. 

--- Document Chunk 3411 ---
d) New Speed Restriction to ensure Permitted Braking Distance information shall 

--- Document Chunk 3412 ---
replace all stored Speed Restriction to ensure Permitted Braking Distance 

--- Document Chunk 3413 ---
information from the start location of the first element of the new information. 

--- Document Chunk 3414 ---
e) New track condition Change of Traction System information shall replace all stored 

--- Document Chunk 3415 ---
Change of Traction System information. 

--- Document Chunk 3416 ---
f) New track condition Big Metal Masses information shall replace all stored Big Metal 

--- Document Chunk 3417 ---
Masses information from the start location of the first element of the new 

--- Document Chunk 3418 ---
information. 

--- Document Chunk 3419 ---
g) New track condition information of at least one of the types listed here, i.e., sound 

--- Document Chunk 3420 ---
horn, non stopping area, tunnel stopping area,  powerless section - lower 

--- Document Chunk 3421 ---
pantograph, powerless section - switch off the main power switch, radio hole, air 

--- Document Chunk 3422 ---
tightness, switch off regenerative brake, switch off eddy current brake for service 

--- Document Chunk 3423 ---
brake, switch off eddy current brake for emergency brake, switch off magnetic shoe 

--- Document Chunk 3424 ---
brake, shall replace all stored track condition information of the listed types from the 

--- Document Chunk 3425 ---
start location of the first element of the new information. 

--- Document Chunk 3426 ---
h) New route suitability loading gauge information shall replace all stored route 

--- Document Chunk 3427 ---
suitability loading gauge information. 

--- Document Chunk 3428 ---
i) New rou te suitability traction system information shall replace all stored route 

--- Document Chunk 3429 ---
suitability traction system information. 

--- Document Chunk 3430 ---
j) New route suitability axle load information shall replace all stored route suitability 

--- Document Chunk 3431 ---
axle load information. 

--- Document Chunk 3432 ---
k) New reversing area information shall replace all stored reversing area information. 

--- Document Chunk 3433 ---
l) New adhesion factor information shall replace all stored adhesion factor information 

--- Document Chunk 3434 ---
from the start location of the new information.

--- Document Chunk 3491 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3492 ---
3.8 Movement authority 

--- Document Chunk 3493 ---
3.8.1 Characteristics of a MA  

--- Document Chunk 3494 ---
3.8.1.1 The following characteristics can be used in a Movement Authority (see Figure 17: 

--- Document Chunk 3495 ---
Structure of an MA): 

--- Document Chunk 3496 ---
a) The End of Movement Authority is the location to which the train is authorised to 

--- Document Chunk 3497 ---
move. 

--- Document Chunk 3498 ---
b) When t he Target Speed at the End of Movement Authority is zero, the End of 

--- Document Chunk 3499 ---
Movement Authority is called EOA (End of Authority) ; when the target speed is not 

--- Document Chunk 3500 ---
zero, it is called the LOA (Limit of Authority). This non zero target speed can be time 

--- Document Chunk 3501 ---
limited. 

--- Document Chunk 3502 ---
c) If no overlap exists, the Danger Point is a location beyond the End of Movement 

--- Document Chunk 3503 ---
Authority that can be reached by the front end of the train without a risk for a 

--- Document Chunk 3504 ---
hazardous situation.  

--- Document Chunk 3505 ---
d) The e nd of an overlap (if used in the existing interlocking system) is a location 

--- Document Chunk 3506 ---
beyond the Danger Point that can be reached by the front end of the train without a 

--- Document Chunk 3507 ---
risk for a hazardous situation. This additional distance is only valid for a defined 

--- Document Chunk 3508 ---
time. 

--- Document Chunk 3509 ---
e) A release speed is a speed limit under which the train is allowed to run in the vicinity 

--- Document Chunk 3510 ---
of the End of Movement Authority, when the target speed is zero. One release 

--- Document Chunk 3511 ---
speed can be associated with the Danger Point, and another one with the overlap. 

--- Document Chunk 3512 ---
Release speed can also be calculated on-board the train (see section 3.13.9.4). 

--- Document Chunk 3513 ---
f) The MA can be split into several sections, The last one is called End Section. 

--- Document Chunk 3514 ---
 A first time-out value can be attached to each section. This value will be used f or 

--- Document Chunk 3515 ---
the revocation of the associated route when the train has not entered into it yet. It is 

--- Document Chunk 3516 ---
called the Section time-out.  

--- Document Chunk 3517 ---
 In addition, a second time -out value can be attached to the End Section of the 

--- Document Chunk 3518 ---
MA. This second time-out will be used for the revocatio n of the last section when it 

--- Document Chunk 3519 ---
is occupied by the train; it is called the End Section time-out. 

--- Document Chunk 3520 ---
3.8.1.2 The values of the time -outs possibly given in an MA shall take into account the time 

--- Document Chunk 3521 ---
elapsed from the start of validity of information to the sending of the message. 

--- Document Chunk 3522 ---
3.8.1.3 Note: A Danger Point can be (not exhaustive list): 

--- Document Chunk 3523 ---
 the entry point of an occupied block section (if the line is operated according to 

--- Document Chunk 3524 ---
fixed block principles) 

--- Document Chunk 3525 ---
 the position of the safe rear end of a train (if the line is operated according to 

--- Document Chunk 3526 ---
moving block principles) 

--- Document Chunk 3527 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 3528 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3529 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3530 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 3531 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 3532 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 3533 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 3534 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 3535 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 3536 ---
Page 49/204 

--- Document Chunk 3537 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3538 ---
 the fouling point of a switch, positioned for a route, conflicting with the current 

--- Document Chunk 3539 ---
direction of movement of the train (both for fixed and moving block mode of 

--- Document Chunk 3540 ---
operation) 

--- Document Chunk 3541 ---
3.8.1.4 Note: Traditionally the overlap is a piece of track (beyond the danger  point), that is put 

--- Document Chunk 3542 ---
at disposal of a train, to guarantee a non hazardous situation, also in case the driver 

--- Document Chunk 3543 ---
should misjudge the stopping distance for the train. In ERTMS/ETCS the overlap can 

--- Document Chunk 3544 ---
be used to improve the efficiency of the braking supervision. 

--- Document Chunk 3545 ---
3.8.1.5 Note: Time -out values can be given in the MA to cope with the following situations 

--- Document Chunk 3546 ---
depending on the interlocking operations, i.e. the timers on -board will only reflect the 

--- Document Chunk 3547 ---
situation trackside and when expired (on-board) the actions taken are restrictive: 

--- Document Chunk 3548 ---
a) Section time-out or time-out for the speed at the LOA: When a signalman requests 

--- Document Chunk 3549 ---
a route release of a part of a route not yet entered by the approaching train. 

--- Document Chunk 3550 ---
b) End Section time -out: When the train has entered the last part of a route, the 

--- Document Chunk 3551 ---
automatic route rele ase can be delayed to make sure that the train has come to a 

--- Document Chunk 3552 ---
standstill before any switches inside the route can be moved. 

--- Document Chunk 3553 ---
c) Time-out for an overlap: When the train has entered the last part of a route, the 

--- Document Chunk 3554 ---
overlap associated with the route remains valid for  a certain time to make sure that 

--- Document Chunk 3555 ---
the train has successfully stopped before its End of Movement A uthority. If the 

--- Document Chunk 3556 ---
overlap is still unoccupied when the timer expires the interlocking revokes the 

--- Document Chunk 3557 ---
overlap. 

--- Document Chunk 3558 ---
3.8.1.6 Note: If the trackside equipment does not have enough information to give the distance 

--- Document Chunk 3559 ---
to the End of Movement Authority with a target speed equal to zero , a target speed 

--- Document Chunk 3560 ---
higher than zero can be given (LOA, Limit of Authority). It is the responsibility of the 

--- Document Chunk 3561 ---
trackside to ensure that the safe distance beyond the LOA is long enough to brake the 

--- Document Chunk 3562 ---
train from the target speed to a stand still without any hazardous situation. It is the 

--- Document Chunk 3563 ---
responsibility of the on -board equipment to apply the brakes if no new information is 

--- Document Chunk 3564 ---
received when the Limit of Authority is passed.  

--- Document Chunk 3565 ---
3.8.2 MA request to the RBC 

--- Document Chunk 3566 ---
3.8.2.1 It shall be possible for the on -board equipment to request a new M ovement Authority 

--- Document Chunk 3567 ---
from the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 3568 ---
3.8.2.2 The parameters for requesting a new MA shall be given by the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 3569 ---
3.8.2.3 In level 2/3, the following possibilities shall be available: 

--- Document Chunk 3570 ---
a) A def ined time before the train reaches the perturbation location assuming it is 

--- Document Chunk 3571 ---
running at the warning speed (see section 3.13.11 for details). 

--- Document Chunk 3572 ---
b) A defined time before the Section timer (not the End Section timer, not the Overlap 

--- Document Chunk 3573 ---
timer) for any section of the MA expires, or before the LOA speed timer expires. 

--- Document Chunk 3574 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 3575 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3576 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3577 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 3578 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 3579 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 3580 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 3581 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 3582 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 3583 ---
Page 50/204 

--- Document Chunk 3584 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3585 ---
3.8.2.3.1 Regards to the above possibilities, the MA request shall be triggered when the train 

--- Document Chunk 3586 ---
front has passed the resulting location (regards a)/ time (regards b) 

--- Document Chunk 3587 ---
3.8.2.4 The parameters given by the RBC also define whether the MA request shall be 

--- Document Chunk 3588 ---
repeated until a new MA is received or not and if so, the time between each repetition. 

--- Document Chunk 3589 ---
3.8.2.5 The given data shall be valid until new MA request parameters are given from the 

--- Document Chunk 3590 ---
RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 3591 ---
3.8.2.6 In case no MA request parameters are stored on-board and following an MA request 

--- Document Chunk 3592 ---
no MA has been received, the request shall be repeated with a repetition cycle 

--- Document Chunk 3593 ---
according to a fixed value (see appendix). 

--- Document Chunk 3594 ---
3.8.2.7 In level 2/3: an MA request shall be sent to the RBC when the driver selects start. 

--- Document Chunk 3595 ---
3.8.2.7.1 In level 0, 1, NTC: if a le vel 2/3 transition is announced and a communication session 

--- Document Chunk 3596 ---
is already established, an MA request shall be sent to the RBC when the information 

--- Document Chunk 3597 ---
"Track ahead free up to level 2/3 transition location" is received from balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 3598 ---
3.8.2.7.2 In level 0 , 1, NTC: the ER TMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall also inform the RBC 

--- Document Chunk 3599 ---
about the identity of the level 2/3 transition location balise group, as received through 

--- Document Chunk 3600 ---
the information "Track ahead free up to level 2/3 transition location". 

--- Document Chunk 3601 ---
3.8.2.7.3 In level 2/3: An MA request shall be sen t to the RBC when any part of the track 

--- Document Chunk 3602 ---
description is deleted according to A.3.4, except for situations a, b, f, k. 

--- Document Chunk 3603 ---
3.8.2.8 Together with the MA request the on -board shall inform the RBC about the reason(s) 

--- Document Chunk 3604 ---
why the MA request is sent: 

--- Document Chunk 3605 ---
a) Start selection by driver, 

--- Document Chunk 3606 ---
b) Time before reaching perturbation location reached, 

--- Document Chunk 3607 ---
c) Time before a section timer or the LOA speed timer expires reached, 

--- Document Chunk 3608 ---
d) The track description has been deleted, 

--- Document Chunk 3609 ---
e) Track ahead free up to level 2/3 transition location. 

--- Document Chunk 3610 ---
3.8.3 Structure of a Movement Authority (MA) 

--- Document Chunk 3611 ---
3.8.3.1 The distance to the End of Movement Authority can be composed of several sections. 

--- Document Chunk 3612 ---
3.8.3.2 For each section composing the MA the following information shall be given; 

--- Document Chunk 3613 ---
a) Length of the section 

--- Document Chunk 3614 ---
b) Optionally, Section time-out value and distance from beginning of section to Se ction 

--- Document Chunk 3615 ---
timer stop location 

--- Document Chunk 3616 ---
3.8.3.3 In addition, it shall be possible to define for the End Section of the MA: 

--- Document Chunk 3617 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 3618 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3619 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3620 ---

--- Document Chunk 3624 ---

--- Document Chunk 3625 ---

--- Document Chunk 3626 ---

--- Document Chunk 3627 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3628 ---
a) End Section time-out value and distance from the End Section timer start location to 

--- Document Chunk 3629 ---
the end of the last section 

--- Document Chunk 3630 ---
b) Danger point information (distance from en d of section to danger point, release 

--- Document Chunk 3631 ---
speed related to danger point) 

--- Document Chunk 3632 ---
c) Overlap information (distance from end of section to end of overlap, time -out, 

--- Document Chunk 3633 ---
distance from Overlap timer start location to end of section, release speed related to 

--- Document Chunk 3634 ---
overlap)

--- Document Chunk 3647 ---
3.8.3.3.1 Note: If only one section is given in the MA it is regarded as the End Section. 

--- Document Chunk 3648 ---
3.8.3.4 The Section timer stop location shall be inside of the corresponding section. 

--- Document Chunk 3649 ---
3.8.3.4.1 Note: the End Section and Ove rlap timer start locations may be outside their 

--- Document Chunk 3650 ---
corresponding section. One example can be seen referring to figure 22c: An infill MA 

--- Document Chunk 3651 ---
towards a signal at stop will replace the previous End Section by a new short End 

--- Document Chunk 3652 ---
Section starting at the infill location r eference and ending at the next main signal, 

--- Document Chunk 3653 ---
however the End Section and Overlap timer start locations still have to be consistent 

--- Document Chunk 3654 ---
with the Interlocking timer start locations. Another example is when a timer start 

--- Document Chunk 3655 ---
location is in rear of the LRBG. 

--- Document Chunk 3656 ---
3.8.3.5 In level 3, no time-outs shall be used. 

--- Document Chunk 3657 ---
3.8.3.5.1 Note: For level 3 functionality the split of responsibility between the RBC and the 

--- Document Chunk 3658 ---
Interlocking has to be considered. Time -out of routes and related overlap can not be 

--- Document Chunk 3659 ---
based on train position reports since the position repor t can be delayed compared to 

--- Document Chunk 3660 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 3661 ---

--- Document Chunk 3667 ---

--- Document Chunk 3669 ---
Page 52/204 

--- Document Chunk 3670 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3671 ---
the real position of the train. The route release and revocation of routes can not be 

--- Document Chunk 3672 ---
carried out by the interlocking until permitted by the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 3673 ---
3.8.3.6 When an MA is transmitted by a balise group, the length of the first section shal l refer 

--- Document Chunk 3674 ---
to the balise co-ordinate system of that balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 3675 ---
3.8.3.7 In case a main signal is at danger in level 1, the first section shall give the distance 

--- Document Chunk 3676 ---
from the balise group at the main signal to the location of the main signal, i.e. the 

--- Document Chunk 3677 ---
distance to EOA is  given. Where available, information concerning danger point and 

--- Document Chunk 3678 ---
overlap for this EOA may also be given.  

--- Document Chunk 3679 ---
3.8.3.7.1 Justification: The balise group is not necessarily placed at the same location as the 

--- Document Chunk 3680 ---
signal and thus an infill message (which includes the same infor mation as the balise 

--- Document Chunk 3681 ---
group at the main signal) could change the location of the EOA to a position closer to 

--- Document Chunk 3682 ---
the train.  

--- Document Chunk 3683 ---
3.8.3.8 Note: In case the main signal is at danger in level 1, the on -board will supervise the 

--- Document Chunk 3684 ---
given distance (specified in section 3.8.3.7) as the distance to EOA. 

--- Document Chunk 3685 ---
3.8.3.9 When an MA is transmitted by radio from the RBC, the length of the first section shall 

--- Document Chunk 3686 ---
refer to the balise co-ordinate system of the LRBG given in the same message. 

--- Document Chunk 3687 ---
3.8.3.10 It shall be possible to give the length of a section to any location in the track. 

--- Document Chunk 3688 ---
3.8.3.10.1 Note: A section can cover several blocks and is not restricted to block ends (see 

--- Document Chunk 3689 ---
figures).

--- Document Chunk 3721 ---
3.8.4 Use of the MA on board the train 

--- Document Chunk 3722 ---
3.8.4.1 End Section Time-Out 

--- Document Chunk 3723 ---
3.8.4.1.1 The End Section timer shall be started on -board when the train passes the End 

--- Document Chunk 3724 ---
Section timer start location given by trackside with its max safe front end. 

--- Document Chunk 3725 ---
3.8.4.1.2 When the End Section timer value becomes greater than the time -out value given by 

--- Document Chunk 3726 ---
trackside, the following shall apply: 

--- Document Chunk 3727 ---
a) The EOA/LOA shall be withdrawn to the current position of the train . Refer to 

--- Document Chunk 3728 ---
appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of location based information stored on -board, 

--- Document Chunk 3729 ---
which shall be deleted accordingly; 

--- Document Chunk 3730 ---
b) if any, a non zero target speed value at the End of Movement Authority shall be set 

--- Document Chunk 3731 ---
to zero (i.e. an LOA at the End of Movement Authority becomes an EOA w ithdrawn 

--- Document Chunk 3732 ---
to the current position of the train). 

--- Document Chunk 3733 ---
3.8.4.1.3 In case no End Section timer is running when the on -board receives a new MA with an 

--- Document Chunk 3734 ---
End Section timer start location in rear of the max safe front end of the train, the on -

--- Document Chunk 3735 ---
board shall consider that the End Se ction timer value became greater than its time -out 

--- Document Chunk 3736 ---
value and apply 3.8.4.1.2. 

--- Document Chunk 3737 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 3738 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3739 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3740 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 3741 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 3742 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 3743 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 3744 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 3745 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 3746 ---
Page 54/204 

--- Document Chunk 3747 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3748 ---
3.8.4.1.3.1 Justification: in this case the train is already beyond the timer start location, 

--- Document Chunk 3749 ---
therefore it is impossible to determine when that location was crossed and so what 

--- Document Chunk 3750 ---
share of the time-out value has elapsed since the crossing event. The safe assumption 

--- Document Chunk 3751 ---
is to consider that the time -out value has been exceeded and therefore that the End 

--- Document Chunk 3752 ---
Section will soon be released by the Interlocking. 

--- Document Chunk 3753 ---
3.8.4.1.4 In case an End Section timer is already running when the on-board receives a new MA 

--- Document Chunk 3754 ---
with an End Section timer start location in rear of the max safe front end of the train, 

--- Document Chunk 3755 ---
the on-board shall keep the End Section timer running but replace the time -out value 

--- Document Chunk 3756 ---
with the value received with the new MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3757 ---
3.8.4.1.4.1 Justification: this allows repetition of the MA via RBC (e.g. acknowledgment of 

--- Document Chunk 3758 ---
current MA was lost) without unintentionally affecting the End Section timer. 

--- Document Chunk 3759 ---
3.8.4.2 Section Time-Outs 

--- Document Chunk 3760 ---
3.8.4.2.1 The on-board shall start a Section timer for each section: 

--- Document Chunk 3761 ---
a) For Level 2: at the value of the time stamp of the message including the MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3762 ---
b) For Level 1: at the time of passage over the first encountered balise of the balise 

--- Document Chunk 3763 ---
group giving the MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3764 ---
3.8.4.2.1.1 Justification for b): This is to ensure that the timer is always started before or at the 

--- Document Chunk 3765 ---
same time as the related variable information is received. Thus the timer start is 

--- Document Chunk 3766 ---
independent of in which balise the variable information is given.  

--- Document Chunk 3767 ---
3.8.4.2.2 When a Section timer value becomes greater than the time -out value given by 

--- Document Chunk 3768 ---
trackside, the following shall apply: 

--- Document Chunk 3769 ---
a) the EOA/LOA and the SvL shall be withdrawn to the entry point of the revoked 

--- Document Chunk 3770 ---
section. Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of location based information 

--- Document Chunk 3771 ---
stored on-board, which shall be deleted accordingly; 

--- Document Chunk 3772 ---
b) the National/ Default Value of the Release Speed shall apply ; 

--- Document Chunk 3773 ---
c) if any, a non zero target speed value at the End of Movement Authority shall be set 

--- Document Chunk 3774 ---
to zero (i.e. an LOA at the End of Movement Authority becomes an EOA withdrawn 

--- Document Chunk 3775 ---
to the entry point of the revoked section). 

--- Document Chunk 3776 ---
3.8.4.2.2.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 3777 ---
3.8.4.2.3 The Section timer shall be stopped when the min safe front end of the train has passed 

--- Document Chunk 3778 ---
the associated Section timer stop location. 

--- Document Chunk 3779 ---
3.8.4.3 Time-out of the speed associated with the End of Movement Authority  (LOA 

--- Document Chunk 3780 ---
speed time out) 

--- Document Chunk 3781 ---
3.8.4.3.1 The on-board shall start a timer for the LOA speed: 

--- Document Chunk 3782 ---
a) For Level 2: at the value of the time stamp of the message including the MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3783 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 3784 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3785 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3786 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 3787 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 3788 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 3789 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 3790 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 3791 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 3792 ---
Page 55/204 

--- Document Chunk 3793 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3794 ---
b) For Level 1: at the time of passage over the first encountered balise of the balise 

--- Document Chunk 3795 ---
group giving the MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3796 ---
3.8.4.3.1.1 Justification for b): This is to ensure that the timer is alwa ys started before or at the 

--- Document Chunk 3797 ---
same time as the related variable information is received. Thus the timer start is 

--- Document Chunk 3798 ---
independent of in which balise the variable information is given. 

--- Document Chunk 3799 ---
3.8.4.3.2 When the LOA speed timer value becomes greater than the time-out value given by  

--- Document Chunk 3800 ---
trackside, the speed associated with the LOA shall be set to zero (i.e. the Limit of 

--- Document Chunk 3801 ---
Authority becomes an End of Authority  and the SvL  is defined on-board according to 

--- Document Chunk 3802 ---
3.8.4.5). Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of location based information  

--- Document Chunk 3803 ---
stored on-board, which shall be deleted accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 3804 ---
3.8.4.4 Time-out of Overlap 

--- Document Chunk 3805 ---
3.8.4.4.1 The Overlap timer shall be started on -board when the train passes the Overlap timer 

--- Document Chunk 3806 ---
start location given by trackside with its max safe front end.  The timer shall be 

--- Document Chunk 3807 ---
considered as started even if a time-out value “infinite” is given. 

--- Document Chunk 3808 ---
3.8.4.4.2 When the Overlap timer value becomes greater than the time -out value given by 

--- Document Chunk 3809 ---
trackside, the following shall apply: 

--- Document Chunk 3810 ---
a) the overlap information shall be deleted and the Supervised Location shall be  

--- Document Chunk 3811 ---
determined in accordance with 3.8.4. 5. Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive 

--- Document Chunk 3812 ---
list of location based information stored on -board, which shall be deleted 

--- Document Chunk 3813 ---
accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 3814 ---
b) the release speed associated with the Overlap shall be deleted 

--- Document Chunk 3815 ---
c) if any, a non zero target speed v alue at the End of Movement Authority shall be set 

--- Document Chunk 3816 ---
to zero (i.e. an LOA at the End of Movement Authority becomes an EOA). 

--- Document Chunk 3817 ---
3.8.4.4.3 If the train comes to a standstill after the Overlap timer has been started, the on-board 

--- Document Chunk 3818 ---
shall consider that the Overlap timer value became greater than its time -out value and 

--- Document Chunk 3819 ---
shall apply 3.8.4.4.2. 

--- Document Chunk 3820 ---
3.8.4.4.4 In case no Overlap timer is running when the on -board receives a new MA with an 

--- Document Chunk 3821 ---
Overlap timer start location in rear of the max safe front end of the train, the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 3822 ---
shall consider that the Overlap timer value became greater than its time-out value and 

--- Document Chunk 3823 ---
shall apply 3.8.4.4.2. 

--- Document Chunk 3824 ---
3.8.4.4.4.1 Justification: in this case the train is already beyond the timer start location, 

--- Document Chunk 3825 ---
therefore it is impossible to determine when that location was crossed and so what 

--- Document Chunk 3826 ---
share of the time-out value has elapsed since the crossing event. The safe assumption 

--- Document Chunk 3827 ---
is to consider that the time -out value has been exceeded a nd therefore that the 

--- Document Chunk 3828 ---
Overlap will soon be released by the Interlocking. 

--- Document Chunk 3829 ---
3.8.4.4.5 In case an Overlap timer is already running when the on-board receives a new MA with 

--- Document Chunk 3830 ---
an Overlap timer start location in rear of the max safe front end of the train, the on -

--- Document Chunk 3831 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 3841 ---

board shall keep the Overlap timer running but replace the Overlap time-out value with 

--- Document Chunk 3843 ---
the value received with the new MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3844 ---
3.8.4.4.5.1 Justification: this allows repetition of the MA via RBC (e.g. acknowledgment of

--- Document Chunk 3846 ---
3.8.4.5 Supervised Location 

--- Document Chunk 3847 ---
3.8.4.5.1 The Supervised Location (SvL) shall be defined on-board as: 

--- Document Chunk 3848 ---
a) the end of overlap (if any and before time-out). 

--- Document Chunk 3849 ---
b) if not, the Danger Point (if any). 

--- Document Chunk 3850 ---
c) if not, the End Of Authority. 

--- Document Chunk 3851 ---
3.8.4.5.2 As long as a Limit of Authority is supervised, no SvL shall be defined on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 3852 ---
3.8.4.6 Infill MA (level 1 only) 

--- Document Chunk 3853 ---
3.8.4.6.1 An MA given by an infill device is called an infill MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3854 ---
3.8.4.6.2 An infill MA shall be evaluated on -board only if the on -board equipment is in FS or LS 

--- Document Chunk 3855 ---
mode. 

--- Document Chunk 3856 ---
3.8.4.6.3 The infill information shall include the identity of the balise group at the next main 

--- Document Chunk 3857 ---
signal i.e. the identity of the balise group giving the information that is tra nsmitted in 

--- Document Chunk 3858 ---
advance by the infill device. 

--- Document Chunk 3859 ---
3.8.4.6.4 An infill MA shall be evaluated on -board only if the linking information, regarding the 

--- Document Chunk 3860 ---
main signal balise group to which it refers, is available. 

--- Document Chunk 3861 ---
3.8.4.6.5 The on-board shall start a Section timer for each section beyond the next main signal: 

--- Document Chunk 3862 ---
a) When the infill information is received from a balise group at the time of passing the 

--- Document Chunk 3863 ---
first encountered balise of the infill balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 3864 ---
b) When the infill information is received from a loop at the time of receiving the loop 

--- Document Chunk 3865 ---
message. 

--- Document Chunk 3866 ---
c) When the infill information is received from a radio infill unit at the value of the time 

--- Document Chunk 3867 ---
stamp of the radio infill message including the MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3868 ---
3.8.5 MA Update 

--- Document Chunk 3869 ---
3.8.5.1 A new MA shall replace a previously received MA in the following ways: 

--- Document Chunk 3870 ---
a) When the new MA is given from a balise group at a main signal (i.e. not infill 

--- Document Chunk 3871 ---
information) or from the RBC all data included in the previous MA shall be replaced 

--- Document Chunk 3872 ---
by the new data.  

--- Document Chunk 3873 ---
b) When the new MA is given as infill information all data beyond the announced balise 

--- Document Chunk 3874 ---
group at the next main signal shall be replaced. 

--- Document Chunk 3875 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 3876 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3877 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3878 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 3879 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 3880 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 3881 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 3882 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 3883 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 3884 ---
Page 57/204 

--- Document Chunk 3885 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3886 ---
3.8.5.1.1 Note: This refers to all information included in the MA as listed in section 3.8.1.1 and 

--- Document Chunk 3887 ---
the Signalling related speed restriction (see section 3.11.6). 

--- Document Chunk 3888 ---
3.8.5.1.2 When an infill MA is r eceived, the on -board shall start a new MA section at the infill 

--- Document Chunk 3889 ---
location reference, i.e. the balise group at the next main signal (see 3.6.2.3.1). 

--- Document Chunk 3890 ---
3.8.5.1.3 If the SvL defined from the new MA is closer than the one supervised with the former 

--- Document Chunk 3891 ---
MA, this shall be considered by the on-board equipment as an MA shortening. Refer to 

--- Document Chunk 3892 ---
appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of location based information stored on -board, 

--- Document Chunk 3893 ---
which shall be deleted accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 3894 ---
3.8.5.1.4 If a new MA defines an SvL while the on -board was supervising an LOA, th is shall 

--- Document Chunk 3895 ---
always be considered by the on -board equipment as an MA shortening regardless of 

--- Document Chunk 3896 ---
the SvL location. Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of location based 

--- Document Chunk 3897 ---
information stored on-board, which shall be deleted accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 3898 ---
3.8.5.2 It shall be possi ble to update the length of an MA section by means of repositioning 

--- Document Chunk 3899 ---
information contained in a balise group message (see section 3.8.5.3). 

--- Document Chunk 3900 ---
3.8.5.2.1 Note: The concerned MA section need not be the end section. 

--- Document Chunk 3901 ---
3.8.5.2.2 Upon reception of repositioning information and only  if linking information has 

--- Document Chunk 3902 ---
announced a following balise group as unknown but containing repositioning 

--- Document Chunk 3903 ---
information, the on-board shall update the length of the current MA section in which the 

--- Document Chunk 3904 ---
train front end is. 

--- Document Chunk 3905 ---
3.8.5.2.3 A balise group messa ge containing a movement authority shall not contain 

--- Document Chunk 3906 ---
repositioning information for the same direction. 

--- Document Chunk 3907 ---
3.8.5.2.3.1 Note: It is possible to combine repositioning with an infill MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3908 ---
3.8.5.2.4 The reception of repositioning information or of a new MA with an LOA shall not be 

--- Document Chunk 3909 ---
considered as an MA shortening by the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 3910 ---

3.8.5.3.5 Example: Extension of MA in level 1 using a balise group c ontaining repositioning 

--- Document Chunk 4082 ---
information. 

--- Document Chunk 4083 ---
3.8.5.3.5.1 Note: In some existing systems, information about the locked route is not complete. 

--- Document Chunk 4084 ---
3.8.5.3.5.2 History of the situation (refer to the figure below): 

--- Document Chunk 4085 ---
a) Signal A gives an aspect to proceed up to signal Cx because it has received 

--- Document Chunk 4086 ---
information about the locked route. 

--- Document Chunk 4087 ---
b) Signal A can determine whether track 3 or track 1 / 2 is locked but is unable to 

--- Document Chunk 4088 ---
distinguish between track 1 and 2. 

--- Document Chunk 4089 ---
c) In the situation described the route is set to track 1 or 2. 

--- Document Chunk 4090 ---

3.8.5.3.5.3 In balise group A the following information is given: 

--- Document Chunk 4114 ---
a) The most restrictive track description from all routes (which could be a combination 

--- Document Chunk 4115 ---
from the routes); 

--- Document Chunk 4116 ---
b) The linking distance given to the farthest balise group containing repositioning 

--- Document Chunk 4117 ---
information, the identification of the repositioning balise group is not known; 

--- Document Chunk 4118 ---
c) For a given aspect of signal A, the most restrictive MA from all routes (the shortest 

--- Document Chunk 4119 ---
sections from the routes and the lowest tar get speed at the End of Movement 

--- Document Chunk 4120 ---
Authority); 

--- Document Chunk 4121 ---
d) If some sections are time limited, the most restrictive timer. 

--- Document Chunk 4122 ---
3.8.5.3.5.4 Balise groups B (B1 or B2) give the following static information: 

--- Document Chunk 4123 ---
a) This is repositioning information  

--- Document Chunk 4124 ---
b) Linking to the next balise group C  

--- Document Chunk 4125 ---
c) The distance to the end of the current section (i.e. the distance to the end of section 

--- Document Chunk 4126 ---
B1 - C1, or the distance to the end of section B2 - C2) 

--- Document Chunk 4127 ---
d) The track description related to this track. 

--- Document Chunk 4128 ---
