--- Document Chunk 4170 ---
3.8.6 Co-operative shortening of MA (Level 2 and 3 only) 

--- Document Chunk 4171 ---
3.8.6.1 It shall be possible to shorten a given MA using a special procedure between on -board 

--- Document Chunk 4172 ---
equipment and RBC. The procedure is as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 4173 ---
a) The RBC proposes a new MA with an EOA closer to the train than the current 

--- Document Chunk 4174 ---
EOA/LOA, optionally with a mode profile. 

--- Document Chunk 4175 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4176 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4177 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4178 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4179 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 4180 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 4181 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4182 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4183 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4184 ---
Page 64/204 

--- Document Chunk 4185 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4186 ---
b) The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall check the train front end position 

--- Document Chunk 4187 ---
versus the Indication supervision limit of the proposed shortened MA. 

--- Document Chunk 4188 ---
 If it is in rear, the on-board equipment shall accept the new MA. 

--- Document Chunk 4189 ---
 If it is in advance , the request shall be rejected and the previously received MA 

--- Document Chunk 4190 ---
remains valid 

--- Document Chunk 4191 ---
c) The RBC shall be informed about the decision. 

--- Document Chunk 4192 ---
3.8.6.2 If the request from the RBC is granted by the on -board, refer to appendix A.3.4 for the 

--- Document Chunk 4193 ---
exhaustive list of location based information, which shall be deleted accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 4194 ---
3.9 Means to transmit Infill information (Level 1 only) 

--- Document Chunk 4195 ---
3.9.1 General 

--- Document Chunk 4196 ---
3.9.1.1 It shall be possible to transmit infill information to the on-board equipment using 

--- Document Chunk 4197 ---
a) Balise groups 

--- Document Chunk 4198 ---
b) Euroloops 

--- Document Chunk 4199 ---
c) Radio infill units. 

--- Document Chunk 4200 ---
3.9.1.1.1 If the information transmitted by Balise groups, Euroloops, and Radio includes infill 

--- Document Chunk 4201 ---
information, those devices are also identified as infill devices. 

--- Document Chunk 4202 ---
3.9.1.2 The principle used for the infill information shall be the same independent of 

--- Document Chunk 4203 ---
transmission media. 

--- Document Chunk 4204 ---
3.9.1.3 If the on -board system is not equipped with the infill transmission media as requested 

--- Document Chunk 4205 ---
by the announcement balise group, the announcement information  shall be ignored by 

--- Document Chunk 4206 ---
the on -board equipment and the train shall proceed according to the previously 

--- Document Chunk 4207 ---
received information.  

--- Document Chunk 4208 ---
3.9.1.4 Note: No additional description is needed for infill by balise group (other than already 

--- Document Chunk 4209 ---
covered in previous chapters). 

--- Document Chunk 4210 ---
3.9.2 Infill by loop 

--- Document Chunk 4211 ---
3.9.2.1 An End Of Loop Marker (EOLM) is by definition a device to mark the beginning or the 

--- Document Chunk 4212 ---
end of a loop. When receiving this information, the on -board equipment knows that it is 

--- Document Chunk 4213 ---
entering/leaving a track equipped with a loop. In unidirectional applications it is 

--- Document Chunk 4214 ---
possible to have an EOLM only at the entry side of a loop. 

--- Document Chunk 4215 ---
3.9.2.2 Balise groups shall be used as EOLMs. They act as an EOLM by sending the EOLM 

--- Document Chunk 4216 ---
information to the passing train.  

--- Document Chunk 4217 ---
3.9.2.3 EOLMs have an orientation that is identical to the balise group orientation. The g eneral 

--- Document Chunk 4218 ---
rules for balise orientation therefore also apply to EOLMs.  

--- Document Chunk 4219 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4220 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4221 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4222 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4223 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 4224 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 4225 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4226 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4227 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4228 ---
Page 65/204 

--- Document Chunk 4229 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4230 ---
3.9.2.4 EOLM information might be contained in a balise group that contains other information.  

--- Document Chunk 4231 ---
3.9.2.5 The EOLM shall send the identity of the announced loop. 

--- Document Chunk 4232 ---
3.9.2.6 The on-board shall only accept information c oming from the loop with the announced 

--- Document Chunk 4233 ---
identity.  

--- Document Chunk 4234 ---
3.9.2.7 Deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4235 ---
3.9.2.8 Deleted.  

--- Document Chunk 4236 ---
3.9.2.9 The following information shall be sent in advance by the EOLM to prepare for 

--- Document Chunk 4237 ---
reception of the loop information: 

--- Document Chunk 4238 ---
 Loop identity used to identify the loop.  

--- Document Chunk 4239 ---
 Key to select the spread spectrum key necessary to receive the loop telegrams. 

--- Document Chunk 4240 ---
 Distance to the loop giving the distance from the EOLM to the location from where 

--- Document Chunk 4241 ---
on loop messages can be received.  

--- Document Chunk 4242 ---
 Length of the loop giving the length of the loop over which messages can be 

--- Document Chunk 4243 ---
received.  

--- Document Chunk 4244 ---
 Indicator telling the on -board whether the orientation of the loop is identical or 

--- Document Chunk 4245 ---
reverse to the orientation of the announcing EOLM.  

--- Document Chunk 4246 ---
3.9.2.10 The on-board shall be prepared to receive messages from the Euroloop after passing 

--- Document Chunk 4247 ---
the EOLM. 

--- Document Chunk 4248 ---
3.9.2.11 When the on -board equipment reads  the next main signal balise group or when it 

--- Document Chunk 4249 ---
detects that the next main signal balise group was missed, new infill information 

--- Document Chunk 4250 ---
possibly received from the loop shall be ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 4251 ---
3.9.2.12 The distances given in an EOLM (distance to loop, length of loop) are used for  

--- Document Chunk 4252 ---
diagnostic purpose only. They shall therefore not be used to restrict reception of loop 

--- Document Chunk 4253 ---
telegrams to specific locations. 

--- Document Chunk 4254 ---
3.9.3 Infill by radio 

--- Document Chunk 4255 ---
3.9.3.1 In level 1 areas it shall be possible to send to the on -board equipment orders to 

--- Document Chunk 4256 ---
establish/terminate a communication session with a radio infill unit.  

--- Document Chunk 4257 ---
3.9.3.2 The orders shall be sent via balise groups or via Radio Infill units. 

--- Document Chunk 4258 ---
3.9.3.3 The order to establish a communication session shall be ignored: 

--- Document Chunk 4259 ---
a) Intentionally deleted.  

--- Document Chunk 4260 ---
b) If the on-board equipment does not include radio.  

--- Document Chunk 4261 ---
3.9.3.4 If the on -board equipment includes radio, the communication session shall be 

--- Document Chunk 4262 ---
established using the same protocols and interfaces as for Level 2/3 operations.  

--- Document Chunk 4263 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4264 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4265 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4266 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4267 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 4268 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 4269 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4270 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4271 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4272 ---
Page 66/204 

--- Document Chunk 4273 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4274 ---
3.9.3.5 If the order to establish a communication session with a radio infill unit sent via balise 

--- Document Chunk 4275 ---
groups is received, the on-board equipment  shall, once the location indicated in the 

--- Document Chunk 4276 ---
order is reached: 

--- Document Chunk 4277 ---
a) terminate any existing communication session(s) with RIU(s) not indicated in the 

--- Document Chunk 4278 ---
order 

--- Document Chunk 4279 ---
b) as soon as a new communication session can be handled, establish a 

--- Document Chunk 4280 ---
communication session with the RIU indicated in the order 

--- Document Chunk 4281 ---
3.9.3.5.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4282 ---
3.9.3.5.1.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4283 ---
3.9.3.5.2 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4284 ---
3.9.3.6 If the order to establish a communication session with a radio infill unit sent via Radio 

--- Document Chunk 4285 ---
Infill unit is received, the on-board equipment shall: 

--- Document Chunk 4286 ---
a) If only one RIU communication session is ongoing , maintain the existing 

--- Document Chunk 4287 ---
communication session and establish a new one with the RIU indicated in the order. 

--- Document Chunk 4288 ---
b) If two RIU communication sessions are ongoing, maintain the communication 

--- Document Chunk 4289 ---
session related to the current infill area, terminate the other one and establish a new 

--- Document Chunk 4290 ---
one with the RIU indicated in the order. 

--- Document Chunk 4291 ---
3.9.3.6.1 Exception (degraded situation): if the on -board can handle only one communication 

--- Document Chunk 4292 ---
session, the order shall be ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 4293 ---
3.9.3.7 A Radio Infill Unit shall not initi ate a communication session with an on -board 

--- Document Chunk 4294 ---
equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 4295 ---
3.9.3.8 The order to establish/terminate a communication session sent via balise groups shall 

--- Document Chunk 4296 ---
be sent together with the following radio infill area information: 

--- Document Chunk 4297 ---
a) Location where to perform the action (referred to the balise group containing the 

--- Document Chunk 4298 ---
order).Note: if the action is to establish a communication session, this location 

--- Document Chunk 4299 ---
marks the beginning of the Radio Infill Area. 

--- Document Chunk 4300 ---
b) Next main signal balise group identifier ( ignored by the on -board if the action is 

--- Document Chunk 4301 ---
Terminate communication session).Note: the reference location of this balise group 

--- Document Chunk 4302 ---
marks the end of the Radio Infill Area. 

--- Document Chunk 4303 ---
3.9.3.8.1 The order to establish/terminate a communication session sent via Radio Infill units 

--- Document Chunk 4304 ---
(see 3.5.3.6) shall not be sent together with any radio infill area information. 

--- Document Chunk 4305 ---
3.9.3.9 The establishment of a communication session for radio infill shall not change the 

--- Document Chunk 4306 ---
operational level of the on -board i.e. the information in the balise group shall be taken 

--- Document Chunk 4307 ---
into account as usual in level 1.  

--- Document Chunk 4308 ---
3.9.3.10 The on-board equipment shall inform the radio infill unit 

--- Document Chunk 4309 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4310 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4311 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4312 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4313 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 4314 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 4315 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4316 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4317 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4318 ---
Page 67/204 

--- Document Chunk 4319 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4320 ---
a) As soon as the location indicated in the order sent via balise groups is passed (i.e. 

--- Document Chunk 4321 ---
entry of the train in the infill area) 

--- Document Chunk 4322 ---
b) As soon as the next main signal balise group indicated in the order sent via balise 

--- Document Chunk 4323 ---
groups is read or the on-board equipment detects that it was missed.  

--- Document Chunk 4324 ---
3.9.3.11 The information sent to the radio infill unit by the on-board equipment shall include 

--- Document Chunk 4325 ---
a) Train identity (ETCS-ID of the on-board equipment) 

--- Document Chunk 4326 ---
b) Position report 

--- Document Chunk 4327 ---
c) Identifier of the next main signal balise group 

--- Document Chunk 4328 ---
d) Time stamp 

--- Document Chunk 4329 ---
3.9.3.11.1 Justification:  

--- Document Chunk 4330 ---
a) The train identity is used for conformity with other train to track messages 

--- Document Chunk 4331 ---
b) The identifier of the next main signal balise group allows the radio infill unit to 

--- Document Chunk 4332 ---
identify safely where the train is going, even in the case of a points area 

--- Document Chunk 4333 ---
3.9.3.12 As soon as the radio infill unit is informed that a train has entered an infill area  under 

--- Document Chunk 4334 ---
its responsibility, it shall 

--- Document Chunk 4335 ---
a) Terminate a possible previous sending of infill information to the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 4336 ---
equipment, AND 

--- Document Chunk 4337 ---
b) Send cyclically the infill informati on corresponding to the message currently sent by 

--- Document Chunk 4338 ---
the next main signal balise group indicated in the information from the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 4339 ---
equipment.  

--- Document Chunk 4340 ---
3.9.3.12.1 Justification: case a) refers to the possibility that a report from the on-board equipment, 

--- Document Chunk 4341 ---
after having passed the previous main signal, was lost. 

--- Document Chunk 4342 ---
3.9.3.12.2 Note: A Radio infill unit may manage several signals, thus several Radio Infill Areas 

--- Document Chunk 4343 ---
(see Figure 25a) 

--- Document Chunk 4344 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 4391 ---
3.9.3.13 The radio infill unit shall terminate the sending of infill information as soon as 

--- Document Chunk 4392 ---
information is received, that the on -board equipment has read the next main signal 

--- Document Chunk 4393 ---
balise group indicated in the order or that the on -board equipment has det ected that it 

--- Document Chunk 4394 ---
was missed. 

--- Document Chunk 4395 ---
3.9.3.14 The radio infill unit shall evaluate the time stamp according to the principles of section 

--- Document Chunk 4396 ---
3.16.3.2. 

--- Document Chunk 4397 ---
The on-board equipment shall check the consistency of radio infill data, according to 

--- Document Chunk 4398 ---
the principles of section 3.16.3.1 and 3.16.3.3. 

--- Document Chunk 4399 ---
3.9.3.15 When the on -board equipment reads the next main signal balise group or when it 

--- Document Chunk 4400 ---
detects that the next main signal balise group was missed, new infill information 

--- Document Chunk 4401 ---
related to this balise group possibly received shall be ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 4402 ---
3.9.3.16 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall terminate the communication session 

--- Document Chunk 4403 ---
according to the orders received from the trackside (balise group  or Radio Infill units ) 

--- Document Chunk 4404 ---
or when the level 1 is left. 

--- Document Chunk 4405 ---
3.9.3.17 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4406 ---
3.10 Emergency Messages 

--- Document Chunk 4407 ---
3.10.1 General 

--- Document Chunk 4408 ---
3.10.1.1 Emergency messages shall be sent individually to each on -board equipment, either as 

--- Document Chunk 4409 ---
high priority data or as normal priority data of the same radio connection, as described 

--- Document Chunk 4410 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4411 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4412 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4413 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4414 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 4415 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 4416 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4417 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4418 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4419 ---
Page 69/204 

--- Document Chunk 4420 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4421 ---
in Euroradio specification. Only  emergency messages can be sent as high priority 

--- Document Chunk 4422 ---
data, not their acknowledgement or their revocation. 

--- Document Chunk 4423 ---
3.10.1.1.1 Justification: In case of hazardous events, it is possible to use high priority data in the 

--- Document Chunk 4424 ---
radio connection between RBC and on-board equipment to get a quick reaction.  

--- Document Chunk 4425 ---
3.10.1.2 An emergency message shall contain an identifier decided by the trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 4426 ---
3.10.1.3 The same identifier shall be used in case the emergency message is repeated. 

--- Document Chunk 4427 ---
3.10.1.3.1 If the on -board receives a new message with the same identifier it shall replace the 

--- Document Chunk 4428 ---
previous one. 

--- Document Chunk 4429 ---
3.10.1.4 Each emergency message to an on -board equipment shall be acknowledged, using 

--- Document Chunk 4430 ---
the corresponding emergency message identification number. 

--- Document Chunk 4431 ---
3.10.1.4.1 Note: This acknowledgement informs the RBC about the use of the emergency 

--- Document Chunk 4432 ---
message by on -board equipment and i s independent from the general 

--- Document Chunk 4433 ---
acknowledgement for track-to-train messages, as specified in section 3.16.3.5. 

--- Document Chunk 4434 ---
3.10.2 Emergency Stop  

--- Document Chunk 4435 ---
3.10.2.1 It shall be possible to stop a train with a conditional or an unconditional emergency 

--- Document Chunk 4436 ---
stop message.  

--- Document Chunk 4437 ---
3.10.2.2 A conditional emergency stop message shall contain the information of a new stop 

--- Document Chunk 4438 ---
location, referred to the LRBG. In case, when receiving this message 

--- Document Chunk 4439 ---
 the train has already passed with its min safe front end the new stop location, the 

--- Document Chunk 4440 ---
emergency stop message shall be rejected and the RBC shall be informed. 

--- Document Chunk 4441 ---
 the train has not yet passed with its min safe front end the new stop location, the 

--- Document Chunk 4442 ---
emergency stop message shall be accepted, however this location shall be used by 

--- Document Chunk 4443 ---
the onboard to define a new EOA/SvL only if not beyond the current E OA/LOA. 

--- Document Chunk 4444 ---
Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of location based information stored 

--- Document Chunk 4445 ---
on-board, which shall be deleted accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 4446 ---
3.10.2.3 When receiving an unconditional emergency stop message the train shall be tripped 

--- Document Chunk 4447 ---
immediately. 

--- Document Chunk 4448 ---
3.10.2.4 New movement authority r eceived after any accepted emergency stop message and 

--- Document Chunk 4449 ---
before the emergency message has been revoked, shall be rejected. 

--- Document Chunk 4450 ---
3.10.2.5 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4451 ---
3.10.2.6 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4452 ---

--- Document Chunk 4453 ---
3.10.3.1 The revocation message shall refer to the identity of t he concerned emergency 

--- Document Chunk 4454 ---
message. 

--- Document Chunk 4455 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 4467 ---
according to the general acknowledgement procedure (see section 3.16.3.5) 

--- Document Chunk 4468 ---
3.10.3.3 The revocation of an emergency message shall hav e no effect on the management of

other emergency messages possibly received.

--- Document Chunk 4472 ---
3.11 Static Speed Restrictions and Gradients 

--- Document Chunk 4473 ---
3.11.1 Introduction  

--- Document Chunk 4474 ---
3.11.1.1 The permitted speed at which the train is allowed to travel shall be limited to different 

--- Document Chunk 4475 ---
kinds of Static Speed Restrictions. 

--- Document Chunk 4476 ---
3.11.1.2 A Static Speed Restriction shall be handled in the same way independent of ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 4477 ---
level. 

--- Document Chunk 4478 ---
3.11.2 Definition of Static Speed Restriction 

--- Document Chunk 4479 ---
3.11.2.1 Static Speed Restrictions are imposed by the trackside infrastructure, the train 

--- Document Chunk 4480 ---
characteristics, the signalling and the mode of the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 4481 ---
3.11.2.2 There are eleven categories of Static Speed Restrictions:   

--- Document Chunk 4482 ---
a) Static Speed Profile (SSP) 

--- Document Chunk 4483 ---
b) Axle load Speed Profile (ASP) 

--- Document Chunk 4484 ---
c) Temporary Speed Restrictions (TSR) 

--- Document Chunk 4485 ---
d) Maximum Train Speed 

--- Document Chunk 4486 ---
e) Signalling related speed restriction (only level 1) 

--- Document Chunk 4487 ---
f) Mode related Speed Restriction. 

--- Document Chunk 4488 ---
g) STM Max speed (for details refer to Subset-035) 

--- Document Chunk 4489 ---
h) STM System speed (for details refer to Subset-035) 

--- Document Chunk 4490 ---
i) Level Crossing speed restriction (LX SR) 

--- Document Chunk 4491 ---
j) Override function related Speed Restriction 

--- Document Chunk 4492 ---
k) Speed restriction to ens ure a given permitted braking distance (PBD SR) (see 

--- Document Chunk 4493 ---
3.11.11) 

--- Document Chunk 4494 ---
3.11.2.3 The Static Speed Restriction categories are independent of each other. This means 

--- Document Chunk 4495 ---
that one speed restriction category cannot affect, nor be affected by, any other 

--- Document Chunk 4496 ---
category of Static Speed Restrictions.  

--- Document Chunk 4497 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4498 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4499 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4500 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4501 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 4502 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 4503 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4504 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4505 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4506 ---
Page 71/204 

--- Document Chunk 4507 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4508 ---
v

--- Document Chunk 4509 ---
d

--- Document Chunk 4510 ---
Static Speed Profile

--- Document Chunk 4511 ---
Temporary Speed Restriction

--- Document Chunk 4512 ---
Maximum Train Speed

--- Document Chunk 4513 ---
Mode related Speed Restriction

--- Document Chunk 4514 ---
Figure 26: Example of Static Speed Restriction categories on a piece of track. 

--- Document Chunk 4515 ---
3.11.2.4 Depending on the type of Static Speed Restriction train length may have to be used to 

--- Document Chunk 4516 ---
ensure that the full length of the train has passed a Static Speed Restriction 

--- Document Chunk 4517 ---
discontinuity before a speed increase shall be taken into account.  

--- Document Chunk 4518 ---
3.11.2.5 Intentionally deleted.  

--- Document Chunk 4519 ---
3.11.2.6 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4520 ---
3.11.3 Static Speed Profile (SSP) 

--- Document Chunk 4521 ---
3.11.3.1.1 The Static Speed Profile (SSP) is a description of the fixed spee d restrictions of a 

--- Document Chunk 4522 ---
given piece of track. The speed restrictions can be related to e.g. maximum line speed, 

--- Document Chunk 4523 ---
curves, points, tunnel profiles, bridges. 

--- Document Chunk 4524 ---
3.11.3.1.2 The Static Speed Profile is based on factors, which are both track and train dependent. 

--- Document Chunk 4525 ---
The relationship b etween track and train characteristics determine s the individual 

--- Document Chunk 4526 ---
Static Speed Profile for each train.  

--- Document Chunk 4527 ---
3.11.3.1.3 It shall be possible for every element (distance between two discontinuities) of a static 

--- Document Chunk 4528 ---
speed profile to define, if a transition to a higher speed limi t than the speed limit 

--- Document Chunk 4529 ---
specified for this element is permitted before the complete train has left the element. 

--- Document Chunk 4530 ---
3.11.3.2 Static Speed Profile Categories 

--- Document Chunk 4531 ---
3.11.3.2.1 It shall be possible to transmit several Static Speed Profile Categories; one Basic SSP 

--- Document Chunk 4532 ---
category and specific SSP categories related to the international train categories. 

--- Document Chunk 4533 ---
3.11.3.2.1.1 The specific SSP categories are decomposed into two types: 

--- Document Chunk 4534 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4535 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4536 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4537 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4538 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 4539 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 4540 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4541 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4542 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4543 ---
Page 72/204 

--- Document Chunk 4544 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4545 ---
a) The “Cant Deficiency” SSP categories: the cant deficiency value assigned to one 

--- Document Chunk 4546 ---
category shall define the maximum speed, determined by sus pension design, at 

--- Document Chunk 4547 ---
which a particular train can traverse a curve and thus can be used to set a specific 

--- Document Chunk 4548 ---
speed limit in a curve with regards to this category. 

--- Document Chunk 4549 ---
b) The “other specific” SSP categories: it groups all other specific SSP categories 

--- Document Chunk 4550 ---
corresponding to the other international train categories 

--- Document Chunk 4551 ---
3.11.3.2.1.2 Whenever the type of specific SSP category is not explicitly specified in the 

--- Document Chunk 4552 ---
following requirements, it shall be interpreted as being applicable for both types of 

--- Document Chunk 4553 ---
specific SSP categories. 

--- Document Chunk 4554 ---
3.11.3.2.2 For each part of the Static Speed Profile, the ERTMS/ETCS trackside shall: 

--- Document Chunk 4555 ---
a) always give the Basic SSP, which shall be considered as the default “Cant 

--- Document Chunk 4556 ---
Deficiency” SSP 

--- Document Chunk 4557 ---
b) optionally give one or more specific SSPs 

--- Document Chunk 4558 ---
c) specify, for each “other specific” SSP, whether it replaces or not the “Can t 

--- Document Chunk 4559 ---
Deficiency” SSP as selected by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment according to 

--- Document Chunk 4560 ---
3.11.3.2.3 

--- Document Chunk 4561 ---
3.11.3.2.3 For each part of the Static Speed Profile, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 4562 ---
select the SSP best suiting its “Cant Deficiency” train category, according to the  

--- Document Chunk 4563 ---
following order of preference: 

--- Document Chunk 4564 ---
a) if available, the “Cant Deficiency” SSP matching its “Cant Deficiency” train category, 

--- Document Chunk 4565 ---
OR 

--- Document Chunk 4566 ---
b) if available, the “Cant Deficiency” SSP with the highest Cant Deficiency value below 

--- Document Chunk 4567 ---
the value of its “Cant Deficiency” train category, OR 

--- Document Chunk 4568 ---
c) the Basic SSP 

--- Document Chunk 4569 ---
3.11.3.2.3.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4570 ---
3.11.3.2.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4571 ---
3.11.3.2.5 “Other Specific” SSP categories not relevant to the current train shall be ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 4572 ---
3.11.3.2.6 For each part of the Static Speed Profile, t he ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment in a 

--- Document Chunk 4573 ---
train belonging to at least one or more “other international” train categories shall use 

--- Document Chunk 4574 ---
the most restrictive speed amongst: 

--- Document Chunk 4575 ---
a) the ” Cant Deficiency” SSP as selected in 3.11.3.2.3, only if none of the “other 

--- Document Chunk 4576 ---
specific” SSP categories matching the train categories replaces the ” Cant 

--- Document Chunk 4577 ---
Deficiency” SSP, AND 

--- Document Chunk 4578 ---
b) all the “other specific” SSP categories matching the “other international” train 

--- Document Chunk 4579 ---
categories. 

--- Document Chunk 4580 ---
3.11.3.3 Train categories 

--- Document Chunk 4581 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4582 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4583 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4584 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4585 ---
3.6.0

13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 4587 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4588 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4589 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4590 ---
Page 73/204 

--- Document Chunk 4591 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4592 ---
3.11.3.3.1 A maximum of 31 train categories is defined to match the SSP categories. 16 “Cant 

--- Document Chunk 4593 ---
Deficiency” train categories and 15 “other international” train categories. 

--- Document Chunk 4594 ---
3.11.3.3.2 A train shall always belong to one and only one “Cant Deficiency”  train category and 

--- Document Chunk 4595 ---
may optionally belong to one or more “other international” train categories. 

--- Document Chunk 4596 ---
3.11.3.3.3 The train category(ies) to which a train belongs is a part of its Train Data. 

--- Document Chunk 4597 ---
3.11.4 Axle load Speed Profile 

--- Document Chunk 4598 ---
3.11.4.1 It shall be possible to define an Axle load Speed Profile as a non-continuous profile. 

--- Document Chunk 4599 ---
3.11.4.2 For each section with a speed restriction due to axle load, the different speed value(s) 

--- Document Chunk 4600 ---
and for which minimum axle load category this speed value(s) applies shall be 

--- Document Chunk 4601 ---
specified. 

--- Document Chunk 4602 ---
3.11.4.2.1 Note: Different speed restrictions depending on the axle load category can be 

--- Document Chunk 4603 ---
applicable to the same distance. 

--- Document Chunk 4604 ---
3.11.4.3 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment  shall consider the most restrictive speed 

--- Document Chunk 4605 ---
restriction that is associated with any axle load category  lower than, or equal to that of 

--- Document Chunk 4606 ---
the train. 

--- Document Chunk 4607 ---
3.11.4.4 For trains with an axle load category lower than the minimum axle load category given 

--- Document Chunk 4608 ---
in the profile , the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment  shall not consider any speed 

--- Document Chunk 4609 ---
restriction due to axle load. 

--- Document Chunk 4610 ---
3.11.4.5 The initial state for Axle load Speed Profile shall be “no restriction due to axle load”. 

--- Document Chunk 4611 ---
3.11.4.6 Whether a speed increase after the axle load speed restriction shall be delayed with 

--- Document Chunk 4612 ---
train length, shall be determined by the axle load speed pr ofile information sent to the 

--- Document Chunk 4613 ---
on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 4614 ---
3.11.5 Temporary Speed Restrictions 

--- Document Chunk 4615 ---
3.11.5.1 The temporary speed restriction is defined in order to enable a separate category of 

--- Document Chunk 4616 ---
track infrastructure speed restriction, which can be used for working areas etc. 

--- Document Chunk 4617 ---
3.11.5.2 All Temporary Speed Restrictions are independent of each other. This means that an 

--- Document Chunk 4618 ---
individual Temporary Speed Restriction cannot affect, nor be affected by, any other 

--- Document Chunk 4619 ---
individual Temporary Speed Restriction. 

--- Document Chunk 4620 ---
3.11.5.3 Whether a speed increase after the temporary speed restricti on shall be delayed with 

--- Document Chunk 4621 ---
train length, shall be determined by the temporary speed restriction information sent to 

--- Document Chunk 4622 ---
the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 4623 ---
3.11.5.4 When two or more temporary speed restrictions overlap, the most restrictive speed of 

--- Document Chunk 4624 ---
the overlapping temporary speed restrictions shall be used in the area of overlap. 

--- Document Chunk 4625 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4626 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4627 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4628 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4629 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 4630 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 4631 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4632 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4633 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4634 ---
Page 74/204 

--- Document Chunk 4635 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4636 ---
3.11.5.5 Each Temporary Speed Restriction shall have an identity to make it possible to revoke 

--- Document Chunk 4637 ---
the Temporary Speed Restriction using its identity. The speed restriction shall be 

--- Document Chunk 4638 ---
revoked immediately when revocation i s received from trackside, without delay for the 

--- Document Chunk 4639 ---
train length. 

--- Document Chunk 4640 ---
3.11.5.6 It shall be possible to identify whether a Temporary Speed Restriction is possible to 

--- Document Chunk 4641 ---
revoke or not. 

--- Document Chunk 4642 ---
3.11.5.7 A new Temporary Speed Restriction shall not replace a previously received Temporary 

--- Document Chunk 4643 ---
Speed Restriction with another identity.  

--- Document Chunk 4644 ---
3.11.5.8 Temporary Speed Restrictions shall only be revoked on request from the trackside.  

--- Document Chunk 4645 ---
3.11.5.9 If the on-board equipment receives a new Temporary Speed Restriction (TSR) with the 

--- Document Chunk 4646 ---
same identity as an already received TSR, the new Tempo rary Speed Restriction shall 

--- Document Chunk 4647 ---
replace the previous one, except when the Temporary Speed Restriction is identified 

--- Document Chunk 4648 ---
as non revocable in which case this shall be considered as an additional TSR. 

--- Document Chunk 4649 ---
3.11.5.10 In case the train has changed its orientation any Temporary Speed  Restriction shall be 

--- Document Chunk 4650 ---
deleted (operational requirement: will be executed due to the mode change). 

--- Document Chunk 4651 ---
3.11.5.11 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4652 ---
3.11.5.12 It shall be possible for the RBC to order an ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment in Level 

--- Document Chunk 4653 ---
2 or 3 to reject revocable TSRs from balises. 

--- Document Chunk 4654 ---
3.11.5.13 When ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment has accepted an order to reject revocable 

--- Document Chunk 4655 ---
TSRs from balises, this inhibition shall be stored and shall be effective immediately, 

--- Document Chunk 4656 ---
but only for revocable TSRs received from balises thereafter.  

--- Document Chunk 4657 ---
3.11.5.14 The inhibition of revocable TSRs f rom balises shall be deleted if any of the following 

--- Document Chunk 4658 ---
occurs: 

--- Document Chunk 4659 ---
 the communication session established with the RBC that ordered the inhibition is 

--- Document Chunk 4660 ---
terminated, OR 

--- Document Chunk 4661 ---
 in case of RBC/RBC handover, the train front end crosses the RBC/RBC border. 

--- Document Chunk 4662 ---
3.11.5.15 Note: this inhibition  may be useful in Level 1 / Level 2 mixed signalling applications 

--- Document Chunk 4663 ---
when the RBC has more precise information about restrictions than can be given from 

--- Document Chunk 4664 ---
balises. The RBC may then order inhibition of revocable TSRs from balises and 

--- Document Chunk 4665 ---
instead send more precise TSRs to the train. 

--- Document Chunk 4666 ---
3.11.6 Signalling related speed restrictions 

--- Document Chunk 4667 ---
3.11.6.1 In level 1, it shall be possible to send to the on -board equipment a speed restriction 

--- Document Chunk 4668 ---
with a value depending on the current state of signalling. 

--- Document Chunk 4669 ---
3.11.6.2 This speed value shall be taken into account by the on -board equipment as soon as it 

--- Document Chunk 4670 ---
is received on -board, with the exception of a signalling related speed restriction from 

--- Document Chunk 4671 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4672 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4673 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4674 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4675 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 4676 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 4677 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4678 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4679 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4680 ---
Page 75/204 

--- Document Chunk 4681 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4682 ---
an infill device. In case of infill information the speed restriction shall be taken into 

--- Document Chunk 4683 ---
account from the location reference of the balise group at the next main signal. 

--- Document Chunk 4684 ---
3.11.6.3 The speed restriction shall be valid until a new signalling related speed restriction is 

--- Document Chunk 4685 ---
received. 

--- Document Chunk 4686 ---
3.11.6.3.1 If the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment switches from level 1 to level 2 /3, the 

--- Document Chunk 4687 ---
signalling related speed restriction shall remain valid until a L2/3 MA is accepted by the 

--- Document Chunk 4688 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 4689 ---
3.11.6.4 In case of a signal at danger the signalling related speed restriction shall have value  

--- Document Chunk 4690 ---
zero, which shall be evaluated by the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment not as a 

--- Document Chunk 4691 ---
speed limit but as a train trip order. 

--- Document Chunk 4692 ---
3.11.6.5 In case of infill information the signalling related speed restriction at zero shall be 

--- Document Chunk 4693 ---
ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 4694 ---
3.11.6.5.1 Note: The infill information will also include an EOA at the next main signal that will be 

--- Document Chunk 4695 ---
supervised according to the normal rules. 

--- Document Chunk 4696 ---
3.11.7 Mode related speed restrictions 

--- Document Chunk 4697 ---
3.11.7.1 The value of the mode related speed restriction shall be determined by the 

--- Document Chunk 4698 ---
corresponding national value or the corresponding default values if the national values 

--- Document Chunk 4699 ---
are not applicable. 

--- Document Chunk 4700 ---
3.11.7.1.1  Exception 1: For the modes On -sight, Limited  Supervision and Shunting the speed 

--- Document Chunk 4701 ---
limit can also be given from the trackside. The speed limit given from the trackside 

--- Document Chunk 4702 ---
shall prevail over the National value and the default value. 

--- Document Chunk 4703 ---
3.11.7.1.2 Exception 2: For the mode Reversing there is no National/Default value. Th e speed 

--- Document Chunk 4704 ---
limit is always given from trackside.  

--- Document Chunk 4705 ---
3.11.7.1.3 Exception 3: For the mode Staff Responsible the speed limit can also be entered by 

--- Document Chunk 4706 ---
the driver. The speed limit given by the driver shall prevail over the National/Default 

--- Document Chunk 4707 ---
value. 

--- Document Chunk 4708 ---
3.11.8 Train related speed restriction 

--- Document Chunk 4709 ---
3.11.8.1 It shall be possible to define the maximum train speed related to the actual 

--- Document Chunk 4710 ---
performance and configuration of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 4711 ---
3.11.9 LX speed restriction 

--- Document Chunk 4712 ---
3.11.9.1 It shall be possible to define a LX speed restriction when the train has to pass a non 

--- Document Chunk 4713 ---
protected Level Crossing. 

--- Document Chunk 4714 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 4725 ---
3.11.10 Override function related Speed Restriction 

--- Document Chunk 4726 ---
3.11.10.1 While the “override” function is active, the override speed limit (national /default value) 

--- Document Chunk 4727 ---
shall be taken into account. 

--- Document Chunk 4728 ---
3.11.11 Speed restriction to ensure permitted braking distance 

--- Document Chunk 4729 ---
3.11.11.1 It shall be possible for trackside t o request the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment to 

--- Document Chunk 4730 ---
calculate a speed restriction based on a permitted braking distance given by trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 4731 ---
3.11.11.2 The order shall be given by means of a non-continuous profile defining: 

--- Document Chunk 4732 ---
 The start and end location for the speed restriction 

--- Document Chunk 4733 ---
 The permitted braking distance (PBD) used to calculate the speed restriction value 

--- Document Chunk 4734 ---
 Whether the permitted braking distance is to be achieved with the Service Brake or 

--- Document Chunk 4735 ---
Emergency Brake 

--- Document Chunk 4736 ---
 A single gradient value applicable for the calculation 

--- Document Chunk 4737 ---
3.11.11.3 The speed restriction shall be calculated when the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 4738 ---
receives the permitted braking distance information from trackside, and shall be re -

--- Document Chunk 4739 ---
calculated only if any of the inputs taken into account for the calculation of the speed 

--- Document Chunk 4740 ---
restriction changes. 

--- Document Chunk 4741 ---
3.11.11.4 The calculation of the speed restriction by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 4742 ---
take into account that: 

--- Document Chunk 4743 ---
 The single gradient value received from trackside shall be compensated in value 

--- Document Chunk 4744 ---
according to the rotating mass as defined in 3.13.4.3. 

--- Document Chunk 4745 ---
 The safe deceleration shall be computed as in 3.13.6.2.1 but without considering 

--- Document Chunk 4746 ---
the adhesion profiles , the track conditions related to brake inhibition and the track 

--- Document Chunk 4747 ---
conditions related to powerless section given by trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 4748 ---
 The expected deceleration shall be com puted as in 3.13.6.3.1 but without 

--- Document Chunk 4749 ---
considering the track conditions related to brake inhibition and the track conditions 

--- Document Chunk 4750 ---
related to powerless section given by trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 4751 ---
 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall calculate an Emergency Brake 

--- Document Chunk 4752 ---
Deceleration (EBD ) curve based on the safe deceleration and that reaches zero 

--- Document Chunk 4753 ---
speed at a distance equal to the permitted braking distance. 

--- Document Chunk 4754 ---
 If the permitted braking distance is to be achieved with the service brake, the 

--- Document Chunk 4755 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall also calculate a S ervice Brake 

--- Document Chunk 4756 ---
Deceleration (SBD) curve based on the expected deceleration and that reaches 

--- Document Chunk 4757 ---
zero speed at a distance equal to the permitted braking distance. 

--- Document Chunk 4758 ---
 The estimated acceleration shall be set to “zero”. 

--- Document Chunk 4759 ---
 If not inhibited by National Value, the compensat ion of the inaccuracy of the speed 

--- Document Chunk 4760 ---
measurement shall be set to a value calculated from the PBD speed, as defined in 

--- Document Chunk 4761 ---
SUBSET-041 § 5.3.1.2: V_delta0PBD = f41(V_PBD + dV_EBI(V_PBD)) if the 

--- Document Chunk 4762 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4763 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4764 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4765 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4766 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 4767 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 4768 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4769 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4770 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4771 ---
Page 77/204 

--- Document Chunk 4772 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4773 ---
permitted braking distance is to be achieved with the emergency brake;  

--- Document Chunk 4774 ---
V_delta0PBD = f41(V_PBD + dV_SBI(V_PBD))  if the permitted braking distance is 

--- Document Chunk 4775 ---
to be achieved with the service brake. 

--- Document Chunk 4776 ---
 The train will travel a distance from the last encountered balise of a group that 

--- Document Chunk 4777 ---
provides restrictive information until initiating the br ake command. This travelled 

--- Document Chunk 4778 ---
distance shall be set to a value calculated from the PBD speed considering a 

--- Document Chunk 4779 ---
processing delay (T41) equal to SUBSET-041 § 5.2.1.1. 

--- Document Chunk 4780 ---
 Regardless of how the service brake feedback is actually configured (see 

--- Document Chunk 4781 ---
3.13.2.2.7.2), T_bs1 and  T_bs2 (see 3.13.9.3.3) shall be defined as if the service 

--- Document Chunk 4782 ---
brake feedback was not implemented. 

--- Document Chunk 4783 ---
 Regardless of how the traction cut -off interface is actually configured (see 

--- Document Chunk 4784 ---
3.13.2.2.8), T_traction (see 3.13.9.3.2) shall be defined as if the traction cut -off was 

--- Document Chunk 4785 ---
not implemented. 

--- Document Chunk 4786 ---
3.11.11.4.1 Note: Knowing how the PBD speed restriction is computed by the ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 4787 ---
board equipment, it is the responsibility of the trackside to set the appropriate 

--- Document Chunk 4788 ---
permitted braking distance with regard to the risk of not initiating the br ake command 

--- Document Chunk 4789 ---
in due time when encountering a further balise group providing restrictive information. 

--- Document Chunk 4790 ---
In other words, if deemed necessary, the trackside can include provisions based on 

--- Document Chunk 4791 ---
the characteristics of the balise group providing restrictive information  e.g. distances 

--- Document Chunk 4792 ---
between balises in that group with regards to validity direction of transmitted 

--- Document Chunk 4793 ---
information and balise group orientation, accuracy of balise location. 

--- Document Chunk 4794 ---
3.11.11.4.2 Note: If the permitted braking distance is to be achieved with the service brake, it is the 

--- Document Chunk 4795 ---
responsibility of the trackside to also consider an estimation of the on-board over-

--- Document Chunk 4796 ---
reading and under-reading amounts at the time the brake command is initiated in order 

--- Document Chunk 4797 ---
to lower the likelihood of the max safe front end of the train reaching the EBI 

--- Document Chunk 4798 ---
supervision limit. 

--- Document Chunk 4799 ---
3.11.11.5 Note: Throughout the following formulas, all the distances marked with “d” (lower case) 

--- Document Chunk 4800 ---
are counted from a single arbitrary reference location. 

--- Document Chunk 4801 ---
3.11.11.6 If the permitted braking distance is to be achieved with the emergency brake, the 

--- Document Chunk 4802 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall seek the PBD speed restriction value 

--- Document Chunk 4803 ---
(V_PBD) which satisfies the two following inequalities. The resulting value shall then 

--- Document Chunk 4804 ---
be rounded down to the next lower multiple of 5km/h: 

--- Document Chunk 4805 ---

3.11.11.7 If the permitted braking distance is to be achieved with the service brake, the PBD 

--- Document Chunk 4844 ---
speed restriction (V_PBD) shall be equal to  the most restrictive value amongst the one 

--- Document Chunk 4845 ---
computed from the EBD (see 3.11.11.8) and the one computed from the SBD (see 

--- Document Chunk 4846 ---
3.11.11.9). The resulting value shall then be rounded down to the next lower multiple 

--- Document Chunk 4847 ---
of 5km/h. 

--- Document Chunk 4848 ---
3.11.11.8 If the permitted braking distance is to  be achieved with the service brake, the 

--- Document Chunk 4849 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall seek the PBD EBD speed restriction value

which satisfies the two following inequalities:

3.11.11.10 Note: The method chosen (e.g. iterative algorithm) to compute the PBD speed 

--- Document Chunk 4933 ---
restriction(s) is an implementation issue. 

--- Document Chunk 4934 ---
3.11.11.11 The initial state for Speed Restrictio ns to Ensure Permitted Braking Distance shall be 

--- Document Chunk 4935 ---
“no speed restriction”. 

--- Document Chunk 4936 ---
3.11.12 Gradients 

--- Document Chunk 4937 ---
3.11.12.1 The gradient information for a given piece of track shall be transmitted to the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 4938 ---
equipment in form of a gradient profile. 

--- Document Chunk 4939 ---
3.11.12.2 The gradient profile shall be continuous, i .e., give a gradient value for each location 

--- Document Chunk 4940 ---
within the piece of track covered by the profile. 

--- Document Chunk 4941 ---
3.11.12.3 A gradient value shall be identified as a positive value for an uphill slope, and with a 

--- Document Chunk 4942 ---
negative value for a downhill slope. 

--- Document Chunk 4943 ---
3.11.12.4 The gradient profile shall contain the gradient information as a sequence of gradient 

--- Document Chunk 4944 ---
values, constant between two defined locations each, see Figure 27. 

--- Document Chunk 4945 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4946 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4947 ---

Figure 27: Gradient profile 

--- Document Chunk 4966 ---
3.11.12.4.1 Note: The figure above symboli ses the engineering process to provide the values of 

--- Document Chunk 4967 ---
gradients. Following the track height, the track must be split in segments giving for 

--- Document Chunk 4968 ---
each segment a gradient value. 

--- Document Chunk 4969 ---
3.11.12.5 It shall be possible via balise groups to send to the on -board equipment a default 

--- Document Chunk 4970 ---
gradient for TSR, to be used for the parts of the track not covered by the gradient 

--- Document Chunk 4971 ---
profile. 

--- Document Chunk 4972 ---
3.11.12.6 The Default Gradient for TSR stored on -board shall be valid until a new Default 

--- Document Chunk 4973 ---
Gradient for TSR is received. 

--- Document Chunk 4974 ---
3.12 Other Profiles 

--- Document Chunk 4975 ---
3.12.1 Track Conditions  

--- Document Chunk 4976 ---
3.12.1.1 The Track Condition function is used to inform the driver and/or the train of a condition 

--- Document Chunk 4977 ---
in front of the train.  

--- Document Chunk 4978 ---
3.12.1.2 A Track Condition shall be given as profile data (e.g. non -stopping area), i.e. start and 

--- Document Chunk 4979 ---
end of the data is given, or location data (e.g. change of traction system) i.e. start 

--- Document Chunk 4980 ---
location given, depending on the type of track condition.  

--- Document Chunk 4981 ---
3.12.1.2.1 The starting point of a profile type track condition shall be evaluated taking into 

--- Document Chunk 4982 ---
account the max safe front end of the train, the end of the profile taking into account 

--- Document Chunk 4983 ---
the min safe rear end of the train. Location type data shall be evaluated taking into 

--- Document Chunk 4984 ---
account the max safe front of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 4985 ---
3.12.1.2.1.1 Note: The timing of output data to control train equipment (e.g. pantograph) is 

--- Document Chunk 4986 ---
application specific. 

--- Document Chunk 4987 ---
3.12.1.2.1.2 Exception 1: The starting point of a Big  Metal Mass type track condition shall be 

--- Document Chunk 4988 ---
evaluated taking into account the max safe antenna position, the end of the profile 

--- Document Chunk 4989 ---
taking into account the min safe antenna position. 

--- Document Chunk 4990 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4991 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4992 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4993 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4994 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 4995 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 4996 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4997 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4998 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4999 ---
Page 81/204 

--- Document Chunk 5000 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5001 ---
3.12.1.2.1.3 Exception 2: The end of the Powerless section and the end of the Station Platfo rm 

--- Document Chunk 5002 ---
shall be evaluated taking into account the min safe front end of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 5003 ---
3.12.1.2.1.4 Exception 3: The start and end of a tunnel stopping area and of a sound horn track 

--- Document Chunk 5004 ---
condition shall be evaluated taking into account the estimated front end of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 5005 ---
3.12.1.3 The types of track conditions to be covered by this function are: 

--- Document Chunk 5006 ---
 Powerless section, lower pantograph (initial state: no powerless section , i.e. 

--- Document Chunk 5007 ---
pantograph not to be lowered) 

--- Document Chunk 5008 ---
 Powerless section, switch off main power switch (initial state: no powerless section, 

--- Document Chunk 5009 ---
i.e. main power switch not to be switched off) 

--- Document Chunk 5010 ---
 Air tightness (initial state: no request for air tightness) 

--- Document Chunk 5011 ---
 Sound horn (initial state: no request for sound horn) 

--- Document Chunk 5012 ---
 Non stopping area (initial state: stopping permitted) 

--- Document Chunk 5013 ---
 Tunnel stopping area (initial state: no tunnel stopping area) 

--- Document Chunk 5014 ---
 Change of traction system, switch traction system on-board, used for train capable 

--- Document Chunk 5015 ---
of handling several traction systems (initial state: no initial state – keep the current 

--- Document Chunk 5016 ---
setting) 

--- Document Chunk 5017 ---
 Change of allowed current consumption, limit current consumed by the train, used 

--- Document Chunk 5018 ---
to adapt the maximum current consumption of the train to the maximum current 

--- Document Chunk 5019 ---
allowed by the trackside (initial state: no initial state – keep the current setting) 

--- Document Chunk 5020 ---
 Big metal masses, ignore onboard integrity check alarms of balise tr ansmission. 

--- Document Chunk 5021 ---
(initial state: alarms not ignored) 

--- Document Chunk 5022 ---
 Radio hole, stop supervision of the loss of safe radio connection (initial state: loss 

--- Document Chunk 5023 ---
of safe radio connection supervised) 

--- Document Chunk 5024 ---
 Switch off regenerative brake (initial state: regenerative brake on) 

--- Document Chunk 5025 ---
 Switch off eddy current brake for service brake (initial state: eddy current brake on 

--- Document Chunk 5026 ---
for service brake) 

--- Document Chunk 5027 ---
 Switch off eddy current brake for emergency brake (initial state: eddy current brake 

--- Document Chunk 5028 ---
on for emergency brake) 

--- Document Chunk 5029 ---
 Switch off magnetic shoe brake (initial state: magnetic shoe brake on). 

--- Document Chunk 5030 ---
 Station platform, enable passenger doors with or without steps according to 

--- Document Chunk 5031 ---
platform location, side and height (initial state: no platform, i.e. passenger doors 

--- Document Chunk 5032 ---
not enabled). 

--- Document Chunk 5033 ---
3.12.1.3.1 Note: In case of regenerative brake switch off or magnetic shoe br ake switch off, the 

--- Document Chunk 5034 ---
deceleration of the emergency brake might be affected if the effect of these brakes 

--- Document Chunk 5035 ---
was included in the calculation of the deceleration value. 

--- Document Chunk 5036 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 5044 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 5045 ---
Page 82/204 

--- Document Chunk 5046 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5047 ---
3.12.1.3.2 Note: In case of eddy current brake switch off the deceleration of the service brake or 

--- Document Chunk 5048 ---
emergency brake might be affected if the effect of these brakes was included in the 

--- Document Chunk 5049 ---
calculation of the deceleration value. 

--- Document Chunk 5050 ---
3.12.1.3.3 Note: in case of powerless section the deceleration of the service brake or emergency 

--- Document Chunk 5051 ---
brake might be affected if the effect of a regenerat ive brake not independent from the 

--- Document Chunk 5052 ---
presence of voltage in the catenary was included in the calculation of the deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 5053 ---
value. 

--- Document Chunk 5054 ---
3.12.1.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 5055 ---
3.12.1.5 The following actions shall be performed once a track condition has been received: 

--- Document Chunk 5056 ---
a) Indicate on DMI (see chapter 5, procedure “Indication of track conditions”) , except 

--- Document Chunk 5057 ---
“Station platform ”, “Change of allowed current consumption”  and “Big metal 

--- Document Chunk 5058 ---
masses”. 

--- Document Chunk 5059 ---
b) Send information with the remaining distance to an ERTMS/ETCS external function 

--- Document Chunk 5060 ---
(see chapter 5, procedure “G eneration of track conditions related information to an 

--- Document Chunk 5061 ---
ERTMS/ETCS external function”) , with the exception of big metal mass track 

--- Document Chunk 5062 ---
condition, sound horn track condition, non stopping area, tunnel stopping area  and 

--- Document Chunk 5063 ---
supervision of radio transmission which ar e handled inside the ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 5064 ---
board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 5065 ---
3.12.1.5.1 Note: Whether some information shall be filtered (not shown to the driver or not sent to 

--- Document Chunk 5066 ---
an ERTMS/ETCS external function) is outside the scope of ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 5067 ---
3.12.1.5.2 Note: The ERTMS/ETCS external function must be  able to handle new track condition 

--- Document Chunk 5068 ---
of the same type as previously received and covering the same distance. 

--- Document Chunk 5069 ---
3.12.1.6 The train is permitted to run without any track condition information given from the 

--- Document Chunk 5070 ---
trackside. The initial state shall then be used by the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 5071 ---
3.12.2 Route Suitability  

--- Document Chunk 5072 ---
3.12.2.1 Route suitability data defines which values concerning loading gauge, traction system 

--- Document Chunk 5073 ---
and axle load category a train must meet to be allowed to enter the route. 

--- Document Chunk 5074 ---
3.12.2.2 It shall be possible for trackside to send  route suitability dat a as location data when 

--- Document Chunk 5075 ---
needed. 

--- Document Chunk 5076 ---
3.12.2.3 On reception of route suitability data, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 5077 ---
compare it with the corresponding Train Data stored on-board. Unsuitability exists if: 

--- Document Chunk 5078 ---
a) The loading gauge profile of the train is not included in  the list of loading gauges 

--- Document Chunk 5079 ---
accepted by trackside 

--- Document Chunk 5080 ---
b) The list of traction systems  accepted by the engine does not include the one 

--- Document Chunk 5081 ---
received from trackside 

--- Document Chunk 5082 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 5083 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5084 ---

--- Document Chunk 5092 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5093 ---
c) The axle load category of the train is higher than the permitted one received from 

--- Document Chunk 5094 ---
trackside 

--- Document Chunk 5095 ---
3.12.2.4 If at least one unsuitability exists, the closest location corresponding to the 

--- Document Chunk 5096 ---
unsuitability(ies) shall be considered as both the EOA and SvL (instead of the 

--- Document Chunk 5097 ---
EOA/LOA and the SvL (if any) derived from  the MA), with no Release Speed. The 

--- Document Chunk 5098 ---
driver shall be informed about all unsuitabilities.

--- Document Chunk 5104 ---
incompatibility occurs, it shall be tripped. 

--- Document Chunk 5105 ---
3.12.2.9 The Train Data concerning route suitability is part of the Train Data sent to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 5106 ---
3.12.2.9.1 Note: This allows for route suitability supervision to be used in systems external to the 

--- Document Chunk 5107 ---
ERTMS/ETCS system. 

--- Document Chunk 5108 ---
3.12.2.10 The train is permitted to run without any route suitability data g iven from the track. No 

--- Document Chunk 5109 ---
default values shall be used or supervised by the on -board equipment, i.e. the initial 

--- Document Chunk 5110 ---
state is that no restrictions related to route suitability exists.

3.12.3 Text Transmission 

--- Document Chunk 5112 ---
3.12.3.1 General Rules  

--- Document Chunk 5113 ---
3.12.3.1.1 It shall be possible to transmit information to be displayed to the driver from the 

--- Document Chunk 5114 ---
trackside to the on-board equipment in the form of text messages.  

--- Document Chunk 5115 ---
3.12.3.1.2 Text messages shall always be supplemented by conditions on when and where they 

--- Document Chunk 5116 ---
are to be displayed, and whether any acknowledgement is requested from  the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 5117 ---
These parameters shall be transmitted individually for each message.  

--- Document Chunk 5118 ---
3.12.3.1.3 Text messages and the supplementary information shall always be transmitted in one 

--- Document Chunk 5119 ---
message.  

--- Document Chunk 5120 ---
3.12.3.1.4 It shall be possible to send  the text to be displayed in plain text or to send a number 

--- Document Chunk 5121 ---
selecting a fixed message. 

--- Document Chunk 5122 ---
3.12.3.1.4.1 Note: In case of plain text messages the trackside selects the language in which the 

--- Document Chunk 5123 ---
message is displayed. 

--- Document Chunk 5124 ---

3.12.3.4 Conditions for Start/End of Indication 

--- Document Chunk 5159 ---
3.12.3.4.1 It shall be possible to specify individual events for start/end condition of indication.   

--- Document Chunk 5160 ---
3.12.3.4.2 The following events can be used to define the start condition:  

--- Document Chunk 5161 ---
 Location  

--- Document Chunk 5162 ---
 Mode (start display as soon as in mode)  

--- Document Chunk 5163 ---
 Level (start display as soon as in level)  

--- Document Chunk 5164 ---
3.12.3.4.3 The following events can be used to define the end condition: 

--- Document Chunk 5165 ---
 Location  

--- Document Chunk 5166 ---
 Time 

--- Document Chunk 5167 ---
 Mode (stop display when leaving mode) 

--- Document Chunk 5168 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 5172 ---

--- Document Chunk 5173 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 5174 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 5175 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 5176 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 5177 ---
Page 85/204 

--- Document Chunk 5178 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5179 ---
 Level (stop display when leaving level) 

--- Document Chunk 5180 ---
3.12.3.4.3.1 It shall be possible to define whether one or all of the events used from the list in 

--- Document Chunk 5181 ---
3.12.3.4.2/3.12.3.4.3 have to be fulfilled to define the start/end condition. This 

--- Document Chunk 5182 ---
definition shall apply to both start and end conditions checked by the on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 5183 ---
3.12.3.4.3.2 In case a confirmation of the text message is requested, it shall be possible to 

--- Document Chunk 5184 ---
define whether the driver acknowledgement is considered: 

--- Document Chunk 5185 ---
a) As always ending the text display, regardless of the end condition defined in 

--- Document Chunk 5186 ---
3.12.3.4.3.1 

--- Document Chunk 5187 ---
b) As a necessary condition to end the text display, in addition to the end condition 

--- Document Chunk 5188 ---
defined in 3.12.3.4.3.1. 

--- Document Chunk 5189 ---
3.12.3.4.4 The end condition shall be  evaluated as soon as the start condition is fulfilled. No 

--- Document Chunk 5190 ---
display shall take place if the end condition is immediately fulfilled. 

--- Document Chunk 5191 ---
3.12.3.4.5 Once the text message is displayed and the end condition is fulfilled, the start condition 

--- Document Chunk 5192 ---
shall not be re-evaluated. 

--- Document Chunk 5193 ---
3.12.3.4.6 When the end event "location" is used, the length on which the text is displayed shall 

--- Document Chunk 5194 ---
refer to the location used for the start condition, independently from other start events. 

--- Document Chunk 5195 ---
3.12.3.4.7 In case a confirmation of the text message is requested, i t shall be possible to defi ne 

--- Document Chunk 5196 ---
whether the service brake or emergency brake application shall be commanded if the 

--- Document Chunk 5197 ---
driver does not acknowledge before the end condition is fulfilled. 

--- Document Chunk 5198 ---
3.12.3.4.7.1 If the driver does not acknowledge before the end condition is fulfilled, the text 

--- Document Chunk 5199 ---
message shall remain displayed until acknowledged by driver. 

--- Document Chunk 5200 ---
3.12.3.4.7.2 If the driver acknowledges before the end condition is fulfilled, the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 5201 ---
equipment shall consider the driver acknowledgement as requested by trackside (see 

--- Document Chunk 5202 ---
3.12.3.4.3.2). 

--- Document Chunk 5203 ---
3.12.3.4.8 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 5204 ---

--- Document Chunk 5206 ---

--- Document Chunk 5207 ---

--- Document Chunk 5208 ---

--- Document Chunk 5209 ---
acknowledgement, the driver acknowledgement  report, including the text message 

--- Document Chunk 5210 ---
identifier, shall be sent to the RBC referenced in the request. 

--- Document Chunk 5211 ---
3.12.3.5.3 A new text message with request for report of driver acknowledgement shall be 

--- Document Chunk 5212 ---
rejected by the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment if it has the same text message 

--- Document Chunk 5213 ---

--- Document Chunk 5226 ---
3.12.4 Mode profile  

--- Document Chunk 5227 ---
3.12.4.1 It shall be possible for trackside to send a Mode Profile. The Mode Profile can request 

--- Document Chunk 5228 ---
On Sight mode, Limited Supervision mode and Shunting mode. 

--- Document Chunk 5229 ---
3.12.4.2 For OS and LS mode the mode profile define s the entry and the length of the On 

--- Document Chunk 5230 ---
Sight/Limited Supervision area. For SH mode the mode profile only defines the entry 

--- Document Chunk 5231 ---
location to SH mode, any length given shall be ignored by the on-board.  

--- Document Chunk 5232 ---
3.12.4.3 On reception of a new MA (with or without Mode Profile) the on-board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 5233 ---
delete the currently supervised Mode Profile. 

--- Document Chunk 5234 ---
3.12.4.3.1 Exception: When receiving a new MA by infill, any currently supervised Mode Profile 

--- Document Chunk 5235 ---
shall be deleted only beyond the reference location of the infill information. 

--- Document Chunk 5236 ---
3.12.4.4 In case the mode profile information for shunting is overwritten by a new shunting 

--- Document Chunk 5237 ---
profile, before the on -board equipment switches to SH mode, a previous list of balise 

--- Document Chunk 5238 ---
groups for SH area shall be deleted or replaced by a new list of balise groups  for SH 

--- Document Chunk 5239 ---
area. 

--- Document Chunk 5240 ---
3.12.4.5 The beginning of the Mode Profile relates to the max safe front end of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 5241 ---
3.12.4.6 The end of the mode profile relates to the min safe front end of the tra in. 

--- Document Chunk 5242 ---
3.12.5 Level Crossings 

--- Document Chunk 5243 ---
3.12.5.1 It shall be possible for trackside to inform the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 5244 ---
about the conditions under which a Level Crossing (LX) must be passed. 

--- Document Chunk 5245 ---
3.12.5.2 Each Level Crossing shall have an identity, so that all LX information is independent of 

--- Document Chunk 5246 ---
each other. This means that an individual LX information cannot affect, nor be affected 

--- Document Chunk 5247 ---
by, any other individual LX information. 

--- Document Chunk 5248 ---
3.12.5.3 If the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment receives a new LX information with the same 

--- Document Chunk 5249 ---
identity as an already received LX informat ion, the new LX information shall replace 

--- Document Chunk 5250 ---
the previous one. 

--- Document Chunk 5251 ---
3.12.5.4 Level Crossing information shall be given as profile data, corresponding to the LX  start 

--- Document Chunk 5252 ---
location and the length of the LX area. 

--- Document Chunk 5253 ---
3.12.5.5 Level Crossing information shall indicate whether the LX is protected or not. 

--- Document Chunk 5254 ---
3.12.5.6 In case the LX is not protected, ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall be informed: 

--- Document Chunk 5255 ---
a) at which speed the LX is allowed to be passed 

--- Document Chunk 5256 ---
b) whether the stopping of the train in rear of the LX start location is required or not 

--- Document Chunk 5257 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 5258 ---

the LX start location shall be defined. 

--- Document Chunk 5270 ---
3.13 Speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 5271 ---
3.13.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 5272 ---
3.13.1.1 The speed and distance monitoring is the supervision of the speed of the train versus 

--- Document Chunk 5273 ---
its position, in order to ass ure that the train remains within the given speed and 

--- Document Chunk 5274 ---
distance limits. 

--- Document Chunk 5275 ---
3.13.1.1.1 Note: The speed and distance monitoring of the on -board can only assure this when 

--- Document Chunk 5276 ---
the following necessary conditions are fulfilled: 

--- Document Chunk 5277 ---
 Brake system of the train functions as specified 

--- Document Chunk 5278 ---
 wheel/rail adhesion is sufficient for the required safe deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 5279 ---
 Brake characteristics (and other Train related inputs) are correctly entered into the 

--- Document Chunk 5280 ---
on-board 

--- Document Chunk 5281 ---
3.13.1.2 Note: The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment triggers brake commands and revokes 

--- Document Chunk 5282 ---
them, it may also re ceive status information if the brakes are applied or released. 

--- Document Chunk 5283 ---
However, it cannot be made responsible if brake control circuits outside the equipment 

--- Document Chunk 5284 ---
fail. Also the way the brakes are released by the driver after a revocation of a brake 

--- Document Chunk 5285 ---
command is an implementation issue. 

--- Document Chunk 5286 ---
3.13.1.3 Figure 28 gives an overview of the main elements contributing to the speed and 

--- Document Chunk 5287 ---
distance monitoring. These elements (inputs, functions and outputs) are detailed in the 

--- Document Chunk 5288 ---
following chapters. 

--- Document Chunk 5289 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 5290 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5291 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5292 ---

Figure 28: Speed and distance monitoring overview 

--- Document Chunk 5428 ---
3.13.1.4 Throughout the following sections, all the distances marked with “d” (lower case), 

--- Document Chunk 5429 ---
which are referred in parameters, formulas and figures, are counted from the current 

--- Document Chunk 5430 ---
reference location of the on-board equipment (e.g. the LRBG). 

--- Document Chunk 5431 ---
3.13.2 Inputs for speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 5432 ---
3.13.2.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 5433 ---
3.13.2.1.1 The traction / braking models, the brake position / brake percentage are used for the 

--- Document Chunk 5434 ---
definition of the kinematic behaviour of the train after a servi ce brake command or an 

--- Document Chunk 5435 ---
emergency brake command has been initiated. 

--- Document Chunk 5436 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 5437 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5438 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5439 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 5440 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 5441 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 5442 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 5443 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 5444 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 5445 ---
Page 89/204 

--- Document Chunk 5446 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5447 ---
3.13.2.1.2 However, railway brakes have a statistical behaviour and braking distances vary within 

--- Document Chunk 5448 ---
the typical distribution for a given condition. Correction factors are therefore 

--- Document Chunk 5449 ---
incorporated for the speed and distance monitoring. 

--- Document Chunk 5450 ---
3.13.2.1.3 The correction factors will allow obtaining, from the nominal emergency braking 

--- Document Chunk 5451 ---
performance of the train, the minimum emergency braking performances that are 

--- Document Chunk 5452 ---
required for reference conditions set by trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 5453 ---
3.13.2.2 Train related inputs 

--- Document Chunk 5454 ---
3.13.2.2.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 5455 ---
3.13.2.2.1.1 The train related inputs to be considered for the speed and distance monitoring are: 

--- Document Chunk 5456 ---
a) Traction model 

--- Document Chunk 5457 ---
b) Braking models (brake build up time and speed dependent deceleration) or brake 

--- Document Chunk 5458 ---
percentage 

--- Document Chunk 5459 ---
c) Brake position 

--- Document Chunk 5460 ---
d) Special brakes (interface configuration and status) 

--- Document Chunk 5461 ---
e) Service brake (interface configuration and application) 

--- Document Chunk 5462 ---
f) Traction cut-off interface 

--- Document Chunk 5463 ---
g) On-board correction factors 

--- Document Chunk 5464 ---
h) Nominal rotating mass 

--- Document Chunk 5465 ---
i) Train length 

--- Document Chunk 5466 ---
j) Fixed values related to speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 5467 ---
k)  Train related speed restriction (i.e. the maximum train speed) 

--- Document Chunk 5468 ---
3.13.2.2.1.2 These train related inputs are acquired as Train Data (see 3.18.3.2 items b) c) and 

--- Document Chunk 5469 ---
d)), except: 

--- Document Chunk 5470 ---
 the configuration of the special brakes, service brake and traction cut -off interfaces 

--- Document Chunk 5471 ---
which are not affected by the Train Data acquisition, 

--- Document Chunk 5472 ---
 the service brake application and the special brakes statuses which are 

--- Document Chunk 5473 ---
continuously acquired on the Train Interface, 

--- Document Chunk 5474 ---
 the fixed values. 

--- Document Chunk 5475 ---
3.13.2.2.1.3 The speed and distance monitoring shall use braking models acquired as Train 

--- Document Chunk 5476 ---
Data, unless the brake percentage is acquired as Train Data and the conversion model 

--- Document Chunk 5477 ---
is applicable (see 3.13.3.2 for its validity limits). 

--- Document Chunk 5478 ---

--- Document Chunk 5479 ---

--- Document Chunk 5480 ---
shall describe the time delay T_traction_cut_off from the traction cut -off command by 

--- Document Chunk 5481 ---

--- Document Chunk 5492 ---
the on -board (t0) to the moment the acceleration due to traction (A_traction) is 

--- Document Chunk 5493 ---
guaranteed to be zero (t1). The estimated acceleration value of the train shall be 

--- Document Chunk 5494 ---
considered during this time delay.
