3.13.2.2.2.2 Note: The current value of A_traction is not known directly by the on -board. It is 

--- Document Chunk 5503 ---
implicitly known as a contribution to the estimated acceleration, together with the 

--- Document Chunk 5504 ---
acceleration due to gradient. 

--- Document Chunk 5505 ---
3.13.2.2.3 Braking Models 

--- Document Chunk 5506 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1 Speed Dependent Deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 5507 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.1 The deceleration due to braking shall be given as a step function of the speed. 

--- Document Chunk 5508 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.2 It shall be possible to define up to seven steps for each speed dependent 

--- Document Chunk 5509 ---
deceleration model. 

--- Document Chunk 5510 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.3 Note: An example with 4 steps is given in Figure 30. A_brake(V) is calculated as 

--- Document Chunk 5511 ---
follows: 

--- Document Chunk 5512 ---
 A_brake = AD_0  when 0 ≤ speed ≤ V1 

--- Document Chunk 5513 ---
 A_brake = AD_1  when V1 < speed ≤ V2 

--- Document Chunk 5514 ---
 A_brake = AD_2  when V2 < speed ≤ V3 

--- Document Chunk 5515 ---
 A_brake = AD_3  when V3 < speed 

--- Document Chunk 5516 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5517 ---
0 

--- Document Chunk 5518 ---
A_brake 

--- Document Chunk 5519 ---
AD_0 

--- Document Chunk 5520 ---
AD_2 

--- Document Chunk 5521 ---
AD_1 

--- Document Chunk 5522 ---
V1 V2 V3 speed 

--- Document Chunk 5523 ---
AD_3 

--- Document Chunk 5524 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5525 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 5526 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5527 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5528 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 5529 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 5530 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 5531 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 5532 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 5533 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 5534 ---
Page 91/204 

--- Document Chunk 5535 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5536 ---
Figure 30: Speed Dependent Deceleration Model 

--- Document Chunk 5537 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.4 The last step o f A_brake(V) shall by definition be considered as open ended, i.e. it 

--- Document Chunk 5538 ---
has no upper speed limit. 

--- Document Chunk 5539 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.5 The model shall be applicable only after full build up of the braking effort (see a_full 

--- Document Chunk 5540 ---
in Figure 31) 

--- Document Chunk 5541 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.6 The model shall be used for the  emergency brake nominal deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 5542 ---
(A_brake_emergency(V)), for the full service brake deceleration (A_brake_service(V)) 

--- Document Chunk 5543 ---
and for the normal service brake deceleration (A_brake_normal_service(V)). 

--- Document Chunk 5544 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.7 It shall be possible to define individual speed dependent deceleration models of 

--- Document Chunk 5545 ---
A_brake_emergency(V) and A_brake_service(V)  for each combination of use of 

--- Document Chunk 5546 ---
regenerative brake, eddy current brake and magnetic shoe brake. 

--- Document Chunk 5547 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.8 Note: Individual deceleration models may be equal, thereby avoiding the influence 

--- Document Chunk 5548 ---
of a specifi c brake on A_brake_emergency(V) or A_brake_service(V). However, the 

--- Document Chunk 5549 ---
choice to take into account or not the contribution of a specific brake for 

--- Document Chunk 5550 ---
A_brake_emergency(V) or A_brake_service(V) is only rolling stock dependent, not an 

--- Document Chunk 5551 ---
ETCS implementation issue. 

--- Document Chunk 5552 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.9 It shall be possible to define up to two sets of three models of 

--- Document Chunk 5553 ---
A_brake_normal_service(V): 

--- Document Chunk 5554 ---
a) one set applicable when the brake position is in “Freight train in G” 

--- Document Chunk 5555 ---
b) one set applicable when the brake position is in “Passenger train in P” or “Freight 

--- Document Chunk 5556 ---
train in P” 

--- Document Chunk 5557 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.10 A set of A_brake_normal_service(V) shall be defined as a function of the full 

--- Document Chunk 5558 ---
service brake deceleration at zero speed, A_brake_service(V=0): 

--- Document Chunk 5559 ---
If A_brake_service(V = 0)  A_SB01 

--- Document Chunk 5560 ---
A_brake_normal_service(V) = A_brake_normal_service_0(V) 

--- Document Chunk 5561 ---
if A_SB01 < A_brake_service(V = 0)  A_SB12 

--- Document Chunk 5562 ---
A_brake_normal_service(V) = A_brake_normal_service_1(V) 

--- Document Chunk 5563 ---
if A_SB12 < A_brake_service (V = 0) 

--- Document Chunk 5564 ---
A_brake_normal_service(V) = A_brake_normal_service_2(V) 

--- Document Chunk 5565 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.11 Note: the two pivot values A_SB01 and A_SB12 are part of the 

--- Document Chunk 5566 ---
A_brake_normal_service model, i.e. they are train related input data for the speed and 

--- Document Chunk 5567 ---
distance monitoring function. 

--- Document Chunk 5568 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2 Brake build up time 

--- Document Chunk 5569 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 5570 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5571 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5572 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 5573 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 5574 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 5575 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 5576 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 5577 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 5578 ---
Page 92/204 

--- Document Chunk 5579 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5580 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.1 The deceleration A_brake is not available immediately after the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 5581 ---
commands the brake. There is a time lag between brake command and the st art of the 

--- Document Chunk 5582 ---
brake force build-up. There is also time needed to build up the full brake force. 

--- Document Chunk 5583 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.2 The model for the brake build up time shall be given as a step function as explained 

--- Document Chunk 5584 ---
in Figure 31. 

--- Document Chunk 5585 ---
 A_brake 

--- Document Chunk 5586 ---
95% 

--- Document Chunk 5587 ---
a_full 

--- Document Chunk 5588 ---
t3 t2 t1 t0 time 

--- Document Chunk 5589 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5590 ---
Figure 31: Brake Build Up Time Model 

--- Document Chunk 5591 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.3 In Figure 31, the following time intervals are defined: 

--- Document Chunk 5592 ---
a) T_brake_react (t0…t1) is the interval between the command of the brake by the on -

--- Document Chunk 5593 ---
board and the moment the brake force starts to build up. 

--- Document Chunk 5594 ---
b) T_brake_increase (t1...t2) is the interval in which the brake force increases from the 

--- Document Chunk 5595 ---
zero to the moment when 95% of full brake power is reached. 

--- Document Chunk 5596 ---
c) T_brake_build_up (t0...t3) is the equivalent brake build up time. 

--- Document Chunk 5597 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.4 The equivalent brake build up time (T_brake_build_up) is defined as 

--- Document Chunk 5598 ---
T_brake_build_up = T_brake_react + 0.5*T_brake_increase. 

--- Document Chunk 5599 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.5 This model for T_brake_build_up shall be used for the emergency brake 

--- Document Chunk 5600 ---
(T_brake_emergency) and for the full service brake (T_brake_service). 

--- Document Chunk 5601 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.6 Note: The equivale nt brake build up time is a safe approximation. In the beginning 

--- Document Chunk 5602 ---
of the build -up time the model assumes a smaller deceleration, in the later part this is 

--- Document Chunk 5603 ---
compensated by a higher deceleration. 

--- Document Chunk 5604 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.7 Note: T_brake_react and T_brake_increase are indicated in Figure 31 for 

--- Document Chunk 5605 ---
completeness reasons; only T_brake_build_up is to be considered as an input for the 

--- Document Chunk 5606 ---
speed and distance monitoring function. 

--- Document Chunk 5607 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.8 It shall be possible to define individual values of T_brake_emergency and 

--- Document Chunk 5608 ---
T_brake_service for each  combination of use of regenerative brake, eddy current 

--- Document Chunk 5609 ---
brake, magnetic shoe brake and Ep brake. 

--- Document Chunk 5610 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 5611 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5612 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5613 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 5614 ---

--- Document Chunk 5617 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 5618 ---

--- Document Chunk 5619 ---
Page 93/204 

--- Document Chunk 5620 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5621 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.9 Note: Individual values of T_brake_emergency and T_brake_service may be equal, 

--- Document Chunk 5622 ---
thereby avoiding the influence of a specific brake. However, the choice to take into 

--- Document Chunk 5623 ---
account or not the contribution of a specific brake for T_brake_emergency and 

--- Document Chunk 5624 ---
T_brake_service is only rolling stock dependent, not an ETCS implementation issue. 

--- Document Chunk 5625 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.10 Note: In general, T_brake_emergency and T_brake_service are determined by 

--- Document Chunk 5626 ---
the pneumatic br ake therefore avoiding to take into account of the influence of the 

--- Document Chunk 5627 ---
regenerative brake, eddy current brake or magnetic shoe brake. However, if the 

--- Document Chunk 5628 ---
Electro-pneumatic brake system is used, it is possible that T_brake_emergency and 

--- Document Chunk 5629 ---
T_brake_service are determined by another special brake. 

--- Document Chunk 5630 ---
3.13.2.2.4 Brake Position 

--- Document Chunk 5631 ---
3.13.2.2.4.1 The brake position shall be set to one of the following three values: 

--- Document Chunk 5632 ---
a) Passenger train in P 

--- Document Chunk 5633 ---
b) Freight train in P 

--- Document Chunk 5634 ---
c) Freight train in G 

--- Document Chunk 5635 ---
3.13.2.2.4.2 Note: The brake position defines the behaviour of the brake for specific train types. 

--- Document Chunk 5636 ---
3.13.2.2.5 Brake Percentage 

--- Document Chunk 5637 ---
3.13.2.2.5.1 If the brake percentage is captured as Train Data and the conversion model is 

--- Document Chunk 5638 ---
applicable (see  3.13.3.2), they are used to derive A_brake _emergency(V), 

--- Document Chunk 5639 ---
A_brake_service(V), T_brake_emergency and T_brake_service. 

--- Document Chunk 5640 ---
3.13.2.2.5.2 Note: the conversion model has been designed assuming that all the provisions laid 

--- Document Chunk 5641 ---
down in the UIC leaflet 544-1 6th edition, with the exception of sections 9.1.2, 9.2.2 and 

--- Document Chunk 5642 ---
9.3.3, apply for the acquired brake percentage.

3.13.2.2.6.3 When the brake percentage is captured as Train Data and the conversion model is 

--- Document Chunk 5727 ---
applicable, A_brake_emergency(V), T_brake_emergency and A_brake_service(V) 

--- Document Chunk 5728 ---
shall not be influenced by the status of a special brake. However, the conversion 

--- Document Chunk 5729 ---
model offers the possibility that T_brake _service can be affected by the status of the 

--- Document Chunk 5730 ---
regenerative brake, eddy current brake or Ep brake (see A.3.9). 

--- Document Chunk 5731 ---
3.13.2.2.6.4 The on-board equipment shall be configured to define whether it is allowed to take 

--- Document Chunk 5732 ---
into account the contribution of a special/additional brake, which is independent from 

--- Document Chunk 5733 ---
wheel/rail adhesion, for the selection of the maximum emergency brake deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 5734 ---
under reduced adhesion conditions (see 3.13.6.2.1.6). 

--- Document Chunk 5735 ---
3.13.2.2.6.5 Note: the choice to set to “allowed” the contribution of such special/additional brake 

--- Document Chunk 5736 ---
in the selection of the maximum emergency braking effort, is rolling stock dependent. 

--- Document Chunk 5737 ---
3.13.2.2.6.6 If it is allowed to take into account the contribution of a special/additional brake, 

--- Document Chunk 5738 ---
which is independ ent from wheel/rail adhesion, the speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 5739 ---
function shall take into account the status “active” or “not active” of the 

--- Document Chunk 5740 ---
special/additional brake to select the appropriate National Value under reduced 

--- Document Chunk 5741 ---
adhesion conditions (see 3.13.2.3.7.7). 

--- Document Chunk 5742 ---
3.13.2.2.7 Service brake 

--- Document Chunk 5743 ---
3.13.2.2.7.1 The on-board shall be configured to define whether the service brake command is 

--- Document Chunk 5744 ---
implemented or not, i.e. whether a service brake interface is implemented to command 

--- Document Chunk 5745 ---
a full service brake effort. 

--- Document Chunk 5746 ---
3.13.2.2.7.2 The on-board shall be configured to define whether the service brake feedback is 

--- Document Chunk 5747 ---
implemented or not, i.e. whether it is able to acquire from the service brake interface 

--- Document Chunk 5748 ---
the information that the service brake is currently applied. 

--- Document Chunk 5749 ---
3.13.2.2.7.3 If the service brake feedback  is implemented and if not inhibited by National Value , 

--- Document Chunk 5750 ---
the speed and distance monitoring function shall take into account either the main 

--- Document Chunk 5751 ---
brake pipe pressure or the brake cylinder pressure to adjust in real time the expected 

--- Document Chunk 5752 ---
brake build up time (see 3.13.9.3.3.4 and Appendix A.3.10). 

--- Document Chunk 5753 ---
3.13.2.2.8 Traction cut-off interface 

--- Document Chunk 5754 ---
3.13.2.2.8.1 The on-board shall be configured to define whether the traction cut -off command is 

--- Document Chunk 5755 ---
implemented, i.e. whether the interface to the traction system is implemented or not. 

--- Document Chunk 5756 ---
3.13.2.2.9 On-board Correction Factors 

--- Document Chunk 5757 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1 Correction factors for the emergency deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 5758 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1.1 If the braking models are captured as Train Data, rolling stock correction factors 

--- Document Chunk 5759 ---
shall be defined in the ETCS on -board equipment. If the brake percentage is captured 

--- Document Chunk 5760 ---
as Train Data and the conversion model is used (see 3.13.3.2 for its validity limits), no 

--- Document Chunk 5761 ---
rolling stock correction factor shall apply. 

--- Document Chunk 5762 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 5763 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5764 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5765 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 5766 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 5767 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 5768 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 5769 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 5770 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 5771 ---
Page 96/204 

--- Document Chunk 5772 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5773 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1.2 For each defined individual speed dependent deceleration model of 

--- Document Chunk 5774 ---
A_brake_emergency(V) (i.e. corresponding to each combination of use of regenerative 

--- Document Chunk 5775 ---
brake, eddy current bra ke and magnetic shoe brake), one set of rolling stock 

--- Document Chunk 5776 ---
correction factors Kdry_rst(V, EBCL) and Kwet_rst(V) shall be defined in the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 5777 ---
equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 5778 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1.3 For a given confidence level on emergency brake safe deceleration (EBCL), the 

--- Document Chunk 5779 ---
rolling stock correction fa ctor Kdry_rst(V) shall be given as a step function of speed, 

--- Document Chunk 5780 ---
with the same steps as the ones of A_brake_emergency(V). 

--- Document Chunk 5781 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1.4 The confidence level on emergency brake safe deceleration represents the 

--- Document Chunk 5782 ---
probability of the following individual event: the rolling stock emergency brake 

--- Document Chunk 5783 ---
subsystem of the train does ensure a deceleration at least equal to 

--- Document Chunk 5784 ---
A_brake_emergency(V) * Kdry_rst(V), when the emergency brake is commanded on 

--- Document Chunk 5785 ---
dry rails. 

--- Document Chunk 5786 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1.5 The rolling stock correction factor Kwet_rst(V) shall be given as a step function of  

--- Document Chunk 5787 ---
speed, with the same steps as the ones of A_brake_emergency(V). It represents the 

--- Document Chunk 5788 ---
loss of deceleration with regards to emergency braking on dry rails, when the 

--- Document Chunk 5789 ---
emergency brake is commanded on wet rails, according to wheel/rail adhesion 

--- Document Chunk 5790 ---
reference conditions. 

--- Document Chunk 5791 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2 Correction factor for gradient on normal service deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 5792 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2.1 The speed dependent correction factors for gradient on the normal service brake, 

--- Document Chunk 5793 ---
Kn+(V) and Kn-(V), shall be given as step functions in the range from 0 to 10 m/s2. 

--- Document Chunk 5794 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2.2 It shall be possible to define up to five steps for Kn+(V) and for Kn-(V), respectively. 

--- Document Chunk 5795 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2.3 Note: An example with 4 steps is given in Figure 32. Kn is calculated as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 5796 ---
 Kn = Kn_0 when 0 ≤ speed ≤ V1 

--- Document Chunk 5797 ---
 Kn = Kn_1 when V1 < speed ≤ V2 

--- Document Chunk 5798 ---
 Kn = Kn_2 when V2 < speed ≤ V3 

--- Document Chunk 5799 ---
 Kn = Kn_3 when V3 < speed 

--- Document Chunk 5800 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 5801 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5802 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5803 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 5804 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 5805 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 5806 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 5807 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 5808 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 5809 ---
Page 97/204 

--- Document Chunk 5810 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5811 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5812 ---
V3 V2 V1 speed 

--- Document Chunk 5813 ---
Kn 

--- Document Chunk 5814 ---
Kn_1 

--- Document Chunk 5815 ---
Kn_0 

--- Document Chunk 5816 ---
Kn_2 

--- Document Chunk 5817 ---
Kn_3 

--- Document Chunk 5818 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5819 ---
Figure 32  Speed dependent correction factor for normal service brake (Kn) 

--- Document Chunk 5820 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2.4 Kn+(V) shall be applicable for positive gradients. 

--- Document Chunk 5821 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2.5 Kn-(V) shall be applicable for negative gradients. 

--- Document Chunk 5822 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2.6 The last step of the Kn+(V) or Kn -(V) shall by definition be considered as open 

--- Document Chunk 5823 ---
ended, i.e. it has no upper speed limit. 

--- Document Chunk 5824 ---
3.13.2.2.10 Nominal Rotating mass 

--- Document Chunk 5825 ---
3.13.2.2.10.1 It shall be possible to define the nominal rotating mass to be used for compensating 

--- Document Chunk 5826 ---
the gradient, instead of the two related fixed values defined in A.3.1. 

--- Document Chunk 5827 ---
3.13.2.2.11 Train length 

--- Document Chunk 5828 ---
3.13.2.2.11.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into account the train length acquired 

--- Document Chunk 5829 ---
as part of Train Data (see section 3.18.3). 

--- Document Chunk 5830 ---
3.13.2.2.12 Fixed values 

--- Document Chunk 5831 ---
3.13.2.2.12.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into a ccount the fixed values defined 

--- Document Chunk 5832 ---
in A.3.1 that are related to speed and distance monitoring. 

--- Document Chunk 5833 ---
3.13.2.2.13 Maximum train speed 

--- Document Chunk 5834 ---
3.13.2.2.13.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into account the maximum train 

--- Document Chunk 5835 ---
speed defined as part of Train Data (see section 3.18.3). 

--- Document Chunk 5836 ---

--- Document Chunk 5837 ---

--- Document Chunk 5838 ---

--- Document Chunk 5839 ---
are: 

--- Document Chunk 5840 ---
a) Trackside related speed restrictions 

--- Document Chunk 5841 ---
b) Gradients 

--- Document Chunk 5842 ---

--- Document Chunk 5860 ---

--- Document Chunk 5861 ---
maximum train speed. 

--- Document Chunk 5862 ---

--- Document Chunk 5863 ---

--- Document Chunk 5864 ---
the default gradient for TSR (see section 3.11.12). 

--- Document Chunk 5865 ---

--- Document Chunk 5866 ---

--- Document Chunk 5867 ---
track condition received from trackside (see section 3.12.1) : powerless section,  

--- Document Chunk 5868 ---
inhibition of regenerative brake, eddy current brake and magnetic shoe brake. 

--- Document Chunk 5869 ---
3.13.2.3.5 Reduced adhesion conditions 

--- Document Chunk 5870 ---
3.13.2.3.5.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into account the track reduced 

--- Document Chunk 5871 ---
adhesion received from trackside or selected by the driver (see section 3.18.4.6). 

--- Document Chunk 5872 ---
3.13.2.3.6 Specific speed / distance limits 

--- Document Chunk 5873 ---
3.13.2.3.6.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into account the following limits: 

--- Document Chunk 5874 ---
a) the Limit of Authority (LOA), the End of Authority (EOA), the Supervised Location 

--- Document Chunk 5875 ---
(SvL) and its associated release speed, if any. 

--- Document Chunk 5876 ---
b) the maximum permitted distance to run in Staff Responsible 

--- Document Chunk 5877 ---
3.13.2.3.7 National Values for speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 5878 ---
3.13.2.3.7.1 It shall be possible by means of a National Value to inhibit the use of the service 

--- Document Chunk 5879 ---
brake command in target speed monitoring. 

--- Document Chunk 5880 ---
3.13.2.3.7.2 It shall be possible to state by means of a National Value whether an emergency 

--- Document Chunk 5881 ---
brake command has to be revoked, both in cei ling speed and target speed monitoring, 

--- Document Chunk 5882 ---
when: 

--- Document Chunk 5883 ---
a) the Permitted Speed supervision limit is no longer exceeded, or 

--- Document Chunk 5884 ---
b) the train is at standstill. 

--- Document Chunk 5885 ---

--- Document Chunk 5900 ---

--- Document Chunk 5901 ---

--- Document Chunk 5902 ---

--- Document Chunk 5903 ---

--- Document Chunk 5904 ---
equipment the available wheel/rail adhesion, weighted between the wheel/rail adhesion 

--- Document Chunk 5905 ---
for dry rails and the wheel/rail adhesion for wet rails according to reference conditions. 

--- Document Chunk 5906 ---
3.13.2.3.7.7 In order to adapt to the train behaviour under reduced adhesion conditions, it shall 

--- Document Chunk 5907 ---
be possible by means of National Values either to limit to a maximum value the speed 

--- Document Chunk 5908 ---
dependent deceleration for the emergency bra ke when the reduced adhesion 

--- Document Chunk 5909 ---
conditions are known to ETCS (see 3.13.2.3.5) or to request supplementary DMI 

--- Document Chunk 5910 ---
information assisting further the driver in ceiling speed monitoring . Three values shall 

--- Document Chunk 5911 ---
be applicable for a given combination of the brake position and of the type of brakes: 

--- Document Chunk 5912 ---
a) the first value shall be used for “Passe nger train in P” with special/additional brakes 

--- Document Chunk 5913 ---
independent from wheel/rail adhesion; 

--- Document Chunk 5914 ---
b) the second value shall be used for “Passenger train in P” without special/additional 

--- Document Chunk 5915 ---
brakes independent from wheel/rail adhesion; 

--- Document Chunk 5916 ---
c) the third value shall be used for “Freight train in P” or “Freight train in G”. 

--- Document Chunk 5917 ---
3.13.2.3.7.8 It shall be possible by means of a National Value to specify a release speed. 

--- Document Chunk 5918 ---
3.13.2.3.7.9 It shall be possible by means of a National Value to inhibit the compen sation of the 

--- Document Chunk 5919 ---
speed measurement inaccuracy. 

--- Document Chunk 5920 ---
3.13.2.3.7.10 It shall be possible by means of National Values to define integrated correction 

--- Document Chunk 5921 ---
factors, namely Kv_int(V), Kr_int(l) and Kt_int. The integrated correction factors only 

--- Document Chunk 5922 ---
apply to the on-board equipment when the conversion model is used. 

--- Document Chunk 5923 ---

--- Document Chunk 5925 ---

--- Document Chunk 5926 ---
follows:

--- Document Chunk 5928 ---

--- Document Chunk 5929 ---
 Kv_int = Kv_int_2 when V2 < speed ≤ V3 

--- Document Chunk 5930 ---
 Kv_int = Kv_int_3 when V3 < speed

--- Document Chunk 5964 ---

--- Document Chunk 5997 ---
3.13.3 Conversion Models 

--- Document Chunk 5998 ---
3.13.3.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 5999 ---
3.13.3.1.1 For trains with variable composition (loco hauled trains), the brake characteristics can 

--- Document Chunk 6000 ---
vary together with the composition of the train. In this case, it is not convenient to pre -

--- Document Chunk 6001 ---
program the brake parameters necessary to calculate the braking curves. The only 

--- Document Chunk 6002 ---
practical way to obtain the correct values for the current train composition is to include 

--- Document Chunk 6003 ---
them into the data entry process by the driver. However, it cannot be expected from 

--- Document Chunk 6004 ---
the driver to know deceleration values and brake build up times. Conversion models 

--- Document Chunk 6005 ---
are therefore defined to convert the parameters entered by the driver (brake 

--- Document Chunk 6006 ---
percentage and brake position) into the parameters of the corresponding brake model. 

--- Document Chunk 6007 ---
3.13.3.1.2 Note: The process for defining the input parameters for the conversion model (brake 

--- Document Chunk 6008 ---
percentage and brake position) is outside the scope of the ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 6009 ---
specifications. 

--- Document Chunk 6010 ---
3.13.3.2 Applicability of the conversion models 

--- Document Chunk 6011 ---
3.13.3.2.1 The conversion models shall be used by the on -board equipment if the brake 

--- Document Chunk 6012 ---
percentage is acquired as part of Train Data, and if the maximum train speed, the 

--- Document Chunk 6013 ---
brake percentage and the train length are all within the following validity limi ts of the 

--- Document Chunk 6014 ---
conversion models: 

--- Document Chunk 6015 ---
a) 0 ≤ V ≤ 200, where V is the maximum train speed in km/h 

--- Document Chunk 6016 ---
b) 30 ≤ λ ≤ 250, where λ is the brake percentage in % 

--- Document Chunk 6017 ---
c) 0 ≤ L ≤ Lmax, where L is the train length in m  and where Lmax = 900 m if the brake 

--- Document Chunk 6018 ---
position is “Passenger train in P” or  Lmax = 1500 m if the brake position is “Freight 

--- Document Chunk 6019 ---
train in P” or “Freight train in G” 

--- Document Chunk 6020 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6021 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6022 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6023 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6024 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 6025 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 6026 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6027 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6028 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6029 ---
Page 102/204 

--- Document Chunk 6030 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6031 ---
3.13.3.2.1.1 Note: The overspeed above the maximum train speed which may occur due to the 

--- Document Chunk 6032 ---
ceiling speed margins is taken into account in the definition of the conversion model. 

--- Document Chunk 6033 ---
3.13.3.2.2 For trains not fitting into at least one of those validity limits, it is still possible to acquire 

--- Document Chunk 6034 ---
the brake percentage as Train Data, but the conversion models are not applicable, 

--- Document Chunk 6035 ---
which means that braking models (i.e. pre -programmed deceleration profiles and 

--- Document Chunk 6036 ---
brake build up times) shall be used by the speed and distance monitoring function. 

--- Document Chunk 6037 ---
3.13.3.3 Brake percentage conversion model 

--- Document Chunk 6038 ---
3.13.3.3.1 Input parameters 

--- Document Chunk 6039 ---
3.13.3.3.1.1 The input for the model shall be the brake percentage of the train as defined in 

--- Document Chunk 6040 ---
3.13.2.2.5. 

--- Document Chunk 6041 ---
3.13.3.3.2 Calculation of the basic deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 6042 ---
3.13.3.3.2.1 The basic deceleration A_basic(V) shall be given as a step function of the speed 

--- Document Chunk 6043 ---
using the algorithm defined in Appendix A.3.7. 

--- Document Chunk 6044 ---
3.13.3.3.3 Output parameters 

--- Document Chunk 6045 ---
3.13.3.3.3.1 The output of the brake percentage conversion model shall consist of two sp eed 

--- Document Chunk 6046 ---
dependent deceleration brake models, A_brake_emergency(V) for the emergency 

--- Document Chunk 6047 ---
brake and A_brake_service(V) for the service brake. 

--- Document Chunk 6048 ---
3.13.3.4 Brake position conversion model 

--- Document Chunk 6049 ---
3.13.3.4.1 Input parameters 

--- Document Chunk 6050 ---
3.13.3.4.1.1 The input for the model shall consist of the brake position of the train as  defined in 

--- Document Chunk 6051 ---
3.13.2.2.4, the train length and the target speed. 

--- Document Chunk 6052 ---
3.13.3.4.2 Calculation of the emergency brake equivalent time 

--- Document Chunk 6053 ---
3.13.3.4.2.1 The equivalent brake build up time for the emergency brake shall be determined as 

--- Document Chunk 6054 ---
specified in Appendix A.3.8. 

--- Document Chunk 6055 ---
3.13.3.4.3 Calculation of the full service brake equivalent time 

--- Document Chunk 6056 ---
3.13.3.4.3.1 The equivalent brake build up time for the full service brake shall be determined as 

--- Document Chunk 6057 ---
specified in Appendix A.3.9. 

--- Document Chunk 6058 ---
3.13.3.4.4 Output parameters 

--- Document Chunk 6059 ---
3.13.3.4.4.1 The outputs of the brake position conversion model shall consist of: 

--- Document Chunk 6060 ---
a) two values of the equivalent brake build up time to be used when the target speed 

--- Document Chunk 6061 ---
(V_target) is equal to zero, one value for the emergency brake and one for the full 

--- Document Chunk 6062 ---
service brake: 

--- Document Chunk 6063 ---
T_brake_emergency_cm0 as defined for emergency brake in A.3.8 

--- Document Chunk 6064 ---

3.13.4 Acceleration / Deceleration due to gradient 

--- Document Chunk 6082 ---

--- Document Chunk 6083 ---

--- Document Chunk 6084 ---

--- Document Chunk 6085 ---
b) in value according to the rotating mass as defined in 3.13.4.3 in order to derive the 

--- Document Chunk 6086 ---
corresponding acceleration/deceleration.

3.13.4.1.2 The default gradient for TSR shall be compensated in value according to the rotating 

--- Document Chunk 6145 ---
mass as defined in 3.13.4.3. 

--- Document Chunk 6146 ---
3.13.4.1.3 For all loca tions not covered by the gradient profile, the on -board shall consider the 

--- Document Chunk 6147 ---
gradient value as: 

--- Document Chunk 6148 ---
a) the default gradient for TSR, if available and if the concerned target is due to a TSR 

--- Document Chunk 6149 ---
b) zero, for other cases. 

--- Document Chunk 6150 ---
3.13.4.2 Train length compensation 

--- Document Chunk 6151 ---
3.13.4.2.1 Assuming that a fictive tr ain front end would be at any location between the current 

--- Document Chunk 6152 ---
(actual) train front end location and the SvL, the acceleration due to the gradient shall 

--- Document Chunk 6153 ---
be determined using the lowest (taking the sign into account) gradient value given by 

--- Document Chunk 6154 ---
the gradient profile between the location of the fictive train front end and the location of 

--- Document Chunk 6155 ---
the fictive train rear end (see Figure 35). 

--- Document Chunk 6156 ---
3.13.4.3 Rotating mass 

--- Document Chunk 6157 ---
3.13.4.3.1 The influence of gradients shall be compensated for the rotating mass of the train (see 

--- Document Chunk 6158 ---
Figure 35). 

--- Document Chunk 6159 ---
3.13.4.3.1.1 Note: Since the rotating mass works like a flywheel (rotating inertia), the effect of 

--- Document Chunk 6160 ---
the gradient is reduced. Assume for instance a (theoretical) train without any rotating 

--- Document Chunk 6161 ---
mass, not braking, on a downhill gradient from height 1 to height 2. All the energy 

--- Document Chunk 6162 ---
added to the train when it goes from H1 to H2 is converted into linear forward motion. 

--- Document Chunk 6163 ---
This can be observed as an acceleration due to the gradient. Now assume the same 

--- Document Chunk 6164 ---
train with part of the weight rotating. If this train travel s the same distance from H1 to 

--- Document Chunk 6165 ---
H2, the same amount of energy is added to the train. But now a part of that energy is 

--- Document Chunk 6166 ---
converted into rotational motion and only the remaining part is converted into linear 

--- Document Chunk 6167 ---
forward motion. The latter can be observed as an acce leration which is less than for 

--- Document Chunk 6168 ---
the train without rotating mass. 

--- Document Chunk 6169 ---
3.13.4.3.1.2 Note: For the influence of the rotating mass on the deceleration due to the brake, it 

--- Document Chunk 6170 ---
is already taken into account in the values for the brake parameters. 

--- Document Chunk 6171 ---
3.13.4.3.2 The following formulas shall be used: 

--- Document Chunk 6172 ---
a) If M_rotating_nom is unknown: 

--- Document Chunk 6173 ---
 Uphill: A_gradient = g * grad / (1000+10*M_rotating_max) 

--- Document Chunk 6174 ---
 Downhill: A_gradient = g * grad / (1000+10*M_rotating_min) 

--- Document Chunk 6175 ---
b) If M_rotating_nom is known: 

--- Document Chunk 6176 ---
 Uphill: A_gradient = g * grad / (1000+10*M_rotating_nom) 

--- Document Chunk 6177 ---
 Downhill: A_gradient = g * grad / (1000+10*M_rotating_nom) 

--- Document Chunk 6178 ---
Legend: 

--- Document Chunk 6179 ---
A_gradient = acceleration/deceleration due to gradient 

--- Document Chunk 6180 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6181 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6182 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6183 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6184 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 6185 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 6186 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6187 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6188 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6189 ---
Page 105/204 

--- Document Chunk 6190 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6191 ---
g = 9.81 m/s2 - acceleration of gravity in m/s2 

--- Document Chunk 6192 ---
grad = gradient values in ‰ (positive = uphill) 

--- Document Chunk 6193 ---
M_rotating_nom = nominal rotating mass (part of train data) as a percentage of the 

--- Document Chunk 6194 ---
total train weight 

--- Document Chunk 6195 ---
M_rotating_max = maximum possible rotating mass (see A.3.1) as a percentage of the 

--- Document Chunk 6196 ---
total train weight 

--- Document Chunk 6197 ---
M_rotating_min = minimum possible rotating mass (see A .3.1) as a percentage of the 

--- Document Chunk 6198 ---
total train weight 

--- Document Chunk 6199 ---
3.13.5 Determination of locations without special brake contribution and with 

--- Document Chunk 6200 ---
reduced adhesion conditions 

--- Document Chunk 6201 ---
3.13.5.1 As long as  it uses a  track condition profile given by trackside, the on -board shall 

--- Document Chunk 6202 ---
consider locations with out special  brake contribution over a distance going from th e 

--- Document Chunk 6203 ---
start location of the profile to the foot of the deceleration curve (EBD, SBD or GUI, see 

--- Document Chunk 6204 ---
sections 3.13.8.3, 3.13.8.4 and 3.13.8.5). 

--- Document Chunk 6205 ---
3.13.5.2 If the status of a special brake i s “not active”, all locations shall be considered without 

--- Document Chunk 6206 ---
the contribution of this special brake. 

--- Document Chunk 6207 ---
3.13.5.2.1 Note: in such case, a track condition profile implying the inhibition of this special brake 

--- Document Chunk 6208 ---
will have no effect. 

--- Document Chunk 6209 ---
3.13.5.3 From the adhesion profile given by trackside, the on-board shall consider locations with 

--- Document Chunk 6210 ---
reduced adhesion conditions over a distance going from the start location of the profile 

--- Document Chunk 6211 ---
to the location derived by adding the train length to the end location of the profile. 

--- Document Chunk 6212 ---
3.13.5.4 When slippery rail is selected by th e driver, all locations shall be considered with 

--- Document Chunk 6213 ---
reduced adhesion conditions. 

--- Document Chunk 6214 ---
3.13.5.5 The speed and distance monitoring shall use, as resulting reduced adhesion 

--- Document Chunk 6215 ---
conditions, the most restrictive value of the adhesion conditions selected by the driver 

--- Document Chunk 6216 ---
and the adhesion conditions calculated from the trackside profile. 

--- Document Chunk 6217 ---
3.13.6 Calculation of the deceleration and brake build up time 

--- Document Chunk 6218 ---
3.13.6.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 6219 ---
3.13.6.1.1 This chapter describes how the safe  emergency brake, the expected and the normal 

--- Document Chunk 6220 ---
service brake decelerations and the time intervals du e to brake build up time are 

--- Document Chunk 6221 ---
calculated. 

--- Document Chunk 6222 ---
3.13.6.2 Emergency brake 

--- Document Chunk 6223 ---
3.13.6.2.1 Safe deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 6224 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6225 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6226 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6227 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6228 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 6229 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 6230 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6231 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6232 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6233 ---
Page 106/204 

--- Document Chunk 6234 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6235 ---
3.13.6.2.1.1 The safe deceleration, A_safe(V,d), is safety relevant. This means that for the 

--- Document Chunk 6236 ---
calculation of the safe deceleration, all necessary track and train characteristics shall 

--- Document Chunk 6237 ---
be taken into account. 

--- Document Chunk 6238 ---
3.13.6.2.1.2 The train and track related characteristics to be considered are: 

--- Document Chunk 6239 ---
a) The speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the emergency brake either 

--- Document Chunk 6240 ---
acquired as part of Train Data (see 3.13.2.2.3.1) or derived from the brake 

--- Document Chunk 6241 ---
percentage using the conversion model (see 3.13.3.3) 

--- Document Chunk 6242 ---
b) The acceleration/deceleration due to gradient i.e. A_gradient(d) (see 3.13.4) 

--- Document Chunk 6243 ---
c) The locations with reduced adhesion conditions (see 3.13.5) 

--- Document Chunk 6244 ---
d) The National Values for reduced adhesion condition (see 3.13.2.3.7.7) 

--- Document Chunk 6245 ---
e) The locations with out special  brake contribution (see  3.13.5), only if the speed 

--- Document Chunk 6246 ---
dependent deceleration mo del(s) for the emergency brake are acquired as part of 

--- Document Chunk 6247 ---
Train Data 

--- Document Chunk 6248 ---
f) The rolling stock  correction factors K dry_rst(V, EBCL ) and K wet_rst(V) (see 

--- Document Chunk 6249 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1), only if the speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the emergency 

--- Document Chunk 6250 ---
brake are acquired as part of Train Data 

--- Document Chunk 6251 ---
g) The National Values for confidence level on emergency brake safe deceleration and 

--- Document Chunk 6252 ---
for the available wheel/rail adhesion  (see 3.13.2.3.7.5 & 3.13.2.3.7.6), only  if the 

--- Document Chunk 6253 ---
speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the emergency brake are acquired as 

--- Document Chunk 6254 ---
part of Train Data 

--- Document Chunk 6255 ---
h) The integrated correction factors Kv_in t(V) (with the two pivot deceleration values 

--- Document Chunk 6256 ---
for passenger trains) and Kr_int(l) (see 3.13.2.3.7), only if the conversion model is 

--- Document Chunk 6257 ---
used 

--- Document Chunk 6258 ---
i) The brake position (see 3.13.2.2.4) 

--- Document Chunk 6259 ---
j) The acquired train length L_TRAIN  (see 3.13.2.2.11), only if the conversion model 

--- Document Chunk 6260 ---
is used 

--- Document Chunk 6261 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6262 ---
3.13.6.2.1.3 A_safe(V,d) shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 6263 ---
For locations with normal adhesion conditions  and for locations with reduced 

--- Document Chunk 6264 ---
adhesion conditions when A_MAXREDADH does not limit to a maximum value 

--- Document Chunk 6265 ---
the speed dependent deceleration for the emergency brake: 

--- Document Chunk 6266 ---
A_safe(V,d) = A_brake_safe(V,d) + A_gradient(d) 

--- Document Chunk 6267 ---
For locations with reduced adhesion conditions when A_MAXREDADH limits to a 

--- Document Chunk 6268 ---
maximum value the speed dependent deceleration for the emergency brake: 

--- Document Chunk 6269 ---
A_safe(V,d) = MIN(A_brake_safe(V,d) , A_MAXREDADH) + A_gradient(d) 

--- Document Chunk 6270 ---
3.13.6.2.1.4 A_brake_safe(V,d) shall be the  safe emergency brake deceleration. 

--- Document Chunk 6271 ---
A_brake_safe(V,d) shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 6272 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6273 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6274 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6275 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6276 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 6277 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 6278 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6279 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6280 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6281 ---
Page 107/204 

--- Document Chunk 6282 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6283 ---
If the speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the emergency brake are 

--- Document Chunk 6284 ---
acquired as part of Train Data: 

--- Document Chunk 6285 ---
A_brake_safe(V,d) = Kdry_rst(V, M_NVEBCL) * (Kwet_rst(V) + M_NVAVADH 

--- Document Chunk 6286 ---
*(1- Kwet_rst(V))) * A_brake_emergency(V,d) 

--- Document Chunk 6287 ---
If the conversion model is used: 

--- Document Chunk 6288 ---
A_brake_safe(V) = Kv_int(V) * Kr_int(L_TRAIN) * A_brake_emergency(V) 

--- Document Chunk 6289 ---
3.13.6.2.1.5 A_brake_emergency(V,d) shall be the emergency brake deceleration as a function 

--- Document Chunk 6290 ---
of the speed, of the locations with change of special brake(s) contribution  encountered 

--- Document Chunk 6291 ---
between the train front and the foot of the EBD curve . A_brake_emergency(V,d) shall 

--- Document Chunk 6292 ---
be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 6293 ---
A_brake_emergency1(V) when destfront ≤ d ≤ d1 

--- Document Chunk 6294 ---
A_brake_emergency2(V) when d1 < d ≤ d2 

--- Document Chunk 6295 ---
A_brake_emergency3(V) when d2 < d ≤ d3 

--- Document Chunk 6296 ---
.... 

--- Document Chunk 6297 ---
Where 

--- Document Chunk 6298 ---
d1, d2, d3,... are the locations with change of special brake(s) contribution 

--- Document Chunk 6299 ---
A_brake_emergencyx(V) is equal to the emergency brake model, A_brake_emergency, 

--- Document Chunk 6300 ---
applicable for the concerned combination of brake. 

--- Document Chunk 6301 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6302 ---
distance 

--- Document Chunk 6303 ---

--- Document Chunk 6304 ---
brake only 

--- Document Chunk 6305 ---

plus regenerative brake

--- Document Chunk 6308 ---
d1 EBD foot 

--- Document Chunk 6309 ---
regenerative brake off

--- Document Chunk 6312 ---
3.13.6.2.1.6 A_MAXREDADH shall be the value, out of the three related National Values, 

--- Document Chunk 6313 ---
applicable for this train according to: 

--- Document Chunk 6314 ---
a) its brake position 

--- Document Chunk 6315 ---
b) whether special/additional brakes independent from wheel/rail adhesion are active 

--- Document Chunk 6316 ---
and it is allowed to take into account their contribution to the emergency braking 

--- Document Chunk 6317 ---
effort.

3.13.6.2.1.7 Kdry_rst(V, M_NVEBCL) shall be the rolling stock correction factor, as a function of 

--- Document Chunk 6330 ---
speed (with speed steps identical with the ones of A_brake_emergency(V)), 

--- Document Chunk 6331 ---
corresponding to the confidence level on emergency brake safe deceleration required 

--- Document Chunk 6332 ---
by trackside (National Value). 

--- Document Chunk 6333 ---
3.13.6.2.1.8 Kv_int(V) shall be the integrated correction factor applicable for the train, selected 

--- Document Chunk 6334 ---
according to the brake position. 

--- Document Chunk 6335 ---
3.13.6.2.1.8.1 If the brake position is “Passenger train in P”, the set of Kv_int shall be calculated 

--- Document Chunk 6336 ---
as a function of the maximum emergency brake deceleration (A_ebmax) in the 

--- Document Chunk 6337 ---
following way (see also figure 10): 

--- Document Chunk 6338 ---
Kv_int_x = Kv_int_x_a  when  A_ebmax ≤ A_P12. 

--- Document Chunk 6339 ---
Kv_int_x = Kv_int_x_b  when  A_ebmax ≥ A_P23. 

--- Document Chunk 6340 ---
Kv_int_x = Kv_int_x_a + (A_ebmax  - A_P12)/(A_P23 - A_P12) * (Kv_int_x_b - 

--- Document Chunk 6341 ---
Kv_int_x_a) when  A_P12 < A_ebmax < A_P23.”

--- Document Chunk 6402 ---
3.13.6.2.2 Safe brake build up time 

--- Document Chunk 6403 ---
3.13.6.2.2.1 The safe brake build up time, T_be, is safety relevant. This means that for the 

--- Document Chunk 6404 ---
calculation of the safe brake build up time, all necessary track and train characteristics 

--- Document Chunk 6405 ---
shall be taken into account. 

--- Document Chunk 6406 ---
3.13.6.2.2.2 The train and track related characteristics to be considered are: 

--- Document Chunk 6407 ---
a) The values of T_brake_emergency acquired as part of Train Data (see 

--- Document Chunk 6408 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.8) or the value of T_brake_emergency derived from the conversion 

--- Document Chunk 6409 ---
model (see 3.13.3.4) using the brake position and train length acquired as Train 

--- Document Chunk 6410 ---
Data. 

--- Document Chunk 6411 ---
b) The integrated correction factor Kt_in t, only if the conversion model is used  (see 

--- Document Chunk 6412 ---
3.13.2.3.7) 

--- Document Chunk 6413 ---
c) The status of the regenerative brake, eddy current brake, ma gnetic shoe brake and 

--- Document Chunk 6414 ---
Ep brake system (see 3.13.2.2.6), only if the values of T_brake_emergency are 

--- Document Chunk 6415 ---
acquired as part of Train Data 

--- Document Chunk 6416 ---
3.13.6.2.2.3 The safe brake build up time T_be shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 6417 ---
If values of T_brake_emergency are acquired as part of Train Data: 

--- Document Chunk 6418 ---
T_be = T_brake_emergency , with T_brake_emergency corresponding to the 

--- Document Chunk 6419 ---
combination of special brakes currently in use 

--- Document Chunk 6420 ---
If the conversion model is used: 

--- Document Chunk 6421 ---
T_be = Kt_int * T_brake_emergency 

--- Document Chunk 6422 ---
3.13.6.3 Service brake 

--- Document Chunk 6423 ---
3.13.6.3.1 Expected deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 6424 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6425 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6426 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6427 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6428 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 6429 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 6430 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6431 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6432 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6433 ---
Page 110/204 

--- Document Chunk 6434 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6435 ---
3.13.6.3.1.1 Since the ex pected deceleration is not safety relevant, no worst case conditions 

--- Document Chunk 6436 ---
(e.g. correction factors, adhesion conditions) need to be taken into account for its 

--- Document Chunk 6437 ---
calculation. 

--- Document Chunk 6438 ---
3.13.6.3.1.2 The train and track related characteristics to be considered are: 

--- Document Chunk 6439 ---
a) The speed dependent dec eleration model(s) for the full service brake either 

--- Document Chunk 6440 ---
acquired as part of Train Data (see 3.13.2.2.3.1) or derived from the brake 

--- Document Chunk 6441 ---
percentage using the conversion model (see 3.13.3.3) 

--- Document Chunk 6442 ---
b) The acceleration/deceleration due to gradient i.e. A_gradient(d) (see 3.13.4) 

--- Document Chunk 6443 ---
c) The locations without special brake contribution (see 3.13.5) 

--- Document Chunk 6444 ---
3.13.6.3.1.3 A_expected(V,d) shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 6445 ---
A_expected(V,d) = A_brake_service(V,d) +A_gradient(d) 

--- Document Chunk 6446 ---
3.13.6.3.1.4 A_brake_service(V,d) shall be the full deceleration of the service brake as a 

--- Document Chunk 6447 ---
function of the speed, of the locations with change of special brake(s) contribution  

--- Document Chunk 6448 ---
encountered between the train front and the foot of the SBD curve . 

--- Document Chunk 6449 ---
A_brake_service(V,d) shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 6450 ---
A_brake_service1(V) when destfront ≤ d ≤ d1 

--- Document Chunk 6451 ---
A_brake_service2(V) when d1 < d ≤ d2 

--- Document Chunk 6452 ---
A_brake_service3(V) when d2 < d ≤ d3 

--- Document Chunk 6453 ---
.... 

--- Document Chunk 6454 ---
Where 

--- Document Chunk 6455 ---
d1, d2, d3,... are the locations with change of special brake(s) contribution 

--- Document Chunk 6456 ---
A_brake_servicex(V) is equal to the full service brake model, A_brake_service, 

--- Document Chunk 6457 ---
applicable for the concerned combination of brake. 

--- Document Chunk 6458 ---
3.13.6.3.2 Expected brake build up time 

--- Document Chunk 6459 ---
3.13.6.3.2.1 Since the expected brake build up time is not safety relevant, no worst case 

--- Document Chunk 6460 ---
conditions (e.g. correction factors, adhesion conditions) need to be taken into account 

--- Document Chunk 6461 ---
for its calculation. 

--- Document Chunk 6462 ---
3.13.6.3.2.2 No track related characteristics are to be considered for the expected brake build up 

--- Document Chunk 6463 ---
time. 

--- Document Chunk 6464 ---
3.13.6.3.2.3 The train related characteristics to be considered are: 

--- Document Chunk 6465 ---
a) The values of T_brake_service acquired as part of Train Data (see 3.13.2.2.3.2.8) 

--- Document Chunk 6466 ---
or the value (s) of T_brake_service derived from the conversion model (see 

--- Document Chunk 6467 ---
3.13.3.4) using the brake position and train length acquired as Train Data) 

--- Document Chunk 6468 ---
b) The status of the regenerative brake, eddy current brake and Ep brake system (see 

--- Document Chunk 6469 ---
3.13.2.2.6) 

--- Document Chunk 6470 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6471 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6472 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6473 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6474 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 6475 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 6476 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6477 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6478 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6479 ---
Page 111/204 

--- Document Chunk 6480 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6481 ---
3.13.6.3.2.4 The expected brake build up time T_bs shall be equal to the brake build up time of 

--- Document Chunk 6482 ---
the full service brake: 

--- Document Chunk 6483 ---
T_bs = T_brake_service , with T_brake_service corresponding to the combination of 

--- Document Chunk 6484 ---
special brakes currently in use 

--- Document Chunk 6485 ---
3.13.6.4 Normal service brake deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 6486 ---
3.13.6.4.1 Since the normal service brake deceleration is not safety relevant, no worst case 

--- Document Chunk 6487 ---
conditions (e.g. correction factors, adhesion conditions) need to be taken into account 

--- Document Chunk 6488 ---
for its calculation. 

--- Document Chunk 6489 ---
3.13.6.4.2 The train and track related characteristics to be considered are: 

--- Document Chunk 6490 ---
a) The speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the full service brake either 

--- Document Chunk 6491 ---
acquired as part of Train Data (see 3.13.2.2.3.1) or derived from the brake 

--- Document Chunk 6492 ---
percentage using the conversion model (see 3.13.3.3) 

--- Document Chunk 6493 ---
b) The speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the normal service brake acquired 

--- Document Chunk 6494 ---
as part of Train Data (see 3.13.2.2.3.1) 

--- Document Chunk 6495 ---
c) The acceleration/deceleration due to gradient i.e. A_gradient(d) (see 3.13.4) 

--- Document Chunk 6496 ---
d) The brake position (see 3.13.2.2.4) 

--- Document Chunk 6497 ---
e) The on-board correction factors Kn+(V) and Kn-(V) (see 3.13.2.2.9.2) 

--- Document Chunk 6498 ---
f) The locations without special brake contribution (see 3.13.5) 

--- Document Chunk 6499 ---
3.13.6.4.3 The normal service brake deceleration shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 6500 ---
For positive gradient values (uphill): 

--- Document Chunk 6501 ---
A_normal_service(V,d) = A_brake_normal_service(V,d) + A_gradient(d) – 

--- Document Chunk 6502 ---
Kn+(V)*grad/1000 

--- Document Chunk 6503 ---
For negative gradient values (downhill): 

--- Document Chunk 6504 ---
A_normal_service(V,d) = A_brake_normal_service(V,d) + A_gradient(d) –  

--- Document Chunk 6505 ---
Kn-(V)*grad/1000 

--- Document Chunk 6506 ---
Where 

--- Document Chunk 6507 ---
grad = gradient values in ‰ (positive = uphill) 

--- Document Chunk 6508 ---
3.13.6.4.4 A_brake_normal_service(V,d) shall be the normal deceleration of the service brake as 

--- Document Chunk 6509 ---
a function of the speed, of the locations with change of special brake(s) contribution  

--- Document Chunk 6510 ---
encountered between the train front and the foot of the GUI curve . 

--- Document Chunk 6511 ---
A_brake_normal_service(V,d) shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 6512 ---
A_brake_normal_service1(V) when destfront ≤ d ≤ d1 

--- Document Chunk 6513 ---
A_brake_normal_service2(V) when d1 < d ≤ d2 

--- Document Chunk 6514 ---
A_brake_normal_service3(V) when d2 < d ≤ d3 

--- Document Chunk 6515 ---
.... 

--- Document Chunk 6516 ---
Where 

--- Document Chunk 6517 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6518 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6519 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6520 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6521 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 6522 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 6523 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6524 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6525 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6526 ---
Page 112/204 

--- Document Chunk 6527 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6528 ---
d1, d2, d3,... are the locations with change of special brake(s) contribution 

--- Document Chunk 6529 ---
A_brake_normal_servicex(V) is equal to the normal service brake model applicable for  

--- Document Chunk 6530 ---
the concerned combination of brake position and of the value of A_brake_service(V=0) 

--- Document Chunk 6531 ---
between dx-1 and dx (see 3.13.2.2.3.1.9 and 3.13.2.2.3.1.10). 

--- Document Chunk 6532 ---
3.13.7 Determination of Most Restrictive Speed Profile (MRSP) 

--- Document Chunk 6533 ---
3.13.7.1 The Most Restrictive Speed Profile (MRSP) is a description of the most restrictive 

--- Document Chunk 6534 ---
speed restrictions the train shall obey on a given piece of track. 

--- Document Chunk 6535 ---
3.13.7.2 The Most Restrictive Speed Profile shall be computed from all speed restrictions (see 

--- Document Chunk 6536 ---
3.13.2.2.13 & 3.13.2.3.2) by selecting the most restrictive parts of each element, some 

--- Document Chunk 6537 ---
elements being compensated by the train length if requested by trackside (see 

--- Document Chunk 6538 ---
3.11.3.1.3 for SSP, 3.11.4.6 for ASP and 3.11.5.3 for TSR). 

--- Document Chunk 6539 ---
V

--- Document Chunk 6540 ---
d

--- Document Chunk 6541 ---
Speed Restriction categories

--- Document Chunk 6542 ---
Most Restrictive Speed Profile

--- Document Chunk 6543 ---
Train length

--- Document Chunk 6544 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6545 ---
Figure 39: Most Restrictive Speed Profile selection 

--- Document Chunk 6546 ---
3.13.7.3 The Most Restrictive Speed Profile shall be recalculated when any of the elements it is 

--- Document Chunk 6547 ---
built of is changed. 

--- Document Chunk 6548 ---
3.13.8 Determination of targets and brake deceleration curves 

--- Document Chunk 6549 ---
3.13.8.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 6550 ---
3.13.8.1.1 A target is defined by a target location and a target speed, to which the train must 

--- Document Chunk 6551 ---
decelerate before reaching the target location. 

--- Document Chunk 6552 ---
3.13.8.1.2 For that purpose, the on -board equipment shall use brake deceleration curves related 

--- Document Chunk 6553 ---
to the supervised targets, from the deceleration values as specified in sections 

--- Document Chunk 6554 ---
3.13.6.2.1, 3.13.6.3.1and 3.13.6.4. 

--- Document Chunk 6555 ---
3.13.8.1.3 These deceleration values being speed and distance dependent, a brake deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 6556 ---
curve shall be calculated piecewise, i.e. it shall be composed of interconnected arcs of 

--- Document Chunk 6557 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6558 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6559 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6560 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6561 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 6562 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 6563 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6564 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6565 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6566 ---
Page 113/204 

--- Document Chunk 6567 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6568 ---
parabola, each one being based on one of the speed/distance dependent deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 6569 ---
values (see Figure 38). 

--- Document Chunk 6570 ---
3.13.8.2 Determination of the supervised targets 

--- Document Chunk 6571 ---
3.13.8.2.1 The on -board shall continuously supervise a list of targets, which may include the 

--- Document Chunk 6572 ---
following types of target: 

--- Document Chunk 6573 ---
a) the locations corresponding to a speed decrease of the MRSP (if any), which are in 

--- Document Chunk 6574 ---
advance of the max safe front end of the train 

--- Document Chunk 6575 ---
b) the Limit of Authority (LOA) 

--- Document Chunk 6576 ---
c) the End of Authority (EOA) and the Supervised Location (SvL) 

--- Document Chunk 6577 ---
d) the locati on deduced from the maximum permitted distance to run in Staff 

--- Document Chunk 6578 ---
Responsible, with a target speed zero 

--- Document Chunk 6579 ---
3.13.8.2.1.1 Note: depending on the information received from trackside and the position of the 

--- Document Chunk 6580 ---
train, the list of supervised targets may be empty. 

--- Document Chunk 6581 ---
3.13.8.2.2 The list of supervis ed targets shall be re -evaluated when any of the elements it is built 

--- Document Chunk 6582 ---
of is changed (e.g. new MA and/or track description accepted on -board, EOA and/or 

--- Document Chunk 6583 ---
SvL temporarily supervised at the start location of a mode profile, update of stored 

--- Document Chunk 6584 ---
information in specific situations (see sections A.3.4 and 4.10)). 

--- Document Chunk 6585 ---
3.13.8.2.3 A target corresponding to a speed decrease of the MRSP shall be removed from the 

--- Document Chunk 6586 ---
list of supervised targets when the max safe front end of the train has passed the 

--- Document Chunk 6587 ---
target location. 

--- Document Chunk 6588 ---
3.13.8.3 Emergency Brake Deceleration curves (EBD) 

--- Document Chunk 6589 ---
3.13.8.3.1 If a target belongs to the MRSP or is an LOA, the on -board shall calculate an EBD 

--- Document Chunk 6590 ---
curve based on the safe deceleration A_safe(V,d) , that crosses the ceiling speed EBI 

--- Document Chunk 6591 ---
supervision limit (see 3.13.9.2) at the target location , and that extends up to the 

--- Document Chunk 6592 ---
location where the target speed is reached (EBD foot). 

--- Document Chunk 6593 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6594 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6595 ---

--- Document Chunk 6666 ---
3.13.8.5 Guidance curves (GUI) 

--- Document Chunk 6667 ---
3.13.8.5.1 The purpose of the guidance curve (GUI) is to provide a comfortable way of brak ing for 

--- Document Chunk 6668 ---
the driver, to avoid excessive wear of the brakes and to save traction energy. 

--- Document Chunk 6669 ---
3.13.8.5.2 If the National Value does not inhibit them, the on -board shall calculate a guidance 

--- Document Chunk 6670 ---
curve (GUI) for each supervised target, based on the normal service brake 

--- Document Chunk 6671 ---
deceleration A_normal_service(V,d). The foot of a GUI curve (i.e. the location where 

--- Document Chunk 6672 ---
the GUI speed is equal to the target speed) shall be: 

--- Document Chunk 6673 ---
a) the target location, in case of EOA/SvL 

--- Document Chunk 6674 ---
b) the location defined in 3.13.9.3.5.9, for others targets 

--- Document Chunk 6675 ---
3.13.9 Supervision limits 

--- Document Chunk 6676 ---
3.13.9.1 Overview 

--- Document Chunk 6677 ---
3.13.9.1.1 In this chapter the following supervision limits are defined: 

--- Document Chunk 6678 ---
 Emergency brake intervention (EBI) 

--- Document Chunk 6679 ---
 Service brake intervention (SBI) 

--- Document Chunk 6680 ---
 Warning (W) 

--- Document Chunk 6681 ---
 Permitted speed (P) 

--- Document Chunk 6682 ---
 Indication (I) 

--- Document Chunk 6683 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6684 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6685 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6686 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6687 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 6688 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 6689 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6690 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6691 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6692 ---
Page 116/204 

--- Document Chunk 6693 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6694 ---
 Release speed monitoring start location 

--- Document Chunk 6695 ---
3.13.9.1.2 The purpose of the emergency brake intervention supervision limit is to assure that the 

--- Document Chunk 6696 ---
train will remain within the various limits (in distance/speed) imposed by the trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 6697 ---
3.13.9.1.3 The purpose of all other supervision limits is to assist the driver in preventing an 

--- Document Chunk 6698 ---
emergency brake intervention by maintaining the speed of the train within the 

--- Document Chunk 6699 ---
appropriate limits. 

--- Document Chunk 6700 ---
3.13.9.2 Ceiling supervision limits 

--- Document Chunk 6701 ---
3.13.9.2.1 The ceiling supervision limits are derived from the MRSP elements, where the speed is 

--- Document Chunk 6702 ---
constant (refer to 3.13.7) or from the LOA. 

--- Document Chunk 6703 ---
3.13.9.2.2 From an MRSP element or from the LOA, the Permitted speed, Warning, Service 

--- Document Chunk 6704 ---
brake intervention and Emergency brake intervention supervision limits are defined 

--- Document Chunk 6705 ---
(see Figure 43). 

--- Document Chunk 6706 ---

--- Document Chunk 6824 ---
3.13.9.3.2 EBI supervision limit 

--- Document Chunk 6825 ---
3.13.9.3.2.1 If not inhibited by National Value, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 6826 ---
compensate the inaccuracy of the speed measurement by taking into account  the 

--- Document Chunk 6827 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6828 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6829 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6830 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6831 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 6832 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 6833 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6834 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6835 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6836 ---
Page 119/204 

--- Document Chunk 6837 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6838 ---
speed under reading amount (V_ura)  at the moment when the calculation is made : 

--- Document Chunk 6839 ---
V_delta0 = V_ura (see Figure 45). 

--- Document Chunk 6840 ---
3.13.9.3.2.2 The time elapsed between the Emergency brake intervention and the full application 

--- Document Chunk 6841 ---
of the braking effort is reached (EBD) shall be split into two parts: 

--- Document Chunk 6842 ---
a) Time during which the traction effort is still present: T_traction 

--- Document Chunk 6843 ---
b) Remaining time during which the traction effort is not present: T_berem 

--- Document Chunk 6844 ---
3.13.9.3.2.3 The traction time (T_Traction) shall be defined as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 6845 ---
a) when the traction cut-off is implemented: 

--- Document Chunk 6846 ---
T_traction = MAX((T_traction_cut_off - (T_warning + T_bs2)) ; 0). 

--- Document Chunk 6847 ---
b) when the traction cut-off is not implemented: T_traction = T_traction_cut_off 

--- Document Chunk 6848 ---
3.13.9.3.2.4 Note: When the traction cut -off is implemented , the traction cut -off command is 

--- Document Chunk 6849 ---
triggered when passing the warning limit. The term (T_warning + T_bs2) in the 

--- Document Chunk 6850 ---
equation above takes this into account, assuming that the warning limit is derived from 

--- Document Chunk 6851 ---
the EBD. 

--- Document Chunk 6852 ---
3.13.9.3.2.5 T_bs2 and T_warning are defined in sections 3.13.9.3.3 and 3.13.9.3.4. 

--- Document Chunk 6853 ---
3.13.9.3.2.6 The remaining time with no traction (T_berem) shall be equal to MAX(T_be - 

--- Document Chunk 6854 ---
T_traction ; 0). 

--- Document Chunk 6855 ---
3.13.9.3.2.7 Note: T_Traction exceeding T_be is rather a theoretical case, but is nevertheless 

--- Document Chunk 6856 ---
included to make the specifications complete. 

--- Document Chunk 6857 ---
3.13.9.3.2.8 During T_traction, the estimated acceleration (A_est1) shall be the one measured at 

--- Document Chunk 6858 ---
the moment when the calculation is made, but limited to positive or null values. 

--- Document Chunk 6859 ---
3.13.9.3.2.9 If T_be > T_traction, the estimated accelerat ion during T_berem (A_est2) shall be 

--- Document Chunk 6860 ---
the one measured at the moment when the calculation is made, but limited to values 

--- Document Chunk 6861 ---
between 0 and +0.4m/s2. 

--- Document Chunk 6862 ---
3.13.9.3.2.10 The compensated speed and the distance travelled during the time elapsed 

--- Document Chunk 6863 ---
between the Emergency brake intervention and the full application of the braking effort 

--- Document Chunk 6864 ---
is reached shall be derived as follows (see Figure 45): 

--- Document Chunk 6865 ---

3.13.9.3.3 SBI supervision limit 

--- Document Chunk 6914 ---
3.13.9.3.3.1 For the EOA, the on -board shall calculate the location of the SBI supervision limit 

--- Document Chunk 6915 ---

--- Document Chunk 6916 ---

--- Document Chunk 6917 ---
    11 bsestestSBDestSBI TVVdVd 

--- Document Chunk 6918 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6919 ---
3.13.9.3.3.2 For an EBD based target, the on -board shall calculate the location of the SBI 

--- Document Chunk 6920 ---
supervision limit (SBI2) valid for the estimated speed, assuming that this latter remains 

--- Document Chunk 6921 ---
constant during the interval T_bs2, until the location of the EBI supervision limit is 

--- Document Chunk 6922 ---
reached. 

--- Document Chunk 6923 ---
    22 bsestestEBIestSBI TVVdVd 

--- Document Chunk 6924 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6925 ---
3.13.9.3.3.3 If the service brake command is available for use and the service brake feedback is 

--- Document Chunk 6926 ---
not available for use, T_bs1 and T_bs2 shall be equal to T_bs. 

--- Document Chunk 6927 ---
3.13.9.3.3.4 If both the service brake command and the servi ce brake feedback are available for 

--- Document Chunk 6928 ---
use, T_bs1 and T_bs2 shall by default be set to T_bs. When the service brake is used 

--- Document Chunk 6929 ---
by the driver  in target speed monitoring or release speed monitoring , they shall be 

--- Document Chunk 6930 ---
reduced and possibly locked to the respective fixed  values of 0s and T_bs2_locked, 

--- Document Chunk 6931 ---
until the ceiling speed monitoring is entered; they are then reset to T_bs ( refer to  

--- Document Chunk 6932 ---
detailed algorithm in Appendix A.3.10). 

--- Document Chunk 6933 ---
3.13.9.3.3.4.1 In case T_bs < T_bs2_locked then T_bs2 shall be equal to T_bs2_locked. 

--- Document Chunk 6934 ---
3.13.9.3.3.5 If the service brake command is not available for use, T_bs1 and T_bs2 shall be set 

--- Document Chunk 6935 ---
to zero. 

--- Document Chunk 6936 ---
3.13.9.3.3.6 Note: The values T_bs1 and T_bs2 = 0s are defined to achieve the maximum 

--- Document Chunk 6937 ---
performance when service brake command is not used. 

--- Document Chunk 6938 ---

3.13.9.3.3.8.1 Note: the re -use o f the same distance travelled and speed increase between the 

--- Document Chunk 7030 ---
SBI2 supervision limit and the EBD, as for the estimated speed (see Figure 48), leads 

--- Document Chunk 7031 ---
to an overestimation/underestimation of the SBI2 speed to be displayed to the drive r. 

--- Document Chunk 7032 ---
This simplification, which avoids the need of an iterated calculation, is however 

--- Document Chunk 7033 ---
acceptable and necessary since the error made tends to zero when the train reaches 

--- Document Chunk 7034 ---
the SBI2 supervision limit.

3.13.9.3.4 Warning supervision limit (W) 

--- Document Chunk 7037 ---

--- Document Chunk 7038 ---
the estimated speed, assuming that this latter remains constant during the interval 

--- Document Chunk 7039 ---
T_warning until the location of the SBI1 (for the EOA) or the SBI2 (for an EBD based 

--- Document Chunk 7040 ---
target) supervision limit is reached.

--- Document Chunk 7068 ---
3.13.9.3.5.3 Note: The reference for the Permitted speed supervision limit is the  SBI supervision 

--- Document Chunk 7069 ---
limit and not the Warning supervision limit. As a result the permitted and warning 

--- Document Chunk 7070 ---
supervision limits are clearly separated and do not affect each other. In this way it is 

--- Document Chunk 7071 ---
clear that the warning is not part of the critical performance interval. 

--- Document Chunk 7072 ---

3.13.9.3.5.9 In order to determine the reference location of the target distance dis played to the 

--- Document Chunk 7263 ---
driver, in order to check whether the target is masking another one,  and in order to 

--- Document Chunk 7264 ---
determine the foot of the GUI curve (only if it is enabled) in case of target different from  

--- Document Chunk 7265 ---
EOA/SvL, the location of the Permitted speed supervision limit, valid for the target 

--- Document Chunk 7266 ---
speed, shall be calculated from the EBD, taking into account the following 

--- Document Chunk 7267 ---
assumptions: 

--- Document Chunk 7268 ---
a) the estimated acceleration shall be set to “zero” 

--- Document Chunk 7269 ---
b) if not inhibited by National Value, the compensation of the inaccuracy of the speed 

--- Document Chunk 7270 ---
measurement shall be set to a value calculated from the target speed, as defined in 

--- Document Chunk 7271 ---
SUBSET-041 § 5.3.1.2: V_delta0t = f41(V_target) 

--- Document Chunk 7272 ---
3.13.9.3.5.10 To do so, the same formulas defined above with V_est and V_ delta0 shall be 

--- Document Chunk 7273 ---
applied, by substituting V_est with V_target and V_delta0 with V_delta0t. 

--- Document Chunk 7274 ---
       tractionberemtdeltaetttdeltaettEBDettEBI TTVVVVdVd  0arg0argarg

--- Document Chunk 7275 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7276 ---
     2argargarg bsdriverettettEBIettP TTVVdVd 

--- Document Chunk 7277 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7278 ---
3.13.9.3.5.10.1 Justification: these assumptions are intended to avoid fluctuations of the target 

--- Document Chunk 7279 ---
distance displayed to the driver. Moreover the foot of the GUI curve may influence the 

--- Document Chunk 7280 ---
perturbation location, whic h must be fully predictable for trackside engineering 

--- Document Chunk 7281 ---
reasons. 

--- Document Chunk 7282 ---

3.13.9.3.5.12.1 Note: the use of the instantaneous speed under reading amount and acceleration 

--- Document Chunk 7345 ---
in the calculation of this location avoids a jump of display when the substitution takes 

--- Document Chunk 7346 ---
place. 

--- Document Chunk 7347 ---

--- Document Chunk 7348 ---

--- Document Chunk 7349 ---
the estimated speed, assuming that this latter remains constant during the interval 

--- Document Chunk 7350 ---
T_indication until the location of the Permitted speed supervision limit is reached.

3.13.9.3.6.2 If the service brake feedback interfa ce is not available for use, then  T_indication 

--- Document Chunk 7365 ---
shall be calculated as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 7366 ---
   driverbsindication TsTT  5,8.0max

--- Document Chunk 7367 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7368 ---
3.13.9.3.6.3 Note: The reduction of T_indication by a factor is intended to improve performance 

--- Document Chunk 7369 ---
and the feasibility of this reduction is based on experience with real implementations. 

--- Document Chunk 7370 ---
To avoid very low values when T_bs is small, a minimum is defined for T_indication, 

--- Document Chunk 7371 ---
giving the driver always enough time to operate the brake. 

--- Document Chunk 7372 ---
3.13.9.3.6.4 If the service brake feedback interface is available for use then T_indication shall be 

--- Document Chunk 7373 ---
equal to 5s + T_driver. 

--- Document Chunk 7374 ---
3.13.9.4 Release speed supervision limits 

--- Document Chunk 7375 ---
3.13.9.4.1 The release speed is a special ceiling speed limit, applicable in the vicinity of the EOA. 

--- Document Chunk 7376 ---
The EBI supervision limit is equal to the release speed. There is no SBI, W, P, I 

--- Document Chunk 7377 ---
supervision limit associated to the release speed. 

--- Document Chunk 7378 ---
3.13.9.4.2 Note: The release speed may be necessary for two reasons. One is that a train has to 

--- Document Chunk 7379 ---
be able to approach the EOA where the permitted speed reaches zero and might be 

--- Document Chunk 7380 ---
too restrictive to permit acceptable driving due to inaccuracy of the meas ured distance. 

--- Document Chunk 7381 ---
The other reason is that in a level 1 application the train has to be able to overpass the 

--- Document Chunk 7382 ---
balise when the signal clears. For these two reasons a (low) release speed may be 

--- Document Chunk 7383 ---
given from trackside or may be calculated on board, based on the dis tance from the 

--- Document Chunk 7384 ---
EOA to the Supervised Location. 

--- Document Chunk 7385 ---
3.13.9.4.3 With each MA, it shall be possible for the trackside to: 

--- Document Chunk 7386 ---
a) Give the value of the release speed directly to the on-board, OR 

--- Document Chunk 7387 ---
b) Instruct the on-board to calculate the release speed, OR 

--- Document Chunk 7388 ---
c) Instruct the on-board to use the national value. 

--- Document Chunk 7389 ---
3.13.9.4.4 In case the MA does not identify the variant to be used or in case of LOA, no release 

--- Document Chunk 7390 ---
speed shall be supervised. 

--- Document Chunk 7391 ---
3.13.9.4.5 Note: When the release speed is given as a fixed value from trackside, the 

--- Document Chunk 7392 ---
ERTMS/ETCS system cannot be responsible for stopp ing the train in rear of the 

--- Document Chunk 7393 ---
Supervised Location. In this case, it is the full responsibility of the infrastructure 

--- Document Chunk 7394 ---
manager to set the appropriate release speed with regard to the risk of passing the 

--- Document Chunk 7395 ---
Supervised Location. 

--- Document Chunk 7396 ---
3.13.9.4.6 The start location of the release s peed monitoring (i.e. where the EBI supervision limit 

--- Document Chunk 7397 ---
related to EBD is replaced with an EBI supervision limit equal to the release speed 

--- Document Chunk 7398 ---
value) shall be the location of the most restrictive SBI supervision limit among the SBI1 

--- Document Chunk 7399 ---
related to EOA, the SBI2 rel ated to SvL  and, when the Release Speed is calculated 

--- Document Chunk 7400 ---
on-board, the SBI2 supervision limit(s) related to other target(s), if any, between the 

--- Document Chunk 7401 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7402 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7403 ---

Trip location related to the EOA and the SvL,  calculated for the Release Speed value, 

--- Document Chunk 7413 ---

--- Document Chunk 7414 ---

--- Document Chunk 7415 ---
b) if not inhibited by National Value, the compensation of the inaccuracy of the speed 

--- Document Chunk 7416 ---
measurement shall be set to a value calculated from the release speed, as defined 

--- Document Chunk 7417 ---
in SUBSET-041 § 5.3.1.2: V_delta0rs = f41(V_release) 

--- Document Chunk 7418 ---
3.13.9.4.7 To do so, the same formulas defined above with V_est and V_ delta0 shall be applied, 

--- Document Chunk 7419 ---
by substituting V_est with V_release and V_delta0 with V_delta0rs.

3.13.9.4.8.2.1 Note: The above formulas are intended to prevent the calculated release speed 

--- Document Chunk 7571 ---
from fluctuating, according to the distance, speed and acceleration measurements. It 

--- Document Chunk 7572 ---
allows calculating the release speed only once , for a given on-board reference 

--- Document Chunk 7573 ---
location, unless 

--- Document Chunk 7574 ---
 the distance confidence interval exceeds a predicted one, which is based on 

--- Document Chunk 7575 ---
the assumption that the whole distance between the current on -board 

--- Document Chunk 7576 ---
reference location and the EOA would be travelled with SUBSET-041 

--- Document Chunk 7577 ---
odometer performance values  and without any update of the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 7578 ---
reference location, or 

--- Document Chunk 7579 ---
 the speed under reading amount (V_ura) exceeds the SUBSET -041 

--- Document Chunk 7580 ---
performance value 

--- Document Chunk 7581 ---
Whenever the on-board reference location is updated (e.g. new LRBG), the release 

--- Document Chunk 7582 ---
speed will however be recalculated and will increase with a step. This behaviour is 

--- Document Chunk 7583 ---
acceptable from an operational point of view. 

--- Document Chunk 7584 ---

(Figure 52 box 4) the most restrictive value of the MRSP ( Figure 52 box 3) within this
