3.13.9.5 Intentionally deleted 

--- Document Chunk 7629 ---
3.13.10 Speed and distance monitoring commands 

--- Document Chunk 7630 ---
3.13.10.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 7631 ---
3.13.10.1.1 By comparing the train speed and position to the various supervision limits defined in 

--- Document Chunk 7632 ---
the previous section, the on -board equipment generates braking commands, traction 

--- Document Chunk 7633 ---
cut-off commands and relevant information to the driver.  The information displayed t o 

--- Document Chunk 7634 ---
the driver is selected according to the following supervision statuses of the speed and 

--- Document Chunk 7635 ---
distance monitoring function: Normal status, Indication status, Overspeed status, 

--- Document Chunk 7636 ---
Warning status and Intervention status. 

--- Document Chunk 7637 ---
3.13.10.1.2 The following types of speed and distance monitoring are defined: 

--- Document Chunk 7638 ---
 Ceiling speed monitoring (CSM) 

--- Document Chunk 7639 ---
 Target speed monitoring (TSM) 

--- Document Chunk 7640 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7641 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7642 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7643 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 7644 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 7645 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 7646 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 7647 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 7648 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 7649 ---
Page 132/204 

--- Document Chunk 7650 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7651 ---
 Release speed monitoring (RSM) 

--- Document Chunk 7652 ---
ceiling speed monitoring

--- Document Chunk 7653 ---
release speed

--- Document Chunk 7654 ---
monitoring

--- Document Chunk 7655 ---
I

--- Document Chunk 7656 ---
SBI

--- Document Chunk 7657 ---
MRSP

--- Document Chunk 7658 ---
Speed

--- Document Chunk 7659 ---
Distance

--- Document Chunk 7660 ---
EOA SvLStart

--- Document Chunk 7661 ---
RSM

--- Document Chunk 7662 ---
release speed

--- Document Chunk 7663 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7664 ---
Figure 53: Different types of speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 7665 ---
3.13.10.1.3 Ceiling speed monitoring is the speed supervision in the area where the train can run 

--- Document Chunk 7666 ---
without the need to brake to a target. 

--- Document Chunk 7667 ---
3.13.10.1.4 Target speed monitoring is the speed and distance supervision in the area where the 

--- Document Chunk 7668 ---
specific information related to a target is displayed to the driver and wit hin which the 

--- Document Chunk 7669 ---
train brakes to a target. 

--- Document Chunk 7670 ---
3.13.10.1.5 Release speed monitoring is the speed and distance supervision in the area close to 

--- Document Chunk 7671 ---
the EOA where the train is allowed to run with release speed to approach the EOA. 

--- Document Chunk 7672 ---
3.13.10.2 General requirements 

--- Document Chunk 7673 ---
3.13.10.2.1 The train speed indicated to the driver shall be identical to the speed used for the 

--- Document Chunk 7674 ---
speed monitoring. This shall be the estimated speed. 

--- Document Chunk 7675 ---
3.13.10.2.2 Once a Train Interface command (traction cut -off, service brake or emergency brake) 

--- Document Chunk 7676 ---
is triggered, the on -board shall apply it until its correspondi ng revocation condition is 

--- Document Chunk 7677 ---
met. 

--- Document Chunk 7678 ---
3.13.10.2.3 If there is no on-board interface with the service brake or if the use of the service brake 

--- Document Chunk 7679 ---
command is not allowed by a National Value (only in Target speed monitoring), 

--- Document Chunk 7680 ---
whenever a service brake command is specified, the eme rgency brake command shall 

--- Document Chunk 7681 ---
be triggered instead. 

--- Document Chunk 7682 ---
3.13.10.2.4 The emergency brake command, which is triggered instead of the service brake 

--- Document Chunk 7683 ---
command when an SBI supervision limit is exceeded, shall be revoked according to 

--- Document Chunk 7684 ---
the requirements specified for the revocation of service brake command, unless the 

--- Document Chunk 7685 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7686 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7687 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7688 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 7689 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 7690 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 7691 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 7692 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 7693 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 7694 ---
Page 133/204 

--- Document Chunk 7695 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7696 ---
emergency brake command has been also triggered due to an EBI supervision limit. In 

--- Document Chunk 7697 ---
such case, the condition for revoking the emergency brake command due to EBI 

--- Document Chunk 7698 ---
supervision limit shall prevail. 

--- Document Chunk 7699 ---
3.13.10.2.5 The on -board shall revoke th e Intervention status only when no brake command is 

--- Document Chunk 7700 ---
applied by the speed and distance monitoring function. 

--- Document Chunk 7701 ---
3.13.10.2.6 In level 2/3: Train trip shall be initiated if the on -board equipment detects that the 

--- Document Chunk 7702 ---
minimum safe front end has passed the EOA/LOA location. 

--- Document Chunk 7703 ---
3.13.10.2.7 In Lev el 1: Train Trip shall be initiated if the on -board equipment detects that the 

--- Document Chunk 7704 ---
minimum safe antenna position (calculated by subtracting distance between active 

--- Document Chunk 7705 ---
Eurobalise antenna and the front end of the train from the min safe front end position) 

--- Document Chunk 7706 ---
has passed the EOA/LOA location. 

--- Document Chunk 7707 ---
3.13.10.2.8 In the following sections , the term V_MRSP (together with the derived ceiling 

--- Document Chunk 7708 ---
supervision limits) refers to the lowest MRSP element encountered between the min 

--- Document Chunk 7709 ---
safe front end and the max safe front end of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 7710 ---
3.13.10.3 Requirements for Ceiling speed monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 7711 ---
3.13.10.3.1 The on-board equipment shall display the Permitted speed ceiling supervision limit. 

--- Document Chunk 7712 ---
3.13.10.3.2 When the supervision status is Overspeed, Warning or Intervention, the on -board

--- Document Chunk 7849 ---

3.13.10.3.9 If A_MAXREDADH (see 3.13.6.2.1.6) requests the target information as 

--- Document Chunk 7935 ---
supplementary DMI information, the on -board equipment shall display to the driver the 

--- Document Chunk 7936 ---
target information (target speed and distance to target) related to one target at a time: 

--- Document Chunk 7937 ---
the Most Relevant Displayed Target (MRDT). The MRDT shall be selected amongst 

--- Document Chunk 7938 ---
the supervised targets as the one whose remaining distance to its Indication 

--- Document Chunk 7939 ---
supervision limit (as specified in 3.13.10.3.8 and 3.13.10.3.8.1) is the shortest. The 

--- Document Chunk 7940 ---
indicated distance to the target shall be computed in the same way as for target speed 

--- Document Chunk 7941 ---
monitoring, i.e. clauses 3.13.10.4.7, 3.13.10.4.8 and 3.13.10.4.8.1 shall apply. 

--- Document Chunk 7942 ---
3.13.10.3.9.1 Exception: In case the list of supervised targets is empty or in case of LOA with no 

--- Document Chunk 7943 ---
EBD based target whose speed value is below or equal to the estimated speed, the 

--- Document Chunk 7944 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall not display any target information. 

--- Document Chunk 7945 ---
3.13.10.3.10 If A _MAXREDADH (see 3.13.6.2.1.6) requests a time to Indication as 

--- Document Chunk 7946 ---
supplementary DMI information, the on -board equipment shall compute the Time to 

--- Document Chunk 7947 ---
Indication (TTI) as the time to travel at the estimated speed the remaining distance to 

--- Document Chunk 7948 ---
the first Indication loca tion (as specified in 3.13.10.3.8 and 3.13.10.3.8.1). The on -

--- Document Chunk 7949 ---
board equipment shall inform the driver as long as this time is shorter than a fixed 

--- Document Chunk 7950 ---
value (refer to A.3.1). 

--- Document Chunk 7951 ---
3.13.10.3.10.1 Exception: In case the list of supervised targets is empty or in case of LOA with no 

--- Document Chunk 7952 ---
EBD based target whose speed value is below or equal to the estimated speed, the 

--- Document Chunk 7953 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall not compute any time to Indication. 

--- Document Chunk 7954 ---
3.13.10.4 Requirements for Target speed monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 7955 ---
3.13.10.4.1 In target speed monitoring, both the ceiling supervision limits  and the braking to target 

--- Document Chunk 7956 ---
supervision limits, described in sections 3.13.9.2 and 3.13.9.3, are used to determine 

--- Document Chunk 7957 ---
the commands to the Train Interface and the supervision statuses  displayed to the 

--- Document Chunk 7958 ---
driver. 

--- Document Chunk 7959 ---
3.13.10.4.2 The on-board equipment shall display to the driver the target information (target speed 

--- Document Chunk 7960 ---
and distance to target) related to one target at a time: the Most Re levant Displayed 

--- Document Chunk 7961 ---
Target (MRDT). The MRDT shall be selected amongst the supervised targets whos e 

--- Document Chunk 7962 ---
Indication supervision limit is exceeded (i.e. a condition to trigger a supervision status 

--- Document Chunk 7963 ---
with respect to these targets is met, se e table 8 and table 9) and shall be determined 

--- Document Chunk 7964 ---
according to the following steps: 

--- Document Chunk 7965 ---
 Step 0: MRDT 0 = the target of which the br aking to target Permitted speed 

--- Document Chunk 7966 ---
supervision limit (refer to section 3.13.9.3.5), calculated for the current position of 

--- Document Chunk 7967 ---
the train, is the lowest one amongst the concerned targets:

--- Document Chunk 8098 ---

--- Document Chunk 8099 ---

--- Document Chunk 8100 ---
 Step n: the on -board shall apply step n -1, substituting MRDT n-2 with MRDTn-1 and 

--- Document Chunk 8101 ---
checking the list of concerned targets excluding the targets which have bee n 

--- Document Chunk 8102 ---
preselected as MRDT in all the previous steps (i.e. from MRDT 0 to MRDT n-1 

--- Document Chunk 8103 ---
inclusive). 

--- Document Chunk 8104 ---
3.13.10.4.2.1 Note 1: the above process for the determination of the MRDT ensures that in all 

--- Document Chunk 8105 ---
circumstances (especially when several targets are close to each other) it is avoided 

--- Document Chunk 8106 ---
that a target is displayed after its Indication supervision limit has been reached. 

--- Document Chunk 8107 ---

3.13.10.4.2.2 Note 2: when entering target speed monitoring, there is by definition at least one 

--- Document Chunk 8119 ---
target that satisfies the conditions to be selected as MRDT. Afterwards (e.g. due to 

--- Document Chunk 8120 ---
train braking) it is possible that no target satisfies any more the conditions to be 

--- Document Chunk 8121 ---
selected as MRDT, which however only means that the target previously selected 

--- Document Chunk 8122 ---
remains the MRDT (see clause 3.13.10.4.5). 

--- Document Chunk 8123 ---
3.13.10.4.2.3 Note 3: if MRDTn-1 is a target at zero speed (e.g. EOA or SvL), then it is always 

--- Document Chunk 8124 ---
selected as MRDT, i.e. no other target can be selected as MRDT as per step n. 

--- Document Chunk 8125 ---

--- Document Chunk 8192 ---
3.13.10.4.5 Once a target is the MRDT, it shall remain the MRDT until it is removed from the list of 

--- Document Chunk 8193 ---
supervised targets or until it is replaced as MRDT with another target which is selected 

--- Document Chunk 8194 ---
for the first time according to clause 3.13.10.4.2. The driver shall be informed upon any 

--- Document Chunk 8195 ---
change of MRDT. 

--- Document Chunk 8196 ---
3.13.10.4.6 If the MRDT is either the EOA or the SvL, the on -board equipment shall display the 

--- Document Chunk 8197 ---
release speed, if given by the trackside or calculated on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 8198 ---
3.13.10.4.7 If the MRDT is neither the EOA nor the SvL, the indicated distance to the target shall 

--- Document Chunk 8199 ---
be the distance between the maximum safe front end and the location of the Permitted 

--- Document Chunk 8200 ---
speed supervision limit calculated for the target speed (see section 3.13.9.3.5 for the 

--- Document Chunk 8201 ---
calculation of this location), but limited to zero after this location is passed. 

--- Document Chunk 8202 ---
Target distance = 

--- Document Chunk 8203 ---
   0,max maxarg safefrontettP dVd   

--- Document Chunk 8204 ---
3.13.10.4.7.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 8205 ---
3.13.10.4.8 If the MRDT is either the EOA or the SvL, the indicated distance to the target shall be 

--- Document Chunk 8206 ---
calculated as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 8207 ---
Target distance = 

--- Document Chunk 8208 ---
    0,,minmax maxsafefrontSvLestfrontEOA dddd   

--- Document Chunk 8209 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 8220 ---
3.13.10.4.8.1 As long as the displayed values are locked due to SB feedback (see Appendix 

--- Document Chunk 8221 ---
A.3.10 for details), the on -board equipment shall ensure that the displayed Permitted 

--- Document Chunk 8222 ---
speed, the displayed SBI speed (if any) and the distance to target never increase (e.g. 

--- Document Chunk 8223 ---
due to the reduction of T_bs1 and T_bs 2 or e.g. due to relocation). In other terms if a 

--- Document Chunk 8224 ---
concerned displayed value (VP_DMI, VSBI_DMI or target distance) calculated as 

--- Document Chunk 8225 ---
above has a higher value than the previously displayed value, then the previous value 

--- Document Chunk 8226 ---
shall remain displayed until a further calculated value is lower than the displayed one. 

--- Document Chunk 8227 ---
3.13.10.4.9 The on-board shall consider the service brake command as available for use unless: 

--- Document Chunk 8228 ---
a) The service brake command is not implemented, OR 

--- Document Chunk 8229 ---
b) The national value inhibits its use. 

--- Document Chunk 8230 ---
3.13.10.4.10 The on -board equipment shall compare the  estimated speed and train position 

--- Document Chunk 8231 ---
with the ceiling and braking to target supervision limits and shall trigger /revoke 

--- Document Chunk 8232 ---
commands to the train interface (traction cut -off if implemented, service brake if 

--- Document Chunk 8233 ---
available for use or emergency brake) and supervision statuses, by evaluating and 

--- Document Chunk 8234 ---
taking into account the conditions as specified in clause 3.13.10.4.10.1. 

--- Document Chunk 8235 ---
3.13.10.4.10.1 The conditions in Table 8 and Table 10 shall be evaluated for each target related to 

--- Document Chunk 8236 ---
an MRSP speed dec rease or LOA, the conditions in Table 9 and Table 11 shall be 

--- Document Chunk 8237 ---
evaluated for the targets EOA and SvL and for the end of the maximum permitted 

--- Document Chunk 8238 ---
distance to run in Staff Responsible. 

--- Document Chunk 8239 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.13.10.4.12 Note: Figure 55 shows the parts of the ceiling speed and braking to target 

--- Document Chunk 8760 ---
supervision limits, which are used in target speed monitoring to trigger the brake 

--- Document Chunk 8761 ---
commands and the transitions between supervision  statuses. It does not show what is 

--- Document Chunk 8762 ---
displayed to the driver: in particular, the braking to target Permitted supervision limit is 

--- Document Chunk 8763 ---
displayed (even if not supervised) for values lower than the release speed. 

--- Document Chunk 8764 ---
3.13.10.4.13 In case of target EOA/SvL without any supervised re lease speed, the Table 9 

--- Document Chunk 8765 ---
and Table 11 shall be applied, by substituting V_release with the value 0. 

--- Document Chunk 8766 ---
3.13.10.4.13.1 In case the target is the location at the end of the maximum permitted distance to 

--- Document Chunk 8767 ---
run in Staff Responsi ble, the Table 9 and Table 11 shall be applied, by substituting 

--- Document Chunk 8768 ---
V_release with the value 0, SvL with staff responsible end location and by ignoring any 

--- Document Chunk 8769 ---
formula related to EOA. 

--- Document Chunk 8770 ---
3.13.10.4.14 A TI command shall be triggered if a corresponding triggering condition is met for 

--- Document Chunk 8771 ---
at least one target. On the other hand it shall be revoked only if a corresponding 

--- Document Chunk 8772 ---
revocation condition is met for each supervised target. 

--- Document Chunk 8773 ---
3.13.10.4.15 The on -board equipment shall execute the transitions between t he different 

--- Document Chunk 8774 ---
supervision statuses as described in Table 12 (see section 4.6.1 for details about the 

--- Document Chunk 8775 ---
symbols). A triggering condition shall be taken into account as soon as it is satisfied for 

--- Document Chunk 8776 ---
any target. On the other hand a transi tion from Overspeed, Warning or Intervention 

--- Document Chunk 8777 ---
status to the Indication status shall be made only if a revocation condition specified for 

--- Document Chunk 8778 ---
the concerned transition is met for each supervised target.

3.13.10.4.16 When the speed and distance monitoring function becomes active and the target 

--- Document Chunk 8832 ---
speed monitoring is the first one entered, the triggering conditio n t3 defined in Table 8 

--- Document Chunk 8833 ---
or Table 9 shall be checked for each target in order to determine whether the 

--- Document Chunk 8834 ---
Indication status applies. If it is not the case, the on -board shall immediately set the 

--- Document Chunk 8835 ---
supervision status to the relevant value, applying a transition from the Indication status 

--- Document Chunk 8836 ---
according to clause 3.13.10.4.15. 

--- Document Chunk 8837 ---
3.13.10.4.17 The Normal status is not used in target speed monitoring. However, in case the 

--- Document Chunk 8838 ---
target speed monitoring is entered and the supervision statu s was  previously set to 

--- Document Chunk 8839 ---
Normal, the on-board equipment shall immediately execute one of the transition s from 

--- Document Chunk 8840 ---
the Normal status, as specified in clause 3.13.10.4.15. 

--- Document Chunk 8841 ---
3.13.10.4.18 Note: Depending upon train speed/position it is possible that for some target(s) 

--- Document Chunk 8842 ---
none of the tri ggering conditions specified in table 8 and 9 is met. However the 

--- Document Chunk 8843 ---
conditions to enter the target speed monitoring are such (see condition [1] in table 16) 

--- Document Chunk 8844 ---
that the clauses 3.13.10.4.16 and 3.13.10.4.17 always allow determining a supervision 

--- Document Chunk 8845 ---
status. 

--- Document Chunk 8846 ---
3.13.10.5 Requirements for release speed monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 8847 ---
3.13.10.5.1 The on-board equipment shall display the Release speed. 

--- Document Chunk 8848 ---
3.13.10.5.2 The on-board equipment shall display the target distance in the same way as for target 

--- Document Chunk 8849 ---
speed monitoring, i.e. clauses 3.13.10.4.8 and 3.13.10.4.8.1 shall apply. 

--- Document Chunk 8850 ---
3.13.10.5.3 The braking to target Permitted speed supervision limit related to the MRDT (i.e. EOA 

--- Document Chunk 8851 ---
or SvL), as calculated in target speed monitoring from the EBD or SBD, shall also be 

--- Document Chunk 8852 ---
displayed in the same way as for target speed monitoring, i.e. clauses 3.13.10.4.3 and 

--- Document Chunk 8853 ---
3.13.10.4.8.1 shall apply. 

--- Document Chunk 8854 ---
3.13.10.5.4 The on -board equipment shall compare the estimated speed with the release speed 

--- Document Chunk 8855 ---
and shall trigger/revoke commands to the train interface (emergency brake) and 

--- Document Chunk 8856 ---
supervision statuses as described in Table 13 and Table 14. 

--- Document Chunk 8857 ---

--- Document Chunk 8938 ---

Table 16: Transitions between types of Speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 8990 ---
3.13.10.6.2 If a  transition of speed and distance monitoring occurs while a brake command is 

--- Document Chunk 8991 ---
already applied, the concerned command shall be maintained until the revocation 

--- Document Chunk 8992 ---
condition, if specified for the newly entered speed and distance monitoring, is fulfilled. 

--- Document Chunk 8993 ---
3.13.10.6.2.1 Note: Th is means that when the service brake is commanded in ceiling speed 

--- Document Chunk 8994 ---
monitoring while it is not available in target speed monitoring, the service brake 

--- Document Chunk 8995 ---
remains commanded when the on -board switches to target speed monitoring and is 

--- Document Chunk 8996 ---
only revoked when the Permitted speed supervision limit is no longer exceeded. 

--- Document Chunk 8997 ---
3.13.10.6.3 If a transition from target speed monitoring to ceiling speed or release speed 

--- Document Chunk 8998 ---
monitoring occurs while a traction cut -off command is already applied, the traction cut -

--- Document Chunk 8999 ---
off command shall be immediately revoked. 

--- Document Chunk 9000 ---
3.13.10.6.4 If a transition from target speed monitoring to release speed monitoring occurs while a 

--- Document Chunk 9001 ---
service brake command is already applied, the service brake command shall be 

--- Document Chunk 9002 ---
immediately revoked. 

--- Document Chunk 9003 ---

3.13.10.6.5 On executing a transition between types of speed and distance mon itoring, the 

--- Document Chunk 9015 ---
supervision status shall be determined according to the requirements specified for the 

--- Document Chunk 9016 ---
newly entered speed and distance monitoring. 

--- Document Chunk 9017 ---
3.13.11 Perturbation location 

--- Document Chunk 9018 ---
3.13.11.1 The purpose of the perturbation location is to trigger the MA request to the RBC in 

--- Document Chunk 9019 ---
order to renew the Movement Authority in due time before the train would have to 

--- Document Chunk 9020 ---
brake to an EOA/SvL or LOA target. 

--- Document Chunk 9021 ---
3.13.11.2 For the SvL or the LOA, the on -board shall calculate the perturbation location as 

--- Document Chunk 9022 ---
follows. 

--- Document Chunk 9023 ---
3.13.11.3 Starting from the first element of the MRSP (i.e. from  the start location of the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 9024 ---
stored track description), the on -board shall calculate the location of the Indication 

--- Document Chunk 9025 ---
supervision limit, valid for the speed of the MRSP element, taking into account the 

--- Document Chunk 9026 ---
following assumptions: 

--- Document Chunk 9027 ---
a) the estimated acceleration shall be set to “zero” 

--- Document Chunk 9028 ---
b) if not inhibited by National Value, the compensation of the inaccuracy of the speed 

--- Document Chunk 9029 ---
measurement shall be set to a value, calculated from the speed of the MRSP 

--- Document Chunk 9030 ---
element, as defined in SUBSET-041 § 5.3.1.2: V_delta0ind = f41(V_MRSP-n) 

--- Document Chunk 9031 ---
c) If available for use, the service brake feedback shall not have any effect: T_bs1ind 

--- Document Chunk 9032 ---
and T_bs2ind shall be set to T_bs if the service brake command is available for use, 

--- Document Chunk 9033 ---
otherwise they shall be set to “zero”. T_tractionind and T_beremind shall be defined 

--- Document Chunk 9034 ---
as in 3.13.9.3.2 for T_traction and T_berem by substituting T_bs2 with T_bs2ind 

--- Document Chunk 9035 ---
3.13.11.4 To calculate the EBI supervision limit, the same formulas defined above with V_est, 

--- Document Chunk 9036 ---
T_traction, T_berem and V_delta0 shall be applied, by substituting V_est with 

--- Document Chunk 9037 ---
V_MRSP-n, T_tra ction with T_tractionind, T_berem with T_beremind and V_delta0 

--- Document Chunk 9038 ---
with V_delta0ind. 

--- Document Chunk 9039 ---

3.13.11.9 If, in exceptional situation (e.g. after a shortening of MA), the EBD, SBD or GUI speed 

--- Document Chunk 9128 ---
at the start location of the MRSP is lower than the speed of the first element of the 

--- Document Chunk 9129 ---
MRSP, the location to trigger the MA request t o the RBC  shall be considered as 

--- Document Chunk 9130 ---
already passed.

--- Document Chunk 9132 ---
supervision limit are necessary to obtain a fully predictable p erturbation location, i.e. 

--- Document Chunk 9133 ---
independent from the measured acceleration and speed confidence interval. 

--- Document Chunk 9134 ---
3.14 Brake Command Handling and Protection against Undesirable 

--- Document Chunk 9135 ---
Train Movement 

--- Document Chunk 9136 ---
3.14.1 Brake Command Handling 

--- Document Chunk 9137 ---
3.14.1.1 Note: Whenever the type of brake used is not specified explicitly in the text, it shall be 

--- Document Chunk 9138 ---
interpreted as not being  important for technical interoperability and being a property of  

--- Document Chunk 9139 ---
the specific implementation.  

--- Document Chunk 9140 ---
3.14.1.2 In case only the application of  (the non -vital) service brake has been commanded and 

--- Document Chunk 9141 ---
the service brake fails to be applied, the emergency brake command shall be given. 

--- Document Chunk 9142 ---
3.14.1.3 If the emergency brake command was triggered due to a trip condition (see chapter 4) 

--- Document Chunk 9143 ---
the emergency brake command shall be released at standstill and after driver 

--- Document Chunk 9144 ---
acknowledgement of the trip condition. 

--- Document Chunk 9145 ---
3.14.1.4 For handling of brake commands resulting from  the speed and distance monitoring, 

--- Document Chunk 9146 ---
refer to section 3.13.10. 

--- Document Chunk 9147 ---
3.14.1.5 If the brake command was triggered due to roll away protection, reverse movement 

--- Document Chunk 9148 ---
protection or standstill supervision the brake command shall be released at standstill 

--- Document Chunk 9149 ---
and after driver acknowledgement.  

--- Document Chunk 9150 ---
3.14.1.6 If the brake command was triggered due to linking error, balise group message 

--- Document Chunk 9151 ---
inconsistency or RAMS related supervision error, the brake command shall be 

--- Document Chunk 9152 ---
released at standstill. 

--- Document Chunk 9153 ---
3.14.1.7 If the brake command was triggered due to supervision of the safe rad io connection 

--- Document Chunk 9154 ---
(T_NVCONTACT) the brake command shall be released at standstill or if a new 

--- Document Chunk 9155 ---
consistent message has been received from the RBC.  

--- Document Chunk 9156 ---
3.14.1.7.1 If the brake command was triggered due to an overpassed reversing distance related 

--- Document Chunk 9157 ---
to a reversing area or due to any further movement in the direction opposite to the train 

--- Document Chunk 9158 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 9159 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9160 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9161 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 9162 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 9163 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 9164 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 9165 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 9166 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 9167 ---
Page 153/204 

--- Document Chunk 9168 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9169 ---
orientation while the reversing distance is still overpassed , the brake command shall 

--- Document Chunk 9170 ---
be released if the reversing distance becomes extended so that the reversing distance 

--- Document Chunk 9171 ---
is no longer overpassed, or at standstill after driver acknowledgement. 

--- Document Chunk 9172 ---
3.14.1.7.2 If the brake command was triggered due to change of Train Data while running (see 

--- Document Chunk 9173 ---
section 5.17 procedure "Changing Train Data from sources different from the driver”), 

--- Document Chunk 9174 ---
the brake command shall be released at standstill and after driver acknowledgement. 

--- Document Chunk 9175 ---
3.14.1.7.3 If the brake command was triggered due to the detection of a train movement while 

--- Document Chunk 9176 ---
modifying/revalidating train data or while entering SR speed/distance limits, the brake 

--- Document Chunk 9177 ---
command shall be released at standstill and after driver acknowledgement.. 

--- Document Chunk 9178 ---
3.14.1.7.4 If the brake command was triggered due to an overpassed distance allowed for moving 

--- Document Chunk 9179 ---
backwards in Post Trip mode  or due to any further movement in the direction opposite 

--- Document Chunk 9180 ---
to the train orientation while the distance allowed for  moving backwards in Post Trip 

--- Document Chunk 9181 ---
mode is still overpassed , the brake command shall be released at standstill and after 

--- Document Chunk 9182 ---
driver acknowledgement. 

--- Document Chunk 9183 ---
3.14.1.7.5 If the brake command was triggered due to the driver not having acknowledged a text 

--- Document Chunk 9184 ---
message, the brake command shall be released after the driver has acknowledged the 

--- Document Chunk 9185 ---
text message. 

--- Document Chunk 9186 ---
3.14.1.8 An indication shall be given to the driver to indicate when the brakes can be released 

--- Document Chunk 9187 ---
and when an acknowledgement is requested. 

--- Document Chunk 9188 ---
3.14.2 Roll Away Protection 

--- Document Chunk 9189 ---
3.14.2.1 Note: This protection is only applicable if the required information can be obtained from 

--- Document Chunk 9190 ---
the direction controller. 

--- Document Chunk 9191 ---
3.14.2.2 The Roll Away Protection (RAP) shall prevent the train from moving in a direction, 

--- Document Chunk 9192 ---
which conflicts with the current position of the direction controller in the active desk. 

--- Document Chunk 9193 ---
3.14.2.3 If the controller is in neutral position, the RAP shall prevent forward and reverse 

--- Document Chunk 9194 ---
movements of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 9195 ---
3.14.2.4 When the system recognises a movement exceeding the national value for the allowed 

--- Document Chunk 9196 ---
roll away distance the brakes shall be triggered. 

--- Document Chunk 9197 ---
3.14.2.5 Refer to section 3.14.1. 

--- Document Chunk 9198 ---
3.14.2.6 An indication shall be given to the driver showing when the RAP is commanding the 

--- Document Chunk 9199 ---
brakes. 

--- Document Chunk 9200 ---
3.14.2.7 After revocation of the brake command the RAP shall be re-initialised using the current 

--- Document Chunk 9201 ---
position of the train as the new reference location. 

--- Document Chunk 9202 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 9203 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9204 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9205 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 9206 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 9207 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 9208 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 9209 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 9210 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 9211 ---
Page 154/204 

--- Document Chunk 9212 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9213 ---
3.14.3 Reverse Movement Protection 

--- Document Chunk 9214 ---
3.14.3.1 The Reverse Movement Protection (RMP) shall prevent the train from moving in the 

--- Document Chunk 9215 ---
opposite direction to the permitted one. The permitted movement direction of a train 

--- Document Chunk 9216 ---
shall be the one of the currently valid MA, if availabl e on -board. See chapter 4 

--- Document Chunk 9217 ---
concerning permitted direction for special cases. 

--- Document Chunk 9218 ---
3.14.3.2 When a reverse movement is detected, the brake command shall be triggered after a 

--- Document Chunk 9219 ---
distance specified by the national value. 

--- Document Chunk 9220 ---
3.14.3.3 Refer to section 3.14.1. 

--- Document Chunk 9221 ---
3.14.3.4 An indication shall be given to the driver showing when the RMP is commanding the 

--- Document Chunk 9222 ---
brakes. 

--- Document Chunk 9223 ---
3.14.3.5 After revocation of the brake command the RMP shall be reinitialised using the current 

--- Document Chunk 9224 ---
position of the train as the new reference location. 

--- Document Chunk 9225 ---
3.14.3.6 Information received from balises during reverse movement shall be ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 9226 ---
3.14.4 Standstill supervision 

--- Document Chunk 9227 ---
3.14.4.1 This function shall prevent the train from moving. 

--- Document Chunk 9228 ---
3.14.4.2 When a movement is detected, the brake command shall be triggered after a distance 

--- Document Chunk 9229 ---
specified by the national value. 

--- Document Chunk 9230 ---
3.14.4.3 Refer to section 3.14.1. 

--- Document Chunk 9231 ---
3.14.4.4 After revocation of the brake command the standstill supervision shall be re-initialised. 

--- Document Chunk 9232 ---
3.14.4.5 If a cab is active, an indication shall be given to the driver showing when the Standstill 

--- Document Chunk 9233 ---
Supervision is commanding the brakes. 

--- Document Chunk 9234 ---
3.15 Special functions 

--- Document Chunk 9235 ---
3.15.1 RBC/RBC Handover 

--- Document Chunk 9236 ---
3.15.1.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 9237 ---
3.15.1.1.1 The RBC/RBC Handover principles are such that trains are able to pass from one RBC 

--- Document Chunk 9238 ---
area to another automatically (without driver action). 

--- Document Chunk 9239 ---
3.15.1.1.2 This is also granted when, due to a failure in the on -board radio commu nication 

--- Document Chunk 9240 ---
system, the on -board is no longer able to manage two communication sessions at 

--- Document Chunk 9241 ---
once. Thereby, the behaviour of the RBCs is independent from such on -board 

--- Document Chunk 9242 ---
degraded situation. 

--- Document Chunk 9243 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 9244 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9245 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9246 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 9247 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 9248 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 9249 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 9250 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 9251 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 9252 ---
Page 155/204 

--- Document Chunk 9253 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9254 ---
3.15.1.1.3 However, an RBC/RBC handover performed by a train with only one communication 

--- Document Chunk 9255 ---
session available may result in performance penalties since it will not be able to 

--- Document Chunk 9256 ---
“prepare” (session establishment, version determination, …) the expected supervision 

--- Document Chunk 9257 ---
by the Accepting RBC until the on-board disconnects from the Handing Over RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9258 ---
3.15.1.1.4 In level 3, trains following the one with only one communication session available will 

--- Document Chunk 9259 ---
always suffer performance penalties since no more position reports will be issued from 

--- Document Chunk 9260 ---
the disconnection from the Handing Over RBC until the connection to the Accepting 

--- Document Chunk 9261 ---
RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9262 ---
3.15.1.2 Handing Over RBC 

--- Document Chunk 9263 ---
3.15.1.2.1 When the Handing Over RBC detects that a route is set for a train to enter another 

--- Document Chunk 9264 ---
RBC area, it shall send: 

--- Document Chunk 9265 ---
a) Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 9266 ---
b) To the Accepting RBC the following information: 

--- Document Chunk 9267 ---
 The ETCS identity of the on-board equipment; 

--- Document Chunk 9268 ---
 The border lo cation that will be passed by the train when entering the Accepting 

--- Document Chunk 9269 ---
RBC area; 

--- Document Chunk 9270 ---
 Current mode of the on-board equipment; 

--- Document Chunk 9271 ---
 For a leading engine, Train Data and Train Running Number; 

--- Document Chunk 9272 ---
 The system versions supported by the on-board equipment; 

--- Document Chunk 9273 ---
 Optionally, for a non-leading engine, the ETCS identity of the leading engine. 

--- Document Chunk 9274 ---
3.15.1.2.2 The Handing Over RBC shall not send information to an on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 9275 ---
concerning the route in advance of the border without receiving the corresponding 

--- Document Chunk 9276 ---
information from the Accepting RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9277 ---
3.15.1.2.3 It shall be possible for the Handing Over RBC to request route related information from 

--- Document Chunk 9278 ---
the Accepting RBC, limited to a maximum amount of data. 

--- Document Chunk 9279 ---
3.15.1.2.3.1 Route related information is : 

--- Document Chunk 9280 ---
a) Movement authorities 

--- Document Chunk 9281 ---
b) Linking 

--- Document Chunk 9282 ---
c) International static speed profiles 

--- Document Chunk 9283 ---
d) Axle Load Speed profiles 

--- Document Chunk 9284 ---
e) Gradients 

--- Document Chunk 9285 ---
f) Temporary speed restrictions 

--- Document Chunk 9286 ---
g) Mode profiles 

--- Document Chunk 9287 ---
h) Intentionally deleted 

--- Document Chunk 9288 ---
i) Track Conditions 

--- Document Chunk 9289 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 9290 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9291 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9292 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 9293 ---

--- Document Chunk 9296 ---

--- Document Chunk 9297 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 9298 ---
Page 156/204 

--- Document Chunk 9299 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9300 ---
j) Level Transition orders 

--- Document Chunk 9301 ---
k) Intentionally deleted 

--- Document Chunk 9302 ---
l) Route Suitability Data 

--- Document Chunk 9303 ---
m)  National Values 

--- Document Chunk 9304 ---
n) Adhesion Factor 

--- Document Chunk 9305 ---
o) Level Crossings 

--- Document Chunk 9306 ---
p) Permitted Braking Distance Information 

--- Document Chunk 9307 ---
3.15.1.2.3.2 Note: The amount of information to be sent between the RBCs is depending on the 

--- Document Chunk 9308 ---
implementation trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 9309 ---
3.15.1.2.4 Note: Route related information received from the Accepting RBC will be processed by 

--- Document Chunk 9310 ---
the Handing Over RBC if possible. 

--- Document Chunk 9311 ---
3.15.1.2.5 Deleted.  

--- Document Chunk 9312 ---
3.15.1.2.6 When the Handing Over RBC r eceives a position report and detects that the maximum 

--- Document Chunk 9313 ---
safe front end of the train has passed the border location, it shall inform the Accepting 

--- Document Chunk 9314 ---
RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9315 ---
3.15.1.2.6.1 Note: This information might be needed to inform the signalman of the Accepting 

--- Document Chunk 9316 ---
RBC that the train has entered the Accepting RBC area. 

--- Document Chunk 9317 ---
3.15.1.2.7 When the Handing Over RBC receives a position report and detects that the minimum 

--- Document Chunk 9318 ---
safe rear end of the train has crossed the border, it shall send a disconnection order to 

--- Document Chunk 9319 ---
the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 9320 ---
3.15.1.2.8 When the Accepting RBC informs the Handing Over RBC that it has taken over the 

--- Document Chunk 9321 ---
responsibility, the latter shall stop sending route related information to the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 9322 ---
equipment.  

--- Document Chunk 9323 ---
3.15.1.2.9 When the Handing Over RBC detects that the transition to the Accepting RBC has to 

--- Document Chunk 9324 ---
be cancelled, it shall send this cancellation information to the Accepting RBC (including 

--- Document Chunk 9325 ---
the train identification). 

--- Document Chunk 9326 ---
3.15.1.2.9.1 Note: For instance, the cancellation procedure can be triggered by:  

--- Document Chunk 9327 ---
 Change to a route which does no more include the border; 

--- Document Chunk 9328 ---
 The sending of an “end of mission” information from the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 9329 ---
3.15.1.3 On-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 9330 ---
3.15.1.3.1 When receiving an order to switch to another RBC at a given location, the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 9331 ---
equipment shall: 

--- Document Chunk 9332 ---
a) Establish the communication session with the Accepting RBC; 

--- Document Chunk 9333 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 9334 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9335 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9336 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 9337 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 9338 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 9339 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 9340 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 9341 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 9342 ---
Page 157/204 

--- Document Chunk 9343 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9344 ---
b) Send a position report to the Handing Ov er RBC when the maximum safe front end 

--- Document Chunk 9345 ---
of the train passes the given location; 

--- Document Chunk 9346 ---
c) Send a position report to the Handing Over RBC when the minimum safe rear end 

--- Document Chunk 9347 ---
of the train passes the given location; 

--- Document Chunk 9348 ---
3.15.1.3.2 Exception to 3.15.1.3.1 a) (degraded situation):  If the on-board equipment  is able to 

--- Document Chunk 9349 ---
handle only one communication session at a given time, it shall wait until the session 

--- Document Chunk 9350 ---
with the Handing over RBC is terminated due to crossing the border and then establish 

--- Document Chunk 9351 ---
the session with the Accepting RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9352 ---
3.15.1.3.3 As soon as the on -board equipment has established the session with the Accepting 

--- Document Chunk 9353 ---
RBC, it shall send its Train Data unless it is in sleeping or non leading mode. 

--- Document Chunk 9354 ---
3.15.1.3.4 When the on -board equipment is connected to both RBCs, it shall send its position 

--- Document Chunk 9355 ---
reports to both of them with the use of the position report parameters valid for the 

--- Document Chunk 9356 ---
Handing Over RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9357 ---
3.15.1.3.4.1 If the on -board equipment is connected to both RBCs, and it executes an End of 

--- Document Chunk 9358 ---
Mission, it shall execute the End of Mission procedure with both RBCs 

--- Document Chunk 9359 ---
3.15.1.3.5 As soon as the on-board sends a position report directly to the Accepting RBC with its 

--- Document Chunk 9360 ---
maximum safe front end having passed the border, it shall use information received 

--- Document Chunk 9361 ---
from the Accepting RBC and only a disconnection order shall be accepted from the 

--- Document Chunk 9362 ---
Handing Over RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9363 ---
3.15.1.3.5.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 9364 ---
3.15.1.3.6 While both  communication sessions are opened, if information is received from the 

--- Document Chunk 9365 ---
Accepting RBC before a position report is sent to the Accepting RBC with the 

--- Document Chunk 9366 ---
maximum safe front end having passed the border, this information shall be stored on -

--- Document Chunk 9367 ---
board.  

--- Document Chunk 9368 ---
Exception: The acknowledgement of Train Data shall be immediately accepted by the 

--- Document Chunk 9369 ---
on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 9370 ---
3.15.1.3.6.1 Note: for the exhaustive list of accepted/rejected information, please refer to 

--- Document Chunk 9371 ---
Chapter 4 Use of received information.  

--- Document Chunk 9372 ---
3.15.1.3.7 When the train front end passes the ann ounced border or when an order to execute 

--- Document Chunk 9373 ---
the RBC transition immediately is received, the on -board shall substitute the current 

--- Document Chunk 9374 ---
valid RBC ID/phone number with those of the Accepting RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9375 ---
3.15.1.3.8 After this substitution, the on -board shall however retain the RBC ID /phone number of 

--- Document Chunk 9376 ---
the Handing Over RBC until at least one of the following conditions is fulfilled: 

--- Document Chunk 9377 ---
a) Min safe rear end of the train has passed the border and the communication 

--- Document Chunk 9378 ---
session with this Handing Over RBC has been terminated, 

--- Document Chunk 9379 ---
b) The RBC transition order is deleted according to A.3.4 or 4.10. 

--- Document Chunk 9380 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.15.1.3.8.1 Note: Even after the train front end has passed the border, the on -board may have 

--- Document Chunk 9392 ---
to maintain the communication session with the Handing Over RBC (see 3.5.4) or re -

--- Document Chunk 9393 ---
establish it (see 3.5.3.4 f) ) and needs therefore to r emember the RBC ID/phone 

--- Document Chunk 9394 ---
number of this RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9395 ---
3.15.1.3.9 In case the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment has reported that the train has passed 

--- Document Chunk 9396 ---
with its min safe rear end the announced border and no order to terminate the session 

--- Document Chunk 9397 ---
is received from the Handing Over RBC within  a fixed waiting time (see Appendix 

--- Document Chunk 9398 ---
A.3.1) from the time the position report was sent, it shall repeatedly send a position 

--- Document Chunk 9399 ---
report with the fixed waiting time after each repetition, until the order to terminate the 

--- Document Chunk 9400 ---
session is received, or the defined number  of repetitions (see Appendix A.3.1) has 

--- Document Chunk 9401 ---
been reached. If no reply is received within the fixed waiting time after the last 

--- Document Chunk 9402 ---
repetition, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall terminate the communication 

--- Document Chunk 9403 ---
session with the Handing Over RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9404 ---
3.15.1.4 Accepting RBC 

--- Document Chunk 9405 ---
3.15.1.4.1 The Accepting RBC shall keep route related information sent to the Handing Over RBC 

--- Document Chunk 9406 ---
updated. In particular, this possibly includes temporary speed restrictions. 

--- Document Chunk 9407 ---
3.15.1.4.2 As soon as the Accepting RBC receives from the on -board equipment a position report 

--- Document Chunk 9408 ---
and detects that the maximum safe front end of the train has passed the border, it shall 

--- Document Chunk 9409 ---
inform the Handing Over RBC that it has taken over the responsibility. 

--- Document Chunk 9410 ---
3.15.1.4.3 When the Accepting RBC receives Train Data from both the on -board equipment and 

--- Document Chunk 9411 ---
the Handing over RBC Train Dat a provided by the on -board equipment shall take 

--- Document Chunk 9412 ---
precedence. 

--- Document Chunk 9413 ---
3.15.1.4.4 If the Accepting RBC receives a cancellation information from the Handing Over RBC, 

--- Document Chunk 9414 ---
it shall send an order to terminate the communication session to the corresponding on -

--- Document Chunk 9415 ---
board equipment (if already established). 

--- Document Chunk 9416 ---
3.15.1.4.5 The Accepting RBC shall comply with the maximum amount of data contained in the 

--- Document Chunk 9417 ---
last received route related information request from the Handing Over RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9418 ---
3.15.1.5 RBC/RBC message acknowledgement 

--- Document Chunk 9419 ---
3.15.1.5.1 As soon as a consistent RBC/RBC message including the  request for 

--- Document Chunk 9420 ---
acknowledgement is received, the receiving RBC shall send an acknowledgement to 

--- Document Chunk 9421 ---
the emitting RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9422 ---
3.15.1.5.2 The RBC/RBC message is consistent when all checks have been completed 

--- Document Chunk 9423 ---
successfully: 

--- Document Chunk 9424 ---
a) It has passed the checks performed by the RBC/RBC Safe Commun ication 

--- Document Chunk 9425 ---
Interface protocol (see SUBSET-098); 

--- Document Chunk 9426 ---
b) Variables in the message do not have invalid values. 

--- Document Chunk 9427 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 9440 ---
3.15.2 Handling of Trains with Non Leading Engines 

--- Document Chunk 9441 ---
3.15.2.1 It is possible to operate a train using more than one engine, each engine being under 

--- Document Chunk 9442 ---
the control of a driver. 

--- Document Chunk 9443 ---
3.15.2.2 Only the leading engine is responsible for the train movement supervision functions. 

--- Document Chunk 9444 ---
3.15.3 Splitting/joining 

--- Document Chunk 9445 ---
3.15.3.1 ERTMS/ETCS allow s Splitting and Joining using the  normal supervision functions 

--- Document Chunk 9446 ---
available (e.g. On-sight, Shunting). 

--- Document Chunk 9447 ---
3.15.3.2 Splitting only refers to the case that the two resulting trains contain at least one 

--- Document Chunk 9448 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment each. 

--- Document Chunk 9449 ---
3.15.3.2.1 Note: This must be ensured by operational procedures. 

--- Document Chunk 9450 ---
3.15.3.3 ERTMS/ETCS is not responsible for providing information that a Splitting/Joining 

--- Document Chunk 9451 ---
operation has been correctly completed (technical aspect and/or operational aspect). 

--- Document Chunk 9452 ---
3.15.3.4 Justification: ERTMS/ETCS is not able to provide this information. Splitting and Joining 

--- Document Chunk 9453 ---
requires the fulfilment of operating rules ensuring that a Splitting/Joining operation has 

--- Document Chunk 9454 ---
been correctly completed (e.g. physical disconnection). 

--- Document Chunk 9455 ---
3.15.4 Reversing of movement direction 

--- Document Chunk 9456 ---
3.15.4.1 It shall be possible to send in advance to an on -board equipment information about 

--- Document Chunk 9457 ---
areas, where initiation of reversing of movement direction is possible, i.e. change the 

--- Document Chunk 9458 ---
direction of train movement without changing the train orientation. 

--- Document Chunk 9459 ---
3.15.4.1.1 A new reversing area given from the trackside shall replace the one already available 

--- Document Chunk 9460 ---
on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 9461 ---
3.15.4.2 Together with  start and end of reversing area, the following supervision information 

--- Document Chunk 9462 ---
shall be sent: 

--- Document Chunk 9463 ---
a) Maximum distance to run in the direction opposite to the orientation of the reversing 

--- Document Chunk 9464 ---
area, the fixed reference location being the end location of the area where reversing 

--- Document Chunk 9465 ---
of movement is permitted with which the maximum distance information is sent. 

--- Document Chunk 9466 ---
b) Reversing mode speed limit allowed during reverse movement. 

--- Document Chunk 9467 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.15.4.4 While at standstill with the front end of the train inside the indicated area, it shall be 

--- Document Chunk 9540 ---
possible for the driver to reverse the direction of movement. 

--- Document Chunk 9541 ---
3.15.4.5 The on -board equipment shall allow movement in the direction opposite to the train 

--- Document Chunk 9542 ---

--- Document Chunk 9543 ---

--- Document Chunk 9544 ---

--- Document Chunk 9546 ---
movement is permitted. 

--- Document Chunk 9547 ---
3.15.4.8 If the end location of the maximum distance to run in the opposite direction is passed 

--- Document Chunk 9548 ---
by the train front end, the emergency brake command shall be triggered. 

--- Document Chunk 9549 ---
3.15.5 Track ahead free 

--- Document Chunk 9550 ---
3.15.5.1 In a level 2/3 area, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment is able to handle a track 

--- Document Chunk 9551 ---
ahead free request given by the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9552 ---
3.15.5.2 The track ahead free request from the RBC shall indicate to the on-board 

--- Document Chunk 9553 ---
a) at which location the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall begin to display the 

--- Document Chunk 9554 ---
request to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 9555 ---
b) at which location the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall stop to display the 

--- Document Chunk 9556 ---
request to the driver (in case the driver did not acknowledge). 

--- Document Chunk 9557 ---
3.15.5.3 As long as it is displayed, the driver has the possibility to acknowledge the track ahead 

--- Document Chunk 9558 ---
free request (meaning the driver confirms that the track between the head of the train 

--- Document Chunk 9559 ---
and the next signal or board marking signal position is free). 

--- Document Chunk 9560 ---
3.15.5.4 When t he driver acknowledges, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall stop 

--- Document Chunk 9561 ---
displaying the request, and shall inform the RBC that the track ahead is free. 

--- Document Chunk 9562 ---
3.15.5.5 There is no restrictive consequence by the on -board system if the driver does not 

--- Document Chunk 9563 ---
acknowledge. 

--- Document Chunk 9564 ---
3.15.5.6 A new track ahead free request shall replace the one previously received and stored. 

--- Document Chunk 9565 ---
3.15.6 Handling of National Systems 

--- Document Chunk 9566 ---
3.15.6.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board support s driving on national infrastructure u nder the 

--- Document Chunk 9567 ---
supervision of National Systems. 

--- Document Chunk 9568 ---
3.15.6.2 In case the ERTMS/ETCS  on-board equipment is  interfaced to a National System 

--- Document Chunk 9569 ---
through an STM, refer to Subset 035 for detailed requirements. 

--- Document Chunk 9570 ---

3.15.7 Tolerance of Big Metal Mass 

--- Document Chunk 9590 ---
3.15.7.1 Big metal object in the track, exceeding the limits for big metal masses as defined in 

--- Document Chunk 9591 ---
Subset-036, section 6.5.2 “Metal Masses in the Track” may trigger an alarm reporting 

--- Document Chunk 9592 ---
a malfunction for the onboard balise transmission function. 

--- Document Chunk 9593 ---
3.15.7.2 In Levels 0/NTC, the alarms which may be triggered by metal masses shall be ignored 

--- Document Chunk 9594 ---
for a defined distance (see A .3.1). If the alarm persists for a longer distance the 

--- Document Chunk 9595 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall trigger a safety reaction. 

--- Document Chunk 9596 ---
3.15.7.3 Justification: Ignoring the alarm for a defined distance eliminates the need to equip all 

--- Document Chunk 9597 ---
excessive big metal masses with track condition “Big Metal Mass” outside ETCS fitted 

--- Document Chunk 9598 ---
areas. 

--- Document Chunk 9599 ---
3.15.8 Cold Movement Detection 

--- Document Chunk 9600 ---
3.15.8.1 After being switched off (i.e. once in No Power mode), the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 9601 ---
equipment shall be capable, if fitted with, to detect and record whether the engine has 

--- Document Chunk 9602 ---
been moved or not, during a period of at least 72 hours. 

--- Document Chunk 9603 ---
3.15.8.2 When powered on again, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall use, if 

--- Document Chunk 9604 ---
available, the memorised information about cold movement in order to update the 

--- Document Chunk 9605 ---
status of information stored by on -board equipment (see chapter 4 section 4.11 for 

--- Document Chunk 9606 ---
details). 

--- Document Chunk 9607 ---
3.15.8.3 Note: information memorised by Cold Movement Detection function is considered as 

--- Document Chunk 9608 ---
not available if: 

--- Document Chunk 9609 ---
a) no Cold Movement Detection function is implemented in the ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 9610 ---
board equipment, OR 

--- Document Chunk 9611 ---
b) the Cold Movement Detection function has encountered a condition, during the No 

--- Document Chunk 9612 ---
Power period, which prevents the use of the Cold Movement informatio n (e.g. the 

--- Document Chunk 9613 ---
battery ensuring the Cold Movement Detection function has run down during the No 

--- Document Chunk 9614 ---
Power period). 

--- Document Chunk 9615 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 9616 ---

--- Document Chunk 9626 ---
3.15.9 Virtual Balise Cover 

--- Document Chunk 9627 ---
3.15.9.1 It shall be possible to se t and remove from balise a Virtual Balise Cover (VBC). A VBC 

--- Document Chunk 9628 ---
is defined by: 

--- Document Chunk 9629 ---
a) A marker corresponding to  balises to be ignored by the on -board together with the 

--- Document Chunk 9630 ---
area (country or region) in which the VBC is applicable. The VBC marker and the 

--- Document Chunk 9631 ---
country/region identity form the unique VBC identity. 

--- Document Chunk 9632 ---
b) Its validity period. 

--- Document Chunk 9633 ---
3.15.9.2 During a start of mission, the driver shall have the opportunity to set a new VBC, or to 

--- Document Chunk 9634 ---
remove an existing one. 

--- Document Chunk 9635 ---
3.15.9.3 As long as a VBC is stored on-board: 

--- Document Chunk 9636 ---
a) The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall ignore any balise telegram that 

--- Document Chunk 9637 ---
includes a VBC marker  and a country/region identity that both match the VBC 

--- Document Chunk 9638 ---
identity. 

--- Document Chunk 9639 ---
b) No reaction shall be applied if errors in the reading of the rest of such balise 

--- Document Chunk 9640 ---
telegram occur. 

--- Document Chunk 9641 ---
3.15.9.4 If the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment receives from balise or from driver a new 

--- Document Chunk 9642 ---
VBC with the same VBC identity as an already stored VBC, the new VBC sha ll replace 

--- Document Chunk 9643 ---
the previous one, including its validity period. 

--- Document Chunk 9644 ---
3.15.9.5 A VBC shall be retained on-board when the on -board equipment is switched off (i.e. 

--- Document Chunk 9645 ---
enters No Power mode)  and shall remai n applicable when powered on  again. It shall 

--- Document Chunk 9646 ---
be deleted when: 

--- Document Chunk 9647 ---
a) it is ordered by trackside, or 

--- Document Chunk 9648 ---
b) its validity period has elapsed, or 

--- Document Chunk 9649 ---
c) it is removed by the driver (during Start of Mission), or 

--- Document Chunk 9650 ---
d) a mismatch is detected between the country/region identity read from a balise group 

--- Document Chunk 9651 ---
and the country/region identity of the VBC. Not e: this means that the reception of a 

--- Document Chunk 9652 ---
consistent balise group message is a necessary condition for deleting a VBC due to 

--- Document Chunk 9653 ---
mismatching country/region identities. 

--- Document Chunk 9654 ---
3.15.10 Advance display of route related information 

--- Document Chunk 9655 ---
3.15.10.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall display an overview of th e gradient 

--- Document Chunk 9656 ---
profile (as received from trackside), of the MRSP, of the track conditions  (except the 

--- Document Chunk 9657 ---
tunnel stopping areas) , of the first I ndication location , if any (only in Ceiling Speed 

--- Document Chunk 9658 ---
monitoring), and of the EOA/LOA, with the remaining distances referred  to the train 

--- Document Chunk 9659 ---
front end position. 

--- Document Chunk 9660 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 9661 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9662 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9663 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 9664 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 9665 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 9666 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 9667 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 9668 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 9669 ---
Page 164/204 

--- Document Chunk 9670 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9671 ---
3.15.10.2 With regards to the MRSP, the track conditions and the EOA/LOA, the remaining 

--- Document Chunk 9672 ---
distances shall be computed taking into account the min safe, the estimated or the 

--- Document Chunk 9673 ---
max safe train front end position depending on their respective supervision. 

--- Document Chunk 9674 ---
3.15.10.3 With regards to the gradient profile, the remaining distances shall be computed taking 

--- Document Chunk 9675 ---
into account the estimated train front end position. 

--- Document Chunk 9676 ---
3.15.10.3.1 With regards to the first Indication location, the remaini ng distance shall be computed 

--- Document Chunk 9677 ---
as specified in clauses 3.13.10.3.8 and 3.13.10.3.8.1. 

--- Document Chunk 9678 ---
3.15.10.4 The overview of route related information shall be restricted to the elements contained 

--- Document Chunk 9679 ---
within the movement authority and up to the first target at zero speed, if any. 

--- Document Chunk 9680 ---
3.16 Data Consistency 

--- Document Chunk 9681 ---
3.16.1 Criteria of consistency 

--- Document Chunk 9682 ---
3.16.1.1 The on-board shall not consider a message transmitted from the trackside if any of the 

--- Document Chunk 9683 ---
following criteria is not fulfilled. 

--- Document Chunk 9684 ---
a) Correctness of the received message: the whole message shall be complete and 

--- Document Chunk 9685 ---
respect the ETCS language; variables shall not have invalid values  

--- Document Chunk 9686 ---
b) The message shall be received in due time. 

--- Document Chunk 9687 ---
c) The message shall be received at the right expected location. 

--- Document Chunk 9688 ---
3.16.1.1.1 Regarding a): a value of a variable is invalid when a spare value is used. 

--- Document Chunk 9689 ---
3.16.2 Balises 

--- Document Chunk 9690 ---
3.16.2.1 Definitions 

--- Document Chunk 9691 ---
3.16.2.1.1 The information that is sent from a balise is called a balise telegram. 

--- Document Chunk 9692 ---
3.16.2.1.2 The whole set of information (balise telegram or telegrams) coming from a balise 

--- Document Chunk 9693 ---
group is called a balise group message.  

--- Document Chunk 9694 ---
3.16.2.1.2.1 Note: In case of a balise group containing a single balise, telegram and message 

--- Document Chunk 9695 ---
coincide. 

--- Document Chunk 9696 ---
3.16.2.1.3 Intentionally deleted.  

--- Document Chunk 9697 ---
3.16.2.2 General 

--- Document Chunk 9698 ---
3.16.2.2.1 If the on-board is not able to recognise whether a balise group is linked or unlinked (if 

--- Document Chunk 9699 ---
none of the balises in the balise group can be read correctly), it shall consider it as 

--- Document Chunk 9700 ---
unlinked. 

--- Document Chunk 9701 ---
3.16.2.2.2 A balise within a balise group shall be regarded as missed if 

--- Document Chunk 9702 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 9703 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9704 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9705 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 9706 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 9707 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 9708 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 9709 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 9710 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 9711 ---
Page 165/204 

--- Document Chunk 9712 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9713 ---
a) No balise is found within the maximum distance between balises from the previous 

--- Document Chunk 9714 ---
balise in the group. 

--- Document Chunk 9715 ---
or 

--- Document Chunk 9716 ---
b) A following balise within the group has been passed. 

--- Document Chunk 9717 ---
3.16.2.3 Linking Consistency 

--- Document Chunk 9718 ---
3.16.2.3.1 If linking information is used the on -board shall react according to t he linking reaction 

--- Document Chunk 9719 ---
information in the following cases: 

--- Document Chunk 9720 ---
a) If the location reference of the expected balise group is found in rear of the 

--- Document Chunk 9721 ---
expectation window 

--- Document Chunk 9722 ---
b) If the location reference of the expected balise group is not found inside the 

--- Document Chunk 9723 ---
expectation window (i.e . the end of  the expectation window has been reached 

--- Document Chunk 9724 ---
without having found the expected balise group) 

--- Document Chunk 9725 ---
c) If inside the expectation window of the expected balise group another announced 

--- Document Chunk 9726 ---
balise group, expected later, is found. 

--- Document Chunk 9727 ---
3.16.2.3.1.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment s hall reject the message from  a balise 

--- Document Chunk 9728 ---
group found with its location reference outside its expectation window. 

--- Document Chunk 9729 ---
3.16.2.3.2 The on-board shall reject the message from the expected group and trip the train if the 

--- Document Chunk 9730 ---
balise group is passed in the unexpected direction. 

--- Document Chunk 9731 ---
3.16.2.3.2.1 Exception: When the expected balise group is referred in the linking information 

--- Document Chunk 9732 ---
with a balise group with ID “unknown”, 3.4.4.4.2.1 shall apply. 

--- Document Chunk 9733 ---
3.16.2.3.3 If the location reference balise of the group is duplicated and the on -board is only able 

--- Document Chunk 9734 ---
to correctly evaluate the d uplicating one, the duplicating one shall be used as location 

--- Document Chunk 9735 ---
reference instead. 

--- Document Chunk 9736 ---
3.16.2.3.4 If the balise duplicating the location reference balise is used as location reference for 

--- Document Chunk 9737 ---
the group, and is found within the expectation window, no linking reaction shall be 

--- Document Chunk 9738 ---
applied. 

--- Document Chunk 9739 ---
3.16.2.4 Balise Group Message Consistency 

--- Document Chunk 9740 ---
3.16.2.4.1 If linking information is used, the on -board shall reject the message from a linked 

--- Document Chunk 9741 ---
balise group found in the expected location and react according to the linking reaction 

--- Document Chunk 9742 ---
in the following cases: 

--- Document Chunk 9743 ---
a) A balise is missed inside the group. 

--- Document Chunk 9744 ---
b) A balise is detected but no telegram is decoded (e.g. wrong CRC,...). 

--- Document Chunk 9745 ---
c) Variables in the balise group message have invalid values. 

--- Document Chunk 9746 ---
d) Message counters do not match (see 3.16.2.4.7) 

--- Document Chunk 9747 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 9748 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9749 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9750 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 9751 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 9752 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 9753 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 9754 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 9755 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 9756 ---
Page 166/204 

--- Document Chunk 9757 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9758 ---
3.16.2.4.2 Exception: Concerning a) and b) above, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 9759 ---
not reject the message and shall not apply the linking reaction if the balise not found, 

--- Document Chunk 9760 ---
or not decoded, is duplicated within the balise group and the duplicating one is 

--- Document Chunk 9761 ---
correctly read. 

--- Document Chunk 9762 ---
3.16.2.4.3 If linking information is used, the on -board shall re ject the message from a balise 

--- Document Chunk 9763 ---
group marked as linked but not included in the linking information. No reaction shall be 

--- Document Chunk 9764 ---
applied, even if errors in the reading of the balise group occur. 

--- Document Chunk 9765 ---
3.16.2.4.4 If no linking information is used, the on -board shall reject the messa ge from a balise 

--- Document Chunk 9766 ---
group marked as linked and command application of the service brake in the following 

--- Document Chunk 9767 ---
cases: 

--- Document Chunk 9768 ---
a) A balise is missed inside the group. 

--- Document Chunk 9769 ---
b) A balise is detected, but no telegram is decoded (e.g. wrong CRC). 

--- Document Chunk 9770 ---
c) Variables in the balise group message have invalid values. 

--- Document Chunk 9771 ---
d) Message counters do not match (see 3.16.2.4.7) 

--- Document Chunk 9772 ---
3.16.2.4.4.1 Exceptions: Concerning a) and b) of clause 3.16.2.4.4, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board 

--- Document Chunk 9773 ---
equipment:  

--- Document Chunk 9774 ---
a) shall not reject the message and shall not command application of the service brake 

--- Document Chunk 9775 ---
if the balise not found, or not decoded, is duplicated within the balise group, the 

--- Document Chunk 9776 ---
duplicating one is correctly read and contains: 

--- Document Chunk 9777 ---
 directional information while the orientation of the balise group can still be 

--- Document Chunk 9778 ---
evaluated, or 

--- Document Chunk 9779 ---
 only information valid for both directions, or 

--- Document Chunk 9780 ---
 neither directional information nor information valid for both directions, or 

--- Document Chunk 9781 ---
 only data to be used by applications outside ERTMS/ETCS, or 

--- Document Chunk 9782 ---
 only data to be used by applications outside ERTMS/ETCS  together with 

--- Document Chunk 9783 ---
other information valid for both directions. 

--- Document Chunk 9784 ---
b) shall not command application of the service brake  if the telegram correctly read  

--- Document Chunk 9785 ---
from another balise of the group contains the information “ Inhibition of balise group 

--- Document Chunk 9786 ---
message consistency reaction”. 

--- Document Chunk 9787 ---
3.16.2.4.4.2 Concerning clause 3.16.2.4.4, if the service brake is applied,  the location based 

--- Document Chunk 9788 ---
information stored on -board shall be shortened to the current position when the train 

--- Document Chunk 9789 ---
has reached standstill.  Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of information, 

--- Document Chunk 9790 ---
which shall be shortened. 

--- Document Chunk 9791 ---
3.16.2.4.4.3 Concerning clause 3.16.2.4.4, if the  service brake is applied, the driver shall be 

--- Document Chunk 9792 ---
informed that this is due to a balise group message consistency problem. 

--- Document Chunk 9793 ---
3.16.2.4.5 A message counter shall be attached to each balise telegram indicating which balise 

--- Document Chunk 9794 ---
group message the telegram fits to. 

--- Document Chunk 9795 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 9805 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9806 ---
3.16.2.4.6 Instead of a mes sage counter corresponding to a given balise group message, it shall 

--- Document Chunk 9807 ---
be possible to identify a telegram as always fitting all possible messages of the group. 

--- Document Chunk 9808 ---
3.16.2.4.6.1 It shall also be possible to identify a telegram as never fitting any message of the 

--- Document Chunk 9809 ---
group. 

--- Document Chunk 9810 ---
3.16.2.4.7 Comparing message counters of the received telegrams of a balise group message, 

--- Document Chunk 9811 ---
excluding the ones complying with 3.16.2.4.6 and the ones that are not used by the on-

--- Document Chunk 9812 ---
board to compose the message (see 3.16.2.4.8.2) , if their values are not al l identical, 

--- Document Chunk 9813 ---
or at le ast one of  them complies with 3.16.2.4.6.1, this shall be considered as a 

--- Document Chunk 9814 ---
message consistency error. 

--- Document Chunk 9815 ---
3.16.2.4.7.1 In case of single balise group, if the message counter of the received telegram 

--- Document Chunk 9816 ---
complies with 3.16.2.4.6.1, this shall also be considered as a message cons istency 

--- Document Chunk 9817 ---
error. 

--- Document Chunk 9818 ---
3.16.2.4.8 It shall be possible to indicate failures in the system underlying the balise/loop/RIU 

--- Document Chunk 9819 ---
(e.g. the Lineside Electronic Unit, LEU) by sending a balise telegram, a loop message 

--- Document Chunk 9820 ---
or a RIU message including the information "default balise/loop/RIU information". 

--- Document Chunk 9821 ---
3.16.2.4.8.1 If one (and only one) out of a pair of duplicated balise telegrams received by the on -

--- Document Chunk 9822 ---
board includes the information “default balise information”, the on -board shall ignore 

--- Document Chunk 9823 ---
any other information included in this telegram and shall consider in formation from the 

--- Document Chunk 9824 ---
telegram not containing “default balise information". 

--- Document Chunk 9825 ---
3.16.2.4.8.2 When duplicated balises are both found and decoded correctly, and both, or none 

--- Document Chunk 9826 ---
of them, contain "default balise information", the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 9827 ---
shall compose the message using the telegram from the last received balise out of the 

--- Document Chunk 9828 ---
pair. 

--- Document Chunk 9829 ---
3.16.2.4.9 If a message has been received containing the information "default balise information", 

--- Document Chunk 9830 ---
the driver shall be informed. 

--- Document Chunk 9831 ---
3.16.2.5 Unlinked Balise Group Message Consistency 

--- Document Chunk 9832 ---
3.16.2.5.1 An on-board equipment shall reject the message received from a balise group marked 

--- Document Chunk 9833 ---
as unlinked and command application of the service brake in the following cases: 

--- Document Chunk 9834 ---
a) A balise is missed inside the unlinked balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 9835 ---
b) A balise is detected, but no telegram is decoded (e.g. wrong CRC). 

--- Document Chunk 9836 ---
c) Variables in the balise group message have invalid values. 

--- Document Chunk 9837 ---
d) Message counters do not match (see 3.16.2.4.7) 

--- Document Chunk 9838 ---
3.16.2.5.1.1 Exceptions: Concerning a) and b) of clause 3.16.2.5.1, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board 

--- Document Chunk 9839 ---
equipment: 

--- Document Chunk 9840 ---
