3.16.2.6 Linking Reactions 

--- Document Chunk 9871 ---
3.16.2.6.1 When the linking reaction leads to train trip or a service brake applica tion, the driver 

--- Document Chunk 9872 ---
shall be informed that the intervention is due to data consistency problem with the 

--- Document Chunk 9873 ---
expected balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 9874 ---
3.16.2.6.2 If the service brake is initiated due to the linking reaction, the location based 

--- Document Chunk 9875 ---
information stored on -board shall be shortened to the current position when the train 

--- Document Chunk 9876 ---
has reached standstill.  Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of information, 

--- Document Chunk 9877 ---
which shall be shortened. 

--- Document Chunk 9878 ---
3.16.2.7 RAMS related supervision functions 

--- Document Chunk 9879 ---
3.16.2.7.1 Mitigation of balise reception degradation 

--- Document Chunk 9880 ---
3.16.2.7.1.1 If 2 consecutive linked balise groups announced by linking are not detected and the 

--- Document Chunk 9881 ---
end of the expectation window of the second balise group has been passed, the 

--- Document Chunk 9882 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on -board shall command the service brake  and the driver shall be 

--- Document Chunk 9883 ---
informed. At standstill, the location based in formation stored on -board shall be 

--- Document Chunk 9884 ---
shortened to the current position.  Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of 

--- Document Chunk 9885 ---
information, which shall be shortened. 

--- Document Chunk 9886 ---
3.16.2.7.2 Mitigation of balise cross-talk while expecting repositioning information 

--- Document Chunk 9887 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 9888 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9889 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9890 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 9891 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 9892 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 9893 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 9894 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 9895 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 9896 ---
Page 169/204 

--- Document Chunk 9897 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9898 ---
3.16.2.7.2.1 If repositioning is an nounced and the expected repositioning balise group has been 

--- Document Chunk 9899 ---
found, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall keep looking for a balise group 

--- Document Chunk 9900 ---
that satisfies the same criteria as this previously expected and already found 

--- Document Chunk 9901 ---
repositioning balise group, until one of the following events occurs: 

--- Document Chunk 9902 ---
a) the on -board antenna leaves the expectation window of the repositioning balise 

--- Document Chunk 9903 ---
group that was announced and already found 

--- Document Chunk 9904 ---
b) a linked balise group that has been announced with known identity is found. 

--- Document Chunk 9905 ---
3.16.2.7.2.2 If a second balise group is found that satisfies the same criteria as the previously 

--- Document Chunk 9906 ---
expected and already found repositioning balise group, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 9907 ---
equipment shall command the service brake  and the driver shall be informed . At 

--- Document Chunk 9908 ---
standstill, the location based informa tion stored on -board shall be shortened to the 

--- Document Chunk 9909 ---
current position. Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of information, which 

--- Document Chunk 9910 ---
shall be shortened. 

--- Document Chunk 9911 ---
3.16.2.7.2.3 Note: this function is independent from linking function, i.e. the rules related to 

--- Document Chunk 9912 ---
linking always ap ply. This means that once a repositioning balise group has been 

--- Document Chunk 9913 ---
found and if this latter contains new linking information, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 9914 ---
equipment will start expecting the first balise group announced in this new linking 

--- Document Chunk 9915 ---
information in parallel with the monitoring specified in 3.16.2.7.2.1. 

--- Document Chunk 9916 ---
3.16.3 Radio 

--- Document Chunk 9917 ---
3.16.3.1 General issues 

--- Document Chunk 9918 ---
3.16.3.1.1 A radio message is consistent when all checks have been completed successfully: 

--- Document Chunk 9919 ---
a) Checks performed by Euroradio protocol have been passed (see Subset-037) 

--- Document Chunk 9920 ---
b) Time stamps checks have been passed (see 3.16.3.3.3) 

--- Document Chunk 9921 ---
c) Variables in the messages do not have in-valid values. 

--- Document Chunk 9922 ---
3.16.3.1.1.1 The on-board shall reject a message transmitted from the trackside if the message 

--- Document Chunk 9923 ---
is not consistent. 

--- Document Chunk 9924 ---
3.16.3.1.1.2 The on-board shall inform the trackside if a not consistent message is received. 

--- Document Chunk 9925 ---
3.16.3.1.2 Emergency messages shall be transmitted either as high priority data or as normal 

--- Document Chunk 9926 ---
priority data. 

--- Document Chunk 9927 ---
3.16.3.1.3 Other messages shall be sent as normal priority data. 

--- Document Chunk 9928 ---
3.16.3.1.3.1 Messages shall only be accepted when received with the data priority for which they 

--- Document Chunk 9929 ---
are specified. 

--- Document Chunk 9930 ---
3.16.3.1.4 The chap ters 3.16.3.2 to 3.16.3.5 define data consistency principles and 

--- Document Chunk 9931 ---
corresponding checks for data transmitted as normal priority data.  

--- Document Chunk 9932 ---
For high priority data, the checks shall not apply. 

--- Document Chunk 9933 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 9934 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9935 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9936 ---
SUBSET-026-3

System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 9940 ---
Chapter 3

Principles 

--- Document Chunk 9942 ---
Page 170/204 

--- Document Chunk 9943 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9944 ---
3.16.3.2 Time stamping 

--- Document Chunk 9945 ---
3.16.3.2.1 The trackside shall always transmit its information with reference to the train time. 

--- Document Chunk 9946 ---
3.16.3.2.2 To time -stamp its messages, the trackside shall make a safe estimation of the on -

--- Document Chunk 9947 ---
board time, based on the time -stamp of the received messages and the internal 

--- Document Chunk 9948 ---
processing times. The estimation shall be made in such a way that the  on-board time 

--- Document Chunk 9949 ---
estimated by the trackside shall not be in advance of the real on-board time. 

--- Document Chunk 9950 ---
3.16.3.2.3 Wrap around of the onboard timer can occur during a communication session and 

--- Document Chunk 9951 ---
shall have no impact on system behaviour. 

--- Document Chunk 9952 ---
3.16.3.3 Supervision of Sequence 

--- Document Chunk 9953 ---
3.16.3.3.1 The trackside shall  time-stamp a message with a value corresponding to the time of 

--- Document Chunk 9954 ---
sending. 

--- Document Chunk 9955 ---
3.16.3.3.2 There shall always be a time stamp increment between consecutive messages. 

--- Document Chunk 9956 ---
3.16.3.3.3 If the time stamp of the last received message is lower than or equal to the former one 

--- Document Chunk 9957 ---
its content shall not be used. 

--- Document Chunk 9958 ---
3.16.3.3.3.1 Only time stamps of messages received as normal priority data shall be used. 

--- Document Chunk 9959 ---
3.16.3.3.3.2 Note: The supervision does not detect a lost message. This has to be assured by 

--- Document Chunk 9960 ---
means of the “acknowledge” function. 

--- Document Chunk 9961 ---
3.16.3.3.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 9962 ---
T_TRAIN1

--- Document Chunk 9963 ---
T_TRAIN11

T_TRAIN22

--- Document Chunk 9966 ---

3.16.3.4 Supervision of safe radio connection 

--- Document Chunk 9972 ---
3.16.3.4.1 When the difference between the time stamp of the latest consistent received 

--- Document Chunk 9973 ---
message and the current on-board time is greater than the T_NVCONTACT parameter 

--- Document Chunk 9974 ---
(national value), the on -board shall apply the reaction required by trackside (see 

--- Document Chunk 9975 ---
3.16.3.4.2). 

--- Document Chunk 9976 ---

--- Document Chunk 9986 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9987 ---
3.16.3.4.1.1 After the on -board equipment has switched to L2 or 3 with no communication 

--- Document Chunk 9988 ---
session established, the current onboard time shall be compared with the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 9989 ---
time at the moment of the level transition (instead of the time stamp of the latest 

--- Document Chunk 9990 ---
consistent received message) until a new consistent message has been received. 

--- Document Chunk 9991 ---
3.16.3.4.1.2 When an RBC/RBC handover has been announced, the current onboard time shall 

--- Document Chunk 9992 ---
be compared with the t ime stamp of the latest consistent message from the Handing 

--- Document Chunk 9993 ---
over RBC until the train considers the Accepting RBC as the supervising one (refer to 

--- Document Chunk 9994 ---
3.15.1.3.5). From then on the current onboard time shall be compared with the time 

--- Document Chunk 9995 ---
stamp of the latest received consistent message from the Accepting RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9996 ---
3.16.3.4.1.3 As long as the train front end is inside an announced radio hole, the ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 9997 ---
on-board equipment shall stop the supervision of the safe radio connection. 

--- Document Chunk 9998 ---
Afterwards, until a new consistent message has been re ceived, the current onboard 

--- Document Chunk 9999 ---
time shall be compared with the on -board time when the train front end left the radio 

--- Document Chunk 10000 ---
hole (instead of the time stamp of the latest consistent received message).

3.16.3.4.2 It shall be possible to select one of the following reactions (National value) : 

--- Document Chunk 10036 ---
a) Train trip 

--- Document Chunk 10037 ---
b) Apply service brake 

--- Document Chunk 10038 ---
c) No reaction 

--- Document Chunk 10039 ---
3.16.3.4.3 For all reactions,  if no new consistent message has been received  after an additional 

--- Document Chunk 10040 ---
delay time (as defined in A .3.1), the on-board shall release the safe radio conne ction 

--- Document Chunk 10041 ---
and then set-up it again (maintaining the communication session). 

--- Document Chunk 10042 ---
3.16.3.4.4 When the reaction leads to train trip or a service brake application, the driver shall be 

--- Document Chunk 10043 ---
informed that no safe radio message has been received in due time. 

--- Document Chunk 10044 ---
3.16.3.4.5 If the service brake is initiated, the following reaction shall be taken; 

--- Document Chunk 10045 ---
a) For brake command release conditions refer to section 3.14.1.7. 

--- Document Chunk 10046 ---
b) If no new consistent message is received until the train reaches standstill, the 

--- Document Chunk 10047 ---
location based information stored on -board shall be shortened to  the current 

--- Document Chunk 10048 ---
position. Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of information, which shall 

--- Document Chunk 10049 ---
be shortened. 

--- Document Chunk 10050 ---
3.16.3.4.6 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 10051 ---
3.16.3.4.7 To avoid the expiration of the on-board timer and if no new information is needed to be 

--- Document Chunk 10052 ---
sent, the RBC shall send an empty message. 

--- Document Chunk 10053 ---
3.16.3.5 Message Acknowledgement 

--- Document Chunk 10054 ---
3.16.3.5.1 As soon as a consistent message (see 3.16.3.1.1) including the request for 

--- Document Chunk 10055 ---
acknowledgement is received, the on -board shall send an acknowledgement to the 

--- Document Chunk 10056 ---
trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 10057 ---
3.16.3.5.1.1 Note: In order to ensure trackside that the on -board has  correctly received 

--- Document Chunk 10058 ---
transmitted information, the RBC may ask the on-board to acknowledge. 

--- Document Chunk 10059 ---
3.16.3.5.2 Intentionally deleted 

--- Document Chunk 10060 ---
3.16.3.5.3 The acknowledgement message shall refer to the identity of the concerned message 

--- Document Chunk 10061 ---
sent by the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 10062 ---
3.16.3.5.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 10063 ---

--- Document Chunk 10064 ---

--- Document Chunk 10065 ---
soon as the availability of a safe radio connection permits.

3.16.4.2 This refers to balise group errors and radio message errors regardless if there is an 

--- Document Chunk 10078 ---

--- Document Chunk 10079 ---
3.16.4.3 If linking information is used on -board, no error reporting shall be done for balise

--- Document Chunk 10081 ---
3.17 System Version Management  

--- Document Chunk 10082 ---
3.17.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 10083 ---
3.17.1.1 Definitions, high level principles and rules regarding the offli ne management of 

--- Document Chunk 10084 ---
ERTMS/ETCS system version during the ERTMS/ETCS system life time are given in 

--- Document Chunk 10085 ---
SUBSET-104. 

--- Document Chunk 10086 ---
3.17.1.2 The objective of th is section is to define requirements applicable to ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 10087 ---
board equipment and to trackside constituents, when different ver sions of the 

--- Document Chunk 10088 ---
ERTMS/ETCS system have been defined. 

--- Document Chunk 10089 ---
3.17.1.3 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 10090 ---
3.17.2 Determination of the operated system version 

--- Document Chunk 10091 ---
3.17.2.1 The on -board equipment shall be able to operate with (i.e. shall support) any of the 

--- Document Chunk 10092 ---
ERTMS/ETCS system version numbers X included in the e nvelope of legally operated 

--- Document Chunk 10093 ---
system versions, as defined in chapter 6. 

--- Document Chunk 10094 ---
3.17.2.1.1 Within one of its supported system version numbers X, the on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 10095 ---
always operate the highest system version number Y defined in this release of the 

--- Document Chunk 10096 ---
SRS, regardless of the system version number Y transmitted by the trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 10097 ---
3.17.2.2 The on-board equipment shall operate with only one system version at a time, i.e. it 

--- Document Chunk 10098 ---
shall behave according to the whole set of requirements applicable to a system version 

--- Document Chunk 10099 ---
(refer to chapter 6 in case the operated system version is older than the last one 

--- Document Chunk 10100 ---
introduced in this release of the SRS). 

--- Document Chunk 10101 ---
3.17.2.3 The on -board equipment shall determine the operated system version  number X , in 

--- Document Chunk 10102 ---
relation to non -RBC trackside constituents, as the system version number X 

--- Document Chunk 10103 ---
transmitted by any balise, loop or RIU, if this system version number X is higher than 

--- Document Chunk 10104 ---
the currently operated one. 

--- Document Chunk 10105 ---
3.17.2.4 It shall be possible from balise group to order the on -board equipment to operate a 

--- Document Chunk 10106 ---
system version. 

--- Document Chunk 10107 ---
3.17.2.5 On receiving the order to operate system versio n from balise group, the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 10108 ---
equipment shall immediately operate the system version number X given in the order. 

--- Document Chunk 10109 ---
After the order is executed, the requirement 3.17.2.3 shall be again applied for any 

--- Document Chunk 10110 ---
further received balise telegram/loop message or any further contacted RIU. 

--- Document Chunk 10111 ---

--- Document Chunk 10121 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 10122 ---
3.17.2.5.1 Note: the system version order is to be used wherever it is necessary to enforce an 

--- Document Chunk 10123 ---
operated system version number X lower than the currently operated one. 

--- Document Chunk 10124 ---
3.17.2.6 If a mismatch has been detected between the country or region identifier read  from a 

--- Document Chunk 10125 ---
balise/loop and the corresponding identifier(s) for which a set of national values is used 

--- Document Chunk 10126 ---
onboard, the on -board equipment shall consider the system version number X 

--- Document Chunk 10127 ---
transmitted by this balise/loop as the operated one and shall comply again with 

--- Document Chunk 10128 ---
requirement 3.17.2.3. 

--- Document Chunk 10129 ---
3.17.2.7 If the on -board equipment does not support the system version number X transmitted 

--- Document Chunk 10130 ---
by a non -RBC trackside constituent or the one specified in the balise group order, it 

--- Document Chunk 10131 ---
shall consider the operated system version as unchanged. 

--- Document Chunk 10132 ---
3.17.2.8 In case of  communication session established with an RBC, the system version 

--- Document Chunk 10133 ---
number X of the RBC shall take precedence on the operated system version in relation 

--- Document Chunk 10134 ---
to non -RBC constituents and on system version ordered from balise group; the 

--- Document Chunk 10135 ---
operated system version number X  shall be determined according to the following 

--- Document Chunk 10136 ---
principles: 

--- Document Chunk 10137 ---
a) if the on -board equipment is in level 0, NTC or 1 (e.g. entrance in level 2/3 area), 

--- Document Chunk 10138 ---
the RBC system version number X shall be operated when the transition to level 2/3 

--- Document Chunk 10139 ---
is executed; 

--- Document Chunk 10140 ---
b) if the on -board equipment is in level 2/3 (SoM procedure or order received from 

--- Document Chunk 10141 ---
trackside), the RBC system version number X shall be operated immediately; 

--- Document Chunk 10142 ---
c) in case of session established with an accepting RBC (RBC/RBC Handover), the 

--- Document Chunk 10143 ---
accepting RBC system version number X shall be operated as soon as the engine 

--- Document Chunk 10144 ---
has passed the RBC/RBC border location with its maximum safe front end; 

--- Document Chunk 10145 ---
d) in case the on -board equipment switches from level 2/3 to another level (e.g. exit 

--- Document Chunk 10146 ---
from a level 2/3 area), the system version control in rel ation to non -RBC 

--- Document Chunk 10147 ---
constituents shall be again applied and the balise group orders shall be again 

--- Document Chunk 10148 ---
considered; 

--- Document Chunk 10149 ---
e) in case the engine passes the RBC/RBC border location with its maximum safe 

--- Document Chunk 10150 ---
front end and no session is established with the accepting RBC, the syst em version 

--- Document Chunk 10151 ---
control in relation to non -RBC constituents shall be again applied and the balise 

--- Document Chunk 10152 ---
group orders shall be again considered. 

--- Document Chunk 10153 ---
3.17.2.9 The system version currently operated when the on -board equipment is switched off 

--- Document Chunk 10154 ---
(i.e. enters No Power mode) shall be retained and re-used when powered on. 

--- Document Chunk 10155 ---
3.17.2.9.1 If the on -board equipment loses the information (failure situation), the highest 

--- Document Chunk 10156 ---
supported system version shall be used. 

--- Document Chunk 10157 ---

--- Document Chunk 10159 ---
and Radio Infill Unit shall contain only the data related to one system version. It is not

3.17.3.5 The on-board equipment shall check the ERTMS/ETCS system version number X 

--- Document Chunk 10181 ---
transmitted by any balise: 

--- Document Chunk 10182 ---
a) In all levels, if this system version number X equals to 0, the balise information shall 

--- Document Chunk 10183 ---
be ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 10184 ---
b) In all levels, if th is system version number X is different from 0 and lower than the 

--- Document Chunk 10185 ---
lowest system version number X supported by the on -board equipment, it shall be 

--- Document Chunk 10186 ---
able to interpret the balise information, to the extent defined for each type of 

--- Document Chunk 10187 ---
information (see chapter 6 fo r detailed requirements). If the on -board is not able to 

--- Document Chunk 10188 ---
interpret the information, this shall be considered as a message consistency error. 

--- Document Chunk 10189 ---
c) In all levels, if this system version number X is amongst its supported ones, the on -

--- Document Chunk 10190 ---
board equipment shall be able to interpret the balise information. See chapter 6 for 

--- Document Chunk 10191 ---
detailed requirements. 

--- Document Chunk 10192 ---
d) In levels 1, 2 and 3, if this system version number X is greater than the highest 

--- Document Chunk 10193 ---
version number X supported by the on -board equipment, the information from this 

--- Document Chunk 10194 ---
balise shall be ignored, the train shall be tripped and an indication shall be given to 

--- Document Chunk 10195 ---
the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 10196 ---
e) In levels 0 and NTC, if this system version number X is greater than the highest 

--- Document Chunk 10197 ---
version number X supported by the on -board equipment, the information from this 

--- Document Chunk 10198 ---
balise shall be ignored and no reaction shall be applied. 

--- Document Chunk 10199 ---
3.17.3.6 In level 1 the on -board equipment shall check the ERTMS/ETCS system version 

--- Document Chunk 10200 ---
number X transmitted by any Euroloop found: 

--- Document Chunk 10201 ---
a) if this system version number X is lower than the lowest system version number X 

--- Document Chunk 10202 ---
supported by the on -board equipment, it shall be able to interpret the loop 

--- Document Chunk 10203 ---
information, to the extent defined for each type of information (see chapter 6 for 

--- Document Chunk 10204 ---
detailed requirements). If the on -board is not able to interpret the information, this 

--- Document Chunk 10205 ---
shall be considered as a message consistency error. 

--- Document Chunk 10206 ---
b) if this system version number X is amongst its supported ones, the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 10207 ---
equipment shall be able to interpret the loop information. See chapter 6 for detailed 

--- Document Chunk 10208 ---
requirements. 

--- Document Chunk 10209 ---

3.18 System Data 

--- Document Chunk 10245 ---
3.18.1 Fixed Values 

--- Document Chunk 10246 ---
3.18.1.1 Note: Appendix to chapter 3 contains a list of Fixed values used as system parameters 

--- Document Chunk 10247 ---
in the supervision. These parameters are system related and can easily be changed in 

--- Document Chunk 10248 ---
later versions of the ERTMS/ETCS if required. These parameters are not defined as 

--- Document Chunk 10249 ---
National data.  

--- Document Chunk 10250 ---
3.18.2 National / Default Values 

--- Document Chunk 10251 ---
3.18.2.1 Note: Appendix to chapter 3 contains list of National and Default Values.  

--- Document Chunk 10252 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 10253 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 10254 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 10255 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 10256 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 10257 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 10258 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 10259 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 10260 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 10261 ---
Page 177/204 

--- Document Chunk 10262 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 10263 ---
3.18.2.2 Trains shall be supervised according to the National Values of the current 

--- Document Chunk 10264 ---
infrastructure if they are available on-board.  

--- Document Chunk 10265 ---
3.18.2.3 National Values are transmitted with the area(s) (country or region) in which they are 

--- Document Chunk 10266 ---
applicable. They shall become applicable at a defined location, or shall be applicable 

--- Document Chunk 10267 ---
immediately. 

--- Document Chunk 10268 ---
3.18.2.4 Evaluating a balise group message, the balise identity information referring to the 

--- Document Chunk 10269 ---
country or region shall be used to ensure that correct National Values are used. 

--- Document Chunk 10270 ---
3.18.2.5 For each National Value, the corresponding Default Value shall be used as fall back 

--- Document Chunk 10271 ---
value if: 

--- Document Chunk 10272 ---
 the National Value  is not available, or  

--- Document Chunk 10273 ---
 a mismatch has been detected between the cou ntry or region identifier read from a 

--- Document Chunk 10274 ---
balise group and the corresponding identifier(s) of the applicable set with which the 

--- Document Chunk 10275 ---
National Value was received and stored. 

--- Document Chunk 10276 ---
3.18.2.6 Note: even though the National Values are always transmitted as a single  set for a 

--- Document Chunk 10277 ---
given sys tem version, the content of a set depends on the system version, so that 

--- Document Chunk 10278 ---
when a set of National Values is received or becomes applicable, or when passing a 

--- Document Chunk 10279 ---
balise group, the on -board equipment may apply clause 3.18.2.5 for a subset of 

--- Document Chunk 10280 ---
National Values 

--- Document Chunk 10281 ---
3.18.2.7 The National Values currently applicable when the on-board equipment is switched off 

--- Document Chunk 10282 ---
(i.e. enters No Power mode) shall be retained and shall remain applicable when 

--- Document Chunk 10283 ---
powered on. 

--- Document Chunk 10284 ---
3.18.2.7.1 Justification:  The aim of this requirement is to limit the number of balise groups 

--- Document Chunk 10285 ---
containing National Value information. Once a set of National Values has been 

--- Document Chunk 10286 ---
received on-board, there is no need to re -load the information unless National Values 

--- Document Chunk 10287 ---
change, the on -board equipment loses the information (failure situation), or the train 

--- Document Chunk 10288 ---
enters an area requiring different National Values. 

--- Document Chunk 10289 ---
3.18.2.8 The applicable set of National Values data shall be transmitted from the trackside on 

--- Document Chunk 10290 ---
transition between areas requiring a different set of National Values. 

--- Document Chunk 10291 ---
3.18.2.8.1 When a new set of National Values becomes applicable its content  shall always 

--- Document Chunk 10292 ---
overwrite the corresponding National Values  currently applicable regardless of the 

--- Document Chunk 10293 ---
country or region identifier(s). 

--- Document Chunk 10294 ---
3.18.2.9 A previously received set of National Values which is not yet applicable shall be 

--- Document Chunk 10295 ---
deleted if: 

--- Document Chunk 10296 ---
 a new set of National Values is received, or 

--- Document Chunk 10297 ---
 the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment is switched off (i.e., enters No Power 

--- Document Chunk 10298 ---
mode). 

--- Document Chunk 10299 ---
3.18.2.10 If a National Value becomes invalid, i.e., a mismatch has been detected between the 

--- Document Chunk 10300 ---
country or region identifier read from a balise group and the corres ponding identifier(s) 

--- Document Chunk 10301 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 10317 ---

3.18.3 Train Data  

--- Document Chunk 10319 ---
3.18.3.1 Train Data can neither be provided nor modified by ERTMS/ETCS trackside 

--- Document Chunk 10320 ---
equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 10321 ---
3.18.3.2 Before starting a mission, the Train Data shall be acquired by the ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 10322 ---
board equipment of a leading engine 

--- Document Chunk 10323 ---
a) Train category(ies) 

--- Document Chunk 10324 ---
b) Train length 

--- Document Chunk 10325 ---
c) Traction / brake parameters: 

--- Document Chunk 10326 ---
 Traction model 

--- Document Chunk 10327 ---
 Braking models (brake build up time and speed dependent deceleration) o r 

--- Document Chunk 10328 ---
brake percentage 

--- Document Chunk 10329 ---
 Brake position 

--- Document Chunk 10330 ---
 On-board correction factors 

--- Document Chunk 10331 ---
 Nominal rotating mass 

--- Document Chunk 10332 ---
d) Maximum train speed 

--- Document Chunk 10333 ---
e) Loading gauge  

--- Document Chunk 10334 ---
f) Axle load category 

--- Document Chunk 10335 ---
g) Traction system(s) accepted by the engine 

--- Document Chunk 10336 ---
h) Train fitted with airtight system  

--- Document Chunk 10337 ---
i) List of National Systems available on-board 

--- Document Chunk 10338 ---
j) Intentionally deleted 

--- Document Chunk 10339 ---
k) Axle number  

--- Document Chunk 10340 ---
3.18.3.2.1 The Train Data may come from ERTMS/ETCS external sources (e.g. the Train 

--- Document Chunk 10341 ---
Interface), from pre-configured values or from the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 10342 ---
3.18.3.2.2 Exception: The driver shall never be involved in the entry/ modification/validation of  the 

--- Document Chunk 10343 ---
Train Data “Traction system(s) accepted by the engine” , “List of National Systems  

--- Document Chunk 10344 ---
available on-board” and “Axle number”. 

--- Document Chunk 10345 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 10346 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 10347 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 10348 ---

--- Document Chunk 10352 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 10353 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 10354 ---
Page 179/204 

--- Document Chunk 10355 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 10356 ---
3.18.3.2.3 The unit, range and resolution of the Train Data that can be directly entered by the 

--- Document Chunk 10357 ---
driver shall be as specified in A.3.11. 

--- Document Chunk 10358 ---
3.18.3.3 At standstill, it shall be possible for the driver to enter, modify and revalidate the Train 

--- Document Chunk 10359 ---
Data that requires driver validation according to the specific train implementation. 

--- Document Chunk 10360 ---
3.18.3.3.1 In normal operation after the start of mission, if a train movement is detected whi le the 

--- Document Chunk 10361 ---
driver is modifying or revalidating the Train Data, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 10362 ---
equipment shall trigger the brake command. 

--- Document Chunk 10363 ---
3.18.3.4 Following any entry/modification of Train Data when a communication session is 

--- Document Chunk 10364 ---
already established or following the successful est ablishment of a communication 

--- Document Chunk 10365 ---
session when valid Train Data are already available (e.g. when approaching a level 2/3 

--- Document Chunk 10366 ---
area or an accepting RBC area), the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment of the leading 

--- Document Chunk 10367 ---
engine shall send the following set of Train Data to the RBC: 

--- Document Chunk 10368 ---
a) Train category(ies). 

--- Document Chunk 10369 ---
b) Train length.  

--- Document Chunk 10370 ---
c) Maximum train speed. 

--- Document Chunk 10371 ---
d) Loading gauge. 

--- Document Chunk 10372 ---
e) Axle load category. 

--- Document Chunk 10373 ---
f) Traction system(s) accepted by the engine. 

--- Document Chunk 10374 ---
g) Train fitted with airtight system. 

--- Document Chunk 10375 ---
h) List of National Systems available on-board 

--- Document Chunk 10376 ---
i) Axle number 

--- Document Chunk 10377 ---
3.18.3.4.1 The RBC shall acknowledge the reception of this set of Train Data. 

--- Document Chunk 10378 ---
3.18.3.4.2 In case the safe radio connection is lost before the acknowledgement is received, the 

--- Document Chunk 10379 ---
Train Data shall be sent again once the safe radio connection has been re-established 

--- Document Chunk 10380 ---
within the ongoing communication session. 

--- Document Chunk 10381 ---
3.18.3.5 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 10382 ---
3.18.3.6 For modification of Train Data , which is/are affected by a change of input information 

--- Document Chunk 10383 ---
from the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment external interface , refer to procedure 

--- Document Chunk 10384 ---
"Changing Train Data from sources different from the driver" described in section 5.17. 

--- Document Chunk 10385 ---
3.18.3.7 In case the Train Data regarding train category, axle load  category, loading gauge or 

--- Document Chunk 10386 ---
traction system has been changed and the train is at standstill: 

--- Document Chunk 10387 ---
a) the location based information stored on -board shall be shortened to the current 

--- Document Chunk 10388 ---
position of the train . Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of information, 

--- Document Chunk 10389 ---
which shall be shortened. 

--- Document Chunk 10390 ---

3.18.4 Additional Data 

--- Document Chunk 10408 ---
3.18.4.1 Driver ID 

--- Document Chunk 10409 ---
3.18.4.1.1 The driver ID shall be used to identify the responsible person for operating an active 

--- Document Chunk 10410 ---
desk. 

--- Document Chunk 10411 ---
3.18.4.1.1.1 Note: This data is used for recording purposes only. 

--- Document Chunk 10412 ---
3.18.4.1.2 If allowed by a National value, it shall be possible for the driver to change driver ID 

--- Document Chunk 10413 ---
while the train is running. 

--- Document Chunk 10414 ---
3.18.4.1.3 It shall be possible to enter driver ID also in a non-leading engine. 

--- Document Chunk 10415 ---
3.18.4.1.4 The unit, range and resolution of the driver ID shall be as specified in A.3.11. 

--- Document Chunk 10416 ---
3.18.4.2 ERTMS/ETCS Level 

--- Document Chunk 10417 ---
3.18.4.2.1 The driver shall have the possibility to enter the ERTMS/ETCS level dur ing a start of a 

--- Document Chunk 10418 ---
mission. 

--- Document Chunk 10419 ---
3.18.4.2.2 The ERTMS/ETCS level information is required for train operation except sleeping 

--- Document Chunk 10420 ---
mode. 

--- Document Chunk 10421 ---
3.18.4.2.3 In normal operation after the start of mission the driver shall not have to select the 

--- Document Chunk 10422 ---
ERTMS/ETCS level (all other level transitions are executed automatically). 

--- Document Chunk 10423 ---
3.18.4.2.4 For operational fallback situations: at standstill, the onboard equipment shall allow the 

--- Document Chunk 10424 ---
driver to change the ERTMS/ETCS level. 

--- Document Chunk 10425 ---
3.18.4.2.4.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 10426 ---
3.18.4.2.5 If the table of supported levels given by trackside is available, the selection of le vel by 

--- Document Chunk 10427 ---
the driver shall be limited to those contained in this table . If the table of trackside 

--- Document Chunk 10428 ---
supported levels is not available, the driver can select any level  within a default list 

--- Document Chunk 10429 ---
configured on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 10430 ---
3.18.4.3 Radio data: Network identification / RBC Identification / Telephone Number 

--- Document Chunk 10431 ---
3.18.4.3.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall store one valid RBC identity and 

--- Document Chunk 10432 ---
telephone number at a time, obtained from the last driver data entry, from the last 

--- Document Chunk 10433 ---
received order to establish a session with an RBC (excluding RBC transition  orders) or 

--- Document Chunk 10434 ---
from the crossing of a RBC/RBC border (see clause 3.15.1.3.7). 

--- Document Chunk 10435 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 10445 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 10446 ---
3.18.4.3.1.1 Note: If a valid RBC identity and telephone number is available on -board, no driver 

--- Document Chunk 10447 ---
data entry is needed to establish a connection to the RBC when performing a start of 

--- Document Chunk 10448 ---
mission or after a manual level change to level 2/3. 

--- Document Chunk 10449 ---
3.18.4.3.2 In level 2/3 only, at standstill, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment  shall offer the 

--- Document Chunk 10450 ---
driver different means  to select the RBC contact information (RBC identity and 

--- Document Chunk 10451 ---
telephone number to be used), for details see step S3, section 5.4, Start of Mission 

--- Document Chunk 10452 ---
procedure.

--- Document Chunk 10455 ---

--- Document Chunk 10456 ---

--- Document Chunk 10457 ---
reported by EURORADIO and the EIRENE short number, respectively. 

--- Document Chunk 10458 ---
3.18.4.3.4.1 Note: If the short number is re -used by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment (e.g. 

--- Document Chunk 10459 ---
following a loss of safe radio connection) and does not direct t o a RBC with the stored 

--- Document Chunk 10460 ---
RBC ID, the connection will be terminated (EURORADIO functionality). 

--- Document Chunk 10461 ---
3.18.4.3.5 The unit, range and resolution of the RBC identity and telephone number shall be as 

--- Document Chunk 10462 ---
specified in A.3.11. 

--- Document Chunk 10463 ---
3.18.4.3.6 At standstill, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall off er the possibility to the 

--- Document Chunk 10464 ---
driver to modify the Radio Network ID. 

--- Document Chunk 10465 ---
3.18.4.4 ETCS Identity 

--- Document Chunk 10466 ---
3.18.4.4.1 The ETCS identity of an on -board equipment is made of a single identity number. The 

--- Document Chunk 10467 ---
ETCS identity of an RBC, balise group, loop or RIU is composed of a country/region 

--- Document Chunk 10468 ---
identity number and of an identity number within the country/region. 

--- Document Chunk 10469 ---
3.18.4.4.2 All on-board equipments in service, balise groups marked as linked, RBC’s, RIU’s, and 

--- Document Chunk 10470 ---
loops shall be assigned a unique ETCS identity within their respective group. 

--- Document Chunk 10471 ---
3.18.4.4.3 The assignment of (unique or not)  ETCS identities to balise groups marked as 

--- Document Chunk 10472 ---
unlinked is the sole responsibility of the entity in charge of the assignment of values 

--- Document Chunk 10473 ---
(see SUBSET-054), depending on the specific trackside implementation. 

--- Document Chunk 10474 ---
3.18.4.5 Train Running Number 

--- Document Chunk 10475 ---
3.18.4.5.1 During the Start of Mission, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment of a leading engine 

--- Document Chunk 10476 ---
shall acquire the train running number from driver input, from the RBC or from other 

--- Document Chunk 10477 ---
ERTMS/ETCS external sources. 

--- Document Chunk 10478 ---
3.18.4.5.2 It shall be possible to enter train running number also in a non-leading engine. 

--- Document Chunk 10479 ---
3.18.4.5.3 It shall be possible to change the train running number while running, from driver input, 

--- Document Chunk 10480 ---
from the RBC or from other ERTMS/ETCS external sources. 

--- Document Chunk 10481 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 10482 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 10483 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 10484 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 10485 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 10486 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 10487 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 10488 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 10489 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 10490 ---
Page 182/204 

--- Document Chunk 10491 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 10492 ---
3.18.4.5.4 Following any entry/modification of the train running number when a communication 

--- Document Chunk 10493 ---
session is already established or follo wing the successful establishment of a 

--- Document Chunk 10494 ---
communication session when valid train running number is already available, the 

--- Document Chunk 10495 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall send the train running number to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 10496 ---
3.18.4.5.4.1 Exception: if the train running number has been received fr om the RBC, it shall not 

--- Document Chunk 10497 ---
be sent back to the RBC by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 10498 ---
3.18.4.5.5 The unit, range and resolution of the train running number shall be as specified in 

--- Document Chunk 10499 ---
A.3.11. 

--- Document Chunk 10500 ---
3.18.4.6 Adhesion Factor 

--- Document Chunk 10501 ---
3.18.4.6.1 The adhesion factor is used to adjust the emergency brake model of the train  (see 

--- Document Chunk 10502 ---
3.13).  

--- Document Chunk 10503 ---
3.18.4.6.2 The adhesion factor may be changed while the train is running. 

--- Document Chunk 10504 ---
3.18.4.6.2.1 It shall be possible to update the adhesion factor from trackside and - if permitted by 

--- Document Chunk 10505 ---
a National value - by the driver. If, following a change of National Values, the update of 

--- Document Chunk 10506 ---
the adhesion factor is no more permitted to the driver, the adhesion factor previously 

--- Document Chunk 10507 ---
modified by the driver to slippery rail shall immediately be reset to non slippery rail. Any 

--- Document Chunk 10508 ---
trackside adhesion profile is not affected. 

--- Document Chunk 10509 ---
3.18.4.6.2.2 The adhesion factor shall be sent as profile data from trackside when needed. 

--- Document Chunk 10510 ---
3.18.4.6.2.3 The driver shall be informed whether the value of the adhesion factor is “slippery 

--- Document Chunk 10511 ---
rail”. 

--- Document Chunk 10512 ---
3.18.4.6.3 The selection of the adhesion value from trackside or by driver entry shall be limited to 

--- Document Chunk 10513 ---
the options slippery rail/ non slippery rail. 

--- Document Chunk 10514 ---
3.18.4.6.3.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 10515 ---
3.18.4.6.4 The default value for the adhesion factor shall be the highest value (i.e. not slippery 

--- Document Chunk 10516 ---
rail). 

--- Document Chunk 10517 ---
3.18.4.6.5 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 10518 ---
3.18.5 Date and Time 

--- Document Chunk 10519 ---
3.18.5.1 Each ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall be able to provide the date (day, month, 

--- Document Chunk 10520 ---
year) and time (hour, minute, second) in Universal Time Co-ordinated (UTC) and Local 

--- Document Chunk 10521 ---
Time. 

--- Document Chunk 10522 ---
3.18.5.2 The local time shall be presented to the driver, while the UTC shall be used for the 

--- Document Chunk 10523 ---
juridical data. 

--- Document Chunk 10524 ---
3.18.5.3 Deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 10525 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

contact information , the radio network ID, the Virtual Balise Cover(s)  and the Train 

--- Document Chunk 10540 ---

--- Document Chunk 10541 ---
sources. 

--- Document Chunk 10542 ---

*The default value of the correction factor Kr_int shall be valid for any train length, and likewise the 

--- Document Chunk 10767 ---
default value of the correction factor Kv_int shall be valid for any brake position, speed and 

--- Document Chunk 10768 ---

--- Document Chunk 10769 ---
train length step, and that the Kv_int model is valid for all train types and does neither contain any 

--- Document Chunk 10770 ---
speed step nor any pivot deceleration limit.

A.3.3 Handling of information received from trackside 

--- Document Chunk 10772 ---
A.3.3.1  Before it can be accepted and  used by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment, raw 

--- Document Chunk 10773 ---
information received from trackside is subject to various checks, which can lead to the 

--- Document Chunk 10774 ---
individual rejection/ignoring of information (e.g. Movement Authority not valid for the 

--- Document Chunk 10775 ---
train orientation), the ignoring  of a whole balise telegram or the rejection of a whole 

--- Document Chunk 10776 ---
message. The SRS clauses/sections corresponding to these checks are gathered in 

--- Document Chunk 10777 ---
Table 17.

--- Document Chunk 10835 ---
A.3.3.2 With the exception of the clauses/sections referred to in Table 17 and of the clause 

--- Document Chunk 10836 ---
3.16.3.5.1, all the clauses in this specification in which trackside information is referred 

--- Document Chunk 10837 ---
to (through the terms “balise”, “telegram”, “balise group [message]”, “message”, 

--- Document Chunk 10838 ---
“[name of] information”...), shall be applied assuming that the information has not been 

--- Document Chunk 10839 ---
ignored/rejected by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment due to all the checks listed 

--- Document Chunk 10840 ---
in Table 17. 

--- Document Chunk 10841 ---
A.3.3.3 Example 1: clause 3.16.2.4.9 has to be understood as follows: “If a <consistent> 

--- Document Chunk 10842 ---
message <composed with telegrams that have passed the system version check, that 

--- Document Chunk 10843 ---
have not been ignored because of a VBC, that have not been ignored because of 

--- Document Chunk 10844 ---
duplication, and that have been received while no reverse movement was performed> 

--- Document Chunk 10845 ---
has been received <with one of its telegrams composing it>  containing the information 

--- Document Chunk 10846 ---
“default balise information” <which is valid for the train orientation (or the balise group 

--- Document Chunk 10847 ---
crossing direction for NL or SL engines) and which has passed the level and mode 

--- Document Chunk 10848 ---
filters>, the driver shall be informed.” 

--- Document Chunk 10849 ---
A.3.3.4 Example 2: as a result of the clause A.3.3.2, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 10850 ---
will not apply requirements in relation to the content of the telegram or the message 

--- Document Chunk 10851 ---
such as: 

--- Document Chunk 10852 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

A.3.4 Handling of Accepted and Stored Information in specific 

--- Document Chunk 10876 ---
Situations 

--- Document Chunk 10877 ---
A.3.4.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 10878 ---
A.3.4.1.1 All data that can be stored onboard after being accepted may be influenced in special 

--- Document Chunk 10879 ---
situations. 

--- Document Chunk 10880 ---
A.3.4.1.2 The situations acting on the “status” of stored information are: 

--- Document Chunk 10881 ---
a) the execution of a conditional emergency stop (3.10.2.2); 

--- Document Chunk 10882 ---
b) the reception of a shortened MA (3.8.5.1.3, 3.8.5.1.4); 

--- Document Chunk 10883 ---
c) the stored MA is shortened due to a section time-out (3.8.4.2.2); 

--- Document Chunk 10884 ---
d) the SvL is shifted (to the DP if any or to the EOA) due to an overlap time -out 

--- Document Chunk 10885 ---
(3.8.4.4.2) ; 

--- Document Chunk 10886 ---
e) the stored MA is shortened due to an end section time-out (3.8.4.1.2); 

--- Document Chunk 10887 ---
f) a cooperative MA revocation is granted by the onboard (3.8.6.2); 

--- Document Chunk 10888 ---
g) inconsistency in a balise group marked as unlinked and the train  is at standstill 

--- Document Chunk 10889 ---
(3.16.2.5.2); 

--- Document Chunk 10890 ---
h) a linking reaction led to a service brake and the train is at standstill (3.16.2.6.2) ; 

--- Document Chunk 10891 ---
i) the reaction due to the supervision of the safe radio connection led to a service 

--- Document Chunk 10892 ---
brake and the train is at standstill (3.16.3.4.5 b) ; 

--- Document Chunk 10893 ---
j) the train category, axle load  category, loading gauge or traction system is changed 

--- Document Chunk 10894 ---
and the train is at standstill (3.18.3.7) ; 

--- Document Chunk 10895 ---
k) driver closes the desk during SoM ; 

--- Document Chunk 10896 ---
l) RAMS related supervision functions led to a service brake and the train is at 

--- Document Chunk 10897 ---
standstill (3.16.2.7) 

--- Document Chunk 10898 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 11041 ---

--- Document Chunk 11042 ---
reference, i.e. the balise group at the next main signal

--- Document Chunk 11045 ---
procedure.

--- Document Chunk 11054 ---

window of the Mode Profile shall be deleted as well

A.3.5 Handling of Actions in Specific Situations 

--- Document Chunk 11120 ---
A.3.5.1 Regards actions executed in reference to location information received from trackside, 

--- Document Chunk 11121 ---
the on -board equipment shall ensure that the action related to a location is neither 

--- Document Chunk 11122 ---
reverted, nor executed twice. Situations to be considered shall include reverse 

--- Document Chunk 11123 ---
movement (initiated by driver or due to roll -away) and the sub -sequent forward 

--- Document Chunk 11124 ---
movement, or adjustment of train position on passing a new LRBG . This rule shall 

--- Document Chunk 11125 ---
apply to the following actions: 

--- Document Chunk 11126 ---
 Change of National Values (see 3.18.2) 

--- Document Chunk 11127 ---
 Request to acknowledge new level, level transition (see SRS chapter 5.10) 

--- Document Chunk 11128 ---
 Start and stop displaying plain or fixed text messages (see 3.12.3) 

--- Document Chunk 11129 ---
 Request to acknowledge a mode profile, mode tran sition due to mode profile (see 

--- Document Chunk 11130 ---
3.12.4) 

--- Document Chunk 11131 ---
 Start and stop accepting radio infill information (see 3.9.3) 

--- Document Chunk 11132 ---
 Actions related to RBC/RBC handover (see 3.15.1) 

--- Document Chunk 11133 ---
 Actions related to track condition information (see 3.12.1) with the exception of big 

--- Document Chunk 11134 ---
metal masses and non stopping areas 

--- Document Chunk 11135 ---
 Permission to initiate Reversing mode, i.e., limits of Reversing Area (see 3.15.4) 

--- Document Chunk 11136 ---
 Start and stop Track Ahead free request to driver (see 3.15.5) 

--- Document Chunk 11137 ---
 Start and stop calculation of geographical position (see 3.6.6) 

--- Document Chunk 11138 ---
 Substitute the supervision of  the LX start location as the EOA/SvL by the inclusion 

--- Document Chunk 11139 ---
of the LX speed restriction in the MRSP (see 5.16.2 and 5.16.3) 

--- Document Chunk 11140 ---
A.3.5.2 Once the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment has received a balise group message 

--- Document Chunk 11141 ---
(i.e. once it has received the last balise telegram of  the balise group), the action(s) 

--- Document Chunk 11142 ---
resulting from its content shall take into account the train position measured at the time 

--- Document Chunk 11143 ---
of reception of this last telegram and shall take precedence on any other action related 

--- Document Chunk 11144 ---
to a further location that is reached before the message has been fully processed. 

--- Document Chunk 11145 ---
A.3.5.2.1 Example 1: in level 1, the crossing of the EOA/LOA location with the min safe antenna, 

--- Document Chunk 11146 ---
before a new extended MA (received when the min safe antenna was in rear of the 

--- Document Chunk 11147 ---
EOA/LOA) has been processed, will not lead to train trip. In other terms the 

--- Document Chunk 11148 ---
replacement of the EOA/LOA is considered by the on -board as happening before the 

--- Document Chunk 11149 ---
min safe antenna crosses the EOA/LOA location (i.e. preventing that clause 

--- Document Chunk 11150 ---
3.13.10.2.7 applies). 

--- Document Chunk 11151 ---
A.3.5.2.2 Example 2: when the override function is active, the crossing of the former EOA /LOA 

--- Document Chunk 11152 ---
location by the min safe antenna, before a “Stop if in SR” information (received when 

--- Document Chunk 11153 ---
the min safe antenna was in rear of the former EOA /LOA) has been processed, will not 

--- Document Chunk 11154 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 11155 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11156 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11157 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 11158 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 11159 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 11160 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 11161 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 11162 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 11163 ---
Page 195/204 

--- Document Chunk 11164 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11165 ---
lead to the end of the overrid e procedure followed by a train trip due to “Stop if in SR”. 

--- Document Chunk 11166 ---
In other terms, both the deletion of the former EOA /LOA and the end of override 

--- Document Chunk 11167 ---
procedure (see 5.8. 3.1.3 and 5.8.4.1 c)) are considered by the on -board as 

--- Document Chunk 11168 ---
simultaneously happening before the min safe antenna crosses the former EOA/LOA 

--- Document Chunk 11169 ---
location. 

--- Document Chunk 11170 ---
A.3.6 Deletion of accepted and stored information when used 

--- Document Chunk 11171 ---
A.3.6.1 Standard case 

--- Document Chunk 11172 ---
A.3.6.1.1 When the train moves in the direction of its train orientation, storage capacity occupied 

--- Document Chunk 11173 ---
by trackside information  no longer used, i.e., the related on -board functionality has 

--- Document Chunk 11174 ---
been completed, shall be made available immediately. 

--- Document Chunk 11175 ---
A.3.6.1.1.1 Note: The requirement is needed to allow trackside to predict the storage capacity 

--- Document Chunk 11176 ---
available on -board in order to comply with dim ensioning rules regards information 

--- Document Chunk 11177 ---
stored on-board given in Subset 040. 

--- Document Chunk 11178 ---
A.3.6.2 Exception 

--- Document Chunk 11179 ---
A.3.6.2.1 Following information shall remain stored on -board for a distance defined by a fixed 

--- Document Chunk 11180 ---
value in rear of the min safe rear end position of the train: 

--- Document Chunk 11181 ---
 location dependent static speed restrictions , i.e., SSP, ASP, TSR, LX SR, PBD SR 

--- Document Chunk 11182 ---
(see 3.11.2.2) 

--- Document Chunk 11183 ---
 gradient information, 

--- Document Chunk 11184 ---
 reduced adhesion information received from trackside, 

--- Document Chunk 11185 ---
 Track condition “Big metal masses”. 

--- Document Chunk 11186 ---
A.3.6.2.1.1 Note: The above information remains stored for the case of a reverse movement: 

--- Document Chunk 11187 ---
 With the exception of the track condition “Big metal masses”,  the stored 

--- Document Chunk 11188 ---
information allows the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment to calculate speed 

--- Document Chunk 11189 ---
supervision limits after a reverse movement (roll-away, or initiated by the driver)  

--- Document Chunk 11190 ---
 Track condition “Big metal masses” is needed also for a reverse movement itself to 

--- Document Chunk 11191 ---
avoid any false alarms due to Big metal masses in the track. 

--- Document Chunk 11192 ---
A.3.6.2.1.2 Note: The distance to intervention of the roll away or reverse movement supervision is 

--- Document Chunk 11193 ---
determined by a National/Default value.  This is also true for a reverse movement in 

--- Document Chunk 11194 ---
Post trip mode. However, following an intervention, the train will not stop immediately. 

--- Document Chunk 11195 ---
In order to keep the on -board functionality simple, a fixed distance value was chose n 

--- Document Chunk 11196 ---
to define an unambiguous location in rear of the train where the above information is 

--- Document Chunk 11197 ---
no longer required and the related on-board storage capacity is made available again. 

--- Document Chunk 11198 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 11199 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11200 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11201 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 11202 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 11203 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 11204 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 11205 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 11206 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 11207 ---
Page 196/204 

--- Document Chunk 11208 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11209 ---
A.3.7  Calculation of the basic deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 11210 ---
A.3.7.1 The brake percentage (λ) shall be converted into two different input parameters: 

--- Document Chunk 11211 ---
λo = λ for calculation of emergency brake deceleration (A_brake_emergency(V)) 

--- Document Chunk 11212 ---
λo = MIN (λ, 135) for calculation of service brake deceleration (A_brake_service(V)) 

--- Document Chunk 11213 ---
where λ is the brake percentage defined as part of Train Data. 

--- Document Chunk 11214 ---
A.3.7.2 The calculation of the basic deceleration (A_basic(V)) shall use a common algorithm 

--- Document Chunk 11215 ---
that will be used twice, once for the service brake and once for the emergency brake. 

--- Document Chunk 11216 ---
A.3.7.3 The speed limit for the first step shall be calculated as V_lim = x * λoy. 

--- Document Chunk 11217 ---
V_lim is the speed limit for the first step in km/h 

--- Document Chunk 11218 ---
x = 16.85 

--- Document Chunk 11219 ---
y = 0.428 

--- Document Chunk 11220 ---
A.3.7.4 The first step of the basic deceleration shall be calculated as AD_0 = A * λo + B 

--- Document Chunk 11221 ---
AD_0 is the basic deceleration in m/s2 for 0 ≤ speed ≤ V_lim. 

--- Document Chunk 11222 ---
A = 0.0075 

--- Document Chunk 11223 ---
B = 0.076 

--- Document Chunk 11224 ---
A.3.7.5 The following steps of the basic deceleration shall be calculated by means of a set of 

--- Document Chunk 11225 ---
polynomials of the third order with the following format: 

--- Document Chunk 11226 ---
AD_n = a3_n * λo3 + a2_n * λo2 + a1_n * λo + a0_n 

--- Document Chunk 11227 ---
and with the following values for n (all speed limits in km/h): 

--- Document Chunk 11228 ---
n = 1   valid for V_lim < speed ≤ 100  if V_lim < 100 

--- Document Chunk 11229 ---
to be ignored      if V_lim ≥ 100 

--- Document Chunk 11230 ---
n = 2   valid for V_lim < speed ≤ 120  if 100 < V_lim < 120 

--- Document Chunk 11231 ---
valid for 100 < speed ≤ 120   if V_lim ≤ 100 

--- Document Chunk 11232 ---
to be ignored      if V_lim ≥ 120 

--- Document Chunk 11233 ---
n = 3   valid for V_lim < speed ≤ 150  if 120 < V_lim < 150 

--- Document Chunk 11234 ---
valid for 120 < speed ≤ 150   if V_lim ≤ 120 

--- Document Chunk 11235 ---
to be ignored      if V_lim ≥ 150 

--- Document Chunk 11236 ---
n = 4   valid for V_lim < speed ≤ 180  if 150 < V_lim < 180 

--- Document Chunk 11237 ---
valid for 150 < speed ≤ 180   if V_lim ≤ 150 

--- Document Chunk 11238 ---
to be ignored      if V_lim ≥ 180 

--- Document Chunk 11239 ---
n = 5   valid for V_lim < speed    if V_lim > 180 

--- Document Chunk 11240 ---
valid for 180 < speed    if V_lim ≤ 180 

--- Document Chunk 11241 ---
A.3.7.6 The coefficients for the polynomials shall be defined as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 11242 ---
am_n   m =   

--- Document Chunk 11243 ---
  3 2 1 0 

--- Document Chunk 11244 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 11245 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11246 ---

--- Document Chunk 11254 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11255 ---
 1 -6.30E-07 6.10E-05 4.72E-03 0.0663 

--- Document Chunk 11256 ---
 2 2.73E-07 -4.54E-06 5.14E-03 0.1300 

--- Document Chunk 11257 ---
n = 3 5.58E-08 -6.76E-06 5.81E-03 0.0479 

--- Document Chunk 11258 ---
 4 3.00E-08 -3.85E-06 5.52E-03 0.0480 

--- Document Chunk 11259 ---
 5 3.23E-09 1.66E-06 5.06E-03 0.0559 

--- Document Chunk 11260 ---
A.3.8 Calculation of the emergency brake equivalent time 

--- Document Chunk 11261 ---
A.3.8.1 The basic brake build up time for the emergency brake with the brake position in 

--- Document Chunk 11262 ---
passenger trains in P shall be calculated as: 

--- Document Chunk 11263 ---
T_brake_basic_eb = a + b * (L/100) + c * (L/100)2 

--- Document Chunk 11264 ---
where 

--- Document Chunk 11265 ---
L = MAX (400m; train length in m) 

--- Document Chunk 11266 ---
a = 2.30 

--- Document Chunk 11267 ---
b = 0.00 

--- Document Chunk 11268 ---
c = 0.17 

--- Document Chunk 11269 ---
A.3.8.2 The basic brake build up time  for the emergency brake with the brake position in 

--- Document Chunk 11270 ---
freight trains in P shall be calculated as: 

--- Document Chunk 11271 ---
T_brake_basic_eb = a + b * (L/100) + c * (L/100)2 

--- Document Chunk 11272 ---
where 

--- Document Chunk 11273 ---
L = MAX (400m; train length in m) 

--- Document Chunk 11274 ---
If train length ≤ 900m: 

--- Document Chunk 11275 ---
a = 2.30 

--- Document Chunk 11276 ---
b = 0.00 

--- Document Chunk 11277 ---
c = 0.17 

--- Document Chunk 11278 ---
If 900m < train length ≤ 1500m: 

--- Document Chunk 11279 ---
a = -0.40 

--- Document Chunk 11280 ---
b = 1.60 

--- Document Chunk 11281 ---
c = 0.03 

--- Document Chunk 11282 ---
A.3.8.3 The basic brake build up time for the emergency brake with the brake position in 

--- Document Chunk 11283 ---
freight trains in G shall be calculated as: 

--- Document Chunk 11284 ---
T_brake_basic_eb = a + b * (L/100) + c * (L/100)2 

--- Document Chunk 11285 ---
where 

--- Document Chunk 11286 ---
L = train length in m 

--- Document Chunk 11287 ---
If train length ≤ 900m: 

--- Document Chunk 11288 ---
a = 12.00 

--- Document Chunk 11289 ---
b = 0.00 

--- Document Chunk 11290 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 11291 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11292 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11293 ---

Page 198/204 

--- Document Chunk 11300 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11301 ---
c = 0.05 

--- Document Chunk 11302 ---
If 900m < train length ≤ 1500m: 

--- Document Chunk 11303 ---
a = -0.40 

--- Document Chunk 11304 ---
b = 1.60 

--- Document Chunk 11305 ---
c = 0.03 

--- Document Chunk 11306 ---
A.3.8.4 The equivalent brake build up time for the emergency brake shall be computed as 

--- Document Chunk 11307 ---
follows: 

--- Document Chunk 11308 ---
T_brake_emergency_cm0 = T_brake_basic_eb when V_target = 0 

--- Document Chunk 11309 ---
T_brake_emergency_cmt = kto * T_brake_basic_eb when V_target > 0 

--- Document Chunk 11310 ---
where 

--- Document Chunk 11311 ---
V_target is the target speed 

--- Document Chunk 11312 ---
A.3.8.5 The correction factor kto shall depend on the brake position as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 11313 ---
kto = 1 + Ct 

--- Document Chunk 11314 ---
where 

--- Document Chunk 11315 ---
Ct = 0.16  for freight trains in G 

--- Document Chunk 11316 ---
Ct = 0.20  for freight trains in P 

--- Document Chunk 11317 ---
Ct = 0.20  for passenger trains 

--- Document Chunk 11318 ---
A.3.9 Calculation of the full service brake equivalent time 

--- Document Chunk 11319 ---
A.3.9.1 The basic brake build up time for full service brake for passenger trains in P shall be 

--- Document Chunk 11320 ---
calculated as: 

--- Document Chunk 11321 ---
T_brake_basic_sb = a + b * (L/100) + c * (L/100)2 

--- Document Chunk 11322 ---
where 

--- Document Chunk 11323 ---
L = train length in m 

--- Document Chunk 11324 ---
a = 3.00 

--- Document Chunk 11325 ---
b = 1.50 

--- Document Chunk 11326 ---
c = 0.10 

--- Document Chunk 11327 ---
A.3.9.2 The basic brake build up time for full service brake for freight trains in P shall be 

--- Document Chunk 11328 ---
calculated as: 

--- Document Chunk 11329 ---
T_brake_basic_sb = a + b * (L/100) + c * (L/100)2 

--- Document Chunk 11330 ---
where 

--- Document Chunk 11331 ---
L = train length in m 

--- Document Chunk 11332 ---
If train length ≤ 900m: 

--- Document Chunk 11333 ---
a = 3.00 

--- Document Chunk 11334 ---
b = 2.77 

--- Document Chunk 11335 ---
c = 0.00 

--- Document Chunk 11336 ---

--- Document Chunk 11348 ---

--- Document Chunk 11350 ---

--- Document Chunk 11351 ---
A.3.9.3 The basic brake build up time for full service brake for freight trains in G shall be 

--- Document Chunk 11352 ---

--- Document Chunk 11353 ---

--- Document Chunk 11363 ---

--- Document Chunk 11364 ---
A.3.9.4 The equivalent brake build up time for the service brake shall be computed as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 11365 ---
T_brake_service_cm0 = T_brake_basic_sb when V_target = 0 

--- Document Chunk 11366 ---
T_brake_service_cmt = kto * T_brake_basic_sb when V_target > 0 

--- Document Chunk 11367 ---
A.3.9.5 The correction factor kto shall be defined as in A.3.8.5 

--- Document Chunk 11368 ---
A.3.9.6 The values of a, b, c and kto  used in A.3.9.1, A.3.9.2, A.3.9.3 and A.3.9.4  define 

--- Document Chunk 11369 ---
reference value s for the equivalent brake build up time for the service brake , which 

--- Document Chunk 11370 ---
shall be considered as maximum one s. If justified by the specific brake system of the 

--- Document Chunk 11371 ---
train other values of these coefficients, which lead to shorter value s of the equivalent 

--- Document Chunk 11372 ---
brake build up time for the service brake, may be used. 

--- Document Chunk 11373 ---
A.3.9.7 Note: Although certain trains may perform better, the reference values for the 

--- Document Chunk 11374 ---
equivalent brake build up time for the service brake , as defined here, are the 

--- Document Chunk 11375 ---
appropriate basis for infrastructure planning. 

--- Document Chunk 11376 ---
A.3.10 Service brake feedback 

--- Document Chunk 11377 ---
A.3.10.1 The purpose of service brake feedback is to reduce the distance between the SBI and 

--- Document Chunk 11378 ---
EBI supervision limits and between the SBI and SBD curves. 

--- Document Chunk 11379 ---
A.3.10.2 The on-board shall consider the service brake feedback as available for use if: 

--- Document Chunk 11380 ---
a) The service brake feedback is implemented, AND 

--- Document Chunk 11381 ---
b) The national value does not inhibit its use. 

--- Document Chunk 11382 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 11383 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11384 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11385 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 11386 ---
3.6.0 

--- Document Chunk 11387 ---
13/05/2016 

--- Document Chunk 11388 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 11389 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 11390 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 11391 ---
Page 200/204 

--- Document Chunk 11392 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11393 ---
A.3.10.3 Two different types of feedback from the service brake are specified, main brake pipe 

--- Document Chunk 11394 ---
pressure and brake cylinder p ressure. The algorithms below are made for main brake 

--- Document Chunk 11395 ---
pipe pressure. When brake cylinder pressure is used instead this shall be converted 

--- Document Chunk 11396 ---
into a fictive main brake pressure value in the following way: 

--- Document Chunk 11397 ---
p = fictive main brake pipe pressure (kPa) 

--- Document Chunk 11398 ---
p_cylinder = brake cylinder pressure (kPa) 

--- Document Chunk 11399 ---
k1 = vehicle dependent constant (set by engineering of ETCS on -board; k1 is normally 

--- Document Chunk 11400 ---
between 2.0 and 2.7) 

--- Document Chunk 11401 ---
p =  500  - p_cylinder / k1 

--- Document Chunk 11402 ---
A.3.10.4 The value of T_bs1 and T_bs2 shall be calculated according to the following algori thm 

--- Document Chunk 11403 ---
to take the service brake feedback into account: 

--- Document Chunk 11404 ---
p = current main brake pipe pressure (or fictive main brake pipe pressure calculated in  

--- Document Chunk 11405 ---
A.3.10.3) 

--- Document Chunk 11406 ---
p0 = reference pressure when not braking  

--- Document Chunk 11407 ---
p1 = pressure at which the train starts to brake = p0 - 30  

--- Document Chunk 11408 ---
p2 = pressure limit, under which T_bs1 and T_bs2 are locked = p0 - 60  

--- Document Chunk 11409 ---
p3 = pressure at full service brake = p0 - 150  

--- Document Chunk 11410 ---
Q_feedback_active = a Boolean stating whe ther the feedback function is active, i.e. 

--- Document Chunk 11411 ---
once it has started to reduce T_bs1 and T_bs2  until the ceiling speed monitoring is 

--- Document Chunk 11412 ---
entered. 

--- Document Chunk 11413 ---
Q_Tbslocked = a boolean stating whe ther T_bs1 and T_bs2 have been locked to the 

--- Document Chunk 11414 ---
following values due to enough main brake pipe pressure reduction: 

--- Document Chunk 11415 ---
T_bs1_locked =  0 s. 

--- Document Chunk 11416 ---
T_bs2_locked =  2 s. 

--- Document Chunk 11417 ---
Q_displaylocked_P = a boolean stating whether the displayed permitted speed  is 

--- Document Chunk 11418 ---
locked due to SB feedback. 

--- Document Chunk 11419 ---
Q_displaylocked_SBI = a boolean stating whether th e displayed SBI  speed (if any) is 

--- Document Chunk 11420 ---
locked due to SB feedback. 

--- Document Chunk 11421 ---
Q_displaylocked_TD = a boolean stating whether the displayed target  distance is 

--- Document Chunk 11422 ---
locked due to SB feedback. 

--- Document Chunk 11423 ---
A displayed value is locked from the moment the SB feedback has started to reduce 

--- Document Chunk 11424 ---
T_bs1 and T_bs2 until the calculated value becomes less than the displayed and 

--- Document Chunk 11425 ---
locked value. Note: It is only SB feedback that can start  the locking of the displayed 

--- Document Chunk 11426 ---
values. Once started and still locked it remains locked also in case the calculated 

--- Document Chunk 11427 ---
values are increased due to other reasons (e.g. due to relocation), which will prolong 

--- Document Chunk 11428 ---
the locking period. 

--- Document Chunk 11429 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11430 ---
Initial values when the target spe ed monitoring is entered or when the release speed 

--- Document Chunk 11431 ---
monitoring is entered not from target speed monitoring: 

--- Document Chunk 11432 ---
Tbs1_prev= Tbs 

--- Document Chunk 11433 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

Q_feedback_active = false 

--- Document Chunk 11445 ---
Q_displaylocked_P = false 

--- Document Chunk 11446 ---
Q_displaylocked_SBI = false 

--- Document Chunk 11447 ---
Q_displaylocked_TD = false 

--- Document Chunk 11448 ---
Q_Tbslocked =false 

--- Document Chunk 11449 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11450 ---
If on-board is in target speed monitoring or release speed monitoring then 

--- Document Chunk 11451 ---
 If Q_Tbslocked then 

--- Document Chunk 11452 ---
  T_bs1 = T_bs1_locked 

--- Document Chunk 11453 ---
  T_bs2 = T_bs2_locked 

--- Document Chunk 11454 ---
 Else 

--- Document Chunk 11455 ---
  If p > p2 then 

--- Document Chunk 11456 ---
   If Q_feedback_active or p ≤ p1 then  

--- Document Chunk 11457 ---
    Q_feedback_active = true 

--- Document Chunk 11458 ---
    T_bs_feedback = T_bs * (p - p3) / (p0 - p3) 

--- Document Chunk 11459 ---
    T_bs1 = T_bs2 = T_bs_feedback 

--- Document Chunk 11460 ---
    If T_bs_feedback > T_bs then 

--- Document Chunk 11461 ---
     T_bs1 = T_bs2 = T_bs 

--- Document Chunk 11462 ---
    Else if T_bs_feedback < T_bs2_locked then 

--- Document Chunk 11463 ---
     T_bs2 = T_bs2_locked 

--- Document Chunk 11464 ---
    End If 

--- Document Chunk 11465 ---
   Else 

--- Document Chunk 11466 ---
    T_bs1 = T_bs 

--- Document Chunk 11467 ---
    T_bs2 = T_bs 

--- Document Chunk 11468 ---
   End If 

--- Document Chunk 11469 ---
  Else 

--- Document Chunk 11470 ---
   T_bs1 = T_bs1_locked 

--- Document Chunk 11471 ---
   T_bs2 = T_bs2_locked 

--- Document Chunk 11472 ---
   Q_feedback_active = true 

--- Document Chunk 11473 ---
   Q_Tbslocked = true 

--- Document Chunk 11474 ---
  End If 

--- Document Chunk 11475 ---
 End If 

--- Document Chunk 11476 ---
Else 

--- Document Chunk 11477 ---
 T_bs1 = T_bs 

--- Document Chunk 11478 ---
 T_bs2 = T_bs 

--- Document Chunk 11479 ---
End if  

--- Document Chunk 11480 ---
If Q_feedback_active and T_bs1 < T_bs1_prev then 

--- Document Chunk 11481 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

 Q_displaylocked_P = true 

--- Document Chunk 11493 ---
 Q_displaylocked_SBI = true 

--- Document Chunk 11494 ---
 Q_displaylocked_TD = true 

--- Document Chunk 11495 ---
End If 

--- Document Chunk 11496 ---
T_bs1_prev = T_bs1

SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 11537 ---

--- Document Chunk 11539 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 11540 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 11541 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 11542 ---
Page 203/204 

--- Document Chunk 11543 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11544 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11545 ---
The reference pressure p0 (nominal value 500 kPa) shall be set on starting the ETCS:  

--- Document Chunk 11546 ---
 a) To the first stable p value between 400-550 kPa achieved.  

--- Document Chunk 11547 ---
 b) Stable in this instance means that the pressure has not varied more  than ± 

--- Document Chunk 11548 ---
20 kPa over 3 seconds. 

--- Document Chunk 11549 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11550 ---
 The reference pressure p0 shall thereafter be adapted to the current pressure 

--- Document Chunk 11551 ---
according to the following table (which applies if the calculation is performed once per 

--- Document Chunk 11552 ---
second): 

--- Document Chunk 11553 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11554 ---
 CONDITIONS: ACTION: REMARKS 

--- Document Chunk 11555 ---
a) p = p0 No change Constant pressure 

--- Document Chunk 11556 ---
b) p > p0 p0 = p0 + 1,5 Increasing pressure 

--- Document Chunk 11557 ---
c) p < p0 - 30 No change Braking 

--- Document Chunk 11558 ---
d) p0 > p > p0 - 30 p0 = p0  0,5 Decreasing pressure 

--- Document Chunk 11559 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11560 ---
Where:  

--- Document Chunk 11561 ---
- p is limited to max 550 kPa. 

--- Document Chunk 11562 ---
- Values given in kPa. 

--- Document Chunk 11563 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11564 ---
A.3.10.5 Note: If T_bs1 and T_bs2 h ave been locked to 0s and 2 s  on approaching a non zero 

--- Document Chunk 11565 ---
target, the locking will remain even if the train speed comes below the target speed. 

--- Document Chunk 11566 ---
This avoids “jumping” indications  related to the values of T_bs1 and T_bs2 . It also 

--- Document Chunk 11567 ---
makes it possible to release t he brakes before a speed reduction, without having the 

--- Document Chunk 11568 ---
curves moving back again. It might though result in emergency brake intervention if the 

--- Document Chunk 11569 ---
driver releases the brakes too early. But since EBI is not moved, this is not a safety 

--- Document Chunk 11570 ---
issue. To keep 2 s between  the SBI and EBI enables the service brake to be activated 

--- Document Chunk 11571 ---
first and thus may avoid emergency brake. 

--- Document Chunk 11572 ---
A.3.10.6 Note: If feedback is active but T_bs1 and T_bs2 are not locked, the feedback function 

--- Document Chunk 11573 ---
will remain active until the ceiling speed monitoring is ent ered. This avoids “jumping” 

--- Document Chunk 11574 ---
indications in some rare situations. 

--- Document Chunk 11575 ---

Train Data: Maximum train km/h 0-600 5 km/h

--- Document Chunk 11951 ---
4.3 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 11952 ---
4.3.1 Presentation of the document 

--- Document Chunk 11953 ---
4.3.1.1 This document defines the modes of the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment (see 

--- Document Chunk 11954 ---
chapter 4.4 “Definition of the modes” and chapter 4.5 “Modes and on-board functions”. 

--- Document Chunk 11955 ---
4.3.1.2 This document gives all transitions between modes (see chapter 4.6 “Transitions 

--- Document Chunk 11956 ---
between modes”). 

--- Document Chunk 11957 ---
4.3.1.3 This document describes the possible exchanged information between the driver and 

--- Document Chunk 11958 ---
the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment, respect to the mode (see chapter  4.7 “ DMI 

--- Document Chunk 11959 ---
depending on modes”). 

--- Document Chunk 11960 ---
4.3.1.4 This document describes how the received information is filtered, respec t to several 

--- Document Chunk 11961 ---
criteria such as the level, the mode, etc.. (see chapter 4.8 “Acceptance of received 

--- Document Chunk 11962 ---
information”). 

--- Document Chunk 11963 ---
4.3.1.5 This document describes how the stored information is handled, respect to several 

--- Document Chunk 11964 ---
criteria such as the level, the mode, etc. (see chapter 4.9 “What happens to accepted 

--- Document Chunk 11965 ---
and stored information when entering a given level”, and chapter 4.10 “What happens 

--- Document Chunk 11966 ---
to accepted and stored information when entering a given mode”). 

--- Document Chunk 11967 ---
4.3.1.6 All the tables that are included in this document shall be considered as mandatory  

--- Document Chunk 11968 ---
requirements. 

--- Document Chunk 11969 ---
4.3.1.7 Some notes appear in this document. These notes are here to help the reader to 

--- Document Chunk 11970 ---
understand the specifications, or to explain the reason(s) of a requirement. 

--- Document Chunk 11971 ---
4.3.2 Identification of the possible modes 

--- Document Chunk 11972 ---
4.3.2.1 List of the modes: 

--- Document Chunk 11973 ---
Full Supervision  (FS) 

--- Document Chunk 11974 ---
Limited Supervision (LS) 

--- Document Chunk 11975 ---
On Sight   (OS) 

--- Document Chunk 11976 ---
Staff Responsible (SR) 

--- Document Chunk 11977 ---
Shunting   (SH) 

--- Document Chunk 11978 ---
Unfitted   (UN) 

--- Document Chunk 11979 ---
Passive Shunting (PS) 

--- Document Chunk 11980 ---
Sleeping   (SL) 

--- Document Chunk 11981 ---
Stand By   (SB) 

--- Document Chunk 11982 ---
Trip    (TR) 

--- Document Chunk 11983 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 11984 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11985 ---

--- Document Chunk 11997 ---

--- Document Chunk 11998 ---

--- Document Chunk 12009 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 12010 ---
4.4 Definition of the modes 

--- Document Chunk 12011 ---
4.4.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 12012 ---
4.4.1.1 For each mode the following information is given: 

--- Document Chunk 12013 ---
a) The context of utilisation of the mode and the functions that characterise the mode 

--- Document Chunk 12014 ---
(chapter “Description”).  

--- Document Chunk 12015 ---
b) The ERTMS/ETCS levels in whic h the mode can be used (chapter “Used in 

--- Document Chunk 12016 ---
levels”). 

--- Document Chunk 12017 ---
c) The related responsibility of the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment and of the 

--- Document Chunk 12018 ---
driver, once the equipment is in this mode (chapter “Responsibilities”). 

--- Document Chunk 12019 ---
4.4.1.2 A complete list of transitions to and from each mode is g iven in the section 4.6.2 

--- Document Chunk 12020 ---
“Transitions Table” ). 

--- Document Chunk 12021 ---
4.4.2 General Requirements 

--- Document Chunk 12022 ---
4.4.2.1 When the desk is open, a  clear indication of the ERTMS/ETCS mode shall be shown 

--- Document Chunk 12023 ---
to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 12024 ---
4.4.2.2 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 12025 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP
